17 Jan 1992 to 1995, Saturdays, ABC 5; 1996 to 14 Jul 2002, GMA. Producer: Probe Productions, Inc. Executive Producers: Cheche Lazaro, Judith Torres, Grace M. Leung, Data Tolentino-Canlas. Supervising Producers: Meia Lopez, Owen Santos, Yasmin Mapua-Tang. Producers: Marga Ortigas, Maricar Bautista, Kathy Quiaño, Jeanette Ifurung, Lani Feliciano, Ikik Alcaneses, Teret Peña-Pison, Inky Santiago-Nakpil, Lengo Nuñez, Pauline Mangilog-Saltarin, Anabel Rubiano-Maldonado, Auey Calabia-Santos, Priscilla Ruiz-Bangad, Ian Roxas, Aimee Marcelo, Jay C. Orense, Jing Ventura, Tin Macatulad, Tops Brugada, Eva Marie Ercilla, Peejo Pilar, Gisele Aro-Oruga, Abbie S.J. Lara, Marj Mosura-Dumont, Agay Llanera-Reyes, Jason Reyes, Tet Salvador, Sheillavie Ursua, Maitel Ladrido, Melanie Arroyo, Ian Rica Roxas, Marilen Go. Script Supervisors: Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Maria Ressa, Jay C. Orense. Graphics Artists: Jay-Jay Araullo, Albert Biazon, Christian Tolosa, Judex Villamarin, Ruel Asuncion. Hosts: Satin Abad, Byron Abao, Melvin Abundo, Eliza Agabin, Alex Amado, Maureen Araneta, Atom Araullo, Giggles Arceo, Anya Benitez, Phoebe Cabaluna, Pamela Cajilig, Lily Anne Casimiro, Arthur Anthony Cipriano, Jennifer Cremen, Rayver Cruz, Rodjun Cruz, Patrick da Silva, Nicai de Guzman, Justine de Jesus, Wilroy Dilao, Veronica Dorotheo, Jolly Estaris, Rupert Eustaquio, Luigi Exconde, Oly Fernando, Frances Fleta, Jessica Gallegos, Xavi Gonzalez, Chuck Grey, Alwien Raidene Lacanilao, Tin Tin Leones, Maxine Magalona, Krianne Maniego, Diego Maranan, Enzo Marcos, Josh Matic, Carlo Mendoza, Paolo Olbes, Cynthia Ortaleza, Chiyomi Rances, Rex Sayson, Nina Serquina, Niña Torres, Ian Tugas, Joseton Vergel de Dios, Luz Yballe, Zak Yuson.

 

5 and Up is a telemagazine (television magazine) show hosted by kids ages 8 to 14. It features three full-length stories, short sponsored segments, and skits that give prominence to the children’s opinions and interpretations of stories and events. Topics include science, technology, travel, poverty, human interest, culture, arts, music, and politics, which are similar to those covered by its sister program, The Probe Team, but in a language appropriate for its target audience.

 

The Junior Probe Team is considered 5 and Up’s “first” episode, which is the 17 Jan 1992 episode of the awardwinning investigative documentary program The Probe Team. The episode featured three children, Yuson, Torres, and Serquina, who traveled, interviewed, and reported on stories about the Aeta children of Zambales, the Philippine eagle, and the sorbetes (local ice cream). The idea of the episode came from Yuson, producer Cheche Lazaro’s eight-year-old nephew, who formed a Junior Probe Team Club among his classmates in school. This episode received positive feedback, and provided proof that a program for children showing them as children could be a successful endeavor. On 14 May of that year, 5 and Up was launched as a full-fledged morning program, with more kids alternating as reporters for the full-length stories. Through the different batches of reporters, there were at least ten kid reporters on the show, with the older ones “graduating” when they turned 14.

 

The show featured children’s hobbies, talents, and achievements, and places like Batanes, Siargao, Palawan, Germany, Paris, Thailand, Italy, Hong Kong, and Australia. The children discussed sensitive issues, such as child labor, adoption, adolescence, gender, sexuality, the emotional and physical changes that come with growing up, AIDS among children, the ills of smoking and alcohol, the Amerasian children of Pampanga, the descendants of national heroes, and People Power II. The show also produced thematic specials, one of which is the environmental special, “The Adventures of Kool Kid Eco.” Kool Kid Eco is a child superhero with a mission to drum up environmental awareness among kids and adults. He shows how small actions by children can help save the environment.

 

The program’s opening billboard won the gold medal in the New York Festivals in 1996. 5 and Up won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1993, 1996, and 1998; almost yearly from 1992 to 2003 as best children’s show and its hosts as best children’s show hosts in the KBP Golden Dove Awards, the PMPC Star Awards, and the Catholic Mass Media Awards; a special commendation in the Japan Prize in 1998; best television feature in the AIDS Media Awards in 2001; the UNICEF Prize of the prestigious Prix Jeunesse International in 2001; and best children’s program in the Asian Television Awards in 2001. Many of the program’s hosts have continued their careers in media and have won accolades as broadcast journalists, filmmakers, actors, music recording artists, and writers. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Daphne-Tatiana T. Canlas, Kristoffer Brugada, Marj Mosura-Dumont, Eva Marie Ercilla, Grace M. Leung, Ian R. Roxas, Pauline Mangilog-Saltarin, and Yasmin Mapua-Tang

text:
(I Will Sing to You) 1970–2006. 1970-71: KBS 9; 1972: ABS-CBN; 1973: IBC 13; 1973-1997: RPN 9, 7:30-8:30 pm, then 8:30-9:30 pm, Wednesdays; 1997-2001: GMA; 2002-06: ABC 5. Producer, Host, and Theme Music Singer: Armida Siguion-Reyna. Associate Producer: Purita Ponce Enrile. Directors: Freddie Cochran, Mitos Villareal, Carlos Siguion-Reyna, Armida Siguion-Reyna. Writers: Bibeth Orteza, Marina Feleo-Gonzalez, Racquel Villavicencio. Theme Music Composer: Leopoldo Silos. Theme Music Lyricist: Levi Celerio. Vocal Coach: Robert Natividad. Production Assistant: Ricky Yu. Lighting Directors: Ricardo Jacinto, Eduardo Jacinto. Mainstay Singers: Armida Siguion-Reyna, Aurelio Estanislao, Robert Natividad, Diomedes Maturan, Ric Manrique, Chito Ponce-Enrile, Lirio Vital, Leo Valdez, Richard Reynoso.

Aawitan Kita was a weekly musical TV show that was on air for 36 years. It became a monthly special in the 1990s, and was adapted for the stage and performed worldwide beginning in the 2000s. The show reaffirmed and encouraged appreciation of the beauty of Filipino art and culture through music. The care and the skill that the production team put into every episode of the show were a testament of the producer’s commitment to bringing culture closer to television audiences.

The show pioneered in shooting musical performances in scenic spots all over the country. Mainstay and guest singers, garbed in traditional Filipino costumes, rendered musical compositions on locations like rice fields, beaches, old houses, historical places, and tourist destinations.

It regularly featured Filipino musical forms like the kundiman (romantic ballad), the balitaw (Visayan folk songs), harana (serenades), folk songs from other regions of the country, lullabies, excerpts from sarsuwela, and, in some instances, contemporary Filipino compositions. Siguion-Reyna collaborated with artists like Restie Umali, Levi Celerio, and other contemporary composers to contribute to the show. Umali composed 65 original songs and Celerio wrote 180 song lyrics for various Aawitan Kita episodes and specials. The show featured guest artists like Irma Potenciano, Ruben Tagalog, Conching Rosal, Mabuhay Singers, Janet Basco, Darius Razon, Bimbo Cerrudo, and Cris Villonco.

Aawitan Kita’s first year productions were shot at the San Agustin Church and Fort Santiago in Intramuros.

Some episodes of the show were musical docu-dramas that explored significant aspects of our country’s history. Noteworthy examples of these musicals in the 1970s were “Sisa,” directed by Arling Gonzalez and Mitos Villareal, “Pagpatak ng Ulan” (When the Rain Drops), “Ang Lakambini at ang Supremo” (The Muse and the Leader), directed by Lupita Concio, and “Dung-aw” (Death), directed by Lino Brocka. “Ang Lakambini at ang Supremo,” 1975, is an exposé of the death of Katipunan leader Andres Bonifacio in the hands of katipunero leaders from Cavite. “Dung-aw,” 1975, co-produced with the Philippine National Bank, examined agrarian issues in the Ilocos region and how these are implicated in the nationalist movement of katipuneros to create a nation. “Dung-aw” was written by Mario O’Hara, with cinematography by Romy Vitug, production design by Fiel Zabat, music by Lutgardo Labad, editing by Augusto Salvador, sound by Angel Avellana, and starring Armida herself as Gabriela Silang, Mario Montenegro as Diego Silang, and Bey Vito as Pablo.

Aawitan Kita also mounted sarsuwela on television, like “Ang Binhi” (The Seedling), “Sayang” (Lost Opportunity), “Ang Nazareno” (The Nazarene), and Amado Hernandez’s “Ulo ng Lechon” (Head of the Roasted Pig).

In 2005, the show was reformatted as a stage musical series, the first of which was Aawitan Kita sa Makati (I’ll Sing to You in Makati),” a special project for the senior citizens of Makati City that was continued for years as a monthly musical theater piece. Aawitan Kita sa Amerika (I’ll Sing to You in America) and Aawitan Kita sa Australia (I’ll Sing to You in Australia), both in 2011,
were contemporary Filipino sarsuwela in three acts set in a typical Filipino community. Both were directed by Carlos Siguion-Reyna and written by Bibeth Orteza.

The show spawned three music recording albums: Aawitan Kita Volumes 1 and 2 for Villar Records and Sa Lungkot at Saya . . . Aawitan Kita (In Sadness and Happiness . . . I Will Sing to You) for Viva Records.

Aawitan Kita won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1987, 1988, and 1989; the Special Award for Best Cultural Show from the PMPC Star Awards for Television in 1988; and the Ading Fernando Lifetime Achievement Award in 1991 for Armida Siguion-Reyna’s work as producer of the show. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Lily Grace A. Tabanera

text:
ABANGAN ANG SUSUNOD NA KABANATA(Wait for the Next Chapter) 1991–97, ABS-CBN. Executive producer: Gilbert Perez. Associate producer: Malu Sevilla. Director: Johnny Manahan. Writer: Jose Javier Reyes. Cast: Tessie Tomas (Barbara Tengco), Noel Trinidad (Anding Tengco), Anjo Yllana (Dino Tengco), Nova Villa (Tita delos Santos), Freddie Webb (Tito delos Santos), Sammy Lagmay (Sammy Lagmay), Nanette Inventor (Luningning Lagmay-Kataruray), Winnie Cordero (Liwanag Lagmay), Roderick Paulate (Benny dela Croix), Carmi Martin (Clara), Joji Isla (Del), Jolina Magdangal (Jolina), Ina Raymundo (Trina delos Santos), Jennifer Sevilla (Jenny Lagmay), Carmina Villaroel (Elizabeth delos Santos), Alicia Mayer (Adeline), Nina Perez Rubio (Dino’s grandmother), Ruby Rodriguez (Trisha Llamado), Jon Santos (various characters), Eagle Riggs, and Ogie Diaz.

This sitcom (situational comedy), using a multiple character format, pokes fun at three families representing the idiosyncracies of distinct socio-economic classes in Philippine society. The lower class family is beleaguered by the problem of finding money, even turning to prostitution and theft just to get by. The upper class is characterized by exaggerated consumption and the propensity for drugs and violence. The middle class is perpetually stressed by the pressure to move up the social ladder and the fear of falling down into the conditions of the poor.

Characters command scenes with their specific antics: the greedy, corrupt and lascivious Congressman Anding Tengco (Trinidad) who eyes the presidency; his pill-popping, shopping-crazy wife Barbara (Tomas); the spoiled brat and special child Dino Tengco (Yllana), who brandishes his family’s guns, goons, and gold; the Tengco family’s personal driver, hitman and fall guy, Del (Isla); the hysterical social climber Tita de los Santos (Villa), who covers her furniture with plastic; Tita’s husband Tito (Webb), who serves as Congressman Tengco’s campaign manager; the drivers’ union leader Samuel (Lagmay) and his wife Ningning (Inventor) who constantly nags him; the Lagmay daughter, Jenny (Sevilla), who studies in an exclusive girls’ school but who will most likely end up becoming a “cultural” dancer like one of the characters; the gay beautician, Benny dela Croix (Paulate), who brings to light all the other characters’ stupidities; Benny’s idiotic provincial lass and nightclub dancer, Clara (Martin), who graduated with honors from a university in the province; and a host of characters that spoof the lifestyle of the political elite, the economically rich, and the masses. All are portrayed in exaggeration, making caricatures of identifiable real-life personalities and social issues.

The program faced problems as an alternative comedy show. A member of the House of Representatives complained when his family name was used as the congressman’s name, causing the change into the name “Tengco.” Advertisers were wary of supporting a program that was initially too critical of politics. Viewers also had difficulty following the flow of the story when they missed certain episodes and so the show was reformatted as an episodic sitcom. The compromise was to make a socially relevant comedy program that could be enjoyed by the masses but would not touch on specific political situations and real-life personages that would merit censorship and advertisers’ boycott.

Abangan was remade by ABS-CBN as Eto Na Ang Susunod na Kabanata (This is the New Chapter) in 2001-03, following the same format and satirical style, and starred almost all the original members of the program, except Webb and Yllana. New cast members included Gabe Mercado, Candy Pangilinan, Denise Joaquin, Christina Espinosa, and Michelle Estevez.

Abangan won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1991 and 1993, the KBP Golden Dove Award for best comedy program in 1992, 1993, and 1995, and a bronze medal in the New York Festival in 1992. Written by JPaul S. Manzanilla

Caruncho 1991; Wikipedia 2014a, 2014b.

text:
AKLAT NG PAG-IBIG(Book of Love) 1949, 11:15–11:30 am, DZMB; DZRH. Producer: Philippine Manufacturing Company through PhilAds. Director: Domingo Principe. Writer: Genoveva Edroza-Matute. Narrator: Nick Reyes.

This is one of the first radio dramas in Philippine radio broadcast history which began airing in 1949. Aklat ng Pag-ibig featured not the typical love stories between a man and a woman but presented different kinds of love like love for country, God, and family. Stories and characters changed every three to six months, a format different from other soap operas also airing at the time such as Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home) and Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate), which featured continuing stories with various sub-plots through the years.

The story of “Babaing De-Karera” (Career Woman) is one example. It tells the story of a woman who, despite hardships and failures in life, emerged as a successful lawyer and whose lover, who had left her, returned to her.

Another story, titled “May Bakas ang Lumipas” (The Past Leaves a Trace), was likewise adapted to film using the same title in 1954. Richard Gutierrez, host of Anatomy of a Disaster, 2010 (Photo courtesy of GMA Network)

text:
22 Aug 2010 to 6 Nov 2011, monthly, Sunday Night Box Office (SNBO), GMA. Executive in-charge of Production: Wilma V. Galvante. Executive Producer: Mae Zambrano. Supervising Producer: Marivin T. Arayata. Associate Producer: Norman Jasmo Suarez. Program Creator: Suzette Doctolero. Director: Rico Gutierrez. Head Writer: Brian Geli. Segment Producer, Researcher, Writer: Ian Carlos Simbulan. Videographers: Gerardo dela Cruz, Arnel Hugo, Edgar Padil, Donato Villanueva. Lighting Director: Armin Collado. Linear Editor: Benigno Pagayatan. Non-Linear Editors: Sheena Velasco, Benson dela Paz. Program Manager: Cecille de Guzman. Location Manager: Doris Fernando. Host: Richard Gutierrez.

The 13-episode monthly documentary discussed issues and imparted knowledge on disaster preparedness in the wake of perceived negative effects of climate change. Each episode’s focus on natural disasters emphasizes that humanity cannot fully master nature. The program examined several environmental catastrophes that occurred in the Philippines across decades, juxtaposes these events with disasters in Japan, New Zealand, the United States and Africa, and describes the resilience of Filipinos in the wake of tragedies.

The promotional video teasers disseminated prior to the launch of the pilot episode underscored the need for disaster awareness and preparation. Aerial and panoramic shots of Mount Pinatubo revealed the beauty of nature, but were contrasted with images of its cruelty when it finally erupted, after a series of magmatic eruptions, on 15 June 1991. The first episode of Anatomy of a Disaster was launched to mark the 10th year since the volcano’s destructive explosion, now considered the second largest terrestrial eruption of the 20th century. The episode shows images of lahar-trodden roads and destroyed agricultural lands; analyzes the damage wrought on human lives, settlements, and the economy; and features interviews with survivors who recall the moments and aftermath of the eruption.

Some episodes included “Ragasa ng Panganib” (Rush of Danger), “Bangis ng Magma” (Wrath of the Magma), “Himagsik ng Kalikasan” (Revolt of Nature), “Lagablab Ng Kalikasan” (Blaze of Nature), “Urban Inferno,” “Nag-aapoy na Unos” (Fiery Storm), “Ang Poot ng Karagatan” (The Fury of the Seas), “Mga Mukha ng Peligro” (Faces of Danger), “Flashfloods,” “Landslides: Takas sa Guho” (Landslides: Flee from the Rubble), and “Hurricane Force: Alerto sa Bagyo” (Hurricane Force: Ready for Storm). The episodes featured volcanic eruptions, typhoons, flash floods, drought, hurricanes, landslides, earthquakes, maritime disasters, and catastrophic fires. The program provided information on nature’s might, insights from local and international experts on the environment, narratives of those who have experienced natural disasters, and accounts of how natural calamities have radically changed the lives of people.

The program had a weeklong special primetime screening on 21-25 Mar 2011. “Alerto sa Pagyanig: Earthquakes” (Tremors Alert: Earthquakes) surveys the country’s fault lines and alerts the people to prepare for possible major earthquakes. “Ragasa ng Panganib,” in which the host narrated his experiences as well as those of the other victims of Ondoy, one of the most devastating typhoons that hit Manila, was re-aired. “Volcano” educated the public on the different types of volcanoes, “Urban Inferno” informed people on how to prevent fire and live safely in the city, and “Bagsik ng Magma” featured the host visiting Taal Volcano, which at the time of airing had shown signs of a possible eruption.

In 2011, Anatomy of a Disaster received nominations for outstanding natural history/wildlife program and best program host in the Golden Screen TV Awards by the Entertainment Press Society, and a nomination for best documentary special in the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for TV. Written by Laya Boquiren

text:
APPLE PIE, PATIS, ATBP.(Apple Pie, Fish Sauce, Etc.) 1986–89, RPN 9. Producers: Jesse Maxwell, Monique S. R. Villonco. Directors: Peque Gallaga, Leo Martinez, Lorie Reyes. Scriptwriters: Boy Noriega, Tats Rejante-Manahan. Videography: Jerry Cabellon, Boy Martinez. Editing: Ramona S. Diaz. Music: Ruben Cadsawan, Nonong Pedero. Host: Joey de Leon.

Jesse Maxwell, an Italian-American who has lived in the Philippines for a decade, produced this 24-part television documentary on Filipino migrants. The show’s title refers to Filipinos’ love of food and the changes food faces once transplanted to a different culture. Its early episodes gave prominence to Filipinos in the United States, but it eventually also featured successful Filipinos in Europe and the Middle East, leading to the retitling of the program as Apple Pie, Patis, Paté, Atbp. The program featured both successful and tragic stories.

The program’s themes focused on redefining the Filipino. It tackled the dreams of expatriates, their belief in their potentials, employment problems at home, and how they handled pressures of adapting to another culture while remaining Filipino. It presented how Filipino values and character remain or change when they become the minority that must adapt in foreign settings. It exposed and deconstructed “Filipino” attributes embodied in the concepts of Juan Tamad (Lazy Juan), talangka (crab) mentality, and utang na loob or eternal debt of gratitude. The program encouraged travel as a form of education and entertainment, but neither promoted nor discouraged migration. The program was a finalist in the First Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1988. Written by JPaul S. Manzanilla

text:
ART ANGEL17 Apr 2004 to 14 May 2011, 8:30 am to 9:00 am, Saturdays, GMA. Producer: Marissa L. Flores. Executive Producer: Eva Marie Ercilla. Associate Producer and Head Writer: Augie Rivera. Program Creator: Leogarda Sanchez-Matias. Program Manager: Lee Joseph Marquez Castel. Director: Manny Angeles. Art Directors: Benedick Rellama, Ever Lawrence Gutierrez. Original Hosts: Pia Arcangel-Halili, Tonipet Gaba. Other Hosts: Krystal Reyes, Roxanne Barcelo.

Art Angel was a 30-minute educational program for Filipino children aged 6 to 12, which started out as strictly an arts and craft program. Its mission was to bring color and joy to all children by inspiring them to be creative and taking them to different art adventures, thus the program’s slogan “Ating Mundo’y Gawing Makulay” (Let’s Make Our World Colorful).

Each episode revolved around a central theme and featured regular segments done in the huge Art Angel set in GMA’s Studio 2. The “Main Project” featured an exciting, easy-to-do art project. As hosts Ate Pia and Kuya Tonipet gave a step-by-step demo. Gelo, the animated, wise-cracking angel-dog, would pop out onscreen to give his zany remarks as the cautious “Teka-Muna Angel” (Wait-a-Minute Angel), voiced by a kid, is heard every now and then to give safety reminders in using scissors, cutter, and glue gun. “Art Iba Pa…” (Art Etc.) featured Ate Pia and co-host Krystal doing simple arts and crafts projects which children and their moms could also do together. In “Pintado” (Painted), Kuya Tonipet joined Pintado, the tattooed/painted hand, in this guessing game-basic drawing instructional rolled into one. In “Lights, Camera, Obra!” (Lights, Camera, Artwork), guest celebrities would take a break from their hectic schedules to flex their artistic skills. In “Kuwento Na, Obra Pa!” (You Get A Story and An Artwork, Too), Kuya Tonipet would narrate a favorite local children’s book, using new artworks or illustrations done by the show’s creative team employing a variety of art techniques and materials taught and used in the show. “Art a Minute!” features simple, real-time art instructionals. In “Munting Kamay” (Little Hands), kids send in their drawings and artworks.

Soon, Art Angel evolved into a magazine program, innovating with different formats to continue being relevant and interesting to its target viewers. It added a variety of segments as represented by the four new icons in the program’s logo: “Paintbrush” for arts and craft, “Mask” for theater, “Book” for storytelling, and “Musical Note” for the song and dance production numbers.

The opening and closing of the program featured a standard song and dance number. A short musical play segment, “Teatro Art Angel” (Art Angel Theater), was also introduced to showcase Kuya Tonipet and Ate Anne’s strong musical theater background. Here, they also made colorful props and costumes that were easy to replicate at home. Through a song, Ate Anne gave a guide to children on what to do in sticky situations in “Ano Ang Gagawin Mo?” (What Would You Do?).

As a gesture of thanks to its many loyal viewers around the country, Art Angel did a series of mall tours every year, “Art Sayang Summer!” (Summer Fun) where they do musical production numbers, free art workshops for children, and conduct funny games with Art Angel merchandise like t-shirts, bags, pins, and tumblers and the sponsors’ products as prizes. Art Angel also released a series of activity books compiling some of the best arts and crafts projects done and seen on the program.

Art Angel aired its farewell episode on 14 May 2011, with the hosts delivering the trademark “Tatlong M” (Three Ms) reminder to the children: M-magligpit ng mga gamit…M-magpulot ng mga kalat…at M-maghugas ng mga kamay! (Gather your things, clean up, and wash your hands) and its empowering tagline that has become part of every episode’s closing spiel: “Kung kaya nating isipin, kaya nating gawin!” (What you can imagine, you can create!)

Art Angel became a commercial success as it rated consistently high and surpassed all its rival shows, even imported anime cartoons from the other networks. In that decade when there was a scarcity of locally made children’s shows, the program lasted for seven straight years, churning out all-new episodes, week after week, with hardly any replays. It was also a critical success as shown in the many awards and recognitions it received, both from local and international award-giving bodies. It was not only an annual winner of the ANAK-TV Seal Award; it was also included in the ANAK TV Top Ten Most Well-liked TV programs of 2007 and 2008, the only children’s program on the list. It also won Best Children’s Show and Best Children’s Show Hosts at the Star Awards of the Philippine Movie Press Club in 2007, 2008, 2009, and 2011, and the Gawad Tanglaw for Best Children’s Show in 2009. It was a finalist in the New York Film and TV Festival in 2008. It won the Silver Screen Award in the US International Film and Video Festival in Los Angeles in 2007, and the Bronze Award in the children’s category at the 32nd Telly Awards in New York in 2011. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, with notes from Augie Rivera Jr

text:
ART REPUBLIK(Art Republic) 2012, 8:40-9:10 pm, Tuesdays, replays 8:40-9:10 pm, Thursdays; and 2:00-2:30 pm, Saturdays, The Knowledge Channel. Company Producers: Asian Christian Arts Association, Inc, and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Producer: Betty Uy-Regala. Co-producer: Evie dela Cruz. Director, Director of Photography, and Editor: JL Burgos. Head Writer: Ime Morales. Researcher: Opaline Santos. Graphics Designer: Allan Alcantara. Production Assistant: Joel Laserna.

Art Republik was a documentary-magazine program that featured Filipino artists from various fields with each episode focusing on a specific cultural trait of the Filipinos. The show was created as an alternative to the usual entertainment and political programming features in local television. It aimed to increase awareness of the audience regarding Philippine art by way of presenting the artists themselves and their creations. It also promoted various cultural traits that are closely associated with Filipinos, including adaptability, hard work, courage, sentimentality, and perseverance.

The first season of Art Republik was composed of thirteen 30-minute episodes showcasing a total of 53 guests, 51 of whom are artists while two are art collectors. The pilot episode featured Roxlee, a prominent figure in Philippine underground cinema, and his brother, visual artist Romeo Lee. The episode also featured sisters Aba, Kiri, and Sari Lluch Dalena, who are likewise famous names in Philippine film and visual art.

Other prominent figures in Philippine art featured in the first season of Art Republik included visual artist and art advocate Karen Ocampo Flores, filmmaker John Torres, dance artist Myra Beltran, and street artist Whooop. The last episode for the first season showcased three of the country’s national artists, Abdulmari Asia Imao for visual arts, Virgilio S. Almario for literature, and Ildefonso P. Santos for architecture. Written by Isabella Louise D. Javier

The last episode for the first season showcased three of the country’s national artists, Abdulmari Asia Imao for visual arts, Virgilio S. Almario for literature, and Ildefonso P. Santos for architecture. Written by Isabella Louise D. Javier

ARTTALK: BEYOND ENTERTAINMENT29 Mar 2012–2013, 11:00-11:30 pm, Thursdays, replays 2:30-3:00 pm, Sundays, Net25. Producers: National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) and Net25. Concept: Malou Jacob and Libertine Santos de la Cruz. Program Consultant: Libertine Santos de la Cruz. Project Manager and Executive Producer: Leila Sulicipan Vibal. Director-Writer: Malou Jacob, with Shierdan Pamintuan. Set Designer: Rollie de Leon. Host: Gemma Cruz-Araneta.

The show ArtTalk features 21st-century Filipino Moro, Lumad, and Christian artists, art experts, and cultural workers as they discuss their significant role in contemporary Philippine society. With three guests in each episode, the show talks about the current conditions of the Philippine art scene, identifying and raising the concerns of the country’s arts and culture industry. It brings to the fore significant discourses arising from the depiction of contemporary Philippine social realities in various indigenous and Western-influenced art forms like visual art, music, film, literature, dance, and architecture. The discussions examine the cultural dimension of social problems, such as corruption, discrimination, and violence. Other topics include the importance of recognizing art in people’s daily lives, the role of the people in preserving and developing these art forms, the market of the creative industry, Filipino artists’ way of promoting their works to both local and international audiences, projects and activities by cultural workers, and emerging trends and updates on the status of Philippine art.

Some personalities who guested in the program were NCCA chair Felipe de Leon Jr, Cultural Center of the Philippines Board of Trustees chair Emily Abrera, National Museum director Jeremy Barns, Cinemalaya Foundation president Nestor Jardin, Yuchengco Museum curator Jeannie Javelosa, writer Ino Manalo, filmmaker Pepe Diokno, broadcast host Boy Abunda, sociologist Randy David, and critics Nicanor Tiongson and Isagani Cruz. The program completed 13 episodes that ran for one year. Written by Christine A. Palattao, with notes from Leila S. Vibal

AWIT, TULA AT BALAGTASAN(Song, Poetry, and Poetic Joust) 15 Feb 1996 to 21 Sep 2013, 2:00-3:00 am, Sundays, DZRP Radyo Pilipinas of the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS); 1997, 8:00-9:00 pm, Sundays, DZRM Radyo Magasin; 1997, 9:00-10:00 am, DZRB Radyo ng Bayan. Producers: Betty Camaligan Roxas aka “Prinsesa ng Balagtasan” (Princess of Poetic Jousts) and Rafael Francisco Roxas.

 

The program aired Filipino romantic ballads called kundiman and poetic debates, with Filipinos abroad as target audience. After over 17 years of showcasing traditional jousts, it went off air on 21 Sep 2013 when Betty Roxas, its producer, retired from the Philippine Broadcasting Service (PBS).

The program’s mambabalagtas (poetic debater) was led by Aurelio Angeles aka “Prinsipe ng Balagtasan” (Prince of Poetic Jousts) and Tino Estanislao, with lakandiwa (moderator), the balagtasan mediators and judges, Rudy de la Cruz,and Raul Funilas, and the female lakandiwa called lakambini Estella Sebastian. They were joined on the air by Julieta Acenita, Angel Bravo aka Ginoong Pantaleon ng Marikina (Sir Pantaleon of Marikina), Paul Lagman, Erlinda Layug, and Danilo Santos aka Hari ng Kundiman (King of Romantic Ballads). Meynard de la Cruz and Tony Pimentel served as the technical staff.

Among the issues they debated on in verse were Alin ang Higit na Kailangan ng Bayan: Magsasaka O Negosyante? (Which Does the Country Need More, the Farmer or the Businessman?), Alin ang Mas Mahalaga: Doktor, Guro, Inhinyero, o Abogado? (Who is More Important, Doctor, Teacher, Engineer, or Lawyer?), and Alin ang Mas Gugustuhin Mong Kapilas ng Buhay: Babaeng Makalipunan O Babaeng Makatahanan? (Who do You Prefer as Mate, a Society Girl or a Homemaker?).

Awit, Tula at Balagtasan received the Catholic Mass Media Awards ( CMMA ) Special Citation for Best Educational Program, 2003; Best Entertainment Program, 2004 and 2008; and Best Educational Program, 2010. It received the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas ( KBP ) Golden Dove Award for Best Radio Variety Program, 2010 and 2013, while Betty Roxas was awarded the KBP Golden Dove Award as Best Radio Variety Program Host, 2010 and 2013. Written by Victor Emmanuel Carmelo D. Nadera Jr

(That’s New!) 1996–2012, 5:00-6:00 pm, Sundays, DZMM Radyo Patrol 630 kHz. Producer: ABS-CBN Foundation. Hosts/Producers/Scriptwriters: Marie Marciano, Eli Guieb III, Angelo Palmones, Nelso Lubao, Rudy Cristobal, Dexter Ganibe, Nadia Shami, and Pinky Serafica.

This educational program, focusing on science and technology, envisioned a technologically competitive Philippines with the Filipino as a science-conscious person. It aimed to enhance understanding and appreciation of science and technology by featuring the latest technologies, studies, breakthroughs, projects, services, and government programs on science and technology. It encouraged the grassroots to improve their skills and knowledge on fields such as fisheries, agriculture, biotechnology, and nuclear energy to help them achieve productivity. Its segments included “Young Scientists,” which showcased students and their science research projects to stimulate creative thinking among young minds and encourage them to share their projects and innovations; and “Do-it-yourself Projects,” which described practical projects for the youth.

The other segments were DOST Technology, a discussion of the latest government-funded research findings and breakthroughs made by local scientists and researchers; Pinoy Innovation, a conversation on the ingenuity and creativity of Filipinos who developed products and concepts designed to aid the day-to-day living of Filipinos; School-on-the-air, a distance-learning program that encouraged listeners to enlist in the segment and to listen to lectures of resource persons; Internet Report, which provided information to those with no access to global scientific information; and Sci-tech News, a report on the latest on science and technology.

Bago ‘Yan Ah! served as an alternative learning resource in schools, especially in science subjects in elementary and high schools.

The program won the 4th KBP Alay sa Kabataan Award for best children’s program, 2000; the KBP Golden Dove Award for best science and technology program on radio, 2006 and 2007; the Catholic Mass Media Award for best educational program in Metro Manila, 2002 and 2006; the Media Business Advocate of the Year Award, 2004; and the Lopez Achievement Award for Public Responsibility, 2007. Written by Maria Carmela Barbaza

text:
BALAY, TIRAHAN, KANLUNGAN

 

(House, Home, Abode) Sep 2011, with reruns in 2012–14, 7:00 pm, IBC 13. Producer: IBC 13. Co-producers: Eric S. Canoy, Lito Ocampo Cruz, Gina P. Borinaga, National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Executive Producers: Rowie O. Valencia, Lorna Javate-Feliciano. Associate Producer: Kitty A. Menor. Directors: Milo Alto-Paz for Part 1 (Luzon Architecture), Rosalie Matilac for Part 2 (Mindanao and Sulu Architecture). Writer: Rosalie Matilac. Original score: Nonong Buencamino. Narrator: Cathy Eigenmann. Researchers: Cynthia C. Paz, Mary Ann Mendoza. Camera: Kikoy Rapadas. Graphic Artist: Budee Mendoza. Architect Interviewees: Leah Punongbayan-de la Rosa, Francisco Mañosa, Anna Gonzales.

 

Balay, Tirahan, Kanlungan is a two-part documentary series on Philippine indigenous architecture. The first part covered Tagalog and Ifugao architecture in Luzon. It presented the bahay kubo (nipa hut) as the most common house of Filipinos, especially in the past. It is built with basic, cheap but durable materials, such as the kugon (cogon grass) and the bamboo, thereby making it adaptable to the weather conditions of the country. Its large windows let in more air and light, which allows for a natural ventilation of the structure. The bahay kubo developed into a bahay na bato (stone house), a more modern and bigger abode built with stone and wood by the rich minority.

 

The show also presented Ifugao native houses in Banaue in the Cordillera region. Culture, traditions, and beliefs inform the building, location, and design of these houses, which were traditionally handed over from generation to generation. Unfortunately, these native houses from Banaue, as well as the basic bahay kubo, are slowly disappearing.

 

The second part of the series covered Mindanao and Sulu, focusing on Bukidnon and Badjao architecture. It presented the elevated native houses of Bukidnon in Mindanao, which are now rarely seen. It also featured the Monastery of Transfiguration in Malaybalay City designed by Architect Leandro Locsin which was based on the basic bahay kubo. The highlight of the second part is the feature on the architecture of the houses of two indigenous groups, the Daraghuyan-Bukidnon and the Talaandig, whose ancestors have chosen some portions of Mt Kitanglad, also in Bukidnon, as their settlement site.

 

The Daraghuyan Cultural Heritage Center, popularly known in Bukidnon as the modern tologan (clan house), is a living space for the entire tribal community. The Daraghuyan hold rituals and other traditional cultural activities in this structure. These activities and their relationship with the environment informed the processes the community went through to build the structure.

 

The building is made of concrete base to adapt to certain changes in the environment and to impress upon outsiders the capacity of the tribe to adapt to contemporary living conditions. Big windows surround the huge structure to make occupants feel that they remain connected to the environment and feel the warm, comfort, and protection offered by the mountain. The roof symbolizes the birds and the mountains. Most importantly, all members of the Daraghuyan tribe, from the youngest to the oldest member, voluntarily offered their labor to build the structure.

Second, the show presented the culture and architecture of the Talaandig. The materials for various structures that they built were meticulously and carefully taken from their environment. The highlight of the feature is the Talaandig School of Living Traditions for the continuing cultural education of the Talaandig children.

 

Noteworthy about the documentary is the depiction of Philippine architectural works not simply as soulless structures and designs but as contributors to the contemporary life of indigenous groups. These structures, as represented by the documentary, house the communal spirit of peoples that continuously negotiate the possibilities of their future in ways that nurture their identities as part of local and national societies. Written by Cynthia Cruz-Paz

text:
BALINTATAW / BALINTATAW II / RADYO BALINTATAW

(figuratively The Mind’s Eye; literally Iris)

Balintataw I: 19 Aug 1967 to Mar 1972, 8:00-9:00 pm, Saturdays, ABC Channel 5. Producers: Cecile Guidote-Alvarez, Alberto S. Florentino. Literary Manager and Head Writer: Alberto S. Florentino. Script Consultant: Mauro R. Avena. Executive Producer: Olive Montecillo. Head TV Director: Lupita Concio. Acting Director: Nick Lizaso. Pool of Directors: Lizaso, Lino Brocka, Joey Gosiengfiao, Elwood Perez, Jose Roy Jr. Pool of Writers: Tolentino, Avena, Orlando Nadres, Pierre Salas, Tony Perez, Wilfrido Nolledo, Nestor Torre, Ninotchka Rosca, Wilfredo Sanchez, Alfredo Yuson. Floor Director: Roger Velilla. Spinner: Romy Rivera. Host: Robert Arevalo.

Balintataw II: 1987–early 2000s, PTV 4. Producer: Cecile Guidote-Alvarez. Literary Managers: Isagani Cruz, Domingo Landicho. Directors: Lizaso, Nadres, Jose Gruta, Maryo J. de los Reyes, Lupita A. Kashiwahara, Jose Marie Avellana. Writers: Rolando Tinio, Lualhati Bautista, Lito Casaje, Henry Nabong, Dodi Anzures, Ronaldo Tumbokon, Mars D. Cavestany Jr, Lav Diaz, Suzette Doctolero. Hosts: Arevalo and Guidote-Alvarez.

Radyo Balintataw: premiered 2007, DZRH 666. 11:30 pm to midnight, Mondays-Fridays; 6:00-6:30 pm, Sundays. Producer and Host: Guidote-Alvarez.

Conceded by many as the exemplar of Filipino drama on television, the pre-martial law Balintataw was a joint venture of ABC-5, then owned by Marcos Roces, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), which Cecile Guidote-Alvarez founded and headed at that time. The program brought to the mass television audience the best in Philippine literature, especially prize-winning short stories, plays, and excerpts from novels adapted for TV, and original teleplays by established and new writers and playwrights. It ran for a total of 250 weeks.

The title Balintataw, proposed by Mauro R. Avena and highly recommended by writer Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, specifically refers to the mind’s eye, a “space within which the creative imagination can freely breathe, move, and expand.” Lupita Concio and Joey Gosiengfiao, who were then on the pool of artists of Channel 5, were involved with PETA in the planning and execution of the program. Concio served as the program’s first director and Gosiengfiao the show’s first stage manager, a job that would subsequently be handled by Jose Roy Jr, Elwood Perez, and Lino Brocka.

Avena wrote the pilot scripts of the program. The first script he wrote was “Ang Mananayaw” (The Dancer), an adaptation of Alberto Florentino’s one-act play The Dancers. The first script, however, that went on air when Balintataw premiered on 19 Aug 1967 was “Inulang Tipanan” (Rain-drenched Rendezvous), an adaptation of a story written by Concio, about a middle-class young lady, played by an uninitiated in drama, socialite Chingbee Kalaw.

The weekly drama program follows a standard format. The opening billboard that announces the title of the show is embedded with a voice-over of Vic Silayan providing a brief explanation of the term balintataw. Host Arevalo then makes his appearance to introduce the teleplay. Next is the drama proper. The host returns at the end to round up the presentation.

Unlike its contemporaries, Balintataw was not star-oriented. It had no acting mainstay. Actors for both the main and supporting roles, including short appearances, came mainly from theater and film. For example, the episode “Inanod ng Biyaya” (Swept by Grace), an adaptation by Avena of Linda Ty Casper’s short story “The Dead Well,” had stage actor Adul de Leon. “Kabalyerong Tanso” (A Fake Knight), an adaptation by Wilfrido Sanchez of a Filipino literary piece in English, had stage actors Tommy Abuel and Jimmy Asencio essaying roles with respected movie actors Vic Silayan and Barbara Perez. Some of the program’s notable performers included Leopoldo Salcedo, Mary Walter, Tita Muñoz, Dindo Fernando, Tommy Abuel, Liberty Ilagan, Perla Bautista, Alicia Alonso, Anita Linda, Rita Gomez, Fred Montilla, Marie Tuazon, and Eddie del Mar. During the height of the show’s popularity, it featured the varied talents of a motley group: international beauty queen Gemma Cruz Araneta, beauteous socialites Amelia de la Rama, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Elvira Manahan, and Chingbee Kalaw; ballet dancer Tina Santos; opera singers Aurelio Estanislao and Fides Cuyugan-Asensio; stage thespian Jose Avelino III; critics Anthony Morli and Nestor Torre Jr; foreign actors Claude Wilson, Mary Vigard, and Ed Murphy; and would-be popular stars Vilma Santos, Tina Revilla, and Tirso Cruz III.

From the first to the last, the major star in the anthology was the teleplay. Balintataw had a complete and carefully thought-out script for each teleplay, which was a rarity during the period for both television and film, when scripts, if any, were mostly improvised on the taping day itself. Mimeographed copies of the script were distributed to each member of the production team. Prior to the taping session, the stage director rehearsed the script with the cast for dialogue delivery, characterization, and blocking. Rehearsals were held at the Concio residence in La Vista Subdivision.

Some examples of Filipino literary pieces adapted for Balintataw were “Kudyapi” (Lute) written by Brocka based on the short story “The Day the Dancers Came” by Bienvenido N. Santos; “Kabalyerong Tanso” (Fake Knight) by Wilfrido Sanchez, from the “Rice Wine” by Wilfrido D. Nolledo; “Isang Gabi ng Tagsibol” (A Night of Spring) by Alberto S. Florentino, from “May Day Eve” by Nick Joaquin; and “Salambaw” (Fish Net) by Pierre Salas, from the one-act play The Sign of the Seagulls by Jesus T. Peralta. Other short stories that were featured in the program were Nick Joaquin’s “Summer Solstice,” “Guardia de Honor” (Guardian of Honor), “Three Generations,” and “Difficulties of a Diplomat;” Isabelo Crisostomo’s “Earthen Image,” “Mother of the Queen,” and “The Lonely Room;” Claro M. Recto’s “Shadow and Solitude;” Amador Daguio’s “Wedding Dance” and “The Woman Who Looked Out of the Window;” Rogelio Sikat’s “Impeng Negro” (Black Impen) and “Moses, Moses;” Jose Garcia Villa’s “Valse Triste” (Sad Waltz) and “The Man Who Looked Like Rizal;” Kerima Polotan’s “Sounds of Sunday” and “The Virgin;” Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s “A Secret Ageing;” Andres Cristobal Cruz’s “The Quarrel” and “White Wall;” Erwin Castillo’s “Ireland” and “The Fairy Child;” Wilfrido Sanchez’s “Moon Under My Feet;” F. Sionil Jose’s “The God Stealer;” Rony Diaz’s “The President of the Tribe;” Ninotchka Rosca’s “Piniling Lipi” (Chosen Race) and “Bakas ng Daliri” (Imprint of a Finger); and Joe Quirino’s “Night Song.” Among the plays adapted for Balintataw were Jesus Peralta’s The Somnambulists; Marcelino Agana’s New Yorker in Tondo; Julian Balmaceda’s Dahil sa Anak (Because of the Child); Wilfrido Nolledo’s Rice Wine and Sekoya; Estrella Alfon’s Tubig (Water), Bigas (Rice), and With Patches of Many Hues; Sister Maria Angela Barrios’s Hellow…Soldier (Hello… Soldier); and Alberto Florentino’s The World is an Apple, Cavort with Angels, and Cadaver. Younger writers of the period, such as Tony Perez and Franklin Osorio, also contributed memorable teleplays for Balintataw. Some original teleplays were Elwood Perez’s “Ina sa Lupang Malaya” (Mother in a Free Land) and “Ang Pagdalaw ng Isang Kahapon” (The Visit of a Yesterday), and Pierre Salas’s “Ang Aguinaldo Ko ay Ikaw” (You are my Gift) and “Wanted: A Secretary.”

Balintataw also featured foreign literary classics. Among the plays that it adapted to Filipino life and to the television medium were Paddy Chayefsky’s The Mother, Rod Serling’s Requiem for a Heavyweight, Arthur Miller’s Death of a Salesman and All My Sons, Tennessee Williams’s A Streetcar Named Desire and This Property is Condemned, Anton Chekov’s Three Sisters, Eugene Ionesco’s The Bald Soprano, and Robert Anderson’s Tea and Sympathy. Balintataw also adapted for television stories and novels of D. H. Lawrence, Ernest Hemingway, Julio Cortazar, Anatole France, W. Somerset Maugham, and O. Henry.

The program explored human and social relationships through a social realist lens that contextualized the struggles and challenges faced by the characters of the drama in concrete political conditions of the country. Characters included the prostitute, the other woman, a drug pusher, an ageing actress, a Protestant missionary, a revolutionary, a lovelorn landlady, a labor leader, a senator, a poet, a hero, a swinger, and a socialite.

Balintataw introduced many “firsts” in Philippine television. One was the first kiss on local TV, with actor Nestor Torre kissing on the lips a theater actress from the University of the Philippines in the episode “Goodbye, My Gentle”. Most of its episodes concluded with an “unhappy ending,” which was uncommon during the period when much of the drama on TV was romantic and idealist. It also introduced themes unexplored by local soaps during the period: the bakla or gay in “Duplex;” blatantly political issues in “Idolo ng Madla” (Idol of the Masses); religio-sexual themes in “Mambo Girl;” poverty, prostitution, and squatter demolition in “Oli Impan (Holy Infant);” and social unrest, such as those resulting from agrarian conflict in “Lagablab sa Karimlan” (Conflagration in the Twilight) and the massacre of farmers in “Sa Bawat Patak ng Dugo (For Every Drop of Blood).” Other social issues tackled by the program included the Intramuros of the 1800s, postwar Intramuros slums, the bleak Ilocos landscape, a logging camp, indigenous peoples such as the Igorot, issues in a fishing village, sensitive liaisons, the presence of US military bases in the country and its consequences, such as the G.I. baby, and many issues concerning social injustices.

Most of Balintataw’s stories were tragic, the characters ending up dead, defeated, or dehumanized. It presented society as a prison from which the characters could not escape. The program, however, also explored other genres like situational comedy, farce, period play, and dance drama.

Balintataw introduced innovations in local television production: the use of a full script based on quality material; the appointment of a script supervisor to oversee the quality of the scripts; the use of a stable of scriptwriters instead of one regular writer and a pool of stage directors; and the use of serious actors from theater and film instead of box-office stars. Most importantly, the drama anthology respected its audience as thinking and discriminating individuals.

The program went off the air in Mar 1972. Guidote-Alvarez revived the program on the government station PTV-4 in 1987 upon her return to the Philippines from self-exile in the United States. The post-EDSA Balintataw maintained its original format. It also went into radio in 1987, but reformatted as a cultural magazine program aimed at confronting the global challenges of poverty and climate change. Radyo Balintataw, hosted by Guidote-Alvarez, is aired daily on DZRH. It features drama, poetry, music, and storytelling during weekdays, and interviews, reports and commentaries on socio-political issues with focus on eco-cultural concerns every Sunday.

Balintataw and its directors, writers, and performers won 18 Citizens’ Awards for Television (CAT) from the Citizens Council for Mass Media from 1967 to 1972, including five for best drama anthology, plus the CAT Hall of Fame Award in 1972. The revived Balintataw received the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1988 and 1991. Radyo Balintataw won the KBP Golden Dove Award for best culture and arts program, 2008 and 2014; best drama program, 2008; best drama series, 2013 and 2014; and best documentary, 2012. It won best drama and best entertainment program, both in 2014, from the Catholic Mass Media Awards. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

article.value: Conceded by many as the exemplar of Filipino drama on television, the pre-martial law Balintataw was a joint venture of ABC-5, then owned by Marcos Roces, and the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), which Cecile Guidote-Alvarez founded and headed at that time. The program brought to the mass television audience the best in Philippine literature, especially prize-winning short stories, plays, and excerpts from novels adapted for TV, and original teleplays by established and new writers and playwrights. It ran for a total of 250 weeks.

The title Balintataw, proposed by Mauro R. Avena and highly recommended by writer Clodualdo del Mundo Sr, specifically refers to the mind’s eye, a “space within which the creative imagination can freely breathe, move, and expand.” Lupita Concio and Joey Gosiengfiao, who were then on the pool of artists of Channel 5, were involved with PETA in the planning and execution of the program. Concio served as the program’s first director and Gosiengfiao the show’s first stage manager, a job that would subsequently be handled by Jose Roy Jr, Elwood Perez, and Lino Brocka.

Avena wrote the pilot scripts of the program. The first script he wrote was “Ang Mananayaw” (The Dancer), an adaptation of Alberto Florentino’s one-act play The Dancers. The first script, however, that went on air when Balintataw premiered on 19 Aug 1967 was “Inulang Tipanan” (Rain-drenched Rendezvous), an adaptation of a story written by Concio, about a middle-class young lady, played by an uninitiated in drama, socialite Chingbee Kalaw.

The weekly drama program follows a standard format. The opening billboard that announces the title of the show is embedded with a voice-over of Vic Silayan providing a brief explanation of the term balintataw. Host Arevalo then makes his appearance to introduce the teleplay. Next is the drama proper. The host returns at the end to round up the presentation.

Unlike its contemporaries, Balintataw was not star-oriented. It had no acting mainstay. Actors for both the main and supporting roles, including short appearances, came mainly from theater and film. For example, the episode “Inanod ng Biyaya” (Swept by Grace), an adaptation by Avena of Linda Ty Casper’s short story “The Dead Well,” had stage actor Adul de Leon. “Kabalyerong Tanso” (A Fake Knight), an adaptation by Wilfrido Sanchez of a Filipino literary piece in English, had stage actors Tommy Abuel and Jimmy Asencio essaying roles with respected movie actors Vic Silayan and Barbara Perez. Some of the program’s notable performers included Leopoldo Salcedo, Mary Walter, Tita Muñoz, Dindo Fernando, Tommy Abuel, Liberty Ilagan, Perla Bautista, Alicia Alonso, Anita Linda, Rita Gomez, Fred Montilla, Marie Tuazon, and Eddie del Mar. From the first to the last, the major star in the anthology was the teleplay. Balintataw had a complete and carefully thought-out script for each teleplay, which was a rarity during the period for both television and film, when scripts, if any, were mostly improvised on the taping day itself. Mimeographed copies of the script were distributed to each member of the production team. Rehearsals were held at the Concio residence in La Vista Subdivision.

Santos; “Kabalyerong Tanso” (Fake Knight) by Wilfrido Sanchez, from the “Rice Wine” by Wilfrido D. Nolledo; “Isang Gabi ng Tagsibol” (A Night of Spring) by Alberto S. Florentino, from “May Day Eve” by Nick Joaquin; and “Salambaw” (Fish Net) by Pierre Salas, from the one-act play The Sign of the Seagulls by Jesus T. Peralta. Other short stories that were featured in the program were Nick Joaquin’s “Summer Solstice,” “Guardia de Honor” (Guardian of Honor), “Three Generations,” and “Difficulties of a Diplomat;” Isabelo Crisostomo’s “Earthen Image,” “Mother of the Queen,” and “The Lonely Room;” Claro M. Recto’s “Shadow and Solitude;” Amador Daguio’s “Wedding Dance” and “The Woman Who Looked Out of the Window;” Rogelio Sikat’s “Impeng Negro” (Black Impen) and “Moses, Moses;” Jose Garcia Villa’s “Valse Triste” (Sad Waltz) and “The Man Who Looked Like Rizal;” Kerima Polotan’s “Sounds of Sunday” and “The Virgin;” Gilda Cordero-Fernando’s “A Secret Ageing;” Andres Cristobal Cruz’s “The Quarrel” and “White Wall;” Erwin Castillo’s “Ireland” and “The Fairy Child;” Wilfrido Sanchez’s “Moon Under My Feet;” F. Sionil Jose’s “The God Stealer;” Rony Diaz’s “The President of the Tribe;” Ninotchka Rosca’s “Piniling Lipi” (Chosen Race) and “Bakas ng Daliri” (Imprint of a Finger); and Joe Quirino’s “Night Song.” Among the plays adapted for Balintataw were Jesus Peralta’s The Somnambulists; Marcelino Agana’s New Yorker in Tondo; Julian Balmaceda’s Dahil sa Anak (Because of the Child); Wilfrido Nolledo’s Rice Wine and Sekoya; Estrella Alfon’s Tubig (Water), Bigas (Rice), and With Patches of Many Hues; Sister Maria Angela Barrios’s Hellow…Soldier (Hello… Soldier); and Alberto Florentino’s The World is an Apple, Cavort with Angels, and Cadaver. text:
(Martial Law) 1997, ABS-CBN. Producing Company: Foundation for Worldwide People Power. Producers: Eugenia Apostol, Felly Arroyo. Executive Producer: Kara Magsanoc. Director for Film and Field Production: Jon Red. Director for OBB: Mike Alcazaren. Director for Postproduction: Jennifer Ifurung. Assistant Director: Amparo Po. Writer: Lito Tiongson. Script Consultant: Jose Lacaba. Videographers: Ruben Lee, Boy Araneta. Online Editors: Dave Hukom, Reggie Guilo, Ron Dale, Paul dela Cruz, Bob Serrano. Music Director: Jaime Fabregas. Sound Effects Producer: Carol Garcia. Head Researcher: Fe Zamora. Narrator: Joonee Gamboa.

The 90-minute documentary tackles the dark period of the dictatorship of Ferdinand Marcos, beginning from his re-election as President in 1969, to the declaration of martial law in 1972, until the EDSA People Power Revolution that overthrew his regime in 1986. Composed of footage and photos from actual events, the documentary chronologically narrates the horrors of martial rule. It first presents how Marcos appealed the murder conviction against him in the Supreme Court and won acquittal, after which he won government positions, became a Senator, then rose to the presidency. Interviews with Imelda Marcos defending her husband’s “compassionate society,” denying human rights violations, and justifying the vision of “The New Society” are juxtaposed with footage of the violence of the Marcos dispensation, such as torture, summary execution, bloody demonstrations, and arrest of opposition leaders and student activists. The irony is heavily emphasized with the “Bagong Lipunan” (New Society) hymn of the government embedded in the sequences that reveal the tyranny of the regime. The documentary details Marcos’s political moves and corruption to keep himself in power, discusses events such as the First Quarter Storm and the bombing of Plaza Miranda, analyzes crony capitalism, and enumerates the Rolex 12, which is the collective name of 12 of the closest and most powerful advisers of Marcos who were mostly members of the military.

The documentary also chronicles the struggle of Marcos’s erstwhile political opponent, Senator Ninoy Aquino, such as his 40-day hunger strike; his anti-Marcos activities in the United States; his speeches that exposed the Jabidah massacre of Muslims in 1968 by members of the Armed Forces of the Philippines, and Oplan Sagittarius, which is an outline of the imposition of martial law; and his death on the tarmac of the Manila International Airport. His death is described as the final straw in the struggle against the Marcos regime, one of many factors that incited the people to hold the historic People Power Revolution that freed the Filipinos from martial law.

The documentary includes more than 50 interviews with the architects and victims of martial law, some of whom include General Romeo Espino, then Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces of the Philippines; Blas Ople, then Secretary of Labor; Juan Ponce Enrile, defense minister during martial law who would eventually dissociate himself from the dictator; Imelda Marcos, the First Lady; Satur Ocampo, co-founder of the underground National Democratic Front; Bernabe Buscayno, former commander of the armed New People’s Army; Raul Manglapus, a delegate of the 1971 Constitutional Convention; Jovito Salonga, opposition leader from the Liberal Party; Dodong Nemenzo, political scientist who would become president of the University of the Philippines; Manila Archbishop Jaime Cardinal Sin, who called on the people to protect the anti-Marcos military on EDSA; and Corazon Aquino, who would be catapulted to the presidency after the ouster of Marcos.

Batas Militar won the Best TV Special Award in the 10th Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1997. Written byArade Louise P. Villena

(Small But Strong / Batibot Radio) 14 May 1984 to 2000, revived 27 Nov 2010 to 2014; 14 May 1984 to 1991: 4:00-5:00 pm, then 10:00-11:00 am, Monday to Friday, RPN 9; also 9:00-10:00 am, then 3:00-4:00 pm, Monday to Friday, PTV 4; 1991–94, ABS-CBN ; 1994–95, RPN 9; 1995–97, 10:00-11:00 am, Monday to Friday, GMA 7; 1998-99, RPN 9; 1999–2000, GMA 7, as Batang Batibot; 2010–14, 8:30-9:00 am, then 7:30-8:00 am, Monday to Friday, with five-minute spots at 8:55 am and 2:55 pm, Monday to Friday, ABC 5/TV 5. Beginning late 1980s, Monday to Friday, DZAM, later called DZAR. Producer: Philippine Children’s Television Foundation. Executive Producers: Lydia Benitez-Brown, Feny de los Angeles-Bautista. Line Producers: Vivian Recio, Mayee Fabregas, Carina Villanoz, Cielo Reyes, Paula Popple, Liezl Tiamzon, and Margie Templo. Curriculum and Research Director: Feny de los Angeles-Bautista. Directors: Kokoy Jimenez, Noel Añonuevo, Lem Garcellano, Carmelo Sta. Maria, Chuck Escasa, Rico Gutierrez. Creative Director: Rene O. Villanueva . Head Writers: Rene O. Villanueva, Lem Garcellano, Augie Rivera . Writers: Tomas Agulto, Donato Alvarez, Chuck Escasa, Ronald Mina, Pearl Mina, Augie Rivera, Millette Burgos, Elmer L. Gatchalian . Production Designers: Rodell Cruz , Dwight Gaston. Musical Directors and Composers: Louie Ocampo and Mel Villena . Lyricist: Rene O. Villanueva. Ethnic Instrumentation: Kontemporaryong Gamelang Pilipino. Closing Billboard Arrangement: Alamid. Puppet Voices and Puppeteers: Deo Noveno for Pong Pagong, Sammy Badon then Toots Javellana for Kiko Matsing, Rey Binalla for Filemon, Rose Nalundasan for Manang Bola and Ningning, Sandra Palad for Gingging, Rodelia Legazpi for Irma Daldal and Kapitan Basa. Cast: Susan Africa , Adriana Agcaoili , Isay Alvarez -Seña, Ching Arellano, Bunso, Soliman Cruz , Angie Ferro , Joe Gruta , Junix Inocian , Elmer Llaneras, Sienna Olaso, Luisito “Bodjie” Pascua, Dessa Quesada , Tito Quesada, Abner Delina, Kakki Teodoro.

Batibot is one of the Philippines’s longest running television programs for children aged from four to six. The word batibot means “small but strong,” an apt description for the show’s production style and objective of empowering Filipino children. The program’s predecessor, Sesame!, was a 1980s co-production of the Philippine Sesame Street Project (PSSP), then managed by the Philippine government’s Ministry of Human Settlements, and the New York-based Children’s Television Workshop (CTW), the producer of the TV program Sesame Street. Sesame! consisted of segments in English and Filipino in a magazine format. The PSSP became the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation, the producer of Batibot, when it parted ways with CTW in 1984.

Batibot followed a magazine format that mixes studio sequences with storytelling, situational skits, modular lessons, short educational music videos, animation, live action films, and puppetry to produce an integrated learning experience for the child. The contents convey Filipino nationalism through the use of the Filipino language and appreciation of things Filipino. Its segments address the lives of Filipino children, framed by an educational curriculum that considers the child’s intellectual, psycho-motor, moral, and sociocultural development. A significant segment that helps reawaken Filipino children’s love for literature is “Mga Kuwento ni Kuya Bodjie” in which Kuya Bodjie (Pascua) uses direct on-camera storytelling, supplemented by colorful illustrations depicting choice scenes. The show’s 30-minute radio version, Radyo Batibot, specifically designed for children with ages 7 to 12, follows the same format, but designs the lessons, content, and approaches appropriate for the characteristics, needs, and interests of its target audience.

Batibot featured characters from Philippine folk tales, like Pong Pagong, the six-foot giant turtle mascot who stands on his hind legs, towers over human characters, and loves kangkong (water spinach), and Kiko Matsing, the husky-voiced, smart-alecky muppet monkey. Some mainstay muppet characters include the young chatty sisters Ningning and Gingging; the inquisitive and child-like creatures from outer space, Sitsiritsit and Alibangbang, whose names are derived from a nursery rhyme; the talkative and fashion-conscious starlet, Irma Daldal, and her male partner, Tikyo Tiktilaok; the superhero Kapitan Basa who loves to read; and the lovable bespectacled fortune teller Manang Bola who, ironically, sometimes suffers from memory loss and whose lines when consulting her crystal ball “Perlas na bilog, huwag tutulog, sabihin agad sa akin ang sagot” (Crystal ball, be alert, tell me right away the answer) followed by “ba be bi bo bu” became so popular in teaching vowel sounds and an effective way to answer the many questions of children. These muppets keep company with friendly human characters, like the resident storyteller Kuya Bodjie (Pascua), the helpful lady Aling Nena (Ferro), big brothers Mang Lino (Gruta) and Mang Mokyo (Cruz), jeepney driver Kuya Ching (Arellano), and the caring neighborhood friends Luz (Dessa Quesada), Ate Sylvia (Africa), Ate Isay (Alvarez-Seña), Ate Sienna (Olaso), Kuya (Inocian), Ben (Quesada), and JD (Bunso).

In 1994, Pong Pagong and Kiko Matsing were pulled out from the show because of alleged licensing issues with CTW. In 1999, PCTVF cooperated with Ry/Bashman Productions in repackaging the show as Batang Batibot but went off the air in 2000 when it had difficulties facing tough competition from the growing number of Filipino and foreign educational programs. The revived program in 2010, with some original and new cast members, featured two segments, “Kwentong Batibot” (Batibot Stories) and “Balik Batibot” (Return to Batibot), a collection of selected episodes from the original Batibot program.

Batibot is one of the Philippines’s longest running television programs for children aged from four to six. The word batibot means “small but strong,” an apt description for the show’s production style and objective of empowering Filipino children. The program’s predecessor, Sesame!, was a 1980s co-production of the Philippine Sesame Street Project (PSSP), then managed by the Philippine government’s Ministry of Human Settlements, and the New York-based Children’s Television Workshop (CTW), the producer of the TV program Sesame Street. Sesame! consisted of segments in English and Filipino in a magazine format. The PSSP became the Philippine Children’s Television Foundation, the producer of Batibot, when it parted ways with CTW in 1984.

article.value: Batibot followed a magazine format that mixes studio sequences with storytelling, situational skits, modular lessons, short educational music videos, animation, live action films, and puppetry to produce an integrated learning experience for the child. The contents convey Filipino nationalism through the use of the Filipino language and appreciation of things Filipino. Its segments address the lives of Filipino children, framed by an educational curriculum that considers the child’s intellectual, psycho-motor, moral, and sociocultural development. A significant segment that helps reawaken Filipino children’s love for literature is “Mga Kuwento ni Kuya Bodjie” in which Kuya Bodjie (Pascua) uses direct on-camera storytelling, supplemented by colorful illustrations depicting choice scenes. The show’s 30-minute radio version, Radyo Batibot, specifically designed for children with ages 7 to 12, follows the same format, but designs the lessons, content, and approaches appropriate for the characteristics, needs, and interests of its target audience.

Batibot featured characters from Philippine folk tales, like Pong Pagong, the six-foot giant turtle mascot who stands on his hind legs, towers over human characters, and loves kangkong (water spinach), and Kiko Matsing, the husky-voiced, smart-alecky muppet monkey. Some mainstay muppet characters include the young chatty sisters Ningning and Gingging; the inquisitive and child-like creatures from outer space, Sitsiritsit and Alibangbang, whose names are derived from a nursery rhyme; the talkative and fashion-conscious starlet, Irma Daldal, and her male partner, Tikyo Tiktilaok; the superhero Kapitan Basa who loves to read; and the lovable bespectacled fortune teller Manang Bola who, ironically, sometimes suffers from memory loss and whose lines when consulting her crystal ball “Perlas na bilog, huwag tutulog, sabihin agad sa akin ang sagot” (Crystal ball, be alert, tell me right away the answer) followed by “ba be bi bo bu” became so popular in teaching vowel sounds and an effective way to answer the many questions of children. These muppets keep company with friendly human characters, like the resident storyteller Kuya Bodjie (Pascua), the helpful lady Aling Nena (Ferro), big brothers Mang Lino (Gruta) and Mang Mokyo (Cruz), jeepney driver Kuya Ching (Arellano), and the caring neighborhood friends Luz (Dessa Quesada), Ate Sylvia (Africa), Ate Isay (Alvarez-Seña), Ate Sienna (Olaso), Kuya (Inocian), Ben (Quesada), and JD (Bunso).

text:
1992-2001. Saturdays, noon to 1:30 pm, 1:30-3:00 pm, 2:00-3:30 pm, RPN 9 1992-99; PTV-4, 1999–2001. Produced by Focal Media Arts Inc and Uniwide Sales Group, then AMA Computer College, with the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports. Host: David Celdran. Alternates: Chiqui Roa-Puno, Cathy Santillan, Anthony Suntay.

Battle of the Brains was a quiz show for elementary, high school, and university students from public and private schools recognized by the Department of Education, Culture, and Sports. It has consultants from the University of the Philippines and the Ateneo de Manila University who serve as judges. Problem sets cover science, mathematics, arts and culture, history, current events, and general information in easy, average, and difficult rounds with a corresponding increase in prizes.

Each elementary and high school is represented by two students. A university is represented by one student. Weekly winners compete in the monthly finals, the winners of which compete in the quarterfinals, and then battle with the best in the grand finals. Prizes in the grand finals are 300,000 pesos for the elementary level winner, 400,000 pesos for the high school level winner, and 500,000 pesos for the college level winner. 100,000 pesos each is given to the school and coach of the winners in the elementary and high school levels. There are no similar prizes for the college winner. Grand finals are held in big assembly areas such as the Philippine International Convention Center (PICC) and the University Theater of the University of the Philippines in Diliman.

The combined rewards of achieving personal recognition and institutional prestige, honoring one’s parents, and getting big prizes made it one of the most popular television programs in the 1990s. It commanded a huge following, especially among the country’s youth, including their family elders. Thousands of students in hundreds of schools from different parts of the country would contact Focal Media Arts to join the weekly finals. It was said that student viewers at home also tried solving the problems and competing with peers for their own version of prizes. Parents are reported to have written and thanked the producers for encouraging their children to study. Bereft of showbiz gimmicks and utilizing a set with no glamorous design, Battle of the Brains has proven that the Filipino audience also demands substance in entertainment.

Schools that have sent students to the grand finals boast of their alumni’s inclusion in the show on their websites and in promotional materials. The program even had an invitational tournament for the three student levels in the Southeast Asian region which was held on 4 Jul 1997 at the PICC. All the levels were won by the Filipino contestants.

When the Uniwide Sales Group could no longer sustain the program, AMA Computer College stepped in, moved the show to PTV 4 in 1999, and sponsored it until its last run in 2001.

David Celdran was acclaimed best game show host by the PMPC Star Awards for three consecutive years in 1994-96. The Catholic Mass Media Awards conferred on the program the Lorenzo Ruiz Award for Television Entertainment in 1996 for “inspiring its youthful audience to strive for excellence in school and in everything they do.” Written by JPaul S. Manzanilla

text:
(My Country) aka The Politician. 10 Mar to 21 Apr 2013, Sundays, 6:30-8:30 pm, GMA News TV Channel 11. Producer: GMA News and Public Affairs. Creator and Program Manager: Nessa S. Valdellon. Executive Producer: Eliza Zamora-Solis. Associate Producer: Princess C. Gatmaitan. Director: Adolfo B. Alix Jr. Assistant Directors: Marjorie J. Darunday, Grace Simbulan, Armae Supanhari. Writer: Rody Vera. Director of Photography and Lighting Director: Albert Banzon. Cameraperson: Adones S. Ventura. Production Designer: Bobet Lopez. Art Director: Third Colles. Editors: Ben Tolentino, Anna Isabelle Matutina, Mark Joseph Llona, Orlean Joseph Tan. Music: Diwa Felipe S. De Leon. Theme Song Performer: Johnny Danao. Color grading: Outputs Inc. Actors: Rocco Nacino (Mayor Joseph Santiago), Pen Medina (Governor Antonio Rubio), LJ Reyes (Atty Karen Canlas), Ping Medina (Congressman Anton Rubio), Angeli Bayani (Nena Santiago), Mercedes Cabral (Eliza Bauer), Maria Isabel Lopez (Sylvia Rubio), Betong Sumaya (Betong), Love Añover (Liway), Bembol Roco (Ernesto Santiago), Archi Adamos (Mario), Simon Ibarra (Chief of Police), Cecille Adefuin (Nanay Ophie), Ed Lingao.

Bayan Ko is a six-part political drama that follows the career of Joseph Santiago, the young and newly elected mayor of the fictional city of Lagros. Idealistic and principled, Santiago faces the many challenges of Philippine politics, ranging from the improprieties of government employees and needless bureaucracy on the ground to patronage politics and impunity in high places. With echoes from Jose Rizal’s Noli Me Tangere, Santiago returns to his hometown in order to introduce social reforms. His father, a journalist, was ordered killed by the governor of the fictional province of Sibilan, Antonio Rubio.

Drawing upon the historical and nationalist associations of its theme song “Bayan Ko,” the mini-series represents historical problems that beset Philippine society and the call for heroism among Filipinos. The first two episodes, “Inherited Problems” and “Corruption,” establish the political dynasty of Rubio and his son, Congressman Anton Rubio, and their deep-seated corrupt practices that permeate all levels of society, as the main obstacles for Santiago’s mission to introduce change in Lagros. The third and fourth episodes, “Education” and “Jueteng,” depict inadequate public education and health care, as well as the workings of the illegal gambling network run by politicians and men of law who continue to exploit the poor. The last two episodes, “Illegal Logging” and “The Aftermath,” play out the effects of corruption on the environment, which devastate the whole province of Sibilan when it is visited by a storm.

The drama features various social types, such as Santiago’s wife, Nena, and his chief of staff, Atty. Karen Canlas, who are as principled as the mayor; the businesswoman, Eliza Bauer, in cahoots with the governor; and the governor’s tormented wife, Sylvia. It also portrays the common folk as capable of responding heroically to the times, as when disaster hits Lagros.

The mini-series was produced just before the national elections of 2013 and after the death in a plane crash on 18 Aug 2012 of Jesse Robredo, then secretary of the Department of Interior and Local Government (DILG) and former mayor of Naga City, Camarines Sur. Mayor Santiago’s character in the drama is reminiscent of Robredo and his vision of good governance, transparency, and community empowerment.

In 2013, Bayan Ko received the 12th Quill Award for Excellence from the International Business Communicators Philippines, the Best Drama Series by the Catholic Mass Media Awards, and was cited for Outstanding Achievement in the Broadcast Media at the 8thHildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communications by the St Scholastica’s College in Manila. Also in 2013, Pen Medina was nominated for Best Supporting Actor in the 27th PMPC Star Awards for Television. In 2014, it was nominated as Outstanding Original Drama Program and Nacino was nominated as Outstanding Actor in a Drama Program in the 5th Golden Screen TV Awards. Written byPatrick F. Campos

text:
(Hero) 1995-2001, Thursdays and Fridays, 8:30-9:00 am; Saturdays, 10:00-10:30 am, ABS-CBN. Produced by ABS-CBN Foundation under Gina Lopez-Roy, in partnership with the Department of Education. Executive Producers: Carina A. Villanoz, Ma. Cielo L. Reyes. Associate Producers: Marivic Reyes-Trinidad, Claudette V. Sevilla. Creative Committee: Uro dela Cruz, Jaime Veneracion, Bernadette Abrera, Cesar Celestino, Rowena Concepcion, Aurea Duran, Lem Garcellano, Melanie Gardunio, Peachy Gonzales, Myra Flor Sales, Carina Villanoz. Consultants: Jaime Veneracion, Bernadette Abrera, Ed Reyes. Directors: Noel Añonuevo, Jose Mari Avellana, Celso C. Celestino, Uro dela Cruz, Rene Guidote, Malou Jacob, Soxy Topacio. Writers: Reuel Aguila, Uro dela Cruz, Rowena Concepcion, Lem Garcellano, Malou Jacob, Clodualdo del Mundo Jr, Amante del Mundo, Pinky Serafica. Camerapersons: Conrado Amaquin, James Arce, Ricky Fiesta, Galileo Fortin, Genesis Gutierrez. Production Designers: Jens Peter Gaw, Chito Sumera, Willy Urbino. Theme Music Composers: Ditoy Aguila, Noel Zarate, Uro dela Cruz. Theme Music Singers: Brenan Espartinez, Maita Ponce. Music and Sound Effects: Froilan Malimban, Noel Argosino. Editor: Gerry Constantino. VTR and Special Effects Editors: James Arce, Juan Rommel Aquino, Cesar Celestino, Gerry Constantino, Chris Sioco. Technical Directors: Hernan Bartolome, Frederick Dureza. Lighting Directors: Boy Jorge Alcanzia, Totoy Alcanzia, Mariel Cruz. Selected Actors: Angelo Cometa (Noli), Celine Lirio (Aya), Agatha Tapan, Rolando Tinio (old hermit), Caridad Sanchez (Lola), Leticia Tizon, Susan Africa, John Arcilla, Junelle Hernando.

Bayani is a history program for young people, which disseminates a nationalist consciousness through the stories of Philippine national heroes as well as characters from precolonial Philippines rendered in a creative format. It uses the concept of time and space travel as a narrative device to move across the past and the present and to historically significant locales. The plot usually involves a quest where the children need to retrieve important objects from the past. The program is a platform for teaching Filipino values, such as love for family, hard work, and sincerity. Some episodes underscore the equal treatment of men and women in the anti-colonial struggle, like the ones on Josefa Rizal, leader of the association of women in the Katipunan; Ka Oryang or Gregoria de Jesus, the Lakambini of the Katipunan; Gregoria Silang; and the babaylan (indigenous shamans). The program also touches on Filipino concepts like loob (interiority), kapatiran (brotherhood and sisterhood), paglilingkod sa bayan (serving the country), and kalayaan (freedom).

The first episode, “Abaniko” (Fan), directed and written by Uro dela Cruz, was shot in Intramuros and Tanay, Rizal. The adventure begins when young Noli and Aya, running away from school bullies, find their way inside a mysterious cave. Here, they meet an old hermit who Aya realizes is bound by a rope. The hermit says that the cave contains the memories of the past and that history is the soul of the nation. He is sure that the children were brought here by fate. The children then open a book called “Aklat ng Kasaysayan.” The old man tells them that they are the first ones who are able to open it because they are pure of heart (“may busilak na kalooban”). The hermit tells them that he needs their help to recover memories that were stolen from the cave. Their first mission is to find the first abaniko made by Andres Bonifacio. The children then travel back in time and encounter a young Andres peddling abaniko in the streets of Manila. The children are able to obtain the object of their mission. The first abaniko was a prototype, which the young Andres did not like. Noli and Aya go back to the cave to give the old man the abaniko. They are then sent home but they promise to go back. Noli has just discovered his love for Philippine history, the subject he used to hate most in school.
