Bayani is a history program for young people, which disseminates a nationalist consciousness through the stories of Philippine national heroes as well as characters from precolonial Philippines rendered in a creative format. It uses the concept of time and space travel as a narrative device to move across the past and the present and to historically significant locales. The plot usually involves a quest where the children need to retrieve important objects from the past. The program is a platform for teaching Filipino values, such as love for family, hard work, and sincerity. Some episodes underscore the equal treatment of men and women in the anti-colonial struggle, like the ones on Josefa Rizal, leader of the association of women in the Katipunan; Ka Oryang or Gregoria de Jesus, the Lakambini of the Katipunan; Gregoria Silang; and the babaylan (indigenous shamans). The program also touches on Filipino concepts like loob (interiority), kapatiran (brotherhood and sisterhood), paglilingkod sa bayan (serving the country), and kalayaan (freedom).

article.value: The first episode, “Abaniko” (Fan), directed and written by Uro dela Cruz, was shot in Intramuros and Tanay, Rizal. The adventure begins when young Noli and Aya, running away from school bullies, find their way inside a mysterious cave. Here, they meet an old hermit who Aya realizes is bound by a rope. The hermit says that the cave contains the memories of the past and that history is the soul of the nation. He is sure that the children were brought here by fate. The children then open a book called “Aklat ng Kasaysayan.” The old man tells them that they are the first ones who are able to open it because they are pure of heart (“may busilak na kalooban”). text:
(Eve of History) 19 Sep 1994 to 5 Dec 1994, Mondays, 8:30-9:30 pm, RPN 9. Producer: Edith del Rosario. Executive Producer: Domingo Boquiren. Concept: E. Medina Jr. Director: Lupita Aquino Kashiwahara. Assistant Director: Gene Rose Singson. Writer: Patrick Manahan. Videographers: Ed Alinea, Chad Dawal, Norman Galang, Rolly Gallo, Boying Panilio. Production Design: Jake de Asis. Art Direction: Rolando Inocencio, Cris Cajuyon. Lighting Design: Joe Tutanes. Original Music Composition: Lucien Letaba. Cast: Cherie Gil (Gabriela), Michael de Mesa (Dr. Juanito Morga), Mark Gil (Carlos Luzzuriaga), Efren Reyes Jr (Crisanto or Anto), Rosemarie Gil (Señora Corazon), Gina Alajar (Sabel), Amado Cortez, Pinky Amador, Mia Gutierrez (Victoria), Ama Quiambao, Dan Fernandez (Abel), Soliman Cruz (Agustin), Cesar Burgos, Pen Medina (Crispin), Jovit Moya (sergeant of Carlos).

 

Bisperas ng Kasaysayan is an 11-episode historical drama series for television that offers a view of the Philippine revolution against Spanish colonization from the perspective of landless peasants. The drama contextualizes the people’s quest for national identity and the formation of the Filipino nation. It interrogates the encomienda (land ownership) system, the frailocracy of the Catholic Church, the political and economic power of land-owning elites, the complicity of the indio (natives) in the perpetuation of an unjust social order, and the complexity of the revolt of the masses. It disrupts the colonizer-colonized, foreign-native, and rich-poor binary oppositions by pointing out that the social cancer is brought about by a mix of imperialist expansion, patron-client human relations, and conflicting self-interests in all social classes in a highly stratified society undergoing profound changes.

 

The story begins in Manila in a meeting of the kilusan, a clandestine revolutionary organization, attended by Crispin, one of its leaders, and Victoria, one of the women, who play a key role in the movement. News has spread that the propagandist Jose Rizal has been arrested by the authorities. Carlos Luzzuriaga, a young teniente (assistant to the political leader) assigned in Manila, returns to his hometown in Sta. Filomena in Ilocos to help his mother, Señora Corazon, a criolla (a Spaniard born in the Philippines), deal with farmworkers who are opposing the increase in the rent for the use of the land of the family’s hacienda. He orders the houses of the peasants burned.

 

The initial episodes introduce other key characters. Gabriela is the spoiled, educated, and adventurous Luzzuriaga heiress who keeps copies of the banned novels of Jose Rizal. She has recently been fired from her teaching stint in Manila. Dr. Juanito Morga, a Spaniard who is a guest of the Luzzuriagas, is in Sta. Filomena to provide medical services to the community. He is attracted to his assistant Sabel, who introduces him to the plight of the indio and gains their trust. Agustin, an indio, provides Teniente Carlos and his sergeant information about the activities of the indio. The articulate leader of the hacienda workers, Crisanto or Anto, and his friend Abel discuss with workers two organizations to which they can belong, the Cuerpo de Compromisarios (assimilationists) or the organization they know only by its acronym, the KKK. Gabriela seeks out Anto and listens to his story: he went to school, but was bullied and kicked out because of the color of his skin, imprisoned for retaliating against a classmate, and tortured. He then swore never to go back to school, and returned to Sta. Filomena to work in the hacienda.

 

Victoria, posing as Anto’s aunt, arrives in the hacienda, introduces the Katipunan to the farm workers, and convinces them of the importance of a national movement over scattered local groups. Doubted at first because of her being a woman, she exhorts the people to take up arms, but explains that awakening and unity entail a change of one’s loob (interiority), which many neglect when they join the revolutionary group. Anto, marked by Agustin as the leader of the clandestine organization, is arrested and tortured by a fellow indio working in the cuartel. Victoria flees for her safety and hides in Sabel’s house. Gabriela begs her mother to convince Carlos to set Anto and his comrades free, but Carlos stands firm in his view that the affairs of war, like running the hacienda, cannot be reduced to a choice between misericordia (misery) and crueldad (cruelty). Anto and Victoria are able to convince Sabel, whose father was humiliated by a Spanish friar, to join the Katipunan. Gabriela, disregarding her class origins, also joins them, invoking rootedness to a place and identity as emblems of the revolutionary: “Tagarito ako. Isa akong Filipina.” (I am from this place. I am a Filipina.) The women become key strategists in the armed uprising. Gabriela leads the men in battle. Victoria teaches the revolutionaries how to use firearms and holds discussions with members on why the Philippines is poor. Señora Corazon learns to accept the path her daughter has taken.

 

Rumors circulate among peasants that recent events point to the impending freedom of mythological hero Bernardo Carpio, the hari ng katagalugan (king of the Tagalog) trapped between two huge boulders in the mountains, and who people believed will save the Filipinos from oppression and enslavement. The supremo (leader) of the Katipunan, Andres Bonifacio, is arrested and tried by his comrades for sedition and treason against the government of Emilio Aguinaldo. The military might of government authorities and the internal organizational bickering within the KKK deplete the energies and resources of the revolutionaries and lead to the disintegration of the movement. Victoria discusses with members of the Katipunan the offer of amnesty by Carlos in exchange for laying down their arms to rebuild their lives, which Sabel counters by invoking kapakanang pambayan (national interest) over self-interests. The military raids the rebel camp, captures some of the leaders, and puts the rebels’ dead bodies, including that of Abel, on display in the plaza for the whole town to see. The rebels regroup in the forest where Sabel and Dr. Morga are reunited. Sabel, who dies after giving birth, implores Gabriela and Anto to remain steadfast. Gabriela and Anto rally the remaining revolutionaries to continue with their struggle for independence “para sa kapistahan ng ating pagkabansa” (for the celebration of our nationhood).

 

The narrative of the drama is linear and the exposition is enriched by subplots hinged on the romantic entanglements of the characters, questions of filial loyalty, and conflicts of individual principles. The narrative presents each of the characters’ crises and processes of self-discovery. Actors move across the scene space laterally and in depth, at times pausing in classical tableau, to punctuate moments when an epiphany or confession is articulated. The conversations, at times lengthy, voice out relevant issues of the milieu or recount the character’s sad back story. The dialogue occasionally breaks off into a few lines of Spanish, without subtitled translations, to underscore the incomprehensibility to common folks of a foreign language. The costumes, sets, props, and locations collectively emphasize the historical-realistic configuration of the drama. The scenes were shot on location mostly in Ilocos Sur, with the support of local government units.

 

Bisperas ng Kasaysayan was among the ten outstanding television programs in 1994 of the 8th Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon, which also conferred on Lupita Aquino Kashiwahara the Gawad para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon. Written by Laya Boquiren

text:
2003–05, Knowledge Channel. Producer: Women’s Media Circle. Host: Aiza Seguerra.

Bodytalk is a weekly 30-minute television magazine program for teaching high school students about adolescent reproductive health (ARH) broadcast to classrooms through the Knowledge Channel cable station. As the third in a series of media campaigns of the Women’s Media Circle (WMC), the program started as a regular segment of the TV talk show XYZ: Young Women’s TV, 1995-2002, on ANC, which was alternately hosted by Risa Hontiveros, Karen Kunawizc, Lara Parpan, Apol Lejano, Jessica Zafra, and Dina Bonnevie in groups of threes.

The content of each episode is derived from Bodytalk: The XYZ Guide to Young Women’s Health and Body, a two-volume book published in 2000 by WMC Foundation under the Circle Books imprint, written by several doctors and academics, and edited by Gillian Virata, Mary Ann Asico, and Anna Leah Sarabia. The book was a pioneering enterprise, as it was the first publication on science-based reproductive health and puberty education ever produced in this predominantly Catholic country.

Bodytalk discusses topics considered by conservatives daring and controversial for discussion on TV, such as private body parts of males and females, menstruation, masturbation, genital and other viruses, first sex, dating, violence, and other reproductive health concerns. Students and young people from different schools were invited to participate in each episode, either as part of the on-cam talents, people-on-the-street interviewees, or non-speaking “extras.” Because the host is celebrated television and pop music personality Aiza Seguerra, teachers and students almost always agreed to join the episodes.

The subject matter of the program made it impossible to get airing on regular free TV. Bodytalk might never even have been broadcast if the Lopez family, owner of the Knowledge Channel, and its companies did not support reproductive health. Plans to package the series as teaching modules on ARH for public high schools, together with the Bodytalk books, were discussed with the Department of Education officials between 2001 and 2004. Unfortunately, these never materialized. Written byAnna Leah Sarabia

Started 20 Oct 1995, Fridays, 10:00-11:00 pm, GMA. Executive Producers: Camille Hermoso, Jan Navarro. Creator: Marivin Arayata. Director: Uro de la Cruz. Creative Director: Michael V. Writers: Cesar Cosme, Chito Francisco, Henry Maceda, Many Pavia, Roel Raval, Mon Roco, Herman “Isko” Salvador. Original cast: Michael V., Ogie Alcasid, Antonio Aquitania, Wendell Ramos. Selected cast members: Rufa Mae Quinto, Maureen Larrazabal, Boy 2 Quizon, Albert “Betong” Sumaya,Paolo Contis, Sef Cadayona, Herman “Isko” Salvador, Cesar Cosme, Chito Francisco, Diego Llorico, Myka Flores, Eri Neeman, Jacky Woo, Ellen Adarna, LDenise Barbacena, Rainier Castillo, Joyce Ching, Max Collins, Sunshine Cruz, Mikael Daez, Maricar de Mesa, Assunta de Rossi, Jackie de Guzman, Shirley Fuentes, Eric Fructuoso, Toni Gonzaga, Mark Herras, Susan Lozada, Francis Magalona, Jan Manual, Aya Medel, Aiko Melendez, Ara Mina, RJ Padilla, Amanda Page, Sam Pinto, Francine Prieto, Sherilyn Reyes, Jackie Rice, Arny Ross, Chariz Solomon, Andrea Torres, Juancho Triviño, James “Moymoy” Obeso, Rodfil “Roadfill” Obeso, Gwen Zamora, Diana Zubiri.

The comedy sketch program, initially titled Bubble Gang: Just Chew It, was inspired by ABC5’s gag show Tropang Trumpo (Troop of Tops), 1994-99, from which came two of its original cast members, Michael V. and Alcasid. It parodies celebrities, politicians, superheroes, television programs, advertisements, popular music, current events, ethnicities, languages, genders, traditions, and the daily lives of Filipinos.

Among its character sketches are Sex Balls, the half-naked male dance group that is a burlesque of sexy women dancers in popular noontime shows; D’ Wonder Boys, a lampoon of the famous four-boy Korean Pop group Wonder Boyz; the half-sisters Cheche, who is mild-mannered and refined, and Bureche, who is ill-tempered and rough; Yaya (the babysitter) and the spoiled child Angelina; So Poor Man, savior of the poor who is a caricature of Superman; Super Masa, a caricature of former Philippine President Joseph Estrada; Madam Rocha, a satirical imitation of a psychic; Boy Pickup, the undefeated hip hop guy who raps illogical modern balagtasan (poetic) lines; Boy Basag, the challenger of Boy Pickup in their rap battles; Mr. Assimo, a mockery of people’s idiocy; Junie Lee, the farcical interviewer of real-life celebrities; Aling Mary (Miss Mary), a cruel front desk staff whose convenience store is in the front office; Antonietta, the affectations of a prima donna who comments on the absurdity of drama soaps; and Tata Lino (Old Man Lino), the mysterious philosopher in the forest.

Some of its segments are “Ang Dating Doon” (The Old Way), a satirical take on a religious group and a mock gathering of the faithful and their leaders who interpret folk tales and nursery rhymes instead of Biblical passages; “MTB: Myusik Tagalog Bersyon” (MTV: Music Tagalog Version) and “MEV: Music English Version,” spoofs of popular music videos; “Iyo Tube” (Your Tube), a burlesque of Filipino YouTube sensation Moymoy Palaboy lip synching popular songs on YouTube; “Ang Bagong Diks” (The New Dicks, for Dictionary), a play on Filipino words and phrases; “Battle of Pickup Lines,” an exaggerated rendition of hip-hop-attired youths engaged in a modern-day literary joust; “Balitang News” (Nosey News), a lampoon of current events and public figures; “Sumbong-sumbong kay Bonggang Bongbong” (Report it to Fabulous Bongbong), a gay parody of a macho broadcast news commentator; “Ikaw at ang Ina” (You and Mother), a critique of young people’s thoughtless and insensitive use of social networking sites; “Muchas Grasas” (Too Much Grease), a travesty of homeless greasy vagrants in daily soap operas; “Ba’t Ganun?” (How Come?), a charade of people’s senseless behavior, attitudes, activities, and beliefs; “Atlit” (At Least), a stand-up that treats ugliness with vulgar dignity; and “Istambay sa Looban” (Bystanders in the Alley), a sketch of bizarre incidents in a community of informal settlers. Spinoffs of the program and its characters are GMA’s short-lived children’s gag show Bubble Gang Jr., 2005, and the movies Yaya and Angelina, 2009, and Boy Pickup, 2012.

Bubble Gang has received criticisms for many of its insensitive portrayal of persons with disabilities, ethnic groups, gays, people of color, physically challenged individuals, and rape victims. In 2013, the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board called the attention of the program for its derogatory and discriminatory treatment of women as sex objects in the sketch “The Adventures of Susie Lualhati.”

Bubble Gang won several awards and citations from the Asian Television Awards: best comedy program in 2004; best comedy performance for Michael V. in 2005; highly commended best comedy program in 2008; and highly commended best comedy performances for Alcasid in 2008, and Michael V. in 2013.

It won several awards from the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards: sixteen times for best gag show, 1996-2007, 2009, and 2011-2013; five times for best comedy actor for Michael V., 2000, 2002, 2003, 2005, and 2013; five times for best comedy actor for Alcasid, 2002, 2004, 2008, 2010, and 2011; and four times for best comedy actor for Quinto, 2008, 2010, 2012, and 2013.

It also won awards from the Entertainment Press Society Golden Screen Awards for TV: outstanding gag program in 2013 and 2014, best comedy actor for Alcasid in 2005 and 2013, and best supporting performance in a comedy for Cadayona in 2014. It won best gag program from Gawad Tanglaw in 2012. Bubble Gang is also a favorite of student groups, having won best comedy program and best performance for its actors from the Gandingan Awards of the University of the Philippines at Los Baños, the USTV Awards of the University of Santo Tomas, the Mabini Awards of the Polytechnic University of the Philippines, the Paragala Central Luzon Media Awards of Holy Angel University, and the Students’ Choice Awards of Northwest Samar State University. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Jason Paolo R. Telles

CAFE BRAVO14 Aug 1989 to 1990, 10:45 pm-11:45 pm, Mondays, ABS-CBN. Producer: Maria Lopez. Associate Producer: Maita Lopez. Director: Leo Rialp. Head Writer: Roy Iglesias. Musical Scorer: Egay Rustia. VTR Director: Ben Panaligan. Researchers: Laurenti Dyogi, Ronald Arguelles. Hosts: Tweetums Gonzalez, Apa Ongpin, David Celdran.

Cafe Bravo was a telemagazine (television magazine) talk show about arts and culture. It was set in a modern café, the “proprietors” of which were the program’s hosts. A puppet named Phil was a regular member of the cast who served as the cook, janitor, and waiter, all rolled into one. He was also the program’s philistine who added comic relief to the show.

The show’s fast-paced treatment gave it an upbeat mood, in contrast to the impression that art is dull and boring. It regularly featured interviews with and mini-documentaries about local and international artists, comprehensive coverage of events in the performing arts, a complete cultural calendar of noteworthy performances and events, and an editorial by the hosts at the end of the show in which they each shared their personal views about the country’s art and culture scene. The show used contemporary Filipino to reach a wider audience.

The program’s initial episode featured an on-the-spot nude painting session with the Saturday Group of Artists, Tanghalang Pilipino’s staging of Larawan (Portrait of the Artist as Filipino), and Ballet Philippines, with an editorial about the issue of smuggling antiques. Written by Cynthia Cruz-Paz

text:
CAMAY THEATER OF THE AIR1949, BEC DZBC (Bolinao Electronics Corporation); 1950s, 6:00 pm, Sundays, DZBB. Producers: Dramatic Philippines, J. Walter Thompson. Sponsor: Procter & Gamble (P&G). Director: Fred Gonzales. Music: Jimmy Navarro.

The title of this radio program is a product manufactured by P&G, a beauty soap marketed at women, who were believed to be the main audience of the soap. Following a worldwide soap opera guideline at the time, the stories in Camay Theater of the Air revolve around a central figure, such as housewives.

It had a live full orchestra conducted by Ariston Avelino when it was on DZBC. When it moved to DZBB, it featured upcoming movies by producing radio versions shortened to an hour, especially those shown at Life and Dalisay Theaters. The radio versions of the screenplays, rewritten for the ear by Mabini Rey “Mab” Centeno, were voiced live by the movie actors themselves before a studio audience. Fans crowded the studio at Calvo building on Escolta, Manila to watch their favorite screen stars read from movie scripts as Jamie dela Rosa acted as the maestro (host/narrator). Written by Gizelle Louise M. Dasmariñas

CANCIONAN ON THE AIR1960s, 7:00-8:00 pm, DWDW. Producer: International Broadcasting Corporation. Writer and Host: Lorenzo Morante.

A weekly program that featured the traditional poetical joust called cancionan in the province of Pangasinan. The most popular cancionista in the province, Morante adapted cancionan for radio by condensing it to less than one hour from the three to eight hours that it usually took to perform in town fiestas. Cancionan is a verbal joust between two individuals, usually a male and a female, tackling courtship, marriage, romance, and infidelity. Its verses vary from four to eight lines per stanza, usually set to known tunes, using wit, humor, irony, and satire, provoking the audience to take sides. It is also popular in the Ilocos region.

In Cancionan on the Air, Morante chose the tune most requested by the audience. More contemporary themes were employed such as “Siopay Maong ya Manangkaili: Say Mayaman odino say Pobre?” (Who is More Hospitable: The Rich or the Poor?).

Radio offered popularity and commercial possibilities for the cancionan. Several businessmen hired well-known cancionistas to stage the cancionan either in public or on radio for advertising purposes. Commercial sponsors for the Cancionan on the Air included an auto repair shop, a shoe store, a lumberyard, a milkfish vendor, a hardware store, a vulcanizing shop, and a tailor. Aside from Morante, cancionistas who appeared in the program include Fely Manuel, Encarnacion Cabatbat, Benedicta Bandong, and Perlita Radam. Arturo Valenzuela, DWDW station manager, was the first to produce the program.

Interrupted for two years after the declaration of martial law in 1972, it went back on the air in 1974. It then inspired other cancionan programs in Pangasinan, such as Bonikewan ed Caraclan (Riddles for All) on Eagle Broadcasting Corporation’s DWIN and Turbaan Ilocano (Ilocano Cancionan) over DWMC. In 1976-77, the provincial office of the Commission on Population in Pangasinan sponsored a cancionan program on DZDL to disseminate the concept of family planning to its audience.

In 1992, the Cultural Center of the Philippines awarded the Cancionan on the Air the Gawad CCP Para sa Natatanging Kontribusyon for its efforts to continue the tradition of the cancionan, maintaining public interest in the folk art. Written by Maria Criselda C. Sto. Domingo, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

text:
CHECHE LAZARO PRESENTS1998-2003, GMA; 2010–14, ABS-CBN. Producer: Probe Productions Inc, Unlimited Productions Inc. Executive Producers: Judith Torres, Jennifer Vergara, Alexis Loinaz, Booma Cruz, Data Tolentino-Canlas. Segment Producers: Jennifer Domingo, Joy Ibay, JJ Villamarin, Kath Mendoza, Alicia Cruz, Jason Reyes, Tet Salvador, Kala Reyes, Macky Fernando, Ella Evangelista-Martelino, Kay Katigbak, Michie Cabrera, Lucille Sodipe, Hera Sanchez, Zanneth Lago, Jing Ventura, Tops Brugada, Tin Macatulad-Chua, Eva Marie Ercilla, Agay Llanera-Reyes, Marjorie Mosura-Dumont. Graphics Artists: Christian Tolosa, Judex Villamarin, Ruel Asuncion, Lisa Estrada. Host: Cheche Lazaro.

Cheche Lazaro Presents began as a one-hour telemagazine (television magazine) lifestyle show and travelogue that featured Cheche Lazaro interviewing locals in the places she visited, discussing the cultural and historical significance of the place, and experiencing their unique activities, food, or festivals. The program traveled all over the Philippines, Australia, Europe, South America, and the Mekong Region in Southeast Asia. One of the most memorable episodes was on the Tubbataha Reefs in the Sulu Sea east of Palawan. It was one of the first travel documentaries in the country to shoot underwater footage, showcasing the rich biodiversity of Philippine marine life, and making an argument for the need to protect the environment.

 

When Probe Productions Inc transferred to ABS-CBN in 2003, the program discarded its travelogue persona and focused on producing monthly one-hour documentaries that examined political issues and pop culture. Some episodes include “Panahon Na” (It’s About Time), on the effects of climate change in the Philippines, “Sigalot” (Dispute), a look at the territorial dispute between China and the Philippines over Scarborough Shoal on the West Philippine Sea, “LGBT,” a documentary about the state of public acceptance of the gay, lesbian, bisexual, and transgender community in the country, and “Ang Tunay na Pag-Ibig ni Lolo Jose” (The Real Love of Grandfather Jose), a docu-drama about the women in the life of national hero Jose Rizal and the letters he wrote them. The program ended its run on 22 Jun 2014.

Cheche Lazaro Presents won the best program promoting culture and the arts in the KBP Golden Dove Award in 2001, the best TV Special in the 33rd Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2011, and the best documentary special of the year in the 26th PMPC Star Awards for Television in 2012. Written by Daphne-Tatiana T. Canlas

text:
CHINATOWN TV Began 2001, 10:00-11:00 am, Sundays, re-airs 11:30 pm to midnight, Wednesdays, IBC 13. Producer: Lolita See Ching. Director and writer: Lani Esteban. Hosts: Lizbeth Yap, Morgan Say, Wesley Chua, Frances Cham, Paul Cham. Co-hosts: Carolyn Batay, Louella Ching, Joseph Tullao, Roxanne de Castro, Wendyline Ty, Cindy Chan, Richard Valentin, Max Tiu.

Chinatown TV is a one-hour educational and lifestyle magazine television show which showcases Filipino, Chinese, and Chinese-Filipino cultures. It is the longest-running Chinese-Filipino magazine show. It first aired in 2001 as Fil-Chi TV and assumed its current title in 2012. The program presents various topics such as food, restaurants, trendy places in Metro Manila, vacation spots, fashion, health and fitness, tourism, community news, technology, livelihood tips, cultural traditions, religion, and upcoming events of the Chinese-Filipino community.

Chinese languages such as Mandarin, Fukien, and Cantonese are taught in the segment “Ni Hao” (Hello) of Fil-Chi TV. In the reformatted Chinatown TV, the hosts, usually on location, speak their lines in English, Filipino, and other Chinese languages. In one segment, a host speaks a word, which is translated into Mandarin by another host. The segment “Straight from the Boss” features successful Chinese-Filipinos, like Fersal Hotel Group President and Chief Executive Officer Elizabeth Fernando, and singer and songwriter Rachel Alejandro. The program also features Chinese festivals such as the Lunar New Year, Spring Festival, and Lantern Decoration Day, and Filipino Catholic festivals such as the Salubong (Easter Vigil) and Flores de Mayo (May Flowers for the Virgin).

Chinatown TV received an Anak TV Seal award in 2013. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo

Hosts: Lizbeth Yap, Morgan Say, Wesley Chua, Frances Cham, Paul Cham. Co-hosts: Carolyn Batay, Louella Ching, Joseph Tullao, Roxanne de Castro, Wendyline Ty, Cindy Chan, Richard Valentin, Max Tiu.

Chinatown TV is a one-hour educational and lifestyle magazine television show which showcases Filipino, Chinese, and Chinese-Filipino cultures. It is the longest-running Chinese-Filipino magazine show. It first aired in 2001 as Fil-Chi TV and assumed its current title in 2012. The program presents various topics such as food, restaurants, trendy places in Metro Manila, vacation spots, fashion, health and fitness, tourism, community news, technology, livelihood tips, cultural traditions, religion, and upcoming events of the Chinese-Filipino community.

In one segment, a host speaks a word, which is translated into Mandarin by another host. The segment “Straight from the Boss” features successful Chinese-Filipinos, like Fersal Hotel Group President and Chief Executive Officer Elizabeth Fernando, and singer and songwriter Rachel Alejandro. The program also features Chinese festivals such as the Lunar New Year, Spring Festival, and Lantern Decoration Day, and Filipino Catholic festivals such as the Salubong (Easter Vigil) and Flores de Mayo (May Flowers for the Virgin).

text:
COMPAÑERO Y COMPAÑERA(Fellow Lawyers) June 1994, DZMM; 1997, ABS-CBN; 1998, GMA; 2000-01, RPN 9.

This public service program emerged from the DZMM daily talk show Relos Reports hosted by Gel Santos Relos, which had the late Senator and lawyer Renato Cayetano as guest in June 1994. Their discussion of legal perspectives of current events led to a weekly segment of Relos Reports called “Compañero y Compañera.” Relos dubbed Cayetano “Compañero ng Bayan” (The Nation’s Lawyer), while he re-interpreted compañera as “partner” and used the term to address Relos even if she was not a lawyer. Soon “Compañero y Compañera” became a regular daily segment of Relos Reports.

At first, the program discussed on DZMM the laws of the Philippines and their applicability to real-life situations, and the rights and obligations of citizens. It also dispensed free legal advice. It later included a drama portion and subsequently moved to television. The program title is derived from the Filipino usage of the Spanish words compañero and compañera (in Spanish, literally, “companion”), used by lawyers to address each other.

The segment’s format was simple. Listeners called and Relos interviewed them about their problems. Cayetano then joined the interview to clarify the situation from a legal perspective, and then gave legal opinion with the help of other lawyers from Ponce Enrile, Cayetano, Bautista, Reyes Law Firm (PECABAR). In addition to on-air legal advice, the lawyers replied free of charge to listeners who wrote to seek legal counsel.

In 1995, Compañero y Compañera, The Drama began airing from Monday to Friday during the last half hour of Relos Reports. Relos produced, directed, and narrated dramatized stories of letter writers, followed by discussions by Relos and Cayetano and his legal advice. In 1997, Compañero y Compañera was launched on Channel 2 with Arlene de Castro as production supervisor and Oscar Yema as executive producer.Its format followed that of the radio program, with dramatized problem situations of letter writers, discussion, and legal advice. Guests joined Relos and Cayetano in answering questions from a live studio audience, letter writers, and email senders. The legal issues most often discussed involved family, criminal, and civil law.

When Cayetano ran for the Senate in 1998, the program was discontinued in compliance with the ABS-CBN rule banning on-air program hosts and personalities who run for public office.After winning a Senate seat, Cayetano returned to the air, this time on GMA 7, with the same program and the same title that was trademarked in his name. Singer-actress-news anchor Ali Sotto co-hosted the program, replaced by Angelique Lazo the following year. In 2000, the show transferred to RPN 9 where Cayetano hosted the program with actress Nanette Medved until 2001.

Compañero y Compañera, The Drama won the KBP Golden Dove Awards for Best Radio Drama in 1995 and 1997. Written by Maria Angelina S. Relos

text:
CONCERT AT THE PARK6 Apr 1978 to 2012, Channel 4 with simultaneous broadcast on DZRB Radyo ng Bayan 738 KHz; 1978–2000: 6:00-7:00 pm, Sundays; Jan–Aug 2001 and 2010–12: 7:30-8:30 pm, Mondays; Sep 2001–Jun 2002: 11:00 pm, Fridays; Jul 2002–Dec 2004: 6:00-7:00 pm, Thursdays. Producer: Ed Finlan, National Media Production Center. Co-producer: National Parks Development Committee, Department of Tourism. Executive in charge of production: Federico Edos. TV director: Morris Paredes. Musical director: Lino Mangandi. Scriptwriter: Gie Arnold. Hosts: Tina Monzon-Palma, 1978-99; Susan Mercado, 1999-2005; Susan Fernandez-Magno, 2009-12.

Concert at the Park was a musical program that showcased cultural and historical presentations by budding and professional musicians live from Rizal Park in Manila and simultaneously aired on the official government station. Beginning in 2010, the program was broadcast in the United States Bay Area, Canada, and Russia through PTV-4’s international network until its final airing in 2012. The “Concert at the Park” event in Rizal Park , however, is still ongoing. The program’s title was coined by the show’s director Ed Finlan.

Concert at the Park provided its audience the regular public concerts held in Luneta to help in promoting appreciation and support for Filipino culture through music and dance. It mainly featured the classics, but also had performances of popular bands and recording artists.

It was initially conceived to be held at the Philamlife Auditorium on United Nations Avenue in Manila on a Sunday morning to be patterned after the successful Boston Pop Orchestra concert series. It would have featured the Manila Symphony Orchestra under the baton of Professor Regalado Jose and the mezzo-soprano performer Conchita Gaston. The initial plan was shelved because of financial matters. With Gaston diagnosed with cancer, she, together with Jose and Fred Mendoza, sought the support of then National Parks Development Committee vice-chair Teodoro “Ka Doroy” Valencia, who gave his approval and allowed the use of Rizal Park’s Open Auditorium. It was first video recorded by the National Media Production Center (NMPC).

During the program’s 10th anniversary on 6 Apr 1988, the Pop Philharmonic Orchestra, with Dulce and Rico J. Puno as soloists, featured George Canseco’s “Hanggang sa Dulo ng Walang Hanggan” (At the End of Eternity) and “Saan Darating ang Umaga” (Where Will Morning Come). The month-long 22nd anniversary celebration in 2000 included the performances of the Manila Philharmonic Orchestra under the baton of Rodel Colmenar, with Nolyn Cabahug and soprano Lisa Cabahug as soloists, on 2 Apr 2000; the Philippine folk dance group Bayanihan, which performed “Isang Panimula” (One Beginning) on 9 Apr 2000; the UP Jazz Band under Professor Rayben Maigue on 16 Apr 2000; and the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Dance Troupe and the Smokey Mountain Children in “Sayaw ng Kalikasan” (Nature’s Dance) on 23 Apr 2000, with Obusan as director-choreographer.

Concert at the Park was awarded the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) Hall of Fame Award for Best Cultural Program in 1990. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo

"In Focus..." 2005; Japitana 2011

text:
THE CONCERT HALL1959, DZFE; 1970s-2003, 98.7 FM. Producer-Hosts: Maria Catherine Luistro, Dan Andrew, Aileen Cura.

This radio program played records of opera, operetta, oratorio, and Filipino classical music. It aired for over four decades with varying program titles. Its first title was Morning Concert Hall, aired for an hour on weekdays, then Concert Hall when DZFE moved to the FM band, for two hours every morning hosted by Fidel Ramirez. In 1974 its airtime increased to three hours, and then in the 1980s it was conflated with the program Evening Concert which had a similar format, and moved to the evening slot, taking the title The Concert Hall. Aileen Cura, one of the program’s producer-hosts, changed the program’s format by featuring the station’s recordings of live classical concerts held in Metro Manila by Filipino and foreign artists. The program was discontinued in 2003 when DZFE reduced programming hours. In 2006, the station recovered and began airing several programs on different fields of classical music, making The Concert Hall superfluous.

The Concert Hall won the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Award for Best Program Promoting Culture and the Arts in 1997 and 1998. In 2002, the program received the KBP Golden Dove Award for Best Variety Show. Written by Maricel L. Baltazar

98.7 DZFE website.

text:
THE CORRESPONDENTS16 Nov 1998 to 22 Oct 2010, 11:30 pm Tuesdays-12:30 am Wednesdays, ABS-CBN 2. Executive producer: Romel Bernardo. Producer: Wins Aguilar. Directors: JV Noriega, Nico Hernandez. Main hosts: Karen Davila, Ces Oreña-Drilon, Abner Mercado, Bernadette Sembrano. Other hosts: Dominic Almelor, Sol Aragones, Atom Araullo, Adrian Ayalin, Jeff Canoy, Ricky Carandang, Jorge Cariño, Jing Castañeda, Dyan Castillejo, Niña Corpuz, Rose Eclarinal, Mari Kaimo, Jim Libiran, Jade Lopez, Gretchen Malalad, Henry Omaga-Diaz, Patrick Paez, Alex Santos, Anne Torres, Nadia Trinidad, Tony Velasquez, Ron Cruz, Anthony Taberna.

A weekly current affairs-documentary show hosted by senior and junior reporters of ABS-CBN, it mainly features sociopolitical and cultural issues elaborated from the general network news content. The show’s format has the broadcast journalist serving as anchor conversing with correspondents on their experiences in the field.

Some of its notable episodes are the coverage of the US invasion of Iraq in 2003, Mercado’s trip to Mount Everest, a report about a child afflicted with a life-threatening live disease called bilary artesia, a feature about the sea cucumber divers of Sibale Island in Romblon, a documentary on the bells of Balangiga, a piece on the Filipino seafarers in Rotterdam, and a report on the street football players of Tondo. The show gained prominence for episodes that featured the communist revolutionary movement: “Propaganda War,” an episode on the release of prisoners of war by the New People’s Army, “Kasama” (Comrade), Lingao’s report about the armed revolutionaries, and “Isnayp” (Snipe), about the rebel movement’s own guerilla filmmaking.

The Correspondents aired a timely piece on the burgeoning call center industry in 2006, which received strong criticism from one supervisor concerning the unfairness of its reporting on the quality of work and qualification of employees. The program was also criticized by one known blogger for having its reporter cook and eat pagpag or recycled food waste, an unnecessary and sensational reporting on the poor’s depraved conditions.

The program won the PMPC Star Awards for best documentary program in 2003, 2004, and 2006; the Catholic Mass Media Awards for best magazine program in 2007; the KBP Golden Dove Award for best documentary program award for the episode “Mahirap Matuto” (Hard to Learn) in 2009; and the Population Development Media Awards for best TV documentary for Mercado’s team in 2009. Mercado’s episode, “Mt. Cook Chronicles: The Road to Everest,” won the Special Jury Prize at the Moscow International Festival of Mountaineering and Adventure Films in 2005. Davila’s “Batang Preso” (Child Prisoner) won the UNICEF Child Rights Award in 2005 and “Palobo Boys” (Rugby Boys) won the World Silver Medal in the New York Festivals in 2007. Written by JPaul S. Manzanilla

Sources:

“Call Center..." 2014; "The Correspondents..." 2008; Cruz 2008; "Futkal!" 2010; "PSAP and the Making of..." 2005.

text:
CRYSTAL ARCADE1930s, KZIB.

This radio musical program started during the American colonial period. It was named after the building where its studio was located, which was famous for its art deco architecture designed by Andres Luna de San Pedro. The building was also the site of Beck’s Department Store owned by American Isaac Beck, whose initials form the last two call letters of the station.

 

The US-based Columbia Phonograph Company, to which KZIB was affiliated, supplied the music aired on Crystal Arcade, mostly American jazz and blues such as those of Louis Armstrong and Clarence Williams. However, the program also featured Filipino artists like Lina Flor, Carmen Rosales, Ely Ramos, and Ira Davis, who performed live both American popular music and Filipino folk songs, making it the first program during the American period to air local music. Written by Lucia Isabel G. Macaventa

Berg 2013; Enriquez 2008; Gopal 2015; Pacudan 2014; Peterson 2010.

text:
(Dear Sam … Yours, Juan) 1990, ABS-CBN. Producer: Ateneo Center for Social Policy and Public Affairs in cooperation with the Foundation for Media Alternatives. Executive producer: Al Alegre. Writer: Rosalie Matilac. Script adviser: Ricky Lee. Director: Joel C. Lamangan. Assistant director: Nini Matilac. Clay animation: Alcazaren Brothers Production.

 

This 55-minute documentary was aired one year before the renegotiation of the 1947 Military Bases Agreement with the US which was about to lapse by Sep 1991. The mainstream media landscape at the time was dominated by pro-US military bases sentiment and information. The TV special presented the other side of the picture.

 

The documentary has no narrator, and segments are connected by nationalistic songs and poems by artists like Bodgie Pascua, Joonee Gamboa, Patatag, Pol Galang, Lokal Brown, and Gary Granada. Historian Ambeth Ocampo and Huk leaders Jose and Jesus Lava trace why the US enjoys extraterritorial rights in Clark air base and Subic naval base, identifying US control of Philippine politics since the 1898 Mock Battle of Manila Bay. An Aeta from Pampanga recounts how they lived abundantly in precolonial times but lost vast tracts of their ancestral domain when American soldiers “borrowed” a piece of land to build a horse stable. Then, as Americans gave goodies, like chocolates, to the Aeta, they expanded the horse stable into an air strip later known as Clark air base. A popular senator and action star, Joseph Estrada, declares his position to end the US Military Bases Agreement, convinced that the US treated the Philippines unfairly especially after World War II. National Artist Francisco Arcellana, who taught in Clark and Subic, also recounted experiences of discrimination inside the bases. Film actor Julio Diaz believes that US bases only resulted in the prostitution of women.

 

The documentary demolishes the argument that the Philippines benefits in terms of regional security and defense. It exposes the dangerous missiles and nuclear weapons inside the bases that serve to attract nuclear retaliation by enemies of the US. The ongoing military exercises inside the bases also affect the local population, such as the reported impairment of ear drums of Aeta children and the proliferation of military wastes in Subic waters.

 

While there are about 70,000 Filipinos dependent on the US bases—including thousands of sex workers and their children—there are positive alternatives when the US bases are terminated. Sen Wigberto Tañada, constitutional convention commissioners Chito Gascon and Ed Garcia, Angeles businessmen, the city mayor, and an economic planner describe scenarios after the end of the US bases agreement. Clark could be an international airport, while Subic could be a thriving facility for ship building. There are studies that food and manufacturing industries can thrive in Pampanga, while orchards can grow in Subic.

For its resolute anti-US bases stance, the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board under Manuel Morato banned the TV special. The prohibition raised multi-sectoral protests. The issue became the subject of a senate investigation which ruled in favor of airing the TV special. In 1991, the documentary won the Gawad CCP Best TV Special of the Year. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III, with notes from Rosalie S. Matilac

text:
1999-2005, 10:00-11:00 am, Sundays, GMA 7. Producers: LG Electronics Corporation and ALTA Productions. Executive Producers: Lenny C. Parto, Joel Jimenez. Hosts: Paolo Bediones, Regine Tolentino, later replaced by Bernadette Allison then by Pia Guanio.

Digital LG Quiz was a weekly quiz show for sophomore and junior high school students. One season of the program comprised nine months that ran from October to July. It gathered on TV a community of outstanding students and promoted friendly competition among schools in the country. The program was part of the brand identity campaign of LG Electronics, a South Korean company, to market its emerging digital consumer products through activities such as the LG Soccer Cup Games and the TV show LG Scholarship Quiz that was broadcast in Vietnam, Thailand, Kazakhstan, and Indonesia in 1999.

Four students compete through five rounds of competition per episode. The contestant who garners the highest point wins. The first round is “Password,” in which each contestant is given one minute to guess a word. The hosts give five clues, each flashed on LG screens. Correctly guessing the word at the first clue garners huge points for the student, each point lower by a few notches for each subsequent clue. The second round is “Picture Puzzle,” in which the contestants guess the picture hidden beneath nine jigsaw puzzle pieces. The student who buzzes first and answers correctly the question posed by the host gains points and gets to remove one piece of the puzzle. The first to guess correctly the hidden picture gains additional points. The third round is the 10-minute “Think Tac Toe,” a modified tic-tac-toe, in which the students race to form a horizontal, vertical or diagonal line by answering correct answers to questions chosen from “flying saucers” on a 3x3 grid. The fourth round is “Blockbuster,” in which the hosts ask questions based on footage of movies shown on LG digital TVs. The final round is “Megabytes,” in which each student is given chips, each with an assigned subject such as Mathematics, Science, and General Knowledge. A student earns or loses points depending on the value of wagered chips.

Weekly winners compete in the monthly competition. Three monthly champions and the second placer with the highest points earned in the three monthly competitions comprise the quarterfinalists, the winner of which moves on to the grand finals. The weekly winner and monthly winners win cash prizes. A quarterfinal winner receives a scholarship worth 96,000 pesos and a grand champion wins a scholarship worth 1.2 million pesos. The winners’ schools from the weekly competitions to the finals each receives an LG television set.

Grand champions included Armando Tuibeo Jr from Muntinlupa National High School in 1999, Brian Lagazon from Olongapo City’s Regional Science High School in 2000, Andrew John Lena from Manila Science High School in 2001, Laurence Lloyd Parial from the San Isidro campus of Nueva Ecija University of Science and Technology in 2002, Michael Dominique Mendoza from Philippine Science High School in 2003, and Joseph Sy from La Salle Greenhills in 2004.

In 2003, the program was reformatted and renamed Digital LG Challenge. The program received the PMPC Star Awards for the best game show and its hosts Bediones and Tolentino the best game show hosts in 2001. It also received the Anak TV Seal from the South East Asian Foundation for Children and Television in 2001, 2002, and 2003. Written by Jason Paolo R. Telles

June 2007, Mondays to Fridays, 8:30-9:00 am, and Saturdays, 7:30-8:30 am, DWWW 774. Host: Dr Jaime Galvez Tan (Doc Jimmy). Co-host: Nathalie David. Production staff: Nina Manzares and Bheo Barrera.

Doctor’s Orders is a health program hosted by former secretary of the Department of Health (DOH) Dr Jaime Galvez Tan, Doc Jimmy to his listeners, who is a well-known advocate of alternative, herbal, and Filipino healing practices such as hilot, a traditional healing massage. The program was the brainchild of Dr Girlie Bacsal, the wife of then DWWW station manager Bert Bacsal. A neurologist and then president of the Brain Society of the Philippines, Dr Bacsal proposed the show to her husband upon hearing Dr Galvez Tan speak at her organization’s conference. The program started as a 15-minute segment within the show of program host Lilibeth Nacion. Soon the program became a separate 30-minute show, which quickly expanded into one hour.

With free prescriptions, dubbed resetang walang gastos, dispensed by Doc Jimmy to listeners who call or text about their health concerns, the show has the largest audience share in its time slot. Due to the growing listenership of wellness and health programs, many shows similar to Doctor’s Orders are popular on both radio and television. However, Galvez Tan’s approach to wellness, such as using available natural remedies to illnesses, makes the program distinct from other health shows that favor Western methods of medicine. His emphasis is on community medicine, which is based on diet, food as medicine, and herbal medicine; holistic healing, which treats the body, mind, and spirit as one, for which he prescribes yoga, meditation, forgiveness therapy, and laughter and happiness therapy; and other alternative healing practices such as acupuncture and hilot.

Doctor’s Orders features guest doctors from different medical fields, with whom Galvez Tan discusses various health concerns, including obesity, diabetes, arthritis, cancer, hypertension, kidney problems, stress, and reproductive health. Written byElizabeth L. Enriquez

Premiered 2004, 1:30-2:30 pm, weekdays, DZAS Agapay ng Sambayanan (The Nation’s Help) simulcast on DXKI 1062 KHz on the FM band, and online through live streaming at febc.org.ph. Producer: Far Eastern Broadcasting Company (FEBC). Hosts: Carmen Go-Vargas and Haydee Bernardo-Sampang. Production staff: Janine Peras, Banelle Canlas, Precious Gorospe, and Engr Rex Capuno.

The radio program integrates physical and mental health with spirituality. The program’s main segment, “Health Forum,” guests doctors and medical experts who dispense health advice on air for free to listeners who send questions by text, post messages on the program’s Facebook page, or call from as far as the United States. Each episode is devoted to a health issue, which may be as serious as cancer or as mild as vitamin deficiencies. Another segment, “Glossario Medico” (Medical Glossary), explains in layman’s language health terms related to the topic, causes of a particular disease, and possible remedies; while the segment “Doctors’ Billboard” informs listeners of free public health services provided by organizations and hospitals.

The other segments of the program are “Health Watch,” a news report relevant to health issues; “Health Today,” which discusses the latest researches on health; “Health Tips,” or advice on health symptoms to watch out for; “Health Meditation,” a reading of Bible verses; and “Prayer Time.”

Doctors on Line received the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Award for best public affairs program, 2005, and for best science and technology program, 2008. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo

text:
1 Mar 1995-97; Apr 2000, 11:30 pm-12:30 am, Wednesdays; 28 Aug 2003 to 23 Jun 2005, 11:30 pm-12:30 am, Thursdays, ABS-CBN. Executive Producer: Rome Roque. Associate Producer: Jerome Araullo. Director: Zaldy Bolaños. Writer-Researcher: Ronald Agustin. Reporters: Danny Buenafe, later replaced by Doris Bigornia. Host: Atty Ricardo “Dong” Puno Jr

Dong Puno Live is a late-night television current affairs debate show. ABS-CBN General Manager Freddie Garcia patterned the program after the tabloid-style, revenue-raking news programs of the network, such as TV Patrol, Hoy Gising! (Hey, Wake Up!), and Magandang Gabi, Bayan (Good Evening, Nation). Host Puno analyzed the week’s hot issues by interviewing public officials and celebrities, who were either in the studio or on-location, the signals of which are fed live to the program via video satellite or phone patch.

An episode begins with the introduction of guests, followed by a reporter’s short coverage of the issue up for discussion, then the host’s discussion with the guests. During the debate, the screen is divided into three panels, two of which are for each of the guests, while the third at the center is for the host. One of the two panels for guests is switched to an on-location guest, if there is any. In some cases, both panels for guests are shown on the screen, maintaining the center panel for the host.

With the intensified infrastructure and systems upgrade of ABS-CBN, Dong Puno Live is able to do multi-point simultaneous broadcasts from various parts of the country, making it one of the first interactive programs on Philippine television. Its pilot episode, for instance, which was about the MV Gretchen sea mishap, brought in various live video coverage interviews with the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) headquarters in two areas in Manila and a phone patch interview in Cadiz City, Negros Occidental in the Visayas. The program made use of a similar technical format for its other episodes with guests from Cebu in the Visayas, and Davao, Cagayan de Oro, and Zamboanga in Mindanao. Live phone-patched questions, usually from four to five televiewers, also come from different regions of the country.

Some notable episodes are those featuring political rivals, particularly during the elections of 1995 and 1998. Examples include the debate between Alfredo Lim and Mel Lopez, Joey Marquez and Pablo Olivares, Rey Malonzo and Macario Asistio, and Eduardo Joson and Honorato Perez. Other prominent episodes include the alleged abduction by the military of students from the University of the Philippines Diliman and interviews with actors Ruffa Gutierrez and Rosanna Roces on controversial showbiz issues.

The program was able to bring in an average of five to eight minutes of commercial break, a feat for a late-night current affairs show during that time.

Dong Puno Live, after going off the air for two years, was reformatted to Dong Puno Tonight, which began its broadcast in 2003. When Puno moved to TV5 in 2011, his new talk program, Dong Puno De Kalibre (Dong Puno, Of High Quality), followed the format of its precursor.

Dong Puno Live was one of the ten best television programs cited in the 9th and 10th Gawad Cultural Center of the Philippines para sa Telebisyon in 1996 and 1997. Puno’s hosting of the program garnered for him the award for best male host of a magazine show in the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas in 1999. WrittenGian Carlo C. Librojo, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
(Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!) Premiered 1979. Executive Producer: Antonio P. Tuviera and Malou Choa-Fagar. 1979-89, RPN 9; 1989-94, ABS-CBN; since 1994, GMA. Hosts: Tito Sotto, Vic Sotto, Joey de Leon, Allan K, Ryan Agoncillo, Paolo Ballesteros, Wally Bayola, Julia Clarete, Keempee de Leon, Ryzza Mae Dizon, Toni Rose Gayda, Pia Guanio, Pauleen Luna, Jose Manalo, Michael V., Marian Rivera, Ruby Rodriguez, Jimmy Santos. Selected former co-hosts: Iza Calzado, Isabelle Daza, Rio Diaz, Pops Fernandez, BJ Forbes, Toni Gonzaga, Gladys Guevarra, Chiqui Hollman, Richie D’ Horsey, Christine Jacob, Francis Magalona, Teri Onor, Coney Reyes, Aiza Seguerra, Daiana Menezes, Nova Villa.

Eat Bulaga! (EB) is to date the longest-running program in the history of Philippine television. The TVJ triumvirate of brothers Tito and Vic Sotto and friend Joey de Leon began in 1979 on the weekly dance variety program Discorama and later the daily noontime show Student Canteen, both produced by Program Philippines and broadcast on GMA. They initially refused producer Tony Tuviera’s offer to host their own lunchtime program, in deference to competitor Bobby Ledesma who provided them employment through Discorama, but eventually accepted the offer after Ledesma fired them from the show because he believed that they were being congenial to his rival’s moves.

The show’s title is de Leon’s invention, a pun on the children’s game “it bulaga” (peek-a-boo), with “eat” referring to what people do at lunchtime and “bulaga” indicating that the show would be full of surprises. EB initially had problems of low revenues because commercial advertisers went to their rival program. Some of their co-hosts resigned, frustrated with not receiving their pay on time. TVJ were able to survive owing to their other jobs. The switch to domestic satellite (domsat) broadcast that provided nationwide live coverage of a program, beginning on 18 May 1982, coupled by the co-hosting launch of pretty and popular Coney Reyes, who was also ousted from Student Canteen, paved the way for the show’s dominance of its time slot. Prior to domsat, TV shows were only viewed in the provinces days after actual telecast; with it, advertisers gradually flocked to EB, assuring it of sustainability. Certain sectors called the attention of the network not to “overdo commercialism” to protect the integrity of the television industry.

EB crafted pioneering segments, the first of which was “Bulagaan,” which began in 1975. The hosts are in a classroom setup where they act as students who make puns on their supposedly knowledgeable answers to the teacher’s quiz. The segment popularized so-called “knock-knock” jokes.

Beauty and talent search segments for men, ladies, boys, children, gay men, and foreigners are a common offering of the program. One season annually, biennially or when deemed commercially viable by producers is devoted to any of these segments, many of which continue to this day. In 1980, it initiated the contest “Mr. Macho” for the promotion of the film You Can’t Stop the Music starring the Village People. This was the first time that the program won the ratings game against Student Canteen, gaining 31% against the latter’s 29%. “Little Miss Philippines,” undeniably the most popular segment that was launched in 1984, jumpstarted the media career of Aiza Seguerra, a runner-up winner in 1987 who dazzled millions of viewers with her wit and crazy antics, such as the “duck walk” and “acheche” (an expression of surprise or incredulity rendered in a funny way), and Ryzza Mae Dizon, the title holder in 2012 who amuses audiences with her mature takes on various topics. Some runners-up or daily winners made it big in show business, such as Donna Cruz, Geneva Cruz, Pauleen Luna, Angelica Panganiban, Camille Pratts, Francine Prieto, Gladys Reyes, and Jessa Zaragosa. A pageant for young men which began in 1996, “Mr. Pogi” (Mr. Handsome), was seized upon by many who wanted to enter show business, like Jericho Rosales who won in 1996 and became one of the country’s admired actors and who also became popular in Southeast Asia and Africa. It also opened doors for the showbiz careers of Danilo Barrios, 1998 winner, who became a member of a popular dance group, and Edgar Allan Guzman, 2006 winner, who established his career as an actor in indie movies. “That’s My Boy” for young boys, which began in 1991, introduced child actor Atong Redillas and BJ Forbes, while “She’s Got the Look” for ladies, 1991-95, discovered actor Rosanna Roces who initially won its daily round but lost the weekly finals. The segment “TeeVee Babe,” 1999-2002, which paraded contestants in swimsuits and evening wear, produced 2001 runner-up winner Precious Lara Quigaman, who was crowned Miss International in 2005.

Gay men had their share of fame in the comically packaged “Super Sireyna” (Super Mermaid), which began in 1995, and in its lampoon version “Suffer Sireyna” (Suffering Mermaid), 2014. “Maid in the Philippines,” the first and so far the only beauty contest for domestic helpers, was featured in 2009. Beginning in 2014, foreigners who have come to stay in the Philippines and adapted to Philippine culture in different ways have participated in “You’re my Foreignoy,” and “You’re my Foreignay,” a portmanteau of foreigner and “Pinoy” and “Pinay,” the informal term for Filipino.

Popular segments also include those that offer cash and material prizes to their avid viewers. In the 1980s, “Send in Your Dreams” encouraged viewers to write letters detailing their special requests which the show selected and granted on-air. This preceded GMA’s wish-granting TV program Wish Ko Lang. “Lottong Bahay” (Home-made or “Syndicated” Lottery), started in 1995, turned out to be the most popular variety show game: the program had to hold its grand finals at the Quezon City Memorial Circle to accommodate millions of entries. “Meron o Wala” (All or Nothing), 1999-2000, and “Laban o Bawi” (Wager or Take Back), beginning in 2000, offered top contestants risks of betting for the chance of a bigger prize in exchange for a tidy sum already won. These segments upped the ante of surprise and hope to studio viewers and fellow contestants.

For many years now, the guessing game “Pinoy Henyo” (Filipino Genius), which started in 2004, has tested the analytical and encyclopedic knowledge of contestants and has since offered prizes to different categories of players, from representatives of grade and high schools and universities to officemates, family members, media personalities, and foreigners. “Pinoy Henyo” has become an essential game in parties and made variations in the composition of teams by having elderly-child and boyfriend-girlfriend tandems, and even a barkada (team) setup.

Perhaps the most innovative of all programs crafted in Philippine broadcast media, “Juan for All, All for Juan” has literally entered the homes of Filipinos from all walks of life. Each day the EB team visits a barangay (community) for its project of collecting recyclable garbage, which it uses to build chairs for public schools nationwide. Residents bring the requested items in addition to plastics for a chance to win bigger prizes. One resident drawn from a raffle is interviewed by hosts Manalo, Ballesteros, and Bayola inside the winner’s house. The segment becomes hilarious as the trio and the studio hosts subject the winner to a lot of questions and respond to the unexpected extraordinary situations of the people and places they visit. Sometimes it showcases Manalo playing the role of the spirits of the dead loved ones of the winner-interviewees, Bayola eating whatever food is available, and Ballesteros making naughty faces and gestures, and all three lampooning the people involved in the segment, including behind-the-scene staff. Some of their most memorable episodes show the following: the main door of the winning contestant’s house opening into a family’s toilet, a mother interviewed on a crackling dilapidated roof, an abode under a bridge housing a family of stragglers, a diligent couple raising a family inside a public utility bus transformed into an accommodation that rivals hotel rooms, a seemingly unhinged person rebutting questions with crackling humor as he finishes the keychain which he then offers to the show’s hosts in the studio, and a winning contestant interviewed in a seemingly drunken state as he awakens from sleep. Viewers-turned-winning contestants become gracious hosts who intimate their financial and familial problems to the public, many times bringing their audience to tears and often highlighting dignity in the midst of squalor. It has become the show’s bread and butter as almost all the commercial advertisers funnel their sponsorships into the segment. More importantly, the segment broke the barriers of televisual space, with contestants in the barangay given extensive air time and becoming stars themselves as they interact with the hosts and even the audience in the studio. This segment spawned the highly phenomenal AlDub, the split-screen love team of young star Alden Richards and Dubsmash sensation Maine Mendoza aka Yaya Dub, which culminated in the show’s 36th anniversary presentation titled “Sa Tamang Panahon” (At the Right Time), on 24 Oct 2015 at the Philippine Arena, with a record-breaking live audience of 55,000, with the highest number of tickets sold in less than three days, tweets reaching 41 million in 24 hours, much higher than the tweets of the 2014 World Cup semi-final match between Brazil and Germany, and its rival It’s Showtime, ABS-CBN, admitting its defeat in the ratings game.

Many personalities trace their beginnings to Eat Bulaga!, like Richie d’Horsey, Lani Mercado, Plinky Recto, Ces Quesada, Christine Jacob, Alice Dixson, Cindy Kurleto, Kristine Florendo, Lalaine Edson, Lana Asanin, Leila Kuzma, Mickey Ferriols, Nadine Schmidt, Sherilyn Reyes, Tania Paulsen, Illac Diaz, and ABS-CBN hosts Toni Gonzaga and Iza Calzado. Rapper Francis Magalona devoted his last productive years with the dabarkads (from the word barkada, meaning, a group of friends), a term the hosts use to refer to their wacky group.

Eat Bulaga! (EB) is to date the longest-running program in the history of Philippine television. The TVJ triumvirate of brothers Tito and Vic Sotto and friend Joey de Leon began in 1979 on the weekly dance variety program Discorama and later the daily noontime show Student Canteen, both produced by Program Philippines and broadcast on GMA. They initially refused producer Tony Tuviera’s offer to host their own lunchtime program, in deference to competitor Bobby Ledesma who provided them employment through Discorama, but eventually accepted the offer after Ledesma fired them from the show because he believed that they were being congenial to his rival’s moves.

article.value: The show’s title is de Leon’s invention, a pun on the children’s game “it bulaga” (peek-a-boo), with “eat” referring to what people do at lunchtime and “bulaga” indicating that the show would be full of surprises. EB initially had problems of low revenues because commercial advertisers went to their rival program. Some of their co-hosts resigned, frustrated with not receiving their pay on time. TVJ were able to survive owing to their other jobs. The switch to domestic satellite (domsat) broadcast that provided nationwide live coverage of a program, beginning on 18 May 1982, coupled by the co-hosting launch of pretty and popular Coney Reyes, who was also ousted from Student Canteen, paved the way for the show’s dominance of its time slot. Prior to domsat, TV shows were only viewed in the provinces days after actual telecast; with it, advertisers gradually flocked to EB, assuring it of sustainability. Certain sectors called the attention of the network not to “overdo commercialism” to protect the integrity of the television industry.

EB crafted pioneering segments, the first of which was “Bulagaan,” which began in 1975. The hosts are in a classroom setup where they act as students who make puns on their supposedly knowledgeable answers to the teacher’s quiz. The segment popularized so-called “knock-knock” jokes.

Beauty and talent search segments for men, ladies, boys, children, gay men, and foreigners are a common offering of the program. One season annually, biennially or when deemed commercially viable by producers is devoted to any of these segments, many of which continue to this day. In 1980, it initiated the contest “Mr. Macho” for the promotion of the film You Can’t Stop the Music starring the Village People. This was the first time that the program won the ratings game against Student Canteen, gaining 31% against the latter’s 29%. “Little Miss Philippines,” undeniably the most popular segment that was launched in 1984, jumpstarted the media career of Aiza Seguerra, a runner-up winner in 1987 who dazzled millions of viewers with her wit and crazy antics, such as the “duck walk” and “acheche” (an expression of surprise or incredulity rendered in a funny way), and Ryzza Mae Dizon, the title holder in 2012 who amuses audiences with her mature takes on various topics. Some runners-up or daily winners made it big in show business, such as Donna Cruz, Geneva Cruz, Pauleen Luna, Angelica Panganiban, Camille Pratts, Francine Prieto, Gladys Reyes, and Jessa Zaragosa. A pageant for young men which began in 1996, “Mr. Pogi” (Mr. Handsome), was seized upon by many who wanted to enter show business, like Jericho Rosales who won in 1996 and became one of the country’s admired actors and who also became popular in Southeast Asia and Africa. It also opened doors for the showbiz careers of Danilo Barrios, 1998 winner, who became a member of a popular dance group, and Edgar Allan Guzman, 2006 winner, who established his career as an actor in indie movies. “That’s My Boy” for young boys, which began in 1991, introduced child actor Atong Redillas and BJ Forbes, while “She’s Got the Look” for ladies, 1991-95, discovered actor Rosanna Roces who initially won its daily round but lost the weekly finals. The segment “TeeVee Babe,” 1999-2002, which paraded contestants in swimsuits and evening wear, produced 2001 runner-up winner Precious Lara Quigaman, who was crowned Miss International in 2005.

Gay men had their share of fame in the comically packaged “Super Sireyna” (Super Mermaid), which began in 1995, and in its lampoon version “Suffer Sireyna” (Suffering Mermaid), 2014. “Maid in the Philippines,” the first and so far the only beauty contest for domestic helpers, was featured in 2009. Beginning in 2014, foreigners who have come to stay in the Philippines and adapted to Philippine culture in different ways have participated in “You’re my Foreignoy,” and “You’re my Foreignay,” a portmanteau of foreigner and “Pinoy” and “Pinay,” the informal term for Filipino.

Popular segments also include those that offer cash and material prizes to their avid viewers. These segments upped the ante of surprise and hope to studio viewers and fellow contestants.

For many years now, the guessing game “Pinoy Henyo” (Filipino Genius), which started in 2004, has tested the analytical and encyclopedic knowledge of contestants and has since offered prizes to different categories of players, from representatives of grade and high schools and universities to officemates, family members, media personalities, and foreigners. “Pinoy Henyo” has become an essential game in parties and made variations in the composition of teams by having elderly-child and boyfriend-girlfriend tandems, and even a barkada (team) setup.

Perhaps the most innovative of all programs crafted in Philippine broadcast media, “Juan for All, All for Juan” has literally entered the homes of Filipinos from all walks of life. Each day the EB team visits a barangay (community) for its project of collecting recyclable garbage, which it uses to build chairs for public schools nationwide. Residents bring the requested items in addition to plastics for a chance to win bigger prizes. One resident drawn from a raffle is interviewed by hosts Manalo, Ballesteros, and Bayola inside the winner’s house. The segment becomes hilarious as the trio and the studio hosts subject the winner to a lot of questions and respond to the unexpected extraordinary situations of the people and places they visit. Sometimes it showcases Manalo playing the role of the spirits of the dead loved ones of the winner-interviewees, Bayola eating whatever food is available, and Ballesteros making naughty faces and gestures, and all three lampooning the people involved in the segment, including behind-the-scene staff. Some of their most memorable episodes show the following: the main door of the winning contestant’s house opening into a family’s toilet, a mother interviewed on a crackling dilapidated roof, an abode under a bridge housing a family of stragglers, a diligent couple raising a family inside a public utility bus transformed into an accommodation that rivals hotel rooms, a seemingly unhinged person rebutting questions with crackling humor as he finishes the keychain which he then offers to the show’s hosts in the studio, and a winning contestant interviewed in a seemingly drunken state as he awakens from sleep. text:
2 May to 9 Dec 2005, Evening primetime, Mondays to Fridays, GMA. Concept: Suzette Doctolero. Executive Producer: Redgynn Alba. Head Writer: Suzette Doctolero. Director: Mark Reyes. Assistant Director: Gil Tejada Jr. Production Designer: Rodell Cruz. Art Director: Eric Torralba. Costume Designer: Benny Batoctoy. Production Manager: Redgynn Alba. Technical Director: Ayee Hugo. Set Dresser: Daniel Fernandez. Music: Allan Feliciano. Main theme composer and singer: Bayang Barrios. Main Cast in 2005: Sunshine Dizon (Pirena), Iza Calzado (Amihan), Karylle (Alena), Diana Zubiri (Danaya), Dingdong Dantes (Ybarro/Ybrahim), Alfred Vargas (Aquil), Jennylyn Mercado (Lira/Milagros), Yasmien Kurdi (Mira), Mark Herras (Anthony), Pen Medina (Hagorn), Polo Ravales (Hitano), Cindy Kurleto (Cassiopeia), Bobby Andrews (Asval), Arthur Solinap (Muros), Dawn Zulueta (Mine-a), Richard Gomez (Raquim), Noel Urbano (voice of Imaw). Reboot cast in 2016: Glaiza de Castro (Pirena), Kylie Padilla (Amihan), Gabbi Garcia (Alena), Sanya Lopez (Danaya), John Arcilla (Hagorn), Sunshine Dizon (Adhara), Dingdong Dantes (Raquim), Marian Rivera (Ynang Reyna Minea), Rocco Nacino (Aquil), Ruru Madrid (Ybarro), Solenn Heussaff (Cassiopeia), Rochelle Pangilinan (Agane), Christian Bautista (Apitong), Pancho Magno (Hitano), Carlo Gonzales (Muros).

 

Encantadia is a daily fantasy-themed soap opera first produced and aired by GMA in 2005. It is said to be the most extravagant and expensive soap opera ever produced by GMA. Originally, Encantadia was only supposed to be a film entry for the 2004 Metro Manila Film Festival, but due to the high production cost of the show, the producers decided to turn it into a full-blown teleserye.

 

The term Encantadia is derived from the Filipino words “enkanto,” “enkantado,” “enkanta,” or “enkantada,” which refer to supernatural beings who possess powers. In the show, Encantadia is an immense realm comprised of four different kingdoms named Adamya, Sapiro, Hathoria, and Lireo. Each kingdom is protected by a gemstone that holds a distinct power of its own.

 

The birth of Encantadia can be traced to the story of the three bathalumans (or gods)—Emre, Arde, and Ether—who were banished from the heavens when they failed to participate in the first war. When they landed in a strange, barren place, they made it their own and named it Encantadia. The gods created different species of enchanted creatures (encantados) to inhabit the land: the diwata of Lireo, the sapiryan of Sapiro, the prairies or little creatures of Adamya, and the blacksmiths of Hathoria. At first, the relationship among the three bathala was civil, but when Arde and Ether fell in love—a violation of the rules of their exile—Emre cursed both of them and left Encantadia afterwards. He turned Ether into a giant snake as a reminder of her betrayal and Arde into a dragon whom he cast down to Balaak to guard the souls of the dead.

 

The peace of Encantadia relied on an all-powerful gemstone safeguarded by the first queen of Lireo, Cassiopeia. When greedy encantados wanted to steal it, Cassiopeia was forced to break the gem into four—the gems of earth, fire, air, and water—which she handed into the four kingdoms. Driven by greed, the Hathorian king Arvak claimed all the gems for himself, but Prince Raquim of Sapiro took the gems back and gave them to Lireo to be kept safely. The Queen of Lireo, Mine-a, then handed the gems over to her four royal-blood Diwata daughters (Sang’gres) to be their new protectors.

 

As Sang’gres, they have innate abilities that the ordinary diwata do not have, such as teleportation and invisibility. However, being born with the Gifts of Fire, Water, Air, and Earth, the sisters are able to tap the special superpowers possessed by the gems. Pirena, the eldest of the four and the proud and ferocious one, became the keeper of the gem of fire. She has the ability to produce and control fire. Amihan, the good-natured and motherly one, became keeper of the gem of air. The gem enables her to fly into air, control the wind’s movement, and create powerful blasts of it. Alena, the kind-hearted and compassionate one, became keeper of the gem of water. She can influence the movement of water and even summon a storm. Lastly, Danaya, the youngest of all, became keeper of the gem of earth. This enables her to manipulate nature in many ways, such as conjure earthquakes.

 

One of the show’s main themes is the effect that power can have on relationships. When Amihan became the queen after their mother, the jealous Pirena planned to defeat her own sister. Alena and Danaya sided with Amihan, making the case a fight of three against one. Pirena’s anger will drive her to exchange Lira, Amihan’s daughter with the heir of Sapiro, with her own daughter Mira and leave her in the world of the mortals. Lira will soon come back to Encantadia to accomplish her mission as a Sang’gre and resolve the conflict among the sisters.

 

The novel and engrossing narrative close to our folk stories, the intricate costumes and stage design, and the performance of a well-selected ensemble of actors have made Encantadia an instant fan favorite. With very high viewer ratings, it is said to be GMA Network’s most successful TV show. It has also won several awards such as the Best TV Series/Soap Opera in the Gawad America Awards, Student’s Choice of Drama Series in the USTv Student’s Choice Awards, Most Popular TV Program at the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation Box-Office Entertainment Awards, Most Favorite TV Show in K-Zone Magazine, and Best Original Music Score: Highly Commended in the Asian Television Awards, all in year 2005. In 2006, Encantadia became a finalist for the Best Lighting Category at the New York Festivals for Television Programming and Promotions.

 

Due to its success, Encantadia was followed by three more installments, namely Etheria, 2005-06, Encantadia: Pag-ibig Hanggang Wakas (Encantadia: Love to the End), 2006, and Encantadia, 2016. The latest installment is a retelling of the first series, but with a different set of actors and actresses, a few new roles, and some minor differences in the plot. Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya
