Each kingdom is protected by a gemstone that holds a distinct power of its own.

The birth of Encantadia can be traced to the story of the three bathalumans (or gods)—Emre, Arde, and Ether—who were banished from the heavens when they failed to participate in the first war. When they landed in a strange, barren place, they made it their own and named it Encantadia. The gods created different species of enchanted creatures (encantados) to inhabit the land: the diwata of Lireo, the sapiryan of Sapiro, the prairies or little creatures of Adamya, and the blacksmiths of Hathoria. At first, the relationship among the three bathala was civil, but when Arde and Ether fell in love—a violation of the rules of their exile—Emre cursed both of them and left Encantadia afterwards. He turned Ether into a giant snake as a reminder of her betrayal and Arde into a dragon whom he cast down to Balaak to guard the souls of the dead.

The peace of Encantadia relied on an all-powerful gemstone safeguarded by the first queen of Lireo, Cassiopeia. When greedy encantados wanted to steal it, Cassiopeia was forced to break the gem into four—the gems of earth, fire, air, and water—which she handed into the four kingdoms. Driven by greed, the Hathorian king Arvak claimed all the gems for himself, but Prince Raquim of Sapiro took the gems back and gave them to Lireo to be kept safely. The Queen of Lireo, Mine-a, then handed the gems over to her four royal-blood Diwata daughters (Sang’gres) to be their new protectors.

value.desc:
The Sang’gres of Encantadia, Diana Zubiri, left, Sunshine Dizon, Iza Calzado, and Karylle, 2006

(Photo courtesy of GMA Network)

The Sang’gres of the 2016 revival of Encantadia

(Photo courtesy of GMA Network)

article.value: As Sang’gres, they have innate abilities that the ordinary diwata do not have, such as teleportation and invisibility. However, being born with the Gifts of Fire, Water, Air, and Earth, the sisters are able to tap the special superpowers possessed by the gems. Pirena, the eldest of the four and the proud and ferocious one, became the keeper of the gem of fire. She has the ability to produce and control fire. Amihan, the good-natured and motherly one, became keeper of the gem of air. The gem enables her to fly into air, control the wind’s movement, and create powerful blasts of it. Alena, the kind-hearted and compassionate one, became keeper of the gem of water. She can influence the movement of water and even summon a storm. Lastly, Danaya, the youngest of all, became keeper of the gem of earth. This enables her to manipulate nature in many ways, such as conjure earthquakes.

One of the show’s main themes is the effect that power can have on relationships. When Amihan became the queen after their mother, the jealous Pirena planned to defeat her own sister. Alena and Danaya sided with Amihan, making the case a fight of three against one. Pirena’s anger will drive her to exchange Lira, Amihan’s daughter with the heir of Sapiro, with her own daughter Mira and leave her in the world of the mortals. Lira will soon come back to Encantadia to accomplish her mission as a Sang’gre and resolve the conflict among the sisters.

The novel and engrossing narrative close to our folk stories, the intricate costumes and stage design, and the performance of a well-selected ensemble of actors have made Encantadia an instant fan favorite. With very high viewer ratings, it is said to be GMA Network’s most successful TV show. It has also won several awards such as the Best TV Series/Soap Opera in the Gawad America Awards, Student’s Choice of Drama Series in the USTv Student’s Choice Awards, Most Popular TV Program at the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation Box-Office Entertainment Awards, Most Favorite TV Show in K-Zone Magazine, and Best Original Music Score: Highly Commended in the Asian Television Awards, all in year 2005. In 2006, Encantadia became a finalist for the Best Lighting Category at the New York Festivals for Television Programming and Promotions.

Due to its success, Encantadia was followed by three more installments, namely Etheria, 2005-06, Encantadia: Pag-ibig Hanggang Wakas (Encantadia: Love to the End), 2006, and Encantadia, 2016. The latest installment is a retelling of the first series, but with a different set of actors and actresses, a few new roles, and some minor differences in the plot. Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Pilita Corrales

in An Evening with Pilita, 1964

(Pinoy Television:

The Story of

ABS-CBN: The Medium of Our Lives,

edited by Thelma Sioson-San Juan. ABS-CBN Broadcasting, 1999.)

text:
(aka Your Evening with Pilita) 1964-71, 7:00-8:00 pm, then 9:00-10:00 pm, Wednesdays, ABS-CBN Channel 3. Director: Mitos Villareal. Musical Directors: Emil Mijares, Doming Valdez. Host: PilitaCorrales.

An Evening with Pilita was a full-hour musical variety show which set the standards of musical performance on television. Corrales would always start the show with the song “A Million Thanks To You,” which would become her trademark. She introduced and interviewed local and foreign composers, singers, and stars. She rendered interpretations of music in English, Spanish, Cebuano, and Tagalog with her trademark back-bending and hip-bending movements wearing skin tight, fully beaded gowns. She also entertained request numbers, and engaged audiences with her Visayan sense of humor. The show offered nine songs an episode. The heart of the show was Pilita’s performance with the singing group Lemons Three, composed of Nikki Ross, Angie Yoingco, and director Villareal, who performed serious and comedy songs. The Lemons Three was also known as the Wing Duo whenever Villareal did not sing with Ross and Yoingco. The program ended with her singing the compositions or songs made popular by her guests.

An Evening with Pilita was considered the prestige program of ABS-CBN. The show always carried a theme, much like a storyline in a drama series. It was one of the first shows on local television to explore the medium of television to the fullest, especially in editing, lighting, and production design. It was the first Filipino show on television to be taped, using two Ampex videotape recorders bought by the network for the program. The show regularly had the “Three Pilitas,” a split-screen image of a Visayan Pilita, an English Pilita, and a Spanish Pilita, each speaking to one another, an editing technique first seen on local television at a time of analog broadcast production. Lavish sets, novel lighting, and a fabulous wardrobe enhanced the sophistication of the program. It was the first TV program to be videotaped in color in 1969, which changed as well the color schemes of the design of the studio and the wardrobe and makeup of Corrales and her guests.

Corrales, her guests, and the program’s crew received the highest talent fees during the period. Her weekly one-hour performance rate for the show was 990 pesos. The program was rating well and was consistently one of ABS-CBN’s top shows when Corrales decided to stop doing it to concentrate on her singing commitments outside the country. Corrales, however, continued to do specials for ABS-CBN.

An Evening with Pilita was revived as a one-airing special on 7 Oct 1977, Monday, 8:30-9:30 pm, on GMA. Directed again by Villareal, it showcased performances by Corrales with guest Rico Puno who aped each other’s gestures and contortions on a duet, with children Jackie Lou and Ramoncito, and with long-time friend Amado in a duet of Latin American songs. The special also featured a nostalgic browse through Corrales’ souvenir photo albums, a lively song-and-dance number with the group Something Special, and a full-costume rendition of the West Side Story by the choral group The Ambivalent Crowd.

In 1988, An Evening with Pilita returned under the same name, a monthly two-hour musical special, directed by Al Quinn. The revived program’s first guests were Dolphy, Nora Aunor, daughter Jackie Lou Blanco, Martin Nievera, Rico Puno, and Janno Gibbs, who each did duet numbers with Corrales, and Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, who sang a hit of comedy songs. Corrales, Nievera, and Blanco rendered a new treatment of a medley of Visayan songs. Corrales opened and closed the program with her signature songs “A Million Thanks To You” and “If I Never Sing Another Song,” respectively. The elaborate set design of the show, which gave each performance on the show a different look and feel, was by Rollie de Leon, while the musical arrangements were by Homer Flores and Toto Gentica.

An Evening with Pilita won several awards from the Citizens Awards for Television (CAT) of the Citizens’ Council of Mass Media: best musical variety program in 1964, 1965, and 1966; best director and a Hall of Fame Award for Villareal in 1964, 1966, 1967, 1968, and 1970; and best performer for Corrales in 1965, 1967, and 1971. The Philippine Movie Press Club awarded Corrales the Ading Fernando Memorial Award in its First Star Awards in 1986 for her work on and contributions to television, which she started in An Evening with Pilita. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Gizelle Louise M. Dasmariñas

GAMEPLAN1995-2008, GMA; Studio 23, RPN 9; relaunched 2013, online. Production Company: Probe Productions. Producer: Cheche Lazaro. Online producer: Triple Shot Media. Online executive producer: Jake de Guzman. Hosts: 1995-1996, Paolo Abrera, Yasmin Mapua-Tang, Rufi Parpan; 1996-1997, Paolo Bediones, Mon Castro, Suzi Entrata-Abrera; 1997-2001, Abrera, Entrata-Abrera; 2001-06, Akiko Thomson Guevarra, Carlo Ledesma, Rovilson Fernandez, Tricia Chiongbian-Concepcion; 2006-08, Paolo Soler, Wowie Meloto; 2013, Amanda Fernandez, Julian Rodriguez, Ton Vergel de Dios.

Gameplan was a weekly sports magazine show that featured both professional and non-professional sports personalities, popular and little known sporting events, and other outdoor adventures. The show explored a variety of active lifestyle practices and immersed itself in the many possibilities in the world of sports by participating in the actual adventures themselves. In the show’s 13-year run, the set of hosts tasked to bring the action to the viewers were instrumental to the show’s innovative treatment and intense feel. Five sets of hosting changes from 1995 to 2008 did not affect the format of the show.

The show focused mainly on an active and healthy lifestyle. It was divided into segments tackling different topics each. The segments featured the hosts trying out traditional and extreme sports or discussing current trends and lifestyles but with a fresher and deeper angle. Proof of Gameplan’s success and reach was the catchphrase it popularized. The segments and each episode usually ended with the statement “That’s the game plan!” The show pushed the boundaries and drew new standards for sports programming in the Philippines.

Gameplan was rebooted by Tripleshot Media Inc as an online show. Launched on 1 Apr 2013, the show is about having an active, healthy lifestyle while incorporating a generation of travel enthusiasts, a social media savvy look, and virtual interaction with audiences. After laying down the game plan for 13 years on TV, it now stirs the audience to take the first step by asking, “What’s your game plan?”

Gameplan won the Best Sports Show in the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2002. It was a finalist in the New York Festival International Television and Awards, 2000, and a runner up in the Asian Television Awards, 2003. Written by Dale de Jesus

GO TEACHER GO!3 Feb 2011, 4:00-5:00 pm, Thursdays, DZUP 1602. Producers: Broadcast Department of the College of Mass Communication, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman and UP National Institute for Science and Mathematics Education Development (UP NISMED).

This educational talk program aims to raise the level of competence of science and mathematics teachers by providing information and teaching strategies that update their knowledge and skills, particularly in tune with the K-to-12 curriculum. It also discusses ways by which science and math can be applied to real life. Go Teacher Go! is a part of the Radio Iskool program block of DZUP, which includes programs designed with an academic curriculum.

Ma. Lourdes Agad and Lolita Mondigo of the UP NISMED Audiovisual Group host Go Teacher Go! while its program producer is Chryl Bhefer Martinez. Promoting a science culture, the program encourages students to take science courses and become researchers while encouraging scientists and science researchers to collaborate and share their knowledge and works by inviting teachers from different schools and universities as well as individuals from the private sector as resource persons. Listeners participate in the program by sending questions and comments online or through texting or calling.

On 29 Apr 2014, Go Teacher Go! won the 22nd Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Award for Best Radio Science and Technology Program. Written by Alyssa Jean E. Alano with notes from Maria Angelica D. Abad

GORIO AND HIS JEEPNEY12 Apr 1966-69, 7:00-7:30 pm, Tuesdays, ABC DZTM-TV Channel 5. Producer and Director: Rene V. Pangan aka Chiquito. Actors: Chiquito (Gorio), Yolanda Guevarra (Gorio’s wife), Roody “Rudy” Manlapaz, Boy Alvarez.

The sitcom showed the daily routine of a jeepney driver, Gorio, and how he manages to make a living to provide for his family’s needs through his six-seater jeepney, one of the most common forms of public transport in the Philippines. Gorio is often embroiled in conflict situations like being apprehended by the police for committing traffic violations, having an argument with passengers, and being wrongfully incriminated in illegal activities of criminal elements of the city. At a time when most Philippine television comedies of the period resorted to unpalatable and sometimes immoral slapstick, Gorio and His Jeepney always pointed out that good deeds and earning a living through honest means are the best measure of a person’s worth.

The TV sitcom was from Ben Alcantara’s popular daily cartoon strip Gorio and His Jeepney, published in the English broadsheet Manila Times, whose publishers, the heirs of Don Alejandro Roces Sr, also owned DZTM-TV Channel 5. As in most programs of the period, each episode of the comedy program was funded by sponsors such as Goodyear Jitney Service Tires, the Philippine Refining Company, Baguio Oil, the laundry soap Rinso, and Dr. Lyna’s vegetable soap Marvel. The program also had its precursor in the movie of the same title, released on 2 Feb 1962, directed by Pablo Santiago, written by Tommy C. David, and starring Chiquito, Yolanda Guevarra, Arsenio Alonso, Vicente Liwanag, Ponga, Pugak, Paquito Salcedo, Bert Silva, Paquito Toledo, Dely Atay-atayan Lota De Guzman, Francia Ferrer, and Helen Gamboa who was introduced as an actor in the film. Written by Ralph Jake T. Wabingga

text:
GULONG NG PALAD(Wheel of Fate) 1949-56, 11:00-11:15 am, Mondays to Fridays, DZRH. Producer: PhilAds for the Philippine Manufacturing Company. Writer: Lina Flor. Cast: Loida Flores aka Loida Viriña (Luisa), Ric Valdez (Carding), Bessie Castañeda (Mimi), Rosa Mia (Aling Menang), and Paquito Toledo (narrator). Fernando Cruz later replaced Valdez while Betty Roxas took over Castañeda’s part.

Gulong ng Palad was one of the two pioneering serialized dramas aired on Philippine radio, the other being Ilaw ng Tahanan (The Light of the Home) written by Liwayway Arceo. The two soaps aired within a week of each other, both on DZRH from 1949, with Ilaw airing first. Both were scheduled to air at the same time but a delay in the casting of Gulong moved the airing of its premier episode.

The soap is premised on the love story of Carding, from a wealthy family, and Luisa, the daughter of a laundrywoman. The plot takes many turns as Aling Menang objects to their union due to their social class difference while Mimi tries to steal Carding from Luisa. In 1950, Premier Productions produced a film of the same title based on the radio program. With Jose Padilla Jr as Carding and Arsenia Francisco as Luisa, it was the blockbuster of the year. Others in the cast were Lopito, Patria Plata, Ramon D’Salva, and Ester Buenaobra.

In 1977, Gulong ng Palad was adapted as a television serial by the Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation Channel 2. It moved to Radio Philippines Network Channel 9 in 1979, then returned to BBC in 1983, where it stayed until it stopped airing in 1985. It starred Marianne de la Riva as Luisa and Ronald Corveaux as Carding, with Beth Bautista as Mimi and Caridad Sanchez as Mimi’s mother. The show aired from Monday to Friday, 12:30-1:00 pm.

ABS-CBN revived the soap as a telenovela in 2006, starring Kristine Hermosa as Luisa, TJ Trinidad as Carding, Cherie Gil as Aling Menang, and Andrea del Rosario as Mimi. The expanded cast included Rio Locsin, Joel Torre, Luis Alandy, and Julia Barretto. Directed by Eric Salud and Jerome Pobocan, its 88 hour-long episodes ran from January to May, Monday to Friday, after the evening newscast TV Patrol. It aired simultaneously on The Filipino Channel, ABS-CBN’s television channel abroad, with DVD copies available. .

With each adaptation and revival, Gulong ng Palad acquired an updated setting and production design but its premise remained, following Flor’s original storyline.Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez

In 1977, Gulong ng Palad was adapted as a television serial by the Banahaw Broadcasting Corporation Channel 2. It moved to Radio Philippines Network Channel 9 in 1979, then returned to BBC in 1983, where it stayed until it stopped airing in 1985. It starred Marianne de la Riva as Luisa and Ronald Corveaux as Carding, with Beth Bautista as Mimi and Caridad Sanchez as Mimi’s mother. The show aired from Monday to Friday, 12:30-1:00 pm.

ABS-CBN revived the soap as a telenovela in 2006, starring Kristine Hermosa as Luisa, TJ Trinidad as Carding, Cherie Gil as Aling Menang, and Andrea del Rosario as Mimi. The expanded cast included Rio Locsin, Joel Torre, Luis Alandy, and Julia Barretto. Directed by Eric Salud and Jerome Pobocan, its 88 hour-long episodes ran from January to May, Monday to Friday, after the evening newscast TV Patrol. It aired simultaneously on The Filipino Channel, ABS-CBN’s television channel abroad, with DVD copies available. .
With each adaptation and revival, Gulong ng Palad acquired an updated setting and production design but its premise remained, following Flor’s original storyline.Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez

text:
HARANA NG PUSO(The Heart’s Serenade) Premiered 5 Feb 2006, 8:00-10:00 pm, Sundays, Philippine Broadcasting Service DWBR Business Radio on 104.3 FM, DWRB Radyo ng Bayan on 738 AM, and DZRM Radyo Magasin on 1278 AM. Producers: Noel Jusay Lacsamana, Sonia M. Roco, and Jeanette Job-Coroza. Technician: Edith Estrella Hermano. Host: Michael Coroza

This musical program, which features the Filipino romantic ballad called kundiman, began when the long-running Serenatang Kumbidahan (Serenade by Invitation) hosted by Dely Magpayo signed off from Manila Broadcasting Company’s DZRH in December 2005. It promotes the Filipino tradition of serenade and the co-called living legends behind it.

The show includes poetry recitations with guitar accompaniment and the live crooning of the Mabuhay Singers, formed in 1958 and composed of Raye Lucero aka Ray Purugannan Cabailo, Cely Bautista, Emma Lucero aka Emma Purugannan Regis, Peping de Leon, Eddie Suarez, and Jimmy Salonga. Treating the songs as poetry, Coroza explains the content and context of such crowd favorites as “Aking Bituin” (My Star), more popularly known as “O, Ilaw” (Oh, Light), and share little-known details about the songs, in Magpayo’s fashion, such as how Santiago Suarez and Levi Celerio’s “Dungawin Mo, Hirang” (My Love, Throw Me a Glance) was eventually called “Harana Numero Uno” (Serenade Number One), and how it became the model of succeeding kundiman (romantic ballad), danzas (musical genre), balitaw (Visayan folk song), and other romantic songs written by Constancio de Guzman, Miguel Velarde Jr, Tony Maiquez, Josefino Cenizal, Julian Balita, Tex Salcedo, Ruben Escare, and other composers.

The show plays the recordings of singers Ruben Tagalog, Larry Miranda, Cenon Lagman, Ric Manrique Jr, Diomedes Maturan, Danilo Santos, and other haranistas or balladeers. Classical and Filipino folk and popular singers perform on the show, including Gamaliel Viray, Susan Fernandez, Armida Siguion-Reyna, and Joey Ayala. It features poetry readings by poets such as Benilda Santos, Ruth Elynia Mabanglo, Rebecca Añonuevo, Vim Nadera, Teo Antonio, Oscar Peñaranda, and Lourd de Veyra. Discussions on Filipino music and poetry are discussed by guests like National Artists for Literature Virgilio S. Almario and Bienvenido Lumbera, and music scholars Felipe de Leon Jr and Chino Toledo. Even the salin-awit, or Filipino translations of classics, standards, and pop songs, is played, such as those brought to the program by journalist and screenplay writer Jose “Pete” Lacaba.

On 2 Apr 2010, during the Balagtas Day celebration, the Komisyon sa Wikang Filipino awarded the show the Gawad Francisco Balagtas for popularizing the national language through music and literature. Victor Emmanuel Carmelo D. Nadera

HEALTH MATTERSPremiered 1 Jan 2011, 4:00-5:00 pm, Tuesdays, DZUP 1602. Producers: Broadcast Communication Department of the College of Mass Communication, University of the Philippines (UP) Diliman and UP College of Medicine. Host: Jun Austria. Co-hosts: Roj Tirona and Bianca Tallafer.

The program provides information on health problems and possible remedies in layman’s terms as well as services available at the UP College of Medicine, Philippine General Hospital (PGH), and the Department of Health. Health Matters also promotes awareness of health-related advocacies.

The program features guest doctors and other health experts to discuss a topic of the week and to respond to questions from callers. Health Matters is part of the Radio Iskool block of DZUP, which provides a creative and interactive environment for the discussion of academic and non-academic issues.

On 8 Mar 2014, Health Matters was honored in the 8th Hildegarde Awards for Outstanding Achievements in Broadcast Media, an annual citation given by St Scholastica’s College. Written by Divine Marie Joanne P. Endriga

text:
HIMIG NG LAHI(Music of Our People) 1952-85, weekly, DZFM (now DZRB) and DZRM. Musical Director: Felipe Padilla de Leon. Pianist: Illuminada de Leon. Choreographer: Pedro “Edru” Abraham (1976-81). Soloists: Aileen Cura (1980 and 1984), Lisa Florentino, Angie Velasco, Zonia Velasco, and Magdangal de Leon. Rondalla: Marilag de Leon, and Illuminada de Leon.

Founded by Felipe Padilla de Leon in 1948 and active until 1984, Himig ng Lahi (Music of Our People) was a musical group that promoted Philippine music through live performances with choreography using native wear. Recognizing the impact of broadcast media on awareness and appreciation of music, de Leon brought its performances on the air in a program with the same name. Himig ng Lahi followed a lecture-concert format where de Leon, fondly called Tatay (Father), discussed the form and history of one to three-note songs, and then more complex folk songs like “Leron Leron Sinta” (Leron Leron, Beloved), “Ay, Kalisud!” (Ah, Misery!), and “Sarung Banggi” (One Evening). He then annotated the classical kundiman of Francisco Santiago’s “Pakiusap” (Plea), Nicanor Abelardo’s “Kundiman” (Love Song), and“Mutya ng Pasig” (Muse of the Pasig), and Santiago Suarez’s “Sa Kabukiran” (At the Farm). The group ended each concert with pop songs.

Himig ng Lahi toured the country and the globe to bring Philippine music and dance to Filipinos everywhere, including the United States and Canada. Abraham’s choreography complimented the song numbers. The dancers wore the different Filipino dresses including the traditional Igorot wear, the malong of southern Philippines, the baro’t saya, the mestiza gown and even vaudeville-inspired dresses, all sewn by de Leon’s wife Illuminda de Leon, fondly called Nanay (Mother). Written by Camille S. Intal

Asensio 1998; Velasco 2013.

text:
HIRAYA MANAWARI(Reaching One’s Dreams) 1995-2003, 8:30-9:00 am, Mondays-Thursdays and 9:00-9:30 am, Sundays; later 8:30-9:00, Mondays-Wednesdays and 9:00-9:30, Saturdays; then 9:00-9:300 Saturday only, ABS-CBN. Company Producers: ABS-CBN Foundation and the Department of Education, Culture and Sports, now Department of Education. Producer: Gina Lopez. Executive Producer: Mariles H. Gonzales. Directors: Noel Añonuevo, Rene Guidote, Rowena Concepcion, Bernardo Bernardo, Lem Garcellano, Cesar Celestino. Creative Committee: Uro de la Cruz, Lem Garcellano, Aurea Duran, Rebecca Cabrera, Rowena Concepcion. Creative Director: Uro de la Cruz. Head Writers: Uro de la Cruz, Gina Fernandez. Operations Manager: Rowena Concepcion. Theme Music Composer: Ryan Cayabyab. Theme Music Lyricist: Lem Garcellano. Theme Music Performer: Cristina Villonco.

Hiraya Manawari is a fantasy fairy tale program that teaches morals and life lessons to the Filipino youth aged 7 to 12. It first ran as a program aired from Mondays to Thursdays, then became a weekly program aired during the weekend. The title of the program is from “hiraya” meaning imagination and manawari (ma + nawari) meaning hopefully. When combined, the words mean “make your dreams soar” or “may dreams come true.”


The program addressed the television industry’s seeming neglect of its duty to teach children values and how to become responsible individuals. The show also aimed to awaken children’s imagination and creative thinking. Each episode dealt with matters such as courage, respect, honesty, discipline, proper behavior and other positive values that are aligned with the values education curriculum prescribed by then Department of Education, Culture, and Sports (DECS), now Department of Education (DepEd).

The show utilized fantastic sets, colorful costumes, special effects, and animation techniques. The fantasy format, with a storyteller providing the continuity of the narrative, was adapted to teach morals without making the program sound pedagogic. The scripts were based on local and foreign folktales and fairy tales.

Hiraya Manawari won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1996 and was a consistent recipient of the Anak TV Seal Award from 1995-2003. Written by Divine Marie Joanne P. Endriga

text:
HIWAGA SA BAHAY NA BATO(Mystery at the House of Stone) Sep 1962 to Jan 1963, 6:30-7:00 pm, Mondays-Saturdays, ABS-CBN DZAQ-TV Channel 3. Director-Writer: Jose Miranda Cruz. Actors: Dalton de Castro, Flora Cristobal, Eva Darren, Teddy Santos, Noel Nolasco, Estela Grande, Lita de los Reyes, Baby Bernardo, Ernesto Fajardo, Lina Chico, Ben David, Cachupoy, Bentot.

Considered the first soap opera on Philippine television, Hiwaga sa Bahay na Bato is “a spooky, gothic-style soap” about a monstrous hunchback (David) with a disfigured face who lives underneath a stone house. The owner of the huge house (de Castro), a rich hacendero (landowner), is unaware of his existence. Strange events haunt the place. The hunchback, violent and tender, threatens innocent lives in the old house. The hunchback also falls in love with a beautiful woman (Darren).

The program’s production cost was very low. The sets were minimal. Shooting was done in little rooms and not in real studios. The production used only one camera, and the director just pointed the camera in another direction to give the impression of a different setting. The program was aired live. In spite of the limitations, the horror drama became a hit.

The program made its director-writer Jose Miranda Cruz a household name. He later went on to make more soap operas, like Prinsipeng Tulisan (Prince Brigand), 1963; Hanggang May Buhay (As Long as There is Life), 1964; and Larawan ng Pag-ibig (Image of Love), 1964. He wrote the story of GMA’s hit soap Yagit (Pauper) in the 1980s. It also launched the career of Eva Darren, considered a pioneer in television soap operas and who continues to appear in films and television programs. The program also made Ben David a popular broadcast personality. David started as a voice talent on radio, whose trademarks were his deep voice, deliberate “overacting,” and catch phrases like “O, hindi!” (Oh, no!) and “ngitngit ng mga pangit” (fury of the ugly). His was the voice of the intro spiel of DZRH’s Gabi ng Lagim (Night of Horror). Written byEulalio R. Guieb III

Rodrigo 2006; Santos 2009b.

text:
I-WITNESS18 Jan 1999-present, 11:30 pm Monday-12:30 am Tuesday; 1999-2010, then 10:30-11:30 pm Saturday, GMA. Reporters: Howie Severino, Kara David, Sandra Aguinaldo, Jay Taruc. Previous reporters: Cesar Apolinario, Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Karen Davila, Mike Enriquez, Susan Enriquez, Cheche Lazaro, Jiggy Manicad, Vicky Morales, Maki Pulido, Rhea Santos, Jessica Soho, Raffy Tima.

i-Witness, from the words “eyewitness” and “I witness,” is a weekly television documentary program that tackles the difficult lives of marginalized Filipinos. Using the first-person point of view and armed with handy equipment, the mobile team of “documentarists” travels on foot and uses all available means of transportation to the farthest reaches of the archipelago. The episode “Gamu-gamo sa Dilim” (Fireflies in the Dark), 2002, featured the school children of Little Baguio in Oriental Mindoro who literally burn the midnight oil as they study using only candle light. “Buto’t Balat” (Skins and Bones), 2005, demonstrated the plight of severely malnourished children of Mercedes town in Bicol. “Ambulansyang de Paa” (Ambulance on Foot), 2009, highlighted the travails of the Mangyan people who use hammocks and travel on foot to bring the sick to far-away health facilities. “Tarima” (Logging Areas), 2013, featured the miserable plight of the Manobo children in the mountains of Davao del Norte who collect and carry heavy logs on foot, each log weighing about 40 kilos which they sell for a living. “Mga Batang Kalabaw” (Carabao Children) documented the lives of 13 children who work as wood porters in the mountains of Agusan del Sur, each paid 6 to 12 pesos a day for carrying eight-foot-long timber that weighs 15-20 kilos. “Pagbabalik sa Karagatan” (Return to the Ocean), 2012, is the search for the wreck of the sunken ship MV Karagatan that was carrying Chinese guns for the communist New People’s Army in the depths of the country’s northern Pacific coasts.

Contrary to notions that the most marginalized are those who live in rural areas, the show featured people right at the heart of the metropolis neglected by the government and even by the people with whom they live. “Kidneys for Sale,” 2008, exposed the underground trade of human organs involving the men of Baseco Compound in Tondo, Manila. “Gutom” (Hunger), 2006, showed how people living in the shanties along the Port Area of Manila cope with hunger as they shrink all three necessary daily meals into one and just sleep off growling stomach pains. “Hukay-Hukay” (Dig and Dig), 2012, is a “tour” of the sewerage system of Cubao in Quezon City.

The program became instrumental in mobilizing support from citizens and private organizations and in compelling government officials to act. People donated money and material to help build infrastructure and provide for the basic needs of featured indigent subjects. The documentaries, however, veer away from the sensationalistic coverage of poverty and a messianic conception of media, pointing to public accountability and individual compassion as remedy to social ills. They demonstrate how the subjects themselves struggle to have dignity amidst their misery. For instance, “Iskul Ko, No. 1!” (My School, Number 1!), 2008, showed how the pupils of Sindangan Elementary School in Southern Leyte, in spite of poverty and their school’s scant resources, topped the National Elementary Achievement Test.

i-Witness has also become notable for featuring the educational system, environment, health situation, and the cultures of peoples abroad. Aguinaldo crossed the land borders of Myanmar, Cambodia, and Vietnam, and Severino sought old Filipino films in Thailand. The production team is said to be the first Filipino crew that visited the Malampaya Natural Gas Project in Palawan and the Kenyan safari.

The show was also scored by censors when the episode “Lukayo” was suspended in Jun 2006; it featured the lukayo, women past their sexual prime who dance at weddings where, in an act of mocking male power, they wave like trophies and twirl like batons huge phalluses carved out of wood, painted with lipstick, and decorated with flowers and ribbons.

From the KBP Golden Dove Awards, i-Witness received the Best Public Affairs Program in 2000, and Best Public Affairs Program Host for Vicky Morales in 2000 and for Cheche Lazaro in 2001. From the PMPC Star Awards for Television, it won the Best Documentary Award and the Best Documentary Program Hosts in 2000-03, 2005, 2007-09, and 2011-14. From the Catholic Mass Media Awards, it won Best Adult Educational/Cultural Program for Taruc’s “Mga Batang Kalabaw” in 2008 and “Batang Langoy” (Swimming Children) in 2009, and Aguinaldo’s “Iskul Ko, No. 1” in 2008 and “Pasan-Pasan” (Burdened) in 2011. From the US International Film and Video Festival, the program won 3rd place for creative excellence in the documentary category for Severino’s “Unggoy” (Monkey) in 2006; and a Silver Screen Award for David’s “Buto’t Balat” in 2006, and “Sa Mata ni Ekang” (Through Ekang’s Eyes) in 2007. “Buto’t Balat” also won best social awareness program in the Asian Television Awards and a runner-up award in the Japan Prize, both in 2005. From the New York Festivals, the program won the Bronze World Medal for David’s “Paraisong Uhaw” (Thirsty Paradise) in 2011; the Silver World Medals for Cruz-Valdes’s “Mental” in 1999, for Severino’s “Dreams of Shelter” in 2000 and “Huling Hala Bira” (The Last Ati-Atihan Dance) in 2008, for Aguinaldo’s “Iskul Ko, No. 1” in 2008, and for Taruc’s “Lapnos” (Scald) in 2012; and the Gold World Medal for Aguinaldo’s “Boy Pusit” (Boy Squid) in 2007. “Huling Hala Bira” also won 2nd prize in the UN Asia-Pacific Millennium Development Goals Media Awards in 2007. From UNICEF, the program won the Asia-Pacific Child Rights Award for David’s “Mga Batang Kalabaw” in 2008. i-Witness won the George Foster Peabody Awards for Soho’s “Kidneys for Sale” in 1999 and David’s “Ambulansyang de Paa” in 2012. Written by JPaul S. Manzanilla, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Using the first-person point of view and armed with handy equipment, the mobile team of “documentarists” travels on foot and uses all available means of transportation to the farthest reaches of the archipelago. The episode “Gamu-gamo sa Dilim” (Fireflies in the Dark), 2002, featured the school children of Little Baguio in Oriental Mindoro who literally burn the midnight oil as they study using only candle light. “Buto’t Balat” (Skins and Bones), 2005, demonstrated the plight of severely malnourished children of Mercedes town in Bicol. “Ambulansyang de Paa” (Ambulance on Foot), 2009, highlighted the travails of the Mangyan people who use hammocks and travel on foot to bring the sick to far-away health facilities. “Tarima” (Logging Areas), 2013, featured the miserable plight of the Manobo children in the mountains of Davao del Norte who collect and carry heavy logs on foot, each log weighing about 40 kilos which they sell for a living. “Mga Batang Kalabaw” (Carabao Children) documented the lives of 13 children who work as wood porters in the mountains of Agusan del Sur, each paid 6 to 12 pesos a day for carrying eight-foot-long timber that weighs 15-20 kilos. “Pagbabalik sa Karagatan” (Return to the Ocean), 2012, is the search for the wreck of the sunken ship MV Karagatan that was carrying Chinese guns for the communist New People’s Army in the depths of the country’s northern Pacific coasts.

value.desc: Kara David in i-Witness’s award-winning episode, “Ambulansyang de Paa,” 2012 (Photo courtesy of GMA Network)

article.value: Contrary to notions that the most marginalized are those who live in rural areas, the show featured people right at the heart of the metropolis neglected by the government and even by the people with whom they live. “Kidneys for Sale,” 2008, exposed the underground trade of human organs involving the men of Baseco Compound in Tondo, Manila. “Gutom” (Hunger), 2006, showed how people living in the shanties along the Port Area of Manila cope with hunger as they shrink all three necessary daily meals into one and just sleep off growling stomach pains. “Hukay-Hukay” (Dig and Dig), 2012, is a “tour” of the sewerage system of Cubao in Quezon City.

The program became instrumental in mobilizing support from citizens and private organizations and in compelling government officials to act. People donated money and material to help build infrastructure and provide for the basic needs of featured indigent subjects. The documentaries, however, veer away from the sensationalistic coverage of poverty and a messianic conception of media, pointing to public accountability and individual compassion as remedy to social ills. They demonstrate how the subjects themselves struggle to have dignity amidst their misery. For instance, “Iskul Ko, No. 1!” (My School, Number 1!), 2008, showed how the pupils of Sindangan Elementary School in Southern Leyte, in spite of poverty and their school’s scant resources, topped the National Elementary Achievement Test.

i-Witness has also become notable for featuring the educational system, environment, health situation, and the cultures of peoples abroad. Aguinaldo crossed the land borders of Myanmar, Cambodia, and Vietnam, and Severino sought old Filipino films in Thailand. The production team is said to be the first Filipino crew that visited the Malampaya Natural Gas Project in Palawan and the Kenyan safari.

The show was also scored by censors when the episode “Lukayo” was suspended in Jun 2006; it featured the lukayo, women past their sexual prime who dance at weddings where, in an act of mocking male power, they wave like trophies and twirl like batons huge phalluses carved out of wood, painted with lipstick, and decorated with flowers and ribbons.

From the KBP Golden Dove Awards, i-Witness received the Best Public Affairs Program in 2000, and Best Public Affairs Program Host for Vicky Morales in 2000 and for Cheche Lazaro in 2001. From the PMPC Star Awards for Television, it won the Best Documentary Award and the Best Documentary Program Hosts in 2000-03, 2005, 2007-09, and 2011-14. From the Catholic Mass Media Awards, it won Best Adult Educational/Cultural Program for Taruc’s “Mga Batang Kalabaw” in 2008 and “Batang Langoy” (Swimming Children) in 2009, and Aguinaldo’s “Iskul Ko, No. 1” in 2008 and “Pasan-Pasan” (Burdened) in 2011. From the US International Film and Video Festival, the program won 3rd place for creative excellence in the documentary category for Severino’s “Unggoy” (Monkey) in 2006; and a Silver Screen Award for David’s “Buto’t Balat” in 2006, and “Sa Mata ni Ekang” (Through Ekang’s Eyes) in 2007. “Buto’t Balat” also won best social awareness program in the Asian Television Awards and a runner-up award in the Japan Prize, both in 2005. From the New York Festivals, the program won the Bronze World Medal for David’s “Paraisong Uhaw” (Thirsty Paradise) in 2011; the Silver World Medals for Cruz-Valdes’s “Mental” in 1999, for Severino’s “Dreams of Shelter” in 2000 and “Huling Hala Bira” (The Last Ati-Atihan Dance) in 2008, for Aguinaldo’s “Iskul Ko, No. 1” in 2008, and for Taruc’s “Lapnos” (Scald) in 2012; and the Gold World Medal for Aguinaldo’s “Boy Pusit” (Boy Squid) in 2007. “Huling Hala Bira” also won 2nd prize in the UN Asia-Pacific Millennium Development Goals Media Awards in 2007. From UNICEF, the program won the Asia-Pacific Child Rights Award for David’s “Mga Batang Kalabaw” in 2008. i-Witness won the George Foster Peabody Awards for Soho’s “Kidneys for Sale” in 1999 and David’s “Ambulansyang de Paa” in 2012. Written by JPaul S. Manzanilla, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

ILAW NG TAHANAN(Light of the Home) 30 Mar 1949 to 18 Aug 1958, 11:45 am to noon, Mondays to Fridays, DZMB; later 3:45 pm to 4:00 pm, Mondays to Fridays, DZRH. Producer: Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC). Directors: Frankie Gomez, Victor Oyteza, Teddy Baldemor, and Fred Gonzales. Writer: Liwayway Arceo. Narrators: Ernie Malay and Greg Arnaldo.

This is noted as the first soap opera on Philippine radio. Reflecting the culturally constructed role of the Filipino mother as the light of the home, Ilaw ng Tahanan (Light of the Home) dramatized the domestic role of women from all walks of life while depicting human conditions that the audience was assumed to easily identify with. Arceo described it as a dramatization of the ordinary problems faced by the ordinary Filipino family, which was meant for the listeners to see themselves in the characters. Its story exposition style was slow-paced so that a listener who missed an episode could easily catch up.

Ilaw ng Tahanan was produced by the Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC), makers of laundry soap Perla and beauty soap Camay, through its ad agency, the Philippine Advertising Associates (PhilAds), as its first attempt at replicating popular American soap operas. Albert Card, Bill Yanovich, Vic Oteyza, Arling Gonzales, and Ben Pangan oversaw its production. Its cast included Ester Chavez in the lead role of Aling Chayong; Mervyn Samson and later Fidencio Belizario as Alber; Magdea Caneda as Doray, Alber’s mother-in-law; and Fred Gonzales as Mang Maning.

During its run, Ilaw ng Tahanan was translated into four Philippine languages and aired in provincial stations. Written by Yna Marei Aguilar

text:
IPAGLABAN MO(Fight for It) IBC 13, 1989-92; ABS-CBN, 1992-99; RPN 9, 2003-04; GMA News TV, 2012. Line producers: Millard Productions, The Big Top Entertainment, Heaven’s Best Productions, Glad TV, Foundation. Executive producers: Angelina Samson-Valvieja, Jopet Sison, Mary Antonette D. Macalino. Producers: Paolo R. Leaño, Louanda D. Lomibao, Oliver Valvieja. Associate producers: Florida P. Bruzula. Directors: Peque Gallaga, Lorenzo Reyes, Carlos Siguion-Reyna, Nick Lizaso, Rommel Ragasa, Dante Nico Garcia, Hero Bautista. Creative Director: Hero Clarence M. Bautista. Associate Director: Rionel Alati-it. Writers: Mars Cavestany, Raymund Dimayuga, Christian Vidallo. Editor: Laser Diaz. Production Managers: Romy Opulencia, Mary Ann Rivera. Videographer: Rain Yamson II. Editor: Jambyth Tapel. Production Design: Raymund Jorge Fernandez. Postproduction Supervisor: Lisette Pujanes-Dionisio. Hosts: Atty. Jose “Ping” Sison, Jopet Sison.

Ipaglaban Mo ran from 20 Nov 1989 to 16 Aug 1992 on IBC 13. It then aired in 1992 on ABS-CBN under Millard Productions, and after 52 episodes became a station-produced program beginning on Sep 1993 until 1999. It had a short run from 2003 to 2004 on RPN 9, and aired again beginning on 10 Nov 2012 under Big Top Entertainment on GMA News TV. The TV program is one of the country’s longest-running and top-rating drama anthologies. It showcases everyday lives of Filipinos based on court decisions involving the Family Code, and labor, criminal, and civil laws. It is a unique legal show because the stories dramatized are based on facts determined by the courts from actual trials and not on pending cases. Common cases include love triangles, squabbles among heirs over inheritance, infidelity, adultery, concubinage, marriage annulment, rape, incest involving fathers and daughters, child adoption, employer-employee relations, unfair labor practices, and illegal dismissals. The legal answers to the situations do not come from the opinion of the host lawyer but from the decisions of the Supreme Court, which are already considered part of the law of the land. Sison featured the cases not in legal jargon but in a language that could easily be understood by the common people.

 

The concept of the program came from newscaster Jose Mari Velez who saw the potential of Sison’s newspaper column “A Law Each Day” in The Philippine Star. The column was the idea of the paper’s publisher and founding chairperson Betty Go-Belmonte.

Ipaglaban Mo’s initial episode, “Haligi ng Tahanan” (Pillar of the House), starring Richard Gomez and Dina Bonnevie under directors Peque Gallaga and Lorenzo Reyes, was about the custody battle between the wealthy grandparents and the poor father of a child whose mother died while giving birth. The father won the case and the rich parents continued supporting the child. The second episode featured Jaclyn Jose, Jimmy Santos, and Tirso Cruz III and was directed by Carlos Siguion-Reyna. Nick Lizaso, who was a commissioner of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, directed most of the program’s subsequent episodes on IBC 13 and ABS-CBN. Dante Nico Garcia and Hero Bautista, son of movie director and former Quezon City councilor Butch Bautista and brother of actors Harlene and Quezon City Mayor Herbert, took over the directing job in its run on GMA News TV.

The show became so popular that it spawned a daily five-minute legal vignette, “Ikaw at ang Batas” (You and the Law), shown during the daily 5:00 pm news program of IBC 13. When the show transferred to ABS-CBN, the show’s Ikaw at ang Batas (You and the Law) became a segment of the daily evening news Hoy Gising (Hey, Wake Up).

 

Ikaw at ang Batas is now a daily TV program on NBN4, 2008-present, and a public service program on DZRJ. Ipaglaban Mo also gave birth to two movies, 1995 and 1997, written by Ricky Lee and produced by ABS-CBN’s sister company, Star Cinema. Both films starred Nida Blanca, Ronaldo Valdez, Subas Herrero, Joel Torre, Ricky Davao, Gina Alajar, Chin Chin Gutierrez, Marianne dela Riva, and Marvin Agustin. The directors were Marilou Diaz-Abaya, Nick Lizaso, Rolando Quintos, and Carlos Siguion-Reyna. The 1995 movie was exhibited in the same year at the Fukuoka International Film Festival and in New Delhi.

The 18th Catholic Mass Media Award bestowed on the program the St Lorenzo Ruiz Award for its episode “Karahasan o Kamangmangan” (Violence or Ignorance) in 1996. Written by Irma M. Mutuc, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Alano 2012; Sison 2012, 2013; Wikipedia n.d.a.

IROG, PAALAM(Farewell, My Love) 1950-51, 10:00-10:15 am, Mondays to Fridays, DZRH. Director: Domingo Principe. Writer: Manuel Bautista. Sponsor: Gloco Hollywood Products through its local advertising agency PhilProm Advertising. Narrator: Ernie Angeles. Casts: Lita Rio and Fidencio Belizario.

Irog, Paalam is a radio soap opera story that revolves around romantic love and loss. The program rated well against Dr. Ramon Selga, which was the leading drama on the same time slot on DZMB, sponsored by Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC). Irog, Paalam was followed by Lagrimas (Tears), another Gloco-sponsored drama, at 10:15-10:30 am. However, in spite of their popularity, Irog, Paalam and Lagrimas lasted for only a year, but not before Irog inspired a movie of the same title in 1951. Except for Lita Rio, the cast was absorbed by Aking Pag-Ibig (My Love), a soap sponsored by another consumer product manufacturing company, Colgate Palmolive Philippines. Written by Maria Criselda C. Sto. Domingo

ISIP PINOY(Filipino Psyche) Nov 1986-May 1988, 9:00-10:00 pm, Tuesdays, RPN 9. Producer: Lahing Kayumanggi Productions. Executive Producer: Oscar Yumping. Supervising Producer: Steve Sagun. Marketing Supervisor: Ariel Salumbides. Directors: Ishmael Bernal, Mel Chionglo, Behn Cervantes, Gil Portes, Joel Lamangan, Chito Roño, Carlitos Siguion-Reyna, Tony Espejo, Bibsy Carballo, Chanda Romero. Assistant Directors: Emmanuel Sanchez, Milo Paz. Production Assistant: Ronnie Velasco. Head Writer: Ricky Lee. Writers: Amor Olaguer, Eileen Meneses, Milo Paz, Mon Jocson, Nannette Matilac, Agnes Cayaban, Iday Mendigo, Tussy Sid, Noel Zapanta, Lynda Casimiro, Deo Bartolome. Hosts: Pilot and first few episodes were Vic Sumulong and Charo Santos; succeeding episodes hosted by Vic Sumulong with different female co-hosts like Chat Silayan, Gina Alajar, Laarni Enriquez, Cherry Pie Picache, and Raquel Villavicencio.

Isip Pinoy (Filipino Psyche) was a blocktimer produced during the period when there was tremendous outpouring of democratic and nationalistic ideals after the EDSA Revolt.

The show pioneered in the use of Filipino language in evening magazine format that was traditionally in English. It departed from the usual travel, human interest, and lifestyle segments of magazine programs by featuring disturbing issues and current affairs with clear standpoint and opinion on the topics. It also engaged in a more in-depth, innovative, or unconventional treatment of socio-cultural or historical phenomena.

Isip Pinoy became a test to the so-called democratic space of the Cory Aquino government when one of its episodes entitled “Ang Maralitang Tagalunsod” (The Urban Poor), directed by Bernal, was banned by the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB) and labeled as “communist propaganda” in May 1987. The MTRCB headed by Manoling Morato demanded that its producers air the side of the government about issues of informal settlers in Tondo. The censorship became a rallying point of artists and media led by the Concerned Artists of the Philippines with Lino Brocka, Behn Cervantes, and Pete Lacaba. They denounced the said censorship as a resurgence of martial law repression. The urban poor, religious, and other sectors joined the rallies against the censorship of the episode.

Some Isip Pinoy episodes included peace talks between the government and the underground National Democratic Front, the 1987 Mendiola massacre, the situation of farmers in the country, the social ills brought by the US military bases in the country, the situation of Filipino women, Puerto Galera’s sex tourism, close encounter with a torero and torera (live sex performers), the conditions of prisoners in government jails, and the health situation in the Philippines. It also featured sociocultural and art topics such as episodes on Filipino-Americans, Botong Francisco and the social realists, original Pilipino music, the lives of senior citizens, and urban life.

Isip Pinoy received the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1987 and the award for Best Magazine Show in the 2nd Star Awards for Television by the Philippine Movie Press Club in 1988. Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

Sources:

Dela Torre and Nicolas 1987; "The Isip Pinoy Issue..." 1987; Paz 2015.

text:
ISPUP(Spoof) 20 Mar 1999 to 27 Mar 2004, Saturdays, then Fridays beginning 23 Nov 2001, ABC 5. Executive Producer: Mon del Rosario Torres. Associate Producer: Marizel Reyes. Executive In-charge of Production: Vivian C. Recio. Creative Consultant: Ronnie Tumbokon. Director: Al Quinn. Cast: Willie Nepomuceno, Leo Martinez, Jon Santos, Candy Pangilinan, Mystica, Marissa Sanchez, Joy Viado, Selena Sanchez, Ruffa Mae Quinto, Madeleine Nicolas, Selina Sevilla, and the Ispupniks: Mike Nacua aka Pekto, Ate Gay, Ate Shawie, Hyubz Azarcon, Cynthia Marquez.

Ispup (Spoof) is a weekly one-hour lampoon show that pokes fun at politicians, public figures, current events, television programs, advertising commercials, and other forms of popular culture.

The program has served as a venue for irreverence and satire during one of the roughest times of Philippine politics. Some national issues parodied included government officials’ secret offshore bank deposits, the workings of the Hong Kong drug triad in the Philippines, police officers doubling as drug lords and their headquarters resembling a drug den, offensive high prices of basic commodities, the Abu Sayyaf and their hostages, the antics of elective officials, and the Senate hearings on scandals. Scripts, often culled from headlines, usually undergo updating even during taping time.

It also lampooned TV commercials, to the extent that some companies reportedly approached the show to be parodied for a fee. Ispup reportedly received complaints from politicians and advertisers that the program has offended.

Memorable performances were those involving the caricature of political personalities, such as Nepomuceno’s Sherap Entrada for Pres Erap Estrada, His Eminems Jaime Cardinal Sins for Archbishop Jaime Cardinal Sin, Nur Miswa for Moro National Liberation Front (MILF) chair Nur Misuari, and Ramon Revillame orBong Gabilla for action star and senator Ramon Revilla combined with host-comedian Willie Revillame; Pangilinan’s Tita Cory Pepino and Gloring Macabagal-Barroyo for presidents Cory Aquino and Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo, respectively, and Senator KorenorLoren Lagarista for Senator Loren Legarda; and Quintos’s Kris Pepino for presidential daughter Kris Aquino. text:
JOHN EN MARSHA(John and Marsha) May 1973 to 30 Jul 1990, 8:00-9:00 pm, Thursdays, RPN 9. Directors: Ading Fernando, Al Quinn. Writer: Ading Fernando. Mainstay actors: Dolphy (John Puruntong), Nida Blanca (Marsha Puruntong), Dely Atay-atayan (Doña Delilah G. Jones), Maricel Soriano (Shirley Puruntong), Rolly Quizon (Rolly J. Puruntong), Evelyn Bontogon-Guerrero (Matutina), Isko Salvador (Isko).

John en Marsha was a consistently top-rating weekly primetime situational comedy (sitcom) about the daily life of poverty-stricken John Puruntong and his family. It aired a total of 405 episodes in its 17-year run on Philippine television.

The sitcom reflects in a humorous way the life of the typical working class family. Each episode revolves around John Puruntong striving to get his family by. He is the happy-go-lucky family man who does not take life seriously as long as the family lives happily under one roof. John’s patient wife, Marsha, sheds her elite origins, puts on her squatter-area duster, and holds nothing against life in spite of their poverty. Their teenaged son, Rolly, is content in having girls constantly swooning over him, while daughter, Shirley, is often engrossed in her school assignments. John keeps on refusing to accept financial help offered by his wealthy, overweight, condescending mother-in-law Doña Delilah, whose sidekick help, Matutina, scrutinizes every nook and cranny of John’s dilapidated house. Once in a while, neighborhood store keeper and Shirley’s suitor, Isko, pays John’s family a visit. Each episode ends with Doña Delilah humorously insulting John and screaming her advice to her financially challenged son-in-law, “Kaya ikaw, John, magsumikap ka!” (So, John, try even harder!), which became a household catchphrase among audiences of the period.

For many audiences and some critics, the show inspired optimism among viewers on their personal situation and provided comic relief to Filipinos during the time of martial law. Others, however, believe that the caricature of economically poor Filipinos as lazy or not industrious enough to make both ends meet, particularly in the case of John Puruntong, discounts institutional and structural deficiencies in Philippine society that render them poor in the first place, almost always barred from opportunities to rise above their conditions, and only shifts the blame on fate and the individual rather than on the responsibility of the government to provide the citizens with basic social services. Other common criticisms against the show are its paper-thin predictable plots, extended and dragging sequences, old tricks that rely heavily on enthusiastic acting rather than on characterization, sloppy directing, and simplistic solutions to the impoverished life of Filipinos living then under conditions of martial rule.

The success of John en Marsha, in terms of audience reception and commercial success in the ratings game, has made it a template for succeeding family sitcoms. Dolphy starred in similar sitcoms such as Home along da Riles (Home along the Railroad), 1992-2003, and a sequel entitled Home along da Airport (Home along the Airport), 2003-05, both on ABS-CBN, that presented humorous day-to-day experiences of poor families of informal settlers.

The sitcom later on produced nine movie sequels: JohnenMarshasa Pelikula(John and Marsha in a movie), 1974; JohnenMarsha Part Twosa Amerika(John and Marsha Part Two in America), 1975; JohnenMarsha ‘77 (John and Marsha ’77), 1977; JohnenMarsha ‘80 (John and Marsha ’80) 1980; DaBest of JohnenMarsha (The Best of John and Marsha), 1983; DaBest of JohnenMarsha 2 (The Best of John and Marsha 2), 1984; JohnenMarsha ‘85sa Probinsya(John and Marsha in the Province), 1985; JohnenMarsha T.N.T.sa Amerika, (John and Marsha T.N.T. in America), 1986; and JohnenMarshaNgayong‘91 (John and Marsha this 1991), 1991. There was also a spin-off, titled John en Shirley, 2006, ABS-CBN, with John (Dolphy) and daughter Shirley (Soriano) as the only returning actors from the original cast. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Karyll Faye D. Katigbak

text:
JOSE RIZAL: ANG BUHAY NG ISANG BAYANI(Jose Rizal: The Life of a Hero) 1996, Knowledge Channel. Producers: The Bookmark, Inc and History Department, Ateneo de Manila University. Executive Producer: Jose Ma. Lorenzo Tan. Producer: Stella Chiu. Associate Producer: Jose M. Cruz, SJ. Director: Butch Nolasco. Scriptwriter: Jose Bernard T. Capino. Director of Photography: Vincent Craft. Production Designer: Gino Gonzales. Production Manager: Maxi Cajayon. Technical Director and Editor: Rudy Barcenas. Original Music: Gerdie Francisco. Historical Researcher: Noelle Rodriguez. Actor: Pen Medina. Host: Joonee Gamboa.

Produced on the centennial anniversary of Jose Rizal’s death, Jose Rizal: Ang Buhay ng Isang Bayani (Jose Rizal: The Life of a Hero) is a documentary on the life of the Philippine hero, played by Medina. The documentary mixes episodic reenactments, animated graphics, voiceover, and footage of Rizal mementoes, photographs, and icons.

Like other Rizal films in the 1990s, the centennial decade of Philippine independence, the documentary portrays the “human” Rizal, “ang puso at kaluluwa ng isang dakilang Filipino sa loob ng rebulto sa Luneta” (the heart and soul of the great Filipino inside the statue in Luneta), “nakaukit sa pisong barya” (etched on the one-peso coin). It is divided into five parts. Rizal’s childhood and family life are depicted in “Ang Batang si Moy Mercado” (The Child Moy Mercado). His precocity is sketched in “Jose Rizal Mercado: Atenistang Probinsyano” (Jose Rizal Mercado: A Country Bumpkin in Ateneo). His travels around the world and his studies are detailed in “Patungo sa Liwanag ng Dunong at Daigdig” (Into the Light of Knowledge and the World). The troubles he had to face for his writings and political activities are chronicled in “Ang Lakbayin Patungo sa Ligalig” (The Journey Toward Tribulation). His trials, days in prison, and execution are portrayed in “Dapithapon at Dilim” (Twilight and Darkness).

The documentary is unlike other biographic films on Rizal, which usually dramatize his life with a mixture of historical facts and anecdotes to create a coherent artistic whole. It is, instead, based on and structured around Rizal’s own words translated into Filipino, culled from his extant writings, including his diaries, correspondences, essays, and creative works.

Ang Buhay ng Isang Bayani won the Best TV Special Award in the 9th Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1996. It was disseminated in video cassette format for educational use, and remains a part of the programming of local cable Knowledge Channel. Bookmark published the documentary teleplay in 1996. Written by Patrick F. Campos

text:
THE KOLYNOS HOUR1936-41, twice a week, KZRM. Sponsor: Kolynos Toothpaste.

This jazz program aired twice a week for 15 minutes and featured Presentacion Bataclan, who was 13 when she began singing jazz numbers live on the air, and pianists Rafael Artigas and Ariston Avelino. The program was immensely popular, with Bataclan receiving an average of 100 fan mail letters a week, including a few marriage proposals. Some of the mail came from the United States and several Asian countries since KZRM aired both on longwave and shortwave, like other Manila-based radio stations during the American colonial period, allowing its signals to be monitored internationally. Another indicator of the show’s fame was Bataclan’s talent fee, 15 pesos per performance or 30 pesos a week, at a time when other radio performers received one peso per show.

KZRM gave Bataclan the on-air name Priscilla. After some time, the station and her fans began calling her The Kolynos Girl. She sang mostly American jazz numbers and ballads. The program did not go back on the air after the war, but Priscilla’s popularity brought her and her husband, saxophonist Narding Aristorenas, all over Europe and Asia performing in jazz shows. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Enriquez 2008.

KUH BY SPECIAL ARRANGEMENTOct 1986-May 1987, 9:30-10:30 pm, Tuesdays, IBC 13. Producer: Headline Concept, Inc. Director: Mitos Villareal. Musical Director: Rey Cristobal. Scriptwriter: Leo Katigbak. Host: Kuh Ledesma.

Kuh by Special Arrangement was a weekly television special that paid tribute to composers of Original Pilipino Music (OPM) and selected foreign songwriters. The compositions of these artists were performed by Kuh Ledesma, either as a solo singer or with guests.

Each episode featured one composer. Ledesma performs one song of the guest composer in the first segment of the program, then introduces the songwriter, who Ledesma interviews between production numbers. The composer or invited singers join Ledesma in interpreting the songs of the guest songwriter. Featured composers included George Canseco, Ryan Cayabyab, Willy Cruz, and Rey Valera.

Each episode was shot either in a studio or on location. With the help of a creative team, Ledesma herself took charge of the overall production of the show, including the look of the location, the costumes of performers, the identification of featured guests, the selection of songs, and the production numbers.

Kuh by Special Arrangement won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon, 1987, and the Best Musical Television Program in the Catholic Mass Media Awards, 1986 and 1987. Written by Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

KULTURA NG BAYAN(Culture of the People) 1986-92, DZRV Radio Veritas, then 1992-96, DZRM Radyo Magasin. Host: Mon Ilagan. Head Writer and Music Producer: Rody Vera. Producer: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

This was a weekly radio show about Philippine arts and culture that featured music, a discussion on the state of Philippine arts, theatrical performances, and balagtasan (poetic joust) (See index Balagtasan). The theatrical performances were based on plays written by Filipino playwrights like Nick Joaquin’sA Portrait of the Artist as Filipino (Ang Larawan ng Artista Bilang Pilipino), translated toFilipino and produced by Tanghalang Pilipino.

Among the mambabalagtas (poetic debaters) in the balagtasan, called Pambansang Balagtasan (National Poetic Debate), were Teo Antonio,Apolonio Marquez, Yolanda Rambuyon, and Alberto Suallo, who tackled issues posed by poet and essayist Bienvenido Ramos such asNakabubuti o Nakasasama ba sa Lipunan ng Bansa Ang Pagdadala ng Entertainers Abroad? (Does it Benefit the Country to Send Entertainers Abroad or Not?), andAlin ang Higit na Magpapabilis sa Economic Recovery ng Bansa: Pag-asa sa Tulong ng Dayuhan o Pagtindig sa Sarili (Which Will Hasten the Country’s Economic Recovery More, Foreign Aid or Self-reliance?); C.C. Marquez’sDapat bang Sunugin ang Mga Armas na Ilegal ang Pagkaangkat(Should Illegally Imported Arms be Burned?) andDapat ba ang Imports sa PBA [Philippine Basketball Association]? text:
LANDMARKS2011-15, 7:00 pm, Sundays, Net25 TV. Producer: Eagle Broadcasting Corporation. Host: Faye De Castro-Umandal.

Landmarks is a television travel magazine program that features the history and culture of the Philippines. The show highlights the stories and histories of a featured place. In the travelogue, places are not just appreciated for their tourist value but also for the community’s rich tapestry of history and anecdotes that explain how the community came to be what it is today. Landmarks not only raises the importance of retelling community histories and preserving cultural material and non-material heritage, it also helps peoplebecome more appreciative of the vital landmarks and placesin the Philippines.

Landmarks won Best Magazine Show in the 9th Gawad Tanglaw in 2010, Best Arts and Culture Program in the 20th Golden Dove Award of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas in 2011, Best Lifestyle and Travel Show in the 26th Star Awards for Television of the Philippine Movie Press Club in 2012, and an Anak TV Seal Award in 2009, 2010, 2012, 2013, 2014. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
LISTERINE AMATEUR HOUR1936, 9:00 pm, Thursdays, KZRM. Sponsor: Listerine. Musical Director: Ariston Avelino. Audition Master: Arturo Lagasca. Host: Harry Fenton.

An amateur singing contest and pioneer program of its kind, Listerine Amateur Hour inspired several amateur singing contests in the following decades both on radio and television, such as Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) and Hamon sa Kampeon (Challenge to the Champion). It began as Amateur Hour until the consumer product Listerine, a toothpaste, sponsored it and appended its name to the program title, as was the custom until several years after the war.

Station manager Johnny Harris, a Filipino-American, ran the competition by giving away 100 audition passes each week. Preliminary auditions of pass holders were held on Monday and Thursday mornings, from whom 12 were selected to perform live on the following Thursday night. Winners, who received cash and other prizes, were determined through letters, phone calls, and three judges who were hidden from the performers. When a performance failed to meet the standards set by the judges, they would simultaneously press a button that operated a gong. The sound of the copper gong meant the elimination of the contestant from the competition. As one of the station’s most popular programs, it launched the careers of several singers, such as the tenor Don David.

American Harry Fenton emceed the program, wearing the Filipino shirt barong tagalog and a buri hat. Radio performers of the period dressed for their shows as fans regularly provided live studio audiences. Fenton took on the alias Baron Unterheisen, a copy of American radio host Jack Pearl who was known in the United States as Baron Munchausen.

When Fenton moved to Cebu to run KZRC in 1939, he produced the Cebuano version of Listerine Amateur Hour, held also on Thursdays at the Plaza Independencia. It became one of KZRC’s most popular programs, with more than 5000 people flocking to the Plaza to listen to Fenton and comedian Leonardo Gutierrez, who hit the gong for unsuccessful amateurs. After the broadcast in Cebu was interrupted by war from 1942 until the declaration of Philippine Independence in 1946, Amateur Hour resumed airing on KZRC with a different sponsor, Purico, a cooking lard. It was then called Purico Amateur Hour. In Manila, another amateur singing contest had the same title and sponsor. The show was renamed Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) in 1953. Divine Marie Joanne P. Endriga, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Aniceto 2007; Enriquez 2008; "Gong: The Amateur..." 1936; Trinidad 1967; Vamenta 2008.

text:
A LITTLE NIGHT OF MUSICJuly 1989-2001, 10:00-11:00 pm, then 11:00 pm to midnight, then midnight to 1:00 am, Sundays, GMA. Producer: Rebecca Cabrera. Director: Dick Zamora. Writer: Isah V. Red. Pianist: Rey Paguio. Host: Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. Co-hosts: John Lesaca, Jong Cuenco, both later replaced by Leo Martinez.

A Little Night of Music was a weekly cultural musical show that featured opera, Filipino, Broadway, and popular music. It was a revival of the TV noontime show Sunday, Sweet Sunday, 1969-74, on ABS-CBN. The idea to re-introduce the program to a new generation of viewers came from opera singer Asensio and Rey Paguio, musician and then Dean of the College of Music of the University of the Philippines (UP).

The program showcased Filipino and visiting foreign music artists, including choral groups, who guested in the program for free. Artists who were featured include sopranos Camille Lopez-Molina and Margarita Gomez-Giannelli, guitarist Lester Demetillo, flautist Sonny Yangco, vocal stylists Eileen Cura and Jai Sabas, viola player Uwe Schmelter, the Athenaeum String Quartet, the UP Concert Chorus, and the Bayanihan Dance Company. It also introduced then budding talents Donna Yrastoza, Ogie Alcasid, Lani Misalucha, Ariel Rivera, and Iwi Laurel. Some of the show’s episodes featured excerpts from musical theater and films, such as Cats, Man of La Mancha, and Wizard of Oz. It also introduced musical instruments from China, India, and other Asian countries.

The program’s weekly budget of 30,000 pesos was way below that of GMA’s flagship program then, Vilma, which enjoyed a weekly budget of 100,000 pesos. Fides’s husband, Manuel, had to buy a grand piano to lessen their rental fees and the hassle of bringing and pulling out the instrument from the studio every week. The network moved its time slot from its initial 10:00 to 11:00 pm, and finally to midnight before it went off the air after 12 years of broadcast. Written by Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

Sources:

Cuyugan-Asensio 2014; Lopez 1991; San Diego 2012.

LOBO(Werewolf) 28 Jan-11 Jul 2008, evening primetime, Mondays to Fridays, ABS-CBN. Concept: Mark Anthony Bunda. Executive in Charge of Production: Malou Santos. Executive in Charge of Creative: Olive Lamasan. Production Manager: Annaliza A. Goma. Creative Manager: Ricky Lee. Executive Producers: Myleen Ongkiko, Desirey F. Juan. Creative Consultant: Felinda Bagas. Directors: FM Reyes, Cathy Garcia-Molina, Jerry Lopez Sineneng. Head Writer: Felinda Bagas. Writers: Rose Colindres, Tanya Winona Bautista, Arah Jell Badayos, Mark Angos. Production Designers: Eduardo Jacinto, Noel Teehankee, Buboy Gatdula. Art Directors: Melchor Defensor, Melissa Mae Chua, Niño Bustamante. Lead Editor: Froilan Francia. Editors: George Padolina Jr, Michael Mariñas, Sidney Zaid Pascua, Bernie Diasanta, Ray-an Ludwig Peralta, Brehn John de Leon. Computer Graphics: Karl Myshle, Monax Moreno, Jeremiah Parungganan. VFX Head: Leonard Barbin. VFX Supervisor: Tadeo Antonio Belen. Lead Compositor: Aldo Aguilar, Melvin Guinto, Joan Cabrera. 3D: Edsel Yanga, Ron Tinapay, Vince Cheng. Special Make-up and Prosthetic Artists: Joe Lapeña, Bactotoy. Make-up Artists: Michael Bawa, Gigi Gatlabayan, Victor Gregorio, Junice Mayo. Main Cast: Angel Locsin (Lyka Raymundo), Piolo Pascual (Noah Ortega), Ryan Eigenmann (Anton Rivero), Geoff Eigenmann (Alec Aragon/Remus), Pilar Pilapil (Eleanor Blancaflor), Dante Rivero (Gen. Leon Cristobal), Agot Isidro (Nessa Raymundo), Robert Arevalo (Don Manolo Sebastian), Shaina Magdayao (Gabrielle Dizon), Dimples Romana (Trixie), Irma Adlawan (Clara Rivero).

Lobo is a fantasy series about childhood friends Lyka Raymundo and Noah Ortega who were separated during a childhood accident and grew up believing that the other was dead. Lyka works as an assistant to fashion designer Eleanor Blancaflor at the House of Elle, hoping one day to become a designer herself. Behind her delicate and sensuous exterior is a dark secret: Lyka is a werewolf and is involved with the Waya, the protector and defender of the werewolf race. Noah Ortega is a Second Lieutenant in the Philippine Army and a member of Luna, a secret army group that aims to eradicate the werewolves.

Years later, Lyka’s and Noah’s paths cross when Noah, now a robust soldier, saves Don Manolo Sebastian, owner of the House of Elle, from a kidnap group. Manolo hires Noah as a bodyguard after the young soldier is discharged from military service. Unknown to the businessman, Noah is involved in a covert operation for Luna, which suspects that the House of Elle may have ties to the Waya. Lyka meets Noah and they fall in love, as strangers. They eventually figure out that they are the same individuals who sought comfort in each other during their childhood. Gabrielle Dizon, Noah’s mistah and best friend who secretly loves Noah and who is a deep penetration agent, and Anton Rivero, a chemist who is in love with Lyka, are the obstacles to the blossoming romance between Lyka and Noah.

Lobo examines the complexity of love in the midst of uncertainty and duty. Both Lyka and Noah are affiliated with warring groups and their feelings for one another conflict with the roles that society and nature have assigned to them. Nessa, Lyka’s mother, leaves romance and family behind to fulfill a mysterious and fascinating life as a wolf and to secure the safety of her daughter. Lyka is firm about saving her race but, unlike her mother, explores life as a wolf without giving up love. Lyka and Noah are fighting to change the scourge of their past and the uncertainty of their destinations.

Because of the success of this fantasy drama in the ratings, the network produced Imortal (Immortal), 2010-11, as a sequel, starring Locsin again, this time as the daughter of her character and that of Pascual in the prequel, and John Lloyd Cruz who played a vampire who was drawn to Locsin’s werewolf character. Lobo won the Rockie Award for the Telenovela in the Banff World Television Festival in Canada in 2009. It was awarded the Ani ng Dangal for Multimedia by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2010. The series is also the first Filipino telenovela to be dubbed and aired in Thailand. Written by Amor Olaguer and Miguel S.O. Aljibe

text:
LOVINGLY YOURS, HELEN1980-83, weekdays, DZBB radio; 1983, Sunday afternoons, GMA 7; 1984, BBC 2 while the radio program moved to DWOK; 1986-96, DZBB and GMA 7. Producers: Redgie Acuña-Magno and Helen Vela, 1980-92; Princess Punzalan, 1992-96. Creator: Hyper Visions Productions Inc. Director: Argel Joseph.

The popular drama anthology was based on the real lives of letter senders. Hosted and narrated by Helen Vela, nicknamed in the 1980s the Queen of Sunday Afternoon TV, the program’s narratives conveyed traditional family values. The letter senders, addressing Vela as Tita Helen, asked for her advice on problems with family, love and relationships. The stories of hardships and challenges of well-known persons are among the memorable episodes, such as those of actors who themselves hosted their own television drama anthologies like Maricel Soriano of The Maricel Drama Special and Coney Reyes of Coney Reyes on Camera.

Vela dispensed advice in both the radio and television versions of the program, and appeared as narrator in the movie anthology. When she passed away on Valentine’s Day in 1992, her daughter Princess Punzalan replaced her as host and narrator of the drama series, followed by Boots Anson-Roa and Helen Gamboa.

Following the end of the program in Sep 1996 until Nov 1996, GMA 7 aired a collection of its most memorable episodes dubbed Lovingly Yours, Helen: The Classics.

Lovingly Yours, Helen received the 1987 and 1989 Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon and the 1992 KBP Golden Dove Award as Best Drama Program. Written by Peter Lawrence Escobar

Sources:

Bough 2010; "Mysterious Death of Julie Vega" 2013; Wikipedia 2014h.

text:
LUCIA1992. Executive Producer: Peter Firstbrook for Manila Inter-Film and the British Broadcasting Corporation. Director: Mel Chionglo. Writer: Lino Brocka, Ricardo Lee. Director of Photography: Rody Lacap. Editor: Jesus Navarro. Production Design: Edgar Littaua. Music: Max Jocson. Actors: Lolita Rodriguez (Lucia), Gina Alajar, Suzette Ranillo, Elvira Baldomero, William Lorenzo. Distributor: Bullfrog Films.

Originally produced for the BBC television series Developing Stories: Environment and Development Series, Brocka was supposed to direct this television drama. He had submitted the script, and eventually won in a BBC competition on the environment. Brocka, however, died in a vehicular accident on 21 May 1991 in the middle of the project’s preproduction. The producers approached Mel to work on the project.

The movie drama-for-TV chronicles the real story of a Filipino woman and her family who leave their fishing village in Bataan in Central Luzon after an oil spill and move to a community in the outskirts of Manila. It presents the strong willed mother, Lucia, struggling to keep her family together in the midst of terrorism, crime, corruption, and the never-ending threat of eviction from their community. It narrates the passionate effort and pains of the mother to keep her children from falling prey to the dangerous life of the city.

Several social forces, however, make her powerless and eventually force her and her family to move to the slums in the heart of Manila. The last sequence is a powerful scene of a family walking toward Smokey Mountain, the epitome and symbol of poverty during the Marcos dictatorship. Lucia is carrying an image of the Virgin Mary, her entire family in tow, ready to face the new challenges city life has to offer.

Lucia was shown in various festivals abroad but never in commercial theaters in the Philippines. Instead it had several exclusive screenings, such as those at the UP Film Center on 16 Feb 1997 and 25 Jan 2000. It was also aired on different television networks in the Philippines. It won best picture at the London Environmental Film Festival in 1992; the best developing country production award in the Ökomedia Film Festival, an international environment film festival in Germany; the premier award from One World Broadcasting Trust; and best drama special from the Philippine Movie Press Club, all in the early 1990s. Written by Michael B. Makri and Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

Sources:

Carballo 2008; "Lucia" n.d.a, n.d.b.

Instead it had several exclusive screenings, such as those at the UP Film Center on 16 Feb 1997 and 25 Jan 2000. It was also aired on different television networks in the Philippines. It won best picture at the London Environmental Film Festival in 1992; the best developing country production award in the Ökomedia Film Festival, an international environment film festival in Germany; the premier award from One World Broadcasting Trust; and best drama special from the Philippine Movie Press Club, all in the early 1990s. Written by Michael B. Makri and Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel
