text:
(Will You Remember) Since 13 May 1991, ABS-CBN, 7:15-8:45 pm, Saturdays; DZMM, 12:30-1:00 pm, Mondays to Fridays. Producer and host: Charo Santos-Concio. Selected directors: Lino Brocka, Raz de la Torre, Wenn V. Deramas, Rory B. Quintos, Olivia M. Lamasan, Brillante Mendoza, Jeffrey Jeturian. Selected writers: Dado C. Lumibao, Lindsay Anne A. Dizon, Fe Catherine A. San Pablo, Maria Nina Christine Luareano, Rose Ann Guimbangunan. Selected actors: Eula Valdez, Ricky Davao, Cherry Pie Picache, Rio Locsin, Joel Torre, Gina Pareño, Gardo Versoza, Albert Martinez, Carlo Aquino, Jean Garcia, Jodi Sta. Maria, Romnick Sarmenta, Tirso Cruz III, Nora Aunor, Vilma Santos.

Maalaala Mo Kaya (MMK) is a weekly television drama anthology that features true-to-life stories of ordinary Filipinos based on letters sent by the viewers themselves. Stories about and by celebrities, politicians, and noted personalities, on the other hand, are chosen by the production team. The stories revolve around domestic issues, life choices, and the unforgettable struggles of Filipinos. The drama conveys hopeful messages such as love of God, faith in the family, and values like resilience, courage, and joyfulness. Episodes of the drama are always inspirational, making sure that good always triumphs over evil in spite of the characters’ difficult circumstances.

Each episode begins with a letter reading by the host, followed by the narrative. The host periodically appears in between sequences, reading the letter, which provides the continuity of the sequences. Each episode ends with the host providing anecdotes and insights from the dramatized experiences of the letter sender. The show’s theme music is based on the popular habanera of the same title, originally composed by renowned music artist Constancio de Guzman for the movie of the same title, 1954, and first sung for the program by Dulce, then by Carol Banawa beginning in the early 2000s.

The creation of MMK began in 1988 when Santos-Concio signed film director Lino Brocka to do a 13-part drama series for ABS-CBN. Brocka managed to finish only three episodes because of his untimely death in 1991. The network decided to air the three dramas in 1991, with MMK as the show’s title. Since the episodes got rave reviews from critics, the station decided to continue producing the series.

The first episode, “Rubber Shoes,” was about a young student who is ashamed of his poor origins. His father, a street sweeper, works hard to meet the luxurious lifestyle of his son. The son realizes too late that money does not make a man happy.

Some notable episodes of MMK include “Sako” (Sack), about a child forced by his father to work as a sugarcane plantation worker; “Regalo” (Gift), about a mother who divides her time between work and taking care of her daughter who has cerebral palsy; “Pier 39” (Port 39), about the struggles of a young man, who is petitioned by his father to the USA and meets a young woman who helps him pick up the pieces of his life; “Baul” (Chest), about how two women save their friendship in spite of the man who came between them; “Sa Kandungan Mo, Inay” (On Your Lap, Mother), about how two sisters cope with the cruelty of their mother (Anita Linda); “Retaso” (aka Remnant), about how a widower’s second wife tries to win the love of her husband’s children; “Cap,” about Filipino World War II veterans living in San Francisco and their fight for equal benefits in the land of milk and honey; “Apron,” about the struggles of a young couple pursuing their dream of a good life in the USA; “Letters,” about a newly divorced woman finding love again; “Car,” which narrates the friendship between a Filipino caregiver and a patient with Parkinson’s disease; “Tungkod” (aka Palawan), about a mother who fights to stop mining in Palawan; “Susi” (Key), the story of a Filipino cross-dresser living in Barcelona, Spain and his struggle to be accepted by his father; “Passbook,” about a single parent who works in Japan to support her five children; and “Rehas” (Prison Bars), about a mother taking care of her three mentally sick children.

On MMK’s third-year anniversary, Star Cinema produced a film version of the drama anthology, titled Maalaala Mo Kaya: The Movie (Would You Remember: The Movie), 1994, directed by Olivia Lamasan, about a young girl who takes on the responsibility of being the mother to the son of her cousin (Chin Chin Gutierrez) who goes to Japan to work as an entertainer.

The program’s radio version, Maalaala Mo Kaya sa DZMM (Will You Remember on DZMM), started running daily on Mar 2007, also hosted by Santos-Concio. The radio program was later replaced by MMK Klasiks (MMK Classics), which re-airs past episodes of the show and broadcast on DZMM TeleRadyo. Bituin Komiks produced a comic book adaptation of MMK, with its initial issue released on 27 Mar 2008. ABS-CBN soon followed by producing the Maalaala Mo Kaya Romance Paperback novels, which featured romantic stories from the television program.

MMK won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1995; the best television drama in the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) in 2001, 2007, 2009, and 2010, and the CMMA Hall of Fame Award in 2011; best television drama anthology in the Star Awards for TV of the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC) in 1992 and every year from 2000 to 2010, and the PMPC Hall of Fame Award in 2011; and outstanding single drama in the Golden Screen TV Awards of the Entertainment Press Society in 2013 and 2014. MMK sa DZMM won best radio drama in the Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas in 2007, and in the CMMA in 2007, 2009, and 2014.

MMK’s actors won awards in the PMPC Star Awards for TV. The Star Awards for best single performance was won by Jericho Rosales for “Pasa” (Bruise), 1998; Michael de Mesa for “Parol” (Lantern), 2001; Roderick Paulate for “Bituin” (Star), 2004; Baron Geisler for “Trolley,” 2005; Carlo Aquino for “Scapular,” 2006, and “Pulang Laso” (Red Ribbon), 2013; Piolo Pascual for “Piso” (Peso), 2007; Joshua Dionisio for “Sako,” 2008; Joross Gamboa for “Bisikleta” (Bicycle), 2009; Gerald Anderson for “Lubid” (Rope), 2010; Enchong Dee for “Parol” (Lantern), 2011; Nonie Buencamino for “Sapatos” (Shoes), 2012; Arjo Atayde for “Dos Por Dos” (Two By Two), 2014; and John Lloyd Cruz for “Hat,” 2015. The Star Awards for best single performance by an actress was won by Vilma Santos for “Regalo,” 2006; Gina Pareño for “Rehas,” 2007; Angel Locsin for “Pilat” (Scar), 2008; Gretchen Barretto for “Salamin” (Mirror), 2009, and “Larawan” (Portrait), 2010; Ai-Ai de las Alas for “Krus” (Cross), 2011; Sylvia Sanchez for “Aswang” (Malevolent Being), 2012; Nikki Gil for “Ilog” (River), 2013; Sunshine Cruz for “Karayom” (Needle), 2014, and “Barko” (Ship), 2015; and Judy Ann Santos for “Ilog” (River), 2015.

In the Asian Television Awards, MMK won best single drama in 2001, best director for Jerry Sineneng for “Rehas” in 2008, and its actors won best performance awards, including Roderick Paulate for “Abo” (Ash), 1996, and “Wristwatch,” 2000; Raymond Bagatsing for “Wedding Ring,” 2001; Aiza Seguerra for “Songbook,” 2002; Eula Valdez for “Eatery,” 2004; and Gina Pareño for “Rehas,” 2008. “Rehas” also won the Special Award in Drama at the Seoul International Drama Awards in 2008. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III and Yna Marei Aguilar

text:
MAMA

 

1992-93, 8:00 pm, Wednesdays, IBC 13. Producer: Sunny E. de Guzman. Executive Producer: Sonia de Guzman. Director: Mario O’Hara. Head Writer: Lualhati Bautista. Host: Barbara Perez.

 

A weekly drama anthology, Mama is an intelligent examination of mothers in the Philippine context. It veers away from the usual depiction of a lachrymose martyr who is often unable to contextualize and comprehend the social situations in which she is immersed. The drama avoids character stereotypes and situations, and offers credible and realistic stories revolving around emotional, psychological, marital, and other family conflicts. Critic Isagani R. Cruz describes the program as “well-written, well-acted, well-designed, and well-directed, disturbing but entertaining.” Writtenby Ralph Jake T. Wabingga and Michael B. Makri

17 Aug 1992 to 14 Feb 1997, 2:30 pm, then 2:00 pm, then primetime slot at 7:00 pm, weekdays, ABS-CBN. Concept: Emil Cruz Jr. Executive Producer: Annaliza A. Goma. Producer: Maru R. Benitez. Writer: Emil Cruz Jr. Director: Emil Cruz Jr. Main Cast: Judy Ann Santos (Mara Davis/Mara del Valle), Gladys Reyes (Clara del Valle/Clara Davis). Supporting cast: Juan Rodrigo (Amanthe del Valle), Beverly Vergel (Almira del Valle), Eruel Tongco (Gary Davis), Susan Africa (Susan Davis), Dan Fernandez (Kardo), Noel Colet (Enrico), Wowie De Guzman (Christian), Rico Yan (Derick), Eagle Riggs (CG), Christopher Roxas (Erris), Paolo Contis (Jepoy), Angelika Dela Cruz (Joyce), Minnie Aguilar (Lagring), Leni Santos (Lenita), Anita Linda (Pacita).

Mara Clara is a daily soap opera that revolves around the story of two rival girls who have been switched at birth by a hospital staff named Kardo. Mara grew up as the kind-hearted daughter of poverty-stricken parents Gary and Susan Davis, while Clara—the real daughter of the Davis couple—became the spoiled child of the good-natured Amanthe and Almira del Valle, Mara’s biological parents.

The benevolent Del Valle couple takes Mara in as their housemaid, even paying for her education, not knowing that she is their real daughter. Contrary to the good nature of her parents, Clara constantly abuses Mara. At the same time, Mara is also being maltreated by her father Gary, who only uses her so that he can gain money from the Del Valles. In the end, the characters finally learn about their real identities and end up where they truly belong.

The intense melodrama of Mara Clara characterized by the blunt physicality between the two lead characters during emotional fight scenes, often in the form of face-slapping, popularized Judy Ann Santos and Gladys Reyes as the ultimate bida and kontrabida, respectively. For years to come, the two actresses would often be typecast in similar roles.

Mara Clara holds the title for being the longest-running daily soap opera in the history of television, having run for four and a half years. It is also the first TV series to be adapted into a film by Star Cinema. Mara Clara: The Movie, produced in 1996, starred the same ensemble of actors, except William Martinez who replaced Tongco in the role of Gary.

In 2010, 18 years after the series’ pilot episode, ABS-CBN produced a remake in celebration of the network’s “60 Years of Soap Opera,” starring Kathryn Bernardo and Julia Montes for the roles of Mara and Clara, respectively. While the show ranked high in viewer ratings, it lasted for only seven months. Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya

article_title: Marcelino, Pan y Vino: Alamat o Milagro?
text:
MARCELINO, PAN Y VINO: ALAMAT O MILAGRO?

(Marcelino, Bread and Wine: Legend or Miracle?) 11 Apr 1979, BBC 2, 7:30-9:00 pm. Director and Writer: Mario O’Hara. Actors: Romnick Sarmenta (Marcelino), Subas Herrero (friar), Sandy Garcia, Pepe Pimentel.

The drama is a TV adaptation of the Spanish novel Marcelino, Pan y Vino, 1952, by Jose Maria Sanchez-Silva, which was made into a movie by Ladislao Vajda in 1955. Marcelino is an abandoned, naughty boy raised by Franciscan friars. He discovers a life-sized image of the crucified Christ in a prohibited place in the monastery, an image he does not recognize as that of the Lord. He pities the suffering Man, whom he offers bread and wine in his subsequent visits. The statue takes and eats the bread given him by Marcelino. The Lord rewards his kindness by granting his wish to see his and the Lord’s mother. The wooden Jesus figure cradles Marcelino in its arms and tells him to sleep. Marcelino dies happy in his sleep.

In O’Hara’s adaptation, Marcelino is presented as a weak and sickly child who often hallucinates, justifying the boy’s encounters with Christ in the form of imaginative prayers. He withdraws from people, yet is mischievous in some instances. In his imaginative encounters with Christ, the narrative blurs the line between the imagined and the real, leaving the viewers to decide whether the story is a myth or a miracle. The elegiac narrative, as described by Torre sets up the emotionally touching sequences of the drama, especially that of a patient who teaches the boy about motherly love, an emotion unfamiliar to the child, and the farewell sequence between Marcelino and the friar who found and adopted him. The program used locations, such as the Sacred Heart Novitiate, Letran College, and the Santo Domingo Church, to create an atmosphere that highlights or contrasts with Marcelino’s longing for the affection of a mother. The most compelling performance in the drama is that of Pimentel as the grouchy Father Superior.

Marcelino, Pan y Vino continued ABS-CBN’s adaptation of drama classics on Philippine television, such as the productions by Fr James Reuter, SJ in 1953 and Obra Maestra (Masterpiece) by Nick Lizaso in 1973. ABS-CBN’s hit drama series May Bukas Pa (There’s Still Tomorrow), 2009-10, partly based its narrative on O’Hara’s adaptation. Marcelino, Pan y Vino won Best Children’s Program in the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1979. Written by Marian A. Caampued and Eulalio R. Guieb III

Source: Torre 1979a.

text:
(Mask) 1979, Mondays, 7:30-8:30 pm, BBC 2. Producer: Aawitan Kita Productions. Executive Producer: Armida Siguion-Reyna. Director: Mitos Villareal. Writer: Oscar Miranda. Selected actors: Andrea Andolong, Elizabeth Oropesa, Rio Locsin, Aurora Salve, Charo Santos, Gigi Salvador, Armida Siguion-Reyna, Chito Ponce Enrile, Rosemarie Gil, Liza Lorena, Joseph Sytangco, Mary Walter, Lucita Soriano, Soxy Topacio.

First aired on 19 Mar 1979, the weekly anthology is an exposé of the entertainment industry. It dramatizes the problems of people in the film and broadcast industry, such as producers and directors exploiting young, ambitious starlets; untalented young stars willing to bare body and soul to make it big; have-been actors trying to cope with a fading career; small production people enmeshed in the intricate ins and outs of showbiz; sycophants and fans who cannot see through the masquerade of public images; and the machinery of the system that corrupts and dehumanizes individuals.

The premiere episode is a collage of characters that make up the movie industry. A producer beds a starlet who becomes his mistress. His wife gets used to the indecency of the industry. A has-been star maintains the dignity of an artist: “Ang artista, kung tunay na artista, hindi nawawala ang pagkaartista” (Real artists don’t lose their artistry). A makeup artist advises another starlet not to go bold: “Pag napakita mo na ang lahat, wala nang titingin sa ’yo” (Once you’ve shown everything, no one is going to take a second look at you), and consoles another director who is starting to lose faith in himself: “Magkakaroon ka rin ng magandang break bilang direktor, kahit na hindi ka sward” (You will have your break as a director, even if you’re not gay).

text:
(There’s Still Tomorrow) 2 Feb 2009 to 5 Feb 2010, Mondays to Fridays, 7:30-8:30 pm, ABS-CBN. Executive Producer: Roselle Soldao. Associate Producers: Cathy Magdael-Abarrondo, Hazel Parfan. Supervising Producer: Mae N. Santos. Directors: Jerome Chavez Pobocan, Jojo Saguin, Erick C. Salud. Writers: Dindo Perez, Ays de Guzman, Shugo Praico, Jose Maria Sanchez Silva. Production Managers: Julie Anne R. Benitez, Deo Endrinal, Ethel Manaloto-Espiritu. Main Cast: Zaijan Jaranilla (Santino), Albert Martinez (Mayor Enrique D. Rodrigo/Gonzalvo Policarpio), Jaime Fabregas (Fr Anthony), Dominic Ochoa (Fr Jose), Lito Pimentel (Fr Ringo/Gregorio), Tonton Gutierrez (Mario Sta. Maria), Dina Bonnevie (Malena Rodrigo), Chin Chin Gutierrez (narrator in the pilot episode/Teresa Malimban), Precious Lara Quigaman (Selda Sta. Maria), Maja Salvador (Stella Rodrigo), Rayver Cruz (Cocoy Bautista), Liza Lorena (Doña Anita Rodriguez), Ruben Gonzaga (Fr Patrick), Desiree del Valle (Clautilde Katerina Magdael).

 

May Bukas Pa is a 40-minute daily drama series about rediscovering faith, forgiveness, and reconciliation amidst challenges and struggles in life. The plot revolves around an orphaned boy named Santino (Jaranilla) who can converse with “Bro,” a mysterious voice that provides him with supernatural powers to cure the sick, heal internal conflicts, and help resolve domestic disputes.

 

The series is set in a fictional town called Barangay Pag-asa (Village of Hope), a direct reference to the drama’s religious intents. The story opens with a woman named Teresa Malimban leaving her baby boy, who later turns out to be Santino, in a cemetery. A groundskeeper finds the infant and brings it to a monastery under the care of Father Anthony, the chief administrator, Father Ringo, a former social butterfly who decided to become a priest, and Father Jose, who serves as the cook and father figure to the boy. Santino develops close relationships and finds maternal love with police officer Selda, who is the daughter of Doña Anita who left her rich family for Mario, also a policeman whose righteous deeds keep the town’s peace and order. The town is run by the power-hungry Mayor Enrique Rodrigo, whose wealthy wife, Malena, happens to be the older sister of Selda. Malena had killed Santino’s mother. After a series of healings and life-threatening events, it will be revealed that Santino’s biological father is the town mayor. At the end of the series, Tilde, the mayor’s mistress and second wife, accidentally pushes Santino down a flight of stairs, which causes the death of the boy. Santino’s death is reminiscent of the way Santino’s mother died at the hands of the mayor’s first wife Malena, and how Malena will die at the hands of Tilde. After seeing both his parents in the afterlife, Santino is brought back to life to continue his mission of bringing hope to the world.

 

The series featured a powerhouse cast of guest actors for its episodes, which included Dolphy, Gloria Romero, Susan Roces, Johnny Delgado, Lorna Tolentino, Christopher de Leon, John Estrada, Vhong Navarro, Mylene Dizon, Judy Ann Santos, Ryan Agoncillo, and Charo Santos-Concio. This strategy helped increase its viewership. Because of its high ratings, ABS-CBN extended its initial eight-week run to 20 weeks and extended it again until its last episode after a year of daily broadcast. Kantar Media, a survey group, reported that the series posted a 38.6% audience share in 2010. The final episode gained a 47.3% national household share, according to TNS Media Research.

 

The drama featured subplots of family problems, such as parents disapproving their children’s life paths, careers lost due to family responsibilities, characters running away from home, and sibling rivalry. Santino, who stands as the mediator in disputes, mends broken ties through words of wisdom from “Bro.” One of the notable episodes of the series is the battle for the custody of Grace, the daughter of taho (sweetened tofu) vendor Moy, whose wife Jackie left them because she cannot endure a life of poverty with her husband. Unwilling to live with her mother, Grace, accompanied by Santino, runs away from home and goes to her grandfather Pilo who is living in a home for the aged. Panic intensifies in the monastery and the feud between Grace’s parents intensifies. The police conduct a search for the children and track them down to an old house where negotiations become heated until snipers target Pilo’s head. Santino convinces Jackie to give the custody of the child to Moy and agrees to help meet their daughter’s financial needs.

 

The series also shows how faith is usually challenged by non-believers. As Santino gets entangled in dangerous situations because of his healing powers, he meets people like Oleg, a convict who escapes from prison to kidnap and pressure Santino to cure his sick daughter; Tatay Ben, a gang leader who kidnaps children to make them beg for alms; Lito, an atheist doctor who later asks Santino to cure his former love who has leukemia; and Paulo, a journalist and former missionary who rediscovers his faith after seeing Santino come back from the dead.

 

May Bukas Pa won best drama series at the 31st Catholic Mass Media Awards, the 18th Golden Dove Awards of the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster sa Pilipinas, and the Star Awards for Television of the Philippine Movie Press Club (PMPC), and a special award for promoting moral values at the 1st TV Awards of the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board, all in 2009; and a special jury award at the 8th Gawad Tanglaw, and TV Program of the Year at the 41st Box-Office Entertainment Awards of the Guillermo Mendoza Memorial Scholarship Foundation (GMMSF), both in 2010.

 

Jaranilla was awarded best male new TV personality at the PMPC Star Awards for Television, 2009, and Male Makabata Awardee at the Anak TV Seal Award and Natatanging Gawad Tanglaw para sa Sining ng Telebisyon at the 8th Gawad Tanglaw, both in 2010. The program’s directors, Jerome Pobocan and Jojo Saguin, were named TV directors of the year at the 41st GMMSF Box-Office Entertainment Awards, 2010. Written by Christine A. Palattao

 

Sources:

"ABS-CBN, dominates..." 2010; "ABS-CBN wins big..." 2009; IMDb 2014.; "May Bukas Pa" 2014.

Scene from Melinda, 1995

(Photo courtesy of Rosalie S. Matilac)

text:
1995, GMA. Producers: Task Force Detainees of the Philippines and GMA Network. Executive Producer: Rosalie Matilac. Director: Joel Lamangan. Scriptwriter: Ricky Lee. Lighting Director: Monino Duque. Assistant Director: Rosalie Matilac. Musical Scorer: Dodgie Fernandez. Associate Producer: Teresa Jamias. Production Designer: Jeffrey Jeturian. Production Manager: Jenel De Leon. Cast: Chin Chin Gutierrez (Melinda), Cherry Pie Picache (Rose), Rommel Padilla (co-worker of Melinda), Dexter Doria (mother of Melinda).

 

Melinda is one among several feature length movies for TV in the GMA Telesine Special series. The drama revolves around Melinda, a young student activist in the 1980s who was abducted, together with her friend Rose, another young activist, by a group of military men. They were first taken to a military safe house, where Melinda was gang-raped by her military captors. Meanwhile, Rose denies she herself was raped by their captors. While in detention, Melinda writes an affidavit about her ordeal and gives the affidavit to her mother, who is not keen on pressing charges in spite of incessant appeals by Melinda.

 

Melinda and Rose are freed from detention after Ninoy Aquino was assassinated in 1983. Melinda’s detention and rape greatly affects her life. It becomes difficult for her to live without remembering her traumatic ordeal. Rose, on the other hand, tries various endeavors to deny her traumatic experience with the military. Later, Melinda learns touch therapy, and is able to move on with her life and help other sexually and physically abused victims. Slowly, she is able to recover from her trauma and manages to enter into a love relationship with her co-worker in the touch therapy. Melinda and Rose meet a few years later. Rose continues to deny that she was raped. She later witnesses the capture of two of their comrades, an incident which unsettles her. Rose finally admits to Melinda that she was indeed raped during their capture. She reveals to Melinda that she had aborted the child which was the result of her tragic ordeal. Rose cannot get over her traumatic experience and sensed her life at a standstill. She is unable to weather the psychological trauma of rape. She eventually commits suicide.

 

Melinda and other human rights victims file a class suit against Marcos for human rights violations at a time when the country is reeling from the trauma of the assassination of opposition leader Ninoy Aquino. What follows next is a series of the footages of true events from the assassination of Aquino to the people power revolt on Epifanio de los Santos Avenue that forced Marcos, his family, and cronies to flee the country to live a life of exile in Hawaii.

 

Melinda is a brave attempt to tell stories about military rape during the height of the dictatorship of Marcos from the 1970s to the 1980s. It is a telling of the composite stories of human rights victims who sued former President Ferdinand Marcos and eventually won in court.

 

Melinda won best telemovie, Gutierrez won best actress, and Picache won best supporting actress in the First Asian Television Awards in Singapore in 1996. Ricky Lee’s script for Melinda won best story and best teleplay, and Picache’s performance won best supporting actress in the Bahaghari Awards for Television in 1996. Written by Cynthia Cruz-Paz

 

Source:

Matilac n.d.

photos.desc:
Web banner for the television adaptation of Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, 2008

(Photo courtesy of GMA Network)

text:
(The Stories of Grandmother Basyang) Post-World War II until the 1960s, KZPI then on DZRH; 2007-08, Sundays, GMA Network; 2008, DZRV Radio Veritas and DZRH. Writer: Severino Reyes. Director: Argel Joseph and Don Michael Perez.

Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyangwas a highly popular radio drama for children that ends with a moral lesson. The stories were characterized by fairy-tale adventures of heroes and villains in faraway kingdoms and fantastic creatures like giants and elves. The program was set in the living room with the character Lola Basyang calling the names of children Panching, Charing, Felicing, and Efren to listen to the story of the night before going to sleep. The names were of the real-life grandchildren of author Severino Reyes, who wrote the first of the over 400 stories, Ang Plautin ni Periking (The Flute of Periking), about a kind-hearted boy who had a magical flute and a flying carpet, to fill space in an issue of Liwayway, the magazine which he co-founded and edited. Writing in the persona of Lola Basyang, which was inspired by a friend from Quiapo, Manila, Gervacia Guzman de Zamora, better known as Tandang Basyang (Old Basyang), who gathered the youth in her community every afternoon to listen to her stories, Reyes wrote Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyangbeginning in the 1930s until his death in 1942. (See Index, Reyes, Severino.)

In 1949, a few years after the end of World War II, Reyes’s son Pedrito adapted the stories to comics in Tagalog Klasiks, with illustrations by Maning De Leon, Jesus Ramos, Ruben Yandoc, and Jess Jodloman, followed soon after by an adaptation to radio, with Ramona Pablo as the voice of Lola Basyang. Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyangwas adapted to television in 2007 by GMA Network, which produced 26 weekly episodes. The show was also aired on the international cable station GMA Pinoy TV from 2007 to 2008. In 2008, the radio show was revived both on DZRV Radio Veritas, featuring the stories Ang Mahiwagang Bituin (The Magical Star), Ang Prinsipe ng mga Ibon (The Prince of the Birds) and Ang Kapatid ng Tatlong Maria (The Brother of the Three Marias), and on DZRH. The most recent adaptation of the Lola Basyang stories was lolabasyang.com produced by the Idea First Co for TV5 in 2015.

Several of the Lola Basyangstories were adapted to film, beginning with the 1958 Sampaguita Pictures production of Si Pedrong Walang Takot (Fearless Pedro), Ang Mahiwagang Kuba(The Mysterious Hunchback), Ang Dakilang Puso ng Isang Ina (A Mother’s Great Heart), and Ang Prinsesang Naging Pulubi (The Princess Who Became a Pauper). More of the stories were produced in film in 1985 by Regal Films and in 2012 by Unitel Film. In 2007, the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA) mounted on stage what became its longest running children’s plays, written by Christine Bellen based on three of the Lola Basyang stories. These are Ang Prinsipeng Mahaba ang Ilong (The Prince with a Long Nose), Ang Binibining Tumalo sa Mahal na Datu (The Lady who Defeated a King), and Ang Mahiwagang Kuba (The Mysterious Hunchback). Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyangalso found expression on the ballet stage with the production by Ballet Manila at the Cultural Center of the Philippines of three stories in 2008 and another three in 2013.

In 1997, Tahanan Books published The Best of Lola Basyang: Timeless Tales for the Filipino Family, a collection of twelve stories selected by poet and literary critic Bienvenido Lumbera, with translations to English by Gilda Cordero-Fernando and illustrations by Albert Gamos. Beginning in 2004, Anvil Publishing launched a series of picture books based on Mga Kuwento ni Lola Basyang, retold by Christine Bellen and illustrated by Frances C. Alcaráz, Albert Gamos, Elbert Or, Liza A. Flores, and Ruben de Jesus.

The DZRV revival of the radio program won the 2007 Catholic Mass Media Award for Best Children’s Program. Written by Severino P. Reyes III

Sources:

Bellen 2003, n.d.; "The Timeless Tales..." 2013; Villegas 2007; Wikipedia n.d.b, n.d.c.

(Photo courtesy of DXGO)

text:
2004, DXMS, DXMY and DXGO. Producers: Mindanao Program of the Initiatives for International Dialogue (IID) then, later, Mindanao People’s Caucus.

Deriving its name from Mindanao and kalinaw (peace), this program encourages dialogue with community members caught in conflicts in Mindanao.

The first broadcasters were Mahdie Amella, executive director of the Mindanao Action for Peace and Development Initiatives, Inc (MAPAD); Bae Era Espana, Commissioner for Central Mindanao of the National Commission for Indigenous Peoples (NCIP); and Bapa Joe Akmad, a Maguindanao elder. Mindalinaw is a paid radio program heard in Cotabato, Maguindanao, Sultan Kudarat, and Davao del Sur. It provides a platform for understanding and articulating the different perspectives of Muslims, the Lumad, and Christians as well as of policymakers and peace actors.

Mindalinaw mobilizes support for the full recognition of the basic rights and the provision of entitlements for the internally displaced peoples. It provides links for coordination and exchange of information among service providers and agencies, the military, and the Moro Islamic Liberation Front for the promotion of humanitarian protection.

Its programs include dramas on the lives of evacuees, music, news, intercultural dialogues, and public service. Its live news dispatches inform community members on the progress of peace talks and the perspectives of the different peace players. Written by Fraulein A. Oclarit and Ariel Marco T. Oclarit

article_title: The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel

photos.desc:
Anthony “Maverick” Relova and Ariel Villasanta

of The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel, 2012

(Photo courtesy of GMA Network)

text:
Mar 2003-Oct 2005, Mondays 9:30-10:00 pm, and, later, Saturdays 10:00-10:30 pm, ABC5. Producers: Ideal Minds Corporation, ABC5. Executive Producers: Christopher Tan. Creator, Director, Writer: Aleah Aliporo. Camerapersons: Ricky Fiesta, Marc Go, Angel Baclig, Eduard Gagarin, Ramon Lim. Editor: Julius Caesar Herrera. Production Managers: Charissa Sanchez, Joselle Acuña, Roa Anne Rollan. Graphic Artist: Mark Mendoza. Performers: Anthony Relova (Maverick), Ariel Villasanta (Ariel), Elvie Villasanta (Mommy Elvie).

The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel is one of the pioneering reality television-situational comedy programs in the Philippines. Blurring the line between fiction and reality, the camera follows the lives of real-life friends, Maverick Only and Ariel with a Capital A, as they go about their everyday lives and get into a series of real-life and fictional “misadventures” to pursue their elusive dream of making it big in showbiz.

The program, generally unscripted, interweave the personal and public lives of Relova and Villasanta, showing them in their workplaces, interactions with family and friends, and “misadventures” in odd situations with showbiz, political, and other public personalities. One example is the ambush interview with then President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo by one of the hosts who tells her “Ma’am, first time ko po kayong nakita sa personal. Ang ganda n’yo pala. Parang kade-debut n’yo lang.” (Ma’am, this is my first time to meet you in person. I didn’t realize you were so beautiful. You look like an eighteen-year-old.) In another episode, “Versatility,” the hosts join a Santacruzan in Sampaloc, Manila, only to be drenched in rain. Another episode, “Trick or Treat,” shows the duo in Halloween costume, competing with children and entering residences in Alabang. In Season 8 of the show, the two go to Malaysia to interact with Malaysian celebrities. The program was aired in Malaysia’s English Channel NTV7.

The show relies on the irreverent repartee and spontaneity of Relova and Villasanta. They self-reflexively probe “Filipino humor” with references to the work of veteran comedians. Their wild wardrobe and accessories, such as bright-colored ukay-ukay (second-hand) outfits and fake huge diamond apparels, accentuate the program’s caustic humor and witty insults. Villasanta’s real-life mother, 70-plus-year-old Mommy Elvie, provides the tongue-in-cheek counterpoint to the often illogical, unpredictable, and absurd situations in which the two characters find themselves.

The program has spawned television shows which they also hosted, a music recording, and a film project. In 2005, Relova and Villasanta anchored ABC5’s pseudo-investigative news-documentary Totoo TV: Walang Kinatatakutan, Walang Kinikilingan, Walang Hiya (Real TV: Fearless News, Balanced Views, Shameless), an alliteration of claims of balanced reporting by national broadsheets and broadcast news programs.

In 2007, the duo recorded the album Collector’s Edition: Volume 5, under Alpha Music, which contains 11 tracks of varied musical genres. In 2008, they starred in what could have been the first “mockumentary” in Philippine movies, GMA Film’s Maverick and Ariel’s First Ever Ever Movie Hollywood or Else … Ang Pinakamahabang Title ng Pelikula sa Balat ng Lupa (Maverick and Ariel’s First Ever Ever Movie Hollywood or Else … The Longest Film Title on the Face of the Earth), which is about two characters who are let loose in the United States. From 2007 to 2008, Mommy Elvie had her own reality TV program on ABC5, Mommy Elvie’s Problematic Show.

In 2006, The Misadventures of Maverick and Ariel was shortlisted for best comedy show in the Asian TV Awards in Singapore. In 2005, it won the Best Comedy Gag Show in the Golden Screen Awards for Television. Written byPatrick F. Campos and Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
MUSMOS TUKLAS

(Child’s Discovery) 2009, 9:00 am - 10:00 am, DZJV. Production Head: Sheryl Hermosa (2009-11); Kathleen Marie V. Paguio (2012-14). Production Staff: Joshua Sanchez, Milka Dela Cruz, and Kristianne Andrade.

This children-oriented magazine radio program derives inspiration from the words of national hero Jose Rizal: “Ang kabataan ang pag-asa ng bayan” (The youth is the hope of the nation). The program promotes Christian values through storytelling, dramatizations, interviews, and discussions. It segments are tagged “Mga Kwentong Aralin” (Story Lessons), “Alam Mo Ba?” (Did You Know?), “Musmos Pananaw” (Child’s View), and “Musmos Bibo” (Lively Child).

Musmos Tuklas was named best children’s program by the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Awards in two consecutive years, in 2009 and 2010. Written by Arjay B. Bartolome

text:
10 Jun to 18 Oct 2013, Mondays to Fridays, 9:30-10:30 pm, GMA. Producer: GMA Entertainment TV Group. Creator and Head Writer: Suzette Doctolero. Executive Producer: Carolyn Galve. Creative Director: Jun Lana. Program Manager: Helen Rose Sese. Directors: Dominic Zapata, Gil Tejada Jr, Gina Alajar. Writers: Michelle Amog, Jonathan Cruz, Geng Delgado, Jason Lim, Marlon Miguel. Videography: Roman Theodossis. Cast: Dennis Trillo (Eric del Mundo), Carla Abellana (Lally Agatep-Soriano), Tom Rodriguez (Vincent Soriano), Kuh Ledesma (Elaine Soriano), Roi Vinzon (Armando Soriano), Glydel Mercado (Sandra Agatep), Mark Gil, Chanda Romero (Sol del Mundo), Dexter Doria, Victor Basa (David), Kevin Santos (Danny), Bettina Carlos (Vicky Araneta), Keempee de Leon (Zandro “Zsa Zsa” Soriano), Chynna Ortaleza (Stella), Antone Limgenco (Diego “Diegs”), Elijah Alejo (Hannah “Munchkin” Soriano), Rodjun Cruz (Martin Lizada), Pancho Magno (Paul Salcedo), Roy Alvarez (Manuel Soriano), Jaclyn Jose (Doña Charito Vda. De Carbonel), Ryan Agoncillo (Sam).

My Husband’s Lover is a 40-minute daily drama that presents the nuances of gay relationships in contemporary Philippine society and critiques society’s dictates that value only heterosexual relationships. The drama is narrated through the voice-over of Lally, whose husband, Vincent Soriano turns out to be a closeted gay man who forced himself into a heterosexual marriage. His mother Elaine, a conservative religious socialite, and his father Armando, a strict and homophobic retired army general, compounds Vincent’s dilemma. Lally’s mother Sandra constantly reminds her of their struggles after her philandering husband Galo left them for another woman.

Lally is a fulltime housewife, while Vincent runs his car dealership business. The couple and their children, Diego and Hannah, are living in the Soriano mansion. All is well until the couple decides to have their own house, and commissions Eric del Mundo as the architect. It turns out that Eric, who has just arrived home after years of staying in the United States, is Vincent’s high school sweetheart.

Vincent and Eric rekindle their interrupted romance, keeping their affair from Lally. The characters are not without their “consciences” in the person of Vincent’s gay friend and ex-lover David and Eric’s artist mother Sol. Lally has her best friend Vicky as her sounding board, who tells her about the affair but not about Vincent’s sexual orientation.

The first half of the narrative centers on the development of the affair of Vincent and Eric, showing how two men could have a real, authentic, and loving relationship, minus the stereotypical gender roles. The narrative emphasizes that a homosexual relationship, like any heterosexual relationship, also has drama, happiness, love, sadness, struggles, romanticism, obstacles, and victories. The latter half of the show deals with Vincent’s coming-out struggles, punctuated by Lally’s cliffhanger discovery of her husband’s orientation, the individual reaction of Vincent’s parents on the coming-out issue, and the father’s warped machismo-laden dealings of his homophobia. Elaine gradually accepts her son’s orientation, but Armando resists his son’s gayness, and taps his military connections to have Vincent abducted and detained to undergo a 45-day military training to rid him of his gayness. This leads to Vincent’s suicide attempt that, in the end, shakes the family’s prejudices against homosexuality.

The drama portrays various gay characters and their respective dilemmas. David is a non-effeminate restaurateur who does not have any qualms about coming out. Eric’s semi-effeminate gay best friend Danny, who is openly gay, harbors a grudge against his mother who rejects his plan of moving in with his boyfriend and who views gay men as financial providers for less fortunate family members. Zandro/Zsa Zsa Soriano is Vincent’s older cousin who is a transgender woman, whose character provides another homophobic plot point for the Soriano family. The presence of the transgender character provides a good chance to explain the different nuances of the gay and transgender divide.

My Husband’s Lover has some portrayals with contentious implications. Infecting the womanizing Armando with the human immunodeficiency virus or HIV suggests that the disease is a form of punishment for the homophobic. David’s decision to adopt a scavenger woman’s unwanted baby, then falling for the scavenger herself, shunning his boyfriend in the process, traps him within the bounds of the nuclear family. When Vincent punches and hurts Eric who taunts him for his self-closetedness, the show raises the possibilities of physical violence in gay relationships. When Eric readily forgives Vincent for the assault, the narrative seems to suggest that simple remorse can easily absolve anyone who commits physical violence against a person.

The show managed to engage various audiences. The lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) community actively supported the program by providing its creators a critique of the drama and suggesting storylines to improve the narrative. Perhaps because of this engagement, the show wrapped up the program by serving storylines that catered to both the straight and the LGBTQs. Lally and Vincent get their marriage annulled, yet they continue to be a family, albeit in different abodes, and respect the needs of their rearranged relationship. Their children mature and learn to understand their parents’ situation. Eric sacrifices his love, leaves for the US but stays in touch with Lally as a friend. Vincent sets Lally up with Sam, a former client, implying a foreboding romance. Vincent remains single, but a rekindled romance is introduced when he runs again into Eric who returns home to put up his architecture business. In this ending, no character is unnecessarily antagonized, no sexual orientation is misjudged, and those who seek redemption get what they need.

My Husband’s Lover received a plaque of appreciation from the Malate Business Association in 2013. It won outstanding original drama program and best performance awards for Carla Abellana, Dennis Trillo, Glydel Mercado, and Kevin Santos in the 11th Golden Screen TV Awards in 2014. Written by Olivia L. Cantor

Nestor de Villa

text:
THE NIDA-NESTOR SHOW18 Mar 1965-72, 8:00-9:00 pm, Thursdays, ABS-CBN Channel 3. Executive Producer: Pete Roa. Directors: Mitos Villareal, Raul Silos. Technical Director: Ben Vasquez. Assistant and Floor Director: Baldy Topales. Writer: Ading Fernando, Willy Schneider. Choreographer: Julie Borromeo. Cast: Nida Blanca, Nestor de Villa, Chichay, Teofilo Pila Dancers, D’ Tres Trappes, Art Zamora, The Coed.

The Nida-Nestor Show was one of the top-rating musical variety and situational comedy programs of its period, which showcased the dancing talents of the iconic film love team of Blanca and de Villa. Each episode consisted of excellent dance numbers from the two, the show’s mainstay dancers, and their guests, and a light story near the end of the show. The show’s production design provided a rich texture to the show’s well-choreographed dance features. Each episode had one to three guests.

 

Ading Fernando wrote the script of the sitcom on the taping day itself. By the time director Villareal had completed taping the dance numbers, Fernando would be done with the script of the sitcom portion of the show. One sitcom episode tells the story of a rich girl, named Nida who is under threat of being kidnapped, and her bodyguard Nestor who falls for Nida. The girl dislikes the idea of being under the watch of her bodyguard and devices ways to get rid of him, but without success. She gets kidnapped, is saved by her bodyguard, and the rich father of Nida decides to get the two married.

The show won outstanding entertainment program in the Citizens’ Awards for Television (CATV) of the Citizens’ Council of Mass Media in 1965, best variety show in 1966, best male TV performer for de Villa in 1967, best female TV performer twice for Blanca in 1966 and 1967, a special award for artistry of production for director Mitos Villareal in 1965, and best director for Villareal in 1966 and 1967. Written by Cynthia Cruz-Paz, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
NOLI ME TANGERE(Touch Me Not) 1992, ABC5. Producer: Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Joel Torre (Crisostomo Ibarra), Tetchie Agbayani (Sisa), Daniel Fernando (Elias), Ruben Rustia (Kapitan Tiago), Chat Silayan (Sinang), Subas Herrero (Padre Damaso), Perla Bautista (Tiya Isabel), Caridad Sanchez (Donya Victorina), Rolando Tinio (Pilosopo Tasyo), Bembol Roco (Lucas), Lloyd Samartino (Linares), Jaime Fabregas (Alferez), Ishmael Bernal (Don Valentin), Tony Mabesa (Kapitan Basilio), Charlie Davao (Kapitan Heneral), Bert Olivar Sr (Tenyente Guevarra), Ryan Redillas (Basilio), Lorli Villanueva (Donya Consolacion), Manny Palo (Padre Salvi), Raffy Bonanza (Filipo), Susan Africa (Doray), Mia Gutierrez (Lola ni Elias), Spanky Manikan (Lolo ni Elias), Chiqui Xerex-Burgos (Padre Sibyla), Nanding Fernandez (Gobernadorcillo), Ramil Rodriguez (Alkalde), Naty Crame Rogers (Hermana Rufa), Rustica Carpio (Hermana Pule), Ray Ventura (Sakristan Mayor), Mely Tagasa (Hermana Sepa), Gardo Versoza (Tarcilo), Gigette Reyes (Victoria), Pen Medina (Asawa ni Sisa), Ronnie Quizon (Andong), Vicente Legarda (Don Tiburcio), Ces Mathay (Laruja), Tony Carreon (Padre Superior), Tony Espejo (Pedro), Soxy Topacio (Abogado ni Elias), Maria Carminia Lourdes Cynthia (Chin-chin) A. Gutierrez (Maria Clara).

Based on the novel of the same title by Jose P. Rizal, the television drama consists of 13 episodes, each running for about 50 minutes. The television drama, which is part of a long history of adaptations of the Noli Me Tangere (1887), restructures the original novel and comments on the theme of Rizal’s work.

 

The first episode introduces the protagonist, Crisostomo Ibarra, a learned man who comes from a wealthy mestizo family and who has just returned from his studies in Europe to establish a school in his town for the enlightenment of the youth. The second episode highlights the poor life of Sisa. The third episode presents a series of vignettes in the town, while the fourth highlights the wisdom of Pilosopo Tasyo. The fifth up to the last episode unravel a series of events that lead to the unfortunate shattering of Ibarra’s dream of reforming society through education. One of the workers dies during the groundbreaking ceremonies for the school he is building. In a dinner, he earns the ire of the powerful Padre Damaso, whom Ibarra nearly kills for insulting the memory of his father. Ibarra is excommunicated, friends turn their backs on him, and his marriage to the mestiza Maria Clara is called off. He is unjustly implicated by Padre Salvi in an unsuccessful plot of rebellion against the government, but he escapes colonial authorities with the help of the loyal Elias, a man whom his family had oppressed and whom he once saved during a picnic on the lake. Basilio, one of Sisa’s sons, flees the wrath of another friar and eventually meets his dying mother, who has lost her sanity. Elias is shot to death while protecting Ibarra. Maria Clara, upon learning that she is the illegitimate daughter of Padre Damaso, enters the convent to become a nun.

The drama, like Rizal’s novel, examines notions of identity as they are played out in the characters of the indio (native), the mestizo, and the Chinese, who all experience different forms of discrimination. It critiques the corruption and hypocrisy of the church hierarchy. And it explores how the colonizer and the colonized are both accountable for the oppressiveness and backwardness of Philippine colonial society.

While ostensibly following the narrative of the novel in its depiction of fin-de-siècle life in the Philippines under the rule of the Spanish empire and the Roman Catholic clergy, the television miniseries departs from Rizal’s key plot and descriptive points, thereby updating the theme of the story for contemporary viewers. The drama opens with the motif of darkness and raging storms, which Rizal employs extensively in his fiction, but it ends with the brightness of a new day, which is contrary to Rizal’s conclusion. Whereas Rizal ends the novel tragically and ironically, with the final chapter entitled “Christmas Eve,” segueing to the sequel, El Filibusterismo, 1891, the television miniseries ends on a hopeful note, with the final episode titled, “Pasko at Bagong Taon” (Christmas and New Year).

In the adaptation, Ibarra does not disappear, in order to transmogrify into the diabolical Simoun in El Filibusterismo. He is instead shown to have survived and ready to start anew, a denouement that cancels the need for a sequel. Remembering the lost lives of Sisa and Elias, Ibarra gives Basilio the charge to keep the dream of transforming society alive, not only through an abstract notion of education but by living for others and paying forward his debt of gratitude to the dearly departed.

The narration is omniscient, unfolding in a linear timeline. The music sometimes works as a counterpoint, as in the sequence where Damaso’s impassioned sermon is embedded with a score that sounds like a dirge, signifying defeat or an ominous foreshadowing of future events. The realistic production design represents a lowland Christian town in the 19th century. The theatrical staging and gestures of actors inject a period feel to the dramatic composition of the scenes.

The television series was produced during the decade of the Centennial of Philippine Revolution. It won the Best Culture and Arts Program prize in the 15th KBP Golden Dove Awards in 1993. The 13 episodes were re-screened at the Dream Theater of the Cultural Center of the Philippines on 14-17 June 2011 as part of a series of activities to commemorate the sesquicentennial of the birth Jose Rizal. Written by Laya Boquiren and Patrick F. Campos

NUNSENSE, MAKES SENSE Since Feb 2010, Mondays, 9:00-10:00 pm; replays Tuesdays, 4:00-5:00 pm, Global News Network Channel 8, Destiny Cable. Producer: Institute of Women’s Studies, Department of Mass Communication, and Department of Women’s Studies of St. Scholastica’s College (SSC) Manila. Executive Producers-Writers: Sr Mary John Mananzan OSB, Rebecca Padilla-Marquez, Arche Ligo. Additional Executive Producer: Aida Gaerlan. Directors: Alfredo Ongleo, Carlito Comia, Johnathan Rondina. Additional Writer: Aurora Lomibao. Editor: Carlito Comia. Production Team: Ryan Evangelista, Aida Gaerlan, Arche Ligo, Rebecca Padilla-Marquez, Alberto de la Cruz, Rowena Salvador, Carmina de Leon, Klaradel Marquez, Susan Balindo, Mark Espino, and students of the SSC Mass Communication Department. OBB and CBB: Alfredo Ongleo, Ryan Evangelista. Host: Sr Mary John Mananzan OSB.

Nunsense, Makes Sense is a one-hour weekly talk program that aims to increase public awareness on issues confronting women, share women’s experiences, and give voice to women’s perspective. The show, which also serves as a laboratory program for Mass Communication students of St. Scholastica’s College (SSC) Manila, is pre-taped in the television studio of SSC’s Mass Communication Department.


The program discusses women’s issues, from the personal to the political, from the private sphere to the public realm. Issues discussed include violence against women, laws on women and children, trafficking, women heroes, and the education of women and girls. It features different women, their personal journeys to their careers, and their advocacies and expertise. Examples of women featured on the show include Eve Ensler, the Aquino sisters, Monique Wilson, Cheche Lazaro, Gemma Cruz Araneta, as well as women from various sectors. It has also featured women’s organizations, such as GABRIELA, Women’s Feature Service, and Babae Laban sa Korupsyon (BABALA) and government agencies, like the Philippine Commission on Women, the Commission on Higher Education, the Department of Education, and the Department of Labor and Employment. Written by Rebecca Padilla-Marquez

OBRA MAESTRA(Masterpiece) 1973, Saturdays, ABS-CBN 2. Producer: Charito Solis. Director: Nick Lizaso. Writers: Nick Lizaso and Charito Solis. Mainstay Actor: Charito Solis.

Obra Maestra was a weekly drama anthology that featured original works by Filipino literary writers and adaptations of foreign literary classics. Executives of the network asked producer and actor Solis to choose from among the network’s pool of directors. She personally chose Lizaso, who was then among the first to shoot on-location sequences, something rarely done on Philippine television during the period, for the drama series Salamin ng Buhay (Mirror of Life). The sequence treatment and final scripts of Obra Maestra were developed and reading rehearsals for the production were done in the house rented by Solis.

The program featured Akira Kurosawa’s Rashomon, the setting of which was turned by writer Ninotchka Rosca from medieval Japan to turn-of-the-19th century Philippines. The outdoor sequences of the episode, shot on 16mm movie camera, another rarity on Philippine drama programs of the period, featured grand horse-drawn carriages. It starred Ronald Remy, Dindo Fernando, Joonee Gamboa, and Nanding Fernandez. Another episode was Medea by Euripedes, performed by Solis, with Lou Salvador Jr playing the role of Jason and Baby O’Brien as his new bride. Other adaptations include The Visit, a 1956 tragicomic play by Swiss dramatist Friedrich Dürrenmatt, which starred Nestor de Villa, and Wuthering Heights by Emily Bronte, which featured Angelo Castro Jr, who was then with the marketing department of ABS-CBN and who would become one of Philippine television’s most respected news anchors.

The program continued the efforts initiated in 1953 by Fr James Reuter, SJ on ABS-CBN of adapting drama classics for Philippine television. Written by Dean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

text:
OUT!2004, GMA News TV. Executive Producer: Melo Esguerra. Hosts: JM Cobarrubias, Avi Siwa, Jigs Mayuga.

Out! is the first television documentary magazine show in the Philippines and Southeast Asia that is devoted to issues of the lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, and queer (LGBTQ) community. Its three hosts all came out on the show, an act which they consider one of their most dramatic and best decisions in life, in spite of trepidations about repercussions on their relationship with family members and friends. The program documented the hardships and challenges experienced by members of the LGBTQ community in revealing to family and friends their gender orientation and preference, as well as the difficulties experienced by family members, especially parents, after their children identified themselves as gay or lesbian. Examples of featured stories include the gay bars in Malate, gay-friendly establishments in the country, gay breadwinners which is a common phenomenon among many households, same-sex marriage, and abusive relationships. The show featured psychologists and counselors discussing different issues faced by the LGBTQ community. It also recognized actor Celia Rodriguez as babaeng bakla (lady gay) and a gay icon of Philippine showbiz.

Out!, despite being a groundbreaking gender-oriented program, ran for only one season. Some opined that it was ahead of its time. But critics are of the view that the program, short-lived as it was, was able to give voice to the LGBTQ community, particularly in trying to change negative public perception about homosexuality in a conservative medium like television.

GMA 7 remade Out! and produced the TV documentary program Out and Proud, which was aired at 11:15 pm on 22 Jun 2014 as part of the gay pride month. Out and Proud, hosted by Vicky Morales, recollected some stories from Out!, showcased current trends and issues of the LGBTQs, and reviewed popular films and TV programs with LGBTQ themes, like GMA’s daily drama series My Husband’s Lover, 2013. The show featured lesbian twin sisters Crystal and Christine Lin, transman Nil Nolada who is an executive in a security firm, openly gay internet personality Sebastian Castro, Eat Bulaga!’s 2013 “Super Sireyna” (Mermaid Queen) and transwoman Francine Garcia, married gay partners movie and TV directors Jun Lana and Perci Intalan, and transman singer Aiza Seguerra and his wife actor Liza Diño. Its forum tackled the need for an anti-discrimination law and the challenges of pushing for the legalization of same sex marriage in the country. Written by Peter Lawrence Escobar

De Leon 2014; "LGBT docu..." 2014; Togonon 2014.

article_title: Paano Kita Mapasasalamatan: A Tribute to George Canseco

photos.desc: Kuh Ledesma and Basil Valdez in Paano Kita Mapapasalamatan: A Tribute to George Canseco, 2005 (Kuh Ledesma Collection)

text:
(How Can I Thank You: A Tribute to George Canseco) 19 Nov 2005 and 27 Jan 2006, ABS-CBN. Supervising Producers: Chit Guerrero, Jojo Jacob. Producer: Malo Cruz. Executive Producer: Esterbelle F. Francisco. Overall In-charge of Production: Charo Santos-Concio, Kuh Ledesma. Director for TV: Johnny Manahan. Musical Director: Rey Cristobal. Writer: Floy Quintos. Director for the Stage, Host, and Lead Performer: Kuh Ledesma.

The television special featured two music concerts of singer Kuh Ledesma as a tribute to George Canseco, one of the Philippines’ most respected composers. The title of the concerts was from a Canseco composition with the same title. The first concert was staged on 15 Nov 2005, a year after Canseco died of cancer. The repeat show was organized on 27 Jan 2006. The concerts, each running for three hours, were held at the Philippine International Convention Center, and both were broadcast on ABS-CBN’s Sunday’s Best.

Canseco composed Kuh Ledesma’s first single “Dito Ba?” (Is This My Place?), which became a hit and for which she gained recognition as a singer. Other Canseco hit compositions she interpreted were “Ako ay Pilipino” (I am a Filipino), a piece commissioned by First Lady Imelda Marcos for the inauguration of the third term of President Ferdinand Marcos in 1981, and “Bulaklak” (Flower), a Filipino translation of Gilbert Becaud’s “L’important c’est la rose.”

The concerts showcased solo performances by Ledesma and duets with artists who sang other Canseco compositions like Pilita Corrales, Basil Valdez, Dulce, Regine Velasquez, Martin Nievera, Rey Valera, and Zsa Zsa Padilla. Other performers in both concerts were Christian Bautista, Noelle Cassandra, Piolo Pascual, and the band Side A.

Paano Kita Mapasasalamatan received the KBP Golden Dove Award for best cultural and arts program in 2006. Written byDean Airo Salvador E. Dancel

text:
29 Feb 1980-2001, Fridays, 7:00-8:00 pm; 2001-02, Wednesdays, 10:00-11:00 pm; 2002, Fridays, 6:00-7:00 pm; 2003, Fridays, 7:00-8:00 pm; 2004-2012, Fridays, 6:00-7:00 pm; all on PTV 4. Supervising institution: National Parks Development Authority of the Department of Tourism. Executive-in-charge (2000s): Federico Edos. Writer (2000s): Gie Arnold. Hosts: Maribel Fernandez, Thea Perez-Prosia, Josephine Roces.

 

Paco Park Presents is a one-hour musical program that ran for 32 years, from 1980 to 2012. It showcased classical presentations by local and international artists, mainly musicians, live from Paco Park in Manila. Live performances in Paco Park, held in front of the St. Pancratius Chapel, continued even when the television broadcast was terminated in 2012. The concert series continues to run until the present.

 

Following the success of Concert at the Park at Rizal Park, Paco Park Presents came as a product of a collaborative venture between the Embassy of the Federal Republic of Germany and the National Parks Development Committee (NPDC) under the Department of Tourism (DOT) to establish the Philippine-German Month in Feb 1980. Dr Christoph Jessen, then press and cultural attache of the German Embassy, and NPDC vice-chair Teodoro Valencia thought of having concerts in the historic Paco Park. The concert series aimed at raising awareness of Philippine and German cultural and arts heritage. Since then, the Embassy hosted Philippine-German Month every February until 1998 when it was moved to March, then returned to February in 2012 by virtue of a Joint Declaration of Intent for Cultural Relations between the two countries. The joint declaration was signed by German Federal Minister Guido Westerwelle and Foreign Affairs Secretary Albert del Rosario on 7 Dec 2011.

 

Most episodes of Paco Park Presents carried themes, such as “Mga Awitin ng Dakilang Lahi” (Songs of Great People), which featured the Filipino kundiman, the compositions of Filipino artists, such as those by National Artist for Music Lucio San Pedro, and themes regarding famous European composers, such as “A Tribute to Bach” and “A Tribute to the French People.” It featured famous musical compositions by Schubert, Handel, Liszt, Chopin, Puccini, Gounod, Debussy, Faure, Hahn, Berlioz, Poulenc, Bizet, and Offenbach.

 

The episodes in Feb 2012 were the example of a series that best illustrated Philippine-German relations. The series was produced in collaboration with the Goeth- Institut, the Film Development Council of the Philippines, and the German-Philippine Chamber of Commerce, and all episodes were also aired on Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation’s DZFE 98.7. The Feb 10 episode had pianist Alejandro Consolacion II and flutist Antonio Maigue playing compositions by Bach. The Feb 17 episode featured soprano Minette Padilla and pianist Aries Caces performing classical works by Mozart, Beethoven, and Filipino composers F. Buencamino and Ernani Cuenco. The Feb 17 episode also showcased world-renowned pianist Leonor Kilayko. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo

Live performances in Paco Park, held in front of the St. Pancratius Chapel, continued even when the television broadcast was terminated in 2012. (Dream) Oct 1968 to 1972, 9:00-10:00 pm, ABS-CBN. Executive Producer: Orly Punzalan. Director: Mitos Villareal. Associate Producer: Leony Manahan. Scriptwriter and Dialogue Director: Consuelo “Ateng” Osorio. Technical Director: Epifanio Cordero. Floor Director: Jun Silos. Host and lead actor: Marlene Dauden (Remy). Selected Guest Actors: Vic Vargas (Carlos), Norma Blancaflor (Josefa), Manuel Conde (Leonardo).

Panagimpan was a drama anthology re-conceptualized and renamed based on an earlier version of the drama program Salamisim (Reflections), 1966-68, which the pre-martial law ABS-CBN acquired from ABC5 in 1968 at a time when ABS-CBN was doing high profile acquisition of programs and pirating of these programs’ actors and hosts from other networks.

Dauden hosted and performed the lead character in each episode of the program, with each episode guesting one to three notable film actors of the period crossing over to television.

Panagimpan on television was not the same as the movie Panagimpan, 1959, by film director Gregorio Fernandez, starring Lita Gutierrez, Rosa Aguirre and Mario Montenegro.

One episode tells the story of the relationship of Leonardo, his wife, Josefa, and his mistress, Remy. Leonardo admits to Josefa that he no longer loves her and the he has a mistress. Josefa also admits that there is no love between them anymore as husband and wife. Leonardo leaves and visits Remy. He tells her that Josefa already knows about their relationship. Remy is apprehensive about their future and his and Josefa’s son, Carlos, if they continue with their affair. Remy decides to separate from Leonardo. Leonardo and Josefa decide to make their marriage work for the sake of their son. Meanwhile, son Carlos arrives from the United States. He meets Remy in one of his friends’ parties and falls in love with her. Later, he introduces her to his parents not knowing that his father once had an affair with Remy. Leonardo and Remy, however, decide to keep the truth from their son. Carlos and Remy become a family in the end. Written byCynthia C. Paz and Sharon May D. Mesias

text:
(The Promise) 13 Nov 2000 to 20 Sep 2002, Mondays-Fridays, 7:00-8:00 pm, ABS-CBN and Star Cinema. Executive Producer: Ellen Nicholas Criste, Malou Santos. Creative Director: Olivia M. Lamasan. Directors: Jerry Lopez-Sineneng, Tots Sanchez-Mariscal, Trina N. Dayrit, Rory B. Quintos. Writers: Emman dela Cruz, Ted Boborol, Michiko Yamamoto. Music: Rey Valera. Cast: Kristine Hermosa (Maria Amor/Yna Macaspac), Jericho Rosales (Angelo Buenavista), Eula Valdez (Amor de Jesus), Jean Garcia (Claudia Zalamea), Tonton Gutierrez (Eduardo Buenavista), Jestoni Alarcon (Diego Buenavista), Liza Lorena (Doña Benita), John Arcilla (Simon Barcial), Perla Bautista (Aling Chayong), Jodi Sta. Maria (Lia), Dianne de la Fuente (“Maria Amor”/Clarissa), Eva Darren (Belen Macaspac), Cris Daluz (Isko Macaspac), Anita Linda (Aling Puring), Minnie Aguilar (Coring), Amy Austria (Lourdes Magbanua-Buenavista), Patrick Garcia (Jonathan Mobido), Vanessa del Bianco (Bea Bianca Bejerrano/Elektrika Powers), Carlo Muñoz (Mark), Hazel Ann Mendoza (Flerida Macaspac), Evangeline Pascual (Betty Mae Verseles), Michelle Bayle (Felicity Banks).

Pangako Sa ’Yo is a drama series introduced as a teleserye and was conceived as soap opera shot like film. It veers away from traditional studio setups, a practice of earlier productions, and always goes on location to create a cinematic television experience for the audience. The title of the drama series was inspired by the song of the same title popularized by composer and singer Rey Valera and which was also used as the teleserye’s theme music.

This 40-minute daily soap opera is the story of two generations of lovers in the fictional town of Punta Verde. The first story is between Amor de Jesus and Eduardo Buenavista. Amor, a country lass, works as a helper in the Buenavista mansion. Eduardo and Amor fall in love, to the dismay of the Buenavista matriarch Doña Benita. With Eduardo’s brother Diego, Doña Benita plots to besmear Amor’s purity in the eyes of Eduardo, and they succeed. Amor is banished from the hacienda and lives with her mother Chayong in the Payatas dumpsite in Manila. Later, without Eduardo’s knowledge, she gives birth to Eduardo’s child whom she names Maria Amor.

Back in the mansion, Doña Benita, beset with financial problems, tries to save the hacienda, by marrying off her son Eduardo to Claudia Zalamea, the daughter of another rich landowner and politician. But unknown to her and her son, Claudia is already pregnant with the child of her first love, Simon Barcial. Later, Claudia and Eduardo have two children, the rebellious Angelo and the devout Lia, who later dies of cancer.

To support her daughter, Amor ends up dancing in a girly bar where she meets Mr. Powers, an American businessman, who later marries her and brings her to the US. He tells Amor to leave the daughter behind with her mother in the dumpsite. From the US, Amor sends her daughter money, while quietly suffering marital abuse. One stormy night, the dumpsite collapses (alluding to a similar tragic event in real life Payatas). Aling Chayong dies from the accident, but, unknown to Amor, her daughter survives the tragedy and is found by the couple Belen and Isko Macaspac. Amor witnesses the tragedy on TV and pleads with Mr. Powers to send her back home, but she is refused and further battered. One day, Mr. Powers suffers a stroke, never to recover. The vengeful Amor allows her husband to wither away in pain, while she waits to collect her fortune. After he dies, she returns to the country, embodying a new personality expressed in her name: “Amor Powers.” Filled with rage, she returns to exact vengeance on everyone who caused all of her suffering.

Meanwhile, the Macaspac couple adopts the girl they saved and names her Ynamorata or Yna, after the signature in the sketch of a woman they found beside her (it was Eduardo’s sketch of Amor, in happier times). Yna grows up into a fine young girl. By a stroke of luck and due to the appearance to her in dreams of a repentant Doña Benita, she finds herself working at the Buenavista hacienda—like her mother before her. As in the previous generation, Yna also falls in love with the master’s son, Angelo, and vice versa. Their love, however, is suppressed by Claudia, now called Madame Claudia, who scorns Yna’s poverty. Even so, Angelo would always defend Yna, a far cry from Eduardo who was easily swayed by his mother’s ploys.

Soon the wealthy and influential Amor Powers returns to Punta Verde to look for her missing daughter, and to engineer the downfall of the Buenavistas, who by now are already well placed in government and business. Eduardo is now provincial governor. As the governor’s wife, Madame Claudia is notorious for her corrupt practices and involvement in illegal gambling. Madame Claudia now feels threatened by Amor’s presence, because she knows of Amor’s past romance with Eduardo. Amor uses her charm and money to gain economic and political ascendancy over the Buenavistas, setting the occasions for the soap’s most unforgettable and quotable confrontation scenes.

Amor’s search for her daughter leads her to an old woman, Aling Puring, who raised a girl named Maria Amor. It turns out that Maria Amor is the daughter of Claudia, switched at birth with another baby in the hospital, the boy who would grow up to be Angelo, upon the instructions of Doña Benita who preferred a male heir. The girl, also known as Clarissa, is Claudia’s love child with Simon. Not knowing the truth and as a way of getting back at Amor, Claudia, who believes that Clarissa is Amor’s child, subjects the girl to abuse and eventually kills her, a crime for which she would be punished later.

Meanwhile, the realization that Maria Amor (Yna) and Angelo are children of the same father now presents an obstacle to the consummation of the love story between the two lovers. However, witnesses attest that Angelo was sired not by Eduardo but by his brother Diego with an unknown woman, making him Eduardo’s nephew. Later, Diego is further revealed as an adopted son of Doña Benita. After Claudia’s crime and all the revelations, Eduardo abandons Claudia for Amor. Yna and Angelo’s wedding is set.

Claudia’s anger, however, cannot be contained, now aggravated by guilt after discovering that she had killed her own daughter. With her loyal assistant Coring, she plots to kill the Buenavistas during the wedding, but Lia and Angelo plead with her to stop the violence and learn how to forgive and change for the better. Amor also makes peace with her. Overwhelmed, Claudia kneels at the altar and begs for forgiveness from all. The ghost of her daughter Clarissa appears to her smiling, signifying not only the peace her soul has found, but also the closure to all the narrative arcs.

Five years after the wedding, Yna and Angelo are expecting a child. Claudia has found peace inside prison, where she also eventually marries Simon. With all contradictions resolved, Amor and Eduardo fulfill the promise of their undying love.

The soap is also considered an important landmark in Philippine broadcasting for initiating the country’s participation in the global soap opera market. It was shown, in dubbed or subtitled formats, in China, Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, and Africa, earning consistent following among locals. On China’s national television in 2010, it reportedly “rated second over all local and foreign programs airing in that country… and even hit the Top 30 list in the national weekly ranking, covering over 2,000 channels and capturing 1.3 billion viewers” (Asian Journal San Diego). It was the first Filipino soap that became a major hit on Ugandan television in 2012. The Cambodian Television Network bought the soap concept for local adaptation in 2013. This took place even as the network was already preparing for a remake of the soap opera. The local remake started airing on 25 May 2015 and ended on 12 Feb 2016, presenting a more compact and highly improved plot. Popular teen idols Kathryn Bernardo and Daniel Padilla reprised the roles of Yna and Angelo, respectively. Sta. Maria, who was part of the original cast as Claudia’s daughter, played the role of Amor.

Pangako Sa ’Yo received several accolades, including a best drama series runner up and a direction citation from the Asian Television Awards in 2001, the PMPC Star Awards for Best TV Series in 2001, and the PMPC Star Awards for Best Actress for Eula Valdez in 2001 and Jean Garcia in 2002. Written byLouie Jon A. Sanchez

"2001 Winners" n.d.; Lawrence 2015; "Pangako Sa'yo'... 2012; Quintos 2016.

text:
PIN-PIN

1990-93, 10:00-11:00 am, Sundays/Saturdays, PTV-4; 1994, 10:00-11:00 am, Sundays, ABC 5; 1990-94, RPN 9, ABS-CBN, and GMA. Producers: Philippine Children’s Television Foundation (PCTVF), Kaisa Para sa Kaunlaran. Executive Producer: Lyca Benitez-Brown. Research and Curriculum Director: Feny delos Angeles-Bautista. Directors: Kokoy Jimenez, Noel Añonuevo. Head Writer: Rene O. Villanueva. Writers: Joaquin Sy, Charlson Ong, Carolyn Hau, Deanie Go, Teresita Ang See. Musical Director and Theme Song Composer: Louie Ocampo. Theme Song Lyricist: Joaquin Sy. Cast: Shakespeare Ngo, Herbert Go, Kane Errol Choa, Helen Benoza, Meah Ang See, Ang Chak Chi, Kendrick Chua, Liwanag O, Andrew Que, Deanie Go, Walter Sy. Producer for one season: Alvina Sy.

Pin-Pin is a weekly one-hour children’s magazine television program in Filipino and Hokkien languages to encourage four- to six-year-old Chinese Filipino and other Filipino audiences to appreciate things Chinese in the Philippine cultural context. The program’s title is a popular monicker among Chinese Filipino children. “Pin” means “beach” or “seaside” and also the third syllable in the Chinese name of the Philippines, or Fei Lv Bin/Pin. Kaisa Para sa Kaunlaran (Kaisa), one of the show’s producers, is a Chinese Filipino non-government organization that believes in the integration of the ethnic Chinese into the larger Filipino society.

Learning the Hokkien by Chinese Filipino children is an issue among Chinese Filipino families. Hokkien is the lingua franca of the Chinese community in the Philippines. The producers believe that it can be taught in the Filipino language.

Pin-Pin uses the magazine format, with the story and setting in a computer shop called Pin-Pin owned by a young Filipino-Chinese named Choy (Shakespeare Ngo). The first episode introduces the main character Choy and his computer shop, which opens in a typical neighborhood. Also introduced is Pong Pagong, the main character in Batibot, another popular children’s television program by the same producer. The show features Hokkien segments about counting, parts of the face, ways of greetings, writing simple Chinese characters, and storytelling. These segments are continued and developed in the succeeding episodes, with addition of other segments on Chinese Filipino customs and traditions.

Pin-Pin won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1990, 1992, and 1993. It was cited for its excellent use of the Filipino language to teach another language, its focus on the Chinese heritage of Filipinos, and its propagation of the positive aspects of multiculturalism that respect cultural diversity and differences with no entrenched social prejudices. Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr

Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo at Telebisyon 1990, 1992, 1993; Sy 2014.

The program’s title is a popular monicker among Chinese Filipino children. “Pin” means “beach” or “seaside” and also the third syllable in the Chinese name of the Philippines, or Fei Lv Bin/Pin. Kaisa Para sa Kaunlaran (Kaisa), one of the show’s producers, is a Chinese Filipino non-government organization that believes in the integration of the ethnic Chinese into the larger Filipino society.

Learning the Hokkien by Chinese Filipino children is an issue among Chinese Filipino families. Hokkien is the lingua franca of the Chinese community in the Philippines. The producers believe that it can be taught in the Filipino language.

Pin-Pin uses the magazine format, with the story and setting in a computer shop called Pin-Pin owned by a young Filipino-Chinese named Choy (Shakespeare Ngo). The first episode introduces the main character Choy and his computer shop, which opens in a typical neighborhood. Also introduced is Pong Pagong, the main character in Batibot, another popular children’s television program by the same producer. The show features Hokkien segments about counting, parts of the face, ways of greetings, writing simple Chinese characters, and storytelling. These segments are continued and developed in the succeeding episodes, with addition of other segments on Chinese Filipino customs and traditions.

Pin-Pin won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1990, 1992, and 1993. It was cited for its excellent use of the Filipino language to teach another language, its focus on the Chinese heritage of Filipinos, and its propagation of the positive aspects of multiculturalism that respect cultural diversity and differences with no entrenched social prejudices. Written by Romulo P. Baquiran Jr
Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo at Telebisyon 1990, 1992, 1993; Sy 2014.

(Filipino Classics) May 2005-06, 2:00 pm, Mondays to Fridays, DZAS “Agapay ng Sambayanan” (The Nation’s Help). Producer: Far Eastern Broadcasting Corporation (FEBC). Host: Eric Maliwat.

This 30-minute radio drama series was based on Filipino literary classics that the station employed to teach listeners Bible-based values. It opened with a series based on the masterpiece of Francisco Baltazar, the epic Florante at Laura (Florante and Laura). One of the more notable episodes was based on the national hero Jose Rizal’s novel Noli Me Tangere, which was critical of the Roman Catholic Church during the Spanish colonial period from the 16th to the 19th centuries. Pinoy Klasiks stressed the moral values inscribed in classical Filipino literary works. The episodes ended with quotations from the Bible.

Pinoy Klasiks was named by the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Awards as Best Drama Show on Radio in 2006. Written by Gian Carlo C. Librojo
