article_title: Pitlag! Kwento ng Buhay, Isyu ng Bayan
text:
(Jolt! Narratives of Life, Issues of Community and Nation) 4 Dec 2000 to 19 Jan 2001, 9:00-9:30 am, Mondays to Thursdays; 9:00-10:00 am, Fridays, DZRV Radio Veritas. 2002-06, 4:00-4:30 pm, Mondays to Thursdays; 4:00-5:00 pm, Fridays, Radio Mindanao Network. Producer: Pathways Productions under Garth Noel Tolentino. Executive Producer and Story Editor: Teresita G. Maceda. Directors: Eulalio R. Guieb III and Alfredo Lazarte. Scriptwriters: Danilo Flores, Danilo dela Cruz, Gil Olea Mendoza, Reuel Molina Aguila, Richard de Guzman, Joseph Salazar, Ariel Diccion, Jovita Zarate, and Teresita G. Maceda. Research Head: Kalon Tariman. Research Assistant: McBien Saint Garcia. Editing and Musical Scoring: Froilan Malimban. Production Assistants: Leoniza Morales and Noby Penaflor. Host: Glecy Atienza. Anchor-analyst: Ferdinand Quicho Jr. Drama Voice Talents: Leonel Benjamin, Rosanna Villegas, Wendy Villacorta, Alex Agcaoili, Montreal Repuyan, and Ed Legaspi.

The program is a serialized daily radio drama on a selected issue per week and concluded on the last weekday with a forum. It intends to enlighten as it entertained and promoted to build a culture of responsible citizenship and accountable leadership. The first Pitlag! series aired during the impeachment trial of then President Joseph Estrada and a mounting “Erap resign” movement from 2000 to 2001. Its first episode “Dagitab” (Spark) dramatized the dilemma of a presidential appointee who finds himself in conflict with his own family. Notable episodes included “Bundok ng Pangarap sa Lupang Pinangako” (Mountain of Hope in the Land of Promise), about the Payatas dumpsite tragedy on 11 Jul 2000; “Pagtawid sa Katanghalian,” (Crossing the Afternoon), about the LRT bombing incident on 30 Dec 2000; “Ang Kabo” (The Jueteng Collector), about the web of corruption in the world of an illegal numbers game; “Kabit-Kabit, Sabit-Sabit” (Connections and Entanglements), a satire on Erap and his alleged mistresses; and the pop opera Christmas special, featuring the workers artist group Teatro Pabrika, which spoofed the impeachment trial. The anchor-analyst framed the serialized narrative, provided key information, and moderated the forum in which an exchange of ideas and perspectives with invited experts and stakeholders helped clarify the issue and opened pathways to possible solutions. Program guests of the first series included National Artist for literature Bienvenido Lumbera, Ruben Carranza, Karina Constantino-David, Maitet Diokno-Pascual, Gigi Francisco, Joel Rocamora, Dinky Soliman, and Filomeno Sta. Ana.

Relaunched in 2002 and aired via satellite on RMN’s 25 radio stations, the program retained the format as it moved to issues like the social cost of war in the Mindanao conflict in “Giyera sa Dibdib ni Nana Dolor” (The War-Torn Heart of Nana Dolor), the death penalty in “Paghihintay sa Paglisan” (Waiting for the Departure), and the struggle of the Ibaloy indigenous cultural community against the San Roque Dam in “Sagka sa Agos ng Buhay” (Barrier to the Flow of Life). Other narrative approaches were employed to dramatize weekly issues. “Urong-Sulong: Panalo Ka Ba, Bayan? (Retreat-Advance: Nation, Are You the Winner?) and “Bola-Bola, Binobola” (Hoodwinked) are satires and comedies on game shows and get-rich-quick scams, respectively. “Bolang Kristal: Paghahanap sa Nawawalang Memorya” (Crystal Ball: The Search for Lost Memory) is a sci-fi tale of an imaginary planet enveloped by a cloud of forgetfulness. The suspense thriller “Kalawang sa Estrella” (The Tarnished Star) is based on the Kuratong Baleleng police rubout. “Tanod ng Kalikasan” (Guardian of Nature) strategically ties real-life interviews with leaders of the Itogon community in Benguet into the narrative about endangered water rights. Other issues tackled included extrajudicial killings during martial law, education, child labor, domestic violence, overseas Filipino workers and their families, toxic waste left in former US military bases, electoral practices, reproductive health, and transparency and governance.

Among the discussants featured in the second series were Secretary of Defense Angelo Reyes and law professor Raul Pangalanan on Ground Zero, then University of the Philippines President Francisco Nemenzo about the Iraq War, former UP president Jose Abueva and Senator Wigberto Tanada on the issue of possible martial law in the Philippines, Theodore Te on Kuratong Baleleng, Ma. Socorro Diokno and Bonifacio Ilagan on those disappeared by martial law, Bibeth Orteza on game shows, Bayang Barrios and Roland Tolentino on the jologs culture, representatives of the NGO Migrante and the Overseas Worker Welfare Administration and an overseas worker on the OFW issue, a child laborer and a Department of Labor and Employment representative on child stevedores, Maria Concepcion Alfiler on elections, an Ibaloi elder and Lulu Gimenez on the issue of the San Roque Dam, and Ma. Teresa Diokno and a Meralco representative on the issue of electrical power and independent producers.

Pitlag! was one of the first digitally edited drama programs in the country, using multiple tracks for voice, sound effects, and music to add texture to the drama, recreate the particularity of the story’s time, culture, and place, and evoke different emotions and sensations. To achieve authenticity, the program used indigenous music when the issue concerned the plight of indigenous communities or wove interview clips into the story when the drama was based on an actual experience. Its interactive segment allowed listeners to respond via text or email to key questions.

In the Catholic Mass Media Awards, Pitlag! won the best radio drama series award in 2001, a special citation in 2003 “for reinventing radio and its traditional drama format as a potent medium for educating and entertaining the public,” and another Best Radio Drama Series Award in 2004. In the New York Festivals, Pitlag! received a finalist certificate for Best Regularly Scheduled Drama in 2002, and “Giyera sa Dibdib ni Nana Dolor” won the Bronze World Medal for the Best Radio Information Program on History in 2003. Written by Teresita G. Maceda

text:
6 Sep 2009, GMA. Producer: GMA News and Public Affairs. Overall in-charge of Production: Marissa L. Flores. Officer-in-charge for Public Affairs: Clyde Rolando Mercado. Executive Producer and Writer: Angeli Guidaya-Atienza. Program Manager: Ella Evangelista-Martelino. Director: Rember Gelera. OBB Director: Rember Gelera. Head Writer: Elmer L. Gatchalian. Field Producers and Writers: Richelle Figueroa, Pia Faustino, Elaine Tima. Researchers: Annalyn Ardona, Journal Fabella, Allane Orendez, Marie Saballegue. Director of Photography: Rowena Raganit. Videographers: Jayson Dimbla, Gibson Gordola, Edgar Padil, Ronald Rapadas, Ricardo San Jose, Alminh Valenzuela. Edit Supervisors: Jay Orense, Francis Hechanova. Linear Editors: Ruel Militar, November Legayo, Generoso Asuncion. Non-linear Editors: Pia Pamela Casiño, Robert Casiño, Geof Castillo, Peter Jerome Manatbat, Carol Tan. Production Coordinator: Ma. Luningning Bolus-Morcoso. Host: Richard Gutierrez.

Planet Philippines is an environmental documentary that examines the impact of human activities on the country’s biodiversity. The host acts as a guide to explore the remaining virgin forests and unexplored terrestrial and marine territories of the country. The documentary features some of the country’s critically endangered species: the black shama bird, reportedly caught close up on camera for the first time on Philippine television, in the Alcoy forest in Cebu; the 100- to 300-year-old red and white lauan trees found in the Sierra Madre mountain range that are threatened by mining and deforestation; the pygmy forests of Mt. Himaguitan in Davao Oriental in Mindanao; the Philippine eagle, considered the most endangered species of animal in the country; and the rich marine life of the waters of Batangas, considered by scientists “the center of the centers of marine biodiversity” in the world; and a variety of species of bats, scorpions, cockroaches, hermit crabs, and pythons that thrive in caves and underground terrain.

The program also presents a sample of the country’s indigenous communities whose living conditions are as threatened as their habitat but find ways to conserve their environment: the forest-dependent Agta of the Sierra Madre, and the sea-dependent Mandaya in Barangay Lukatan who share the place with the Moro Islamic Liberation Front.

The documentary contrasts the mystery of the wilderness with the routine existence of urban dwellers who, having been disconnected from nature, have brought destruction on the environment. It represents the wilderness as a means to rediscover the harmonious connections between humans and nature, and encourages the audience to bear the responsibility of saving the earth.

In 2010, the documentary won the bronze medal for the environmental category in the 53rd New York Festivals, the best documentary special award in the Philippine Movie Press Club Star Awards for TV, a special citation for best adult educational/cultural program in the 34th Catholic Mass Media Awards. In 2011, it received the Silver Award for the nature/wildlife category in the 32nd Telly Awards in New York. Written by Laya Boquiren and Camille S. Intal

Intal 2011.

text:
(Prince Amante). 1949-53, 6:15-6:30 pm, Mondays to Fridays, DZRH. Writer: Clodualdo del Mundo Sr. Director: Fred Gonzales. Producer: Ben Ildefonso and Albert Card. Cast: Roger Nite/Tony Cayado (Prinsipe Amante), Doro de los Ojos (Prinsipe Rodrigo), Perla Filoteo/Jane Hart (Prinsesa Elena), Lucas Paredes (Haring Falcon), Ester Chavez (Reyna Regina), Jose de Villa (Abad, Amante’s right-hand man), Dely Magpayo (Lini, lady-in-waiting), Greg Arnaldo/Ernesto Malay (Announcer). Sponsor: Philippine Manufacturing Company – Procter & Gamble Inc.

Prinsipe Amante is one of the major works of Clodualdo del Mundo. It started in 1949 as a radio play, broadcast live over DZRH. This radio komedya was adapted into a komiks serial and eventually into a film in 1950. Prinsipe Amante, the movie, was produced by LVN and directed by Lamberto Avellana. The film stars Rogelio de la Rosa and Delia Razon. Its success was followed in 1951 by a movie sequel, Prinsipe Amante sa Rubitanya, also directed by Lamberto Avellana. Unfortunately, the two films are no longer extant; only stills from the movie are available. The radio manuscripts by del Mundo, however, survive in the collection of his family.

Prinsipe Amante centers on the conflict between Prinsipe Amante and Prinsipe Rodrigo, known in Reyno Sevilla as the two warring sons of Haring Falcon and Reyna Regina. Prinsipe Rodrigo wants the kingdom for himself and desires to marry Prinsesa Elena, Prinsipe Amante’s beloved.

The queen is seriously sick and the two brothers are given a mission—to search for the fruit of pao that is known to have magical powers to cure the dying. On their way to search for the magical fruit, Prinsipe Rodrigo, fueled by hatred, attempts to murder his brother by pushing him into a ravine. Luckily, Prinsipe Amante is found by Buruka, the good witch. Buruka, who owes Haring Falcon a debt of gratitude, saves the good prince from certain death by letting him drink the juice of pao, the only remaining one that she has. Prinsipe Amante regrets that the only fruit that Buruka owns has been used to call him back from the dead when his queen-mother needs it. But Buruka promises to help him look for the tree that bears the magical fruit. There is one major problem, though—Dagul, the giant, who guards the miraculous tree. Through the help of the good witch and Prinsesa Elena, the prince is able to get the sword of Maestro Divino from under the sea. Armed with the magical sword, Prinsipe Amante seems invincible.

In the later episodes, Prinsipe Rodrigo is revealed to come from a different lineage. He is the son of Goro, a powerful king who appears to be the epitome of evil. The eternal conflict between good and evil continues in each episode.

Prinsipe Amante became so popular that children echoed Prinsipe Amante’s command to his horse, “Hiyaaaa, Puti,” when they played with their wooden swords. Moreover, “Buruka” and “Dagul” entered the Tagalog lexicon to mean “witch” and “big man,” respectively. In 1951, del Mundo was chosen the Leading Radio Writer of the Year by the Institute of National Language. Written byClodualdo del Mundo Jr

Cheche Lazaro interviewing presidential candidate Nicanor Perlas on Probe Profiles, 2010

text:
Mar 1987-Jun 2010. 1987, 2005-2010: ABS-CBN; 1988-2003: GMA. Producer: Cheche Lazaro. Supervising Producers: Maria Ressa, Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Marga Ortigas, Nessa Valdelleon, Owen Santos. Selected Writers, Segment Producers, Hosts: Cheche Lazaro, Maria Ressa, Luchi Cruz-Valdes, Tony Velasquez, Howie Severino, Twink Macaraig, Bernadette Sembrano, David Celdran, Karen Davila, Apa Ongpin, Love Añover, Joseph Laban, Robert Alejandro, Candy Cantada, Carol Gancia, Ruben Canlas, Nessa Valdelleon, Angie Ramos, Owen Santos, Jessica Domingo, Gabby Lapuz, Cathy Quiano, Henry Nakpil, Mabel Tampinco, Minette Tirona, Ahmad Coo, Vernon Lusing, Jay Cesora Orense, Pinky Webb.

 

Probe, which started on ABS-CBN, was the first most critically acclaimed and longest running investigative news magazine in the Philippines. It pioneered investigative broadcast journalism when public affairs on Philippine television consisted mostly of talk. It ran for a total of 24 years. It was renamed The Probe Team when it moved to GMA as a one-hour monthly special in 1988 but became a weekly one-hour documentary magazine program after the show’s third telecast.

 

In 2003, facing a threat of censorship, the show had a dispute with GMA regarding its feature on the lifestyle of the chair of the Philippine Amusements and Gaming Corporation(PAGCOR), Ephraim Genuino, a close ally of then President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. The program then transferred to ABC 5 and was renamed The Probe Team Documentaries. It returned to ABS-CBN as Probe in 2005 and focused on profiles of people and was thus renamed Probe Profiles, which featured personalities such as controversial celebrity doctor Hayden Kho, billiards world champion Efren “Bata” Reyes, and “King of Comedy” Dolphy. Its last episode aired in 2010 featuring the candidacy of President Benigno Aquino III.

 

Probe raised the standard in news and public affairs programs by combining intensive, well-researched, and courageous reports that focused on giving substantive and hard-hitting analyses of social issues, fearlessly exposing the hard truths about Philippine society, combined with excellent production values. It presented a deeper understanding and appreciation of various socially important subjects. It interrogated the government, exposed anomalies and corruption in public office, with features about its officials and projects, such as passport fixers who operate right beside the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Arroyo government fertilizer scam, and the unpaid GSIS benefits of teachers and government employees. It unearthed anomalies and scams that affected the public, such as life and educational plans that misled consumers. It discussed controversial and sensitive topics like the Maria Theresa Carlson wife abuse case, Abu Sayyaf kidnappings, discriminatory acts committed against Muslims in Manila, the insurgency, and police brutality without resorting to sensationalism or the pressure from the commercial requirements of producing a show.

 

It chased stories of calamities, providing extensive coverage of the 1990 Luzon earthquake, the 1991 Mt. Pinatubo eruption, and many infamous maritime disasters. It also unearthed inspiring stories and explosive revelations in its feature stories about the country’s leaders and celebrities. The show displayed its integrity and independence, particularly in its campaign against “envelopmental’ journalism of the period, in which many journalists, in both the print and broadcast media were reportedly being paid cash in envelopes by individuals and institutions in exchange for good publicity. Probe produced many of the broadcast industry’s best people and stayed true to its brand of ethical journalism.

 

Probe/The Probe Team and its hosts have won over 40 trophies here and abroad from award-giving bodies. It won the Bronze Medal for Best News Magazine Program in 1993 and the Silver World Medal in 2001 from the New York Festivals; the Hall of Fame award from the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2001 and the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1988, 1989, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, and 1996; best female public affairs host for Lazaro in the KBP Golden Dove awards in 1993; and best public affairs program from the KBP Golden Dove Awards, 1992-1996 and 2006. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Karryl Faye D. Katigbak

article_title: Public Forum/Truth Forum/Randy David sa Public Forum/Public Life with Randy David

photos.desc: Randy David, host of Public Forum, 1997 (CCP Collection)

text:
1986-89, IBC 13; 1991-95, ABC 5; 1997-2000, GMA. Producers: Cora Abelardo, Gus Cabrera, Atty. Dan Albert de Padua. Executive Producers: Lily Yap, Tina Monzon Palma, Ces Millado, Risa Hontiveros-Baraquel. Associate Producers: Dinna D. Sanchez, Jeannie Gualberto. Supervising Producers: Olivia M. Villafuerte, Marissa Flores. Director: Marilou Diaz-Abaya. Associate Directors: Vinchy Lirios, Ana Melinda Testa de Ocampo. Head Researcher: Ana Melinda Testa de Ocampo. Researchers: Rebecca Abraham, Nonoy Oplas, Jim Libiran. Writer and Host: Randolf ‘Randy’ S. David.

More popularly known as Public Forum, the program was the first among many public affairs programs on TV that were created right after the EDSA Revolt of 1986. The period witnessed the fluorescence on national television of an open dialogue among the public about national issues that would not have been possible during the Marcos dictatorship. Initially named Truth Forum, a venue for exposing the truth, the program first aired on IBC 13, the management of which was entrusted by Corazon Aquino to Noel Tolentino who conceptualized the program with David and some faculty members of the University of the Philippines (UP). It switched networks and renamed the program to Public Forum, then Randy David sa Public Forum (Randy David on Public Forum) on ABC 5, and Public Life with Randy David on GMA. Modelled after fora held at the UP, where host Randy David was teaching Sociology, the program invites members of the academe and civil society groups to analyze sensitive topics like the US military bases, agrarian reform, foreign policy, human rights abuses, workers’ rights, women concerns, children, the struggle of indigenous peoples, economic issues, governance and accountability, public health, censorship, culture, and other national issues.

Public Forum is the first talk show on television that used Filipino as a medium of intelligent political and social discourse, although its first episode, like all talk programs of the period, was in English. The program’s first guest, Bernabe Buscayno, aka Kumander Dante, the founder and leader of the Communist armed group New People’s Army who was then newly released from prison by the Corazon Aquino dispensation, was replying in Filipino to questions posed in English by David. During one of the breaks, Buscayno requested David to switch to Filipino, a suggestion which the host and the director accommodated. The rest of the interview flowed smoothly and without restraint, demonstrating the benefit of using Filipino. The show became popular to audiences who saw the Filipino language as an empowering tool for the expression of critical opinion about society. Most public affairs programs of the period eventually shifted to Filipino. Earlier attempts on the use of Filipino in television programs did not fare well, as in the case of BBC-2’s Coffee with Lee, 1978, a daily early morning talk program hosted by Lee Andres and Noel Trinidad. Some broadcast programs in Bangkok, Jakarta, and Singapore followed Public Forum’s format of bringing the academe closer to the public in a popular medium like television.

The show experienced forms of harassment because of its attack on government policies and private interests impinging on politics. In 1987, Buscayno, together with UP professors Monico Atienza and Dante Sibal with wife Fatima, pregnant at that time, and cameraperson Manny Sanchez were ambushed outside Broadcast City by unknown gunmen, immediately after guesting in the program for the second time. Buscayno survived the ambush, but Sibal and Sanchez died. The show started to lose sponsors when its discussions began attacking big cigarette and liquor companies. It was pushed to late-night programming when networks started to give priority to entertainment shows to time slots initially given to talk programs. David refused the offer of continuing the program on cable TV, believing that such a move would make the program inaccessible to the masses that comprise its viewing public.

Public Forum won eight times in the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, 1992, 1993, 1994, and 1996. Written by Arade Louise P. Villena, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

Sources:

Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo at Telebisyon 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, 1992, 1993, 1994; Penilla-Yu 2011.

text:
(Sowing on Air) 1989, 6:30-7:15 am, Sundays, DYHP 612 Khz and Radio Mindanao Network. Producer: Central Visayas Farmers Development Center Incorporated (FARDEC).

 

Pugasan sa Kahanginan is a radio magazine show established in 1989 by a group of religious and lay persons to serve as a regional support mechanism for farmers particularly in the provinces of Bohol, Cebu, and Negros Oriental. It discusses issues affecting the agricultural sector, including land reform and sustainable rural development, as well as other social concerns like contractualization of labor, privatization of public hospitals, and elections. The program format includes dramatizations of the conditions of farm workers.

 

In 1995, the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Ikatlong Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo declared the program as best radio play in the Visayas. The Cebu Archdiocesan Mass Media Awards gave it the best developmental radio magazine program award in 1992, 1995, and 1998. Written by Arjay B. Bartolome

text:
(Meeting for Progress) Oct 1972- Feb 1986, 7:30-8:30 pm, all radio and television stations nationwide. Producer: National Media Production Center (NMPC), now the Philippine Information Agency (PIA). Supervising Producer: Johnny Roux. Program Developers: Mary Ruff Tagle, Nati Umali Berthelsen, Nati Nuguid, and Josefina Patron. Director: Ellen Roque followed by others including director Heidi Sison. Scriptwriters: Jesus Matubis and Joaquin Taduran. Host/s: Ray Pedroche, followed by Gabby Mañalac, Gerry Geronimo, Raul Pañares, Paul Lacanilao, Rita Gaddi Baltazar, and a host of other news broadcasters.

 

This public affairs program was the first to be carried live simultaneously by all stations all over the country through a nationwide hook-up link. The carrying station was the government’s Channel 4 while the emanation points were Malacañan Palace, various government offices, or the Channel 4 studios at NMPC in Intramuros. Marcos was the guest at the initial and several broadcasts, followed by members of his cabinet, generals of the armed forces, his wife Imelda, and politicians allied with him. Often conducted with a town hall meeting format, it also featured local government officials, community leaders, and ordinary citizens who raised issues that were immediately addressed by featured guests. In one episode for example, scientists from the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) answered questions raised by rice farmers from Pampanga, Nueva Ecija, and Tarlac.

 

In the context of a controlled press, it was considered the flagship public affairs broadcast program of the martial law regime of Marcos and a critical part of the propaganda machine that attempted to convince the public of the merits and advantages of what he called the New Society by showcasing programs such as the so-called Green Revolution, Masagana 99, family planning, and Imelda’s nutrition program. One of the memorable features of Pulong-Pulong sa Kaunlaran was its theme song, an inspirational and lively jingle about working together to achieve a New Society, with music and lyrics composed by jingle-maker Pedro Galvez Jr, an advertising executive from the Philippine Advertising Counsellors (PAC).

 

In spite of its debatable reputation, Pulong-pulong sa Kaunlaran mainstreamed the public affairs genre of broadcast programs in the country such that public affairs production teams, often linked with the news staff, became part of the structure of the bigger stations and networks. Its town hall meeting format is echoed in the post-Marcos Public Forum on Intercontinental Broadcasting Corporation Channel 13, hosted by Randy David, 1986-89. Its all-station radio-television link-up is employed to deliver nationwide the State-of-the-Nation Address of every president after Marcos. Written by Edgardo Ray G. Pedroche

 

Source:

Taduran 2014.

Chichay and Tolindoy in a promotional photo

of Purico Troubadours, 1940s  (Elizabeth Enriquez Collection)

text:
Premiered in 1940s, KZRH. Sponsors: Philippine Manufacturing Corporation (PMC, present-day Procter and Gamble or P&G).

 

Purico Troubadours / Purico Show was a daily variety show that began airing in 1940 as a blocktime program of writer-musician Remigio Mat. Castro, featuring foreign music as well as Tagalog and Visayan numbers played live by a string orchestra, short skits, and comedy routines. The show carried the brand name of a cooking lard produced by its sponsor, the Philippine Manufacturing Corporation (PMC, present-day Procter and Gamble or P&G), like other shows of the period whose titles carried the brand names of the products of their sponsors, such as Klim Musical Quiz, Lux Theater of the Air, Quaker Oats Spelling Bee, Palmolive Newsreel of the Air, and The Listerine Amateur Hour.

 

In 1946, when commercial radio returned to the country after the interruption of its operation by World War II from 1942 to 1945, PMC sponsored several Purico shows on KZRH. Every Monday at 6:30-7:00 pm, KZRH aired the music variety show Purico Jamboree co-produced by Conde Ubaldo and Ira Davis. Davis and Ubaldo hosted the show with Rebecca Gonzales, Bert Tirona, Elvie del Rio, Connie Lopez, Teddy Baldemor, and Fred Castro. Live music was provided by Pete Aristorenas and his band. On Wednesdays at the same time, the first Tagalog game show on radio after the war, Timpalak ng Purico, aired, hosted by Sixto Castro, Vic San Pedro, Silver Quiano, and Ric Gutierrez. Some of its broadcasts were held at Dalisay Theater on Rizal Avenue.

 

It is uncertain until when Purico Show aired, but in 1956, Purico print advertisements started promoting Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), an amateur singing contest that first aired in 1950 on DZBB. Around 1948, PMC also began sponsoring Purico shows in other radio stations, such as the amateur singing contest Purico Amateur Program on the Cebu station KZRC, Thursdays, 8:00-9:00 pm; and Purico at Star Margarine on KZPI, daily, 7:00-7:30 pm. The Purico Amateur Hour, possibly an amateur singing contest aired in Manila, featured the most popular stars of radio during the period, such as Tolindoy, Chichay, Lily Miraflor, and Milagros Bernardo. It attracted as guests film stars such as Rogelio de la Rosa and Rosa Rosal. Written by Maria Criselda C. Sto. Domingo

 

Sources:

Aniceto 2007; Calero 1999; Castro 2010; Dela Torre 1989; Enriquez 2008; Liwayway 1940a, 1940b, 1940c; Philippines Free Press 1948a, 1948b, 1948c, 1956a, 1956b; The Saturday Herald Magazine 1940, 1956a.

photos.desc: Francisca “Babes” Custodio on Radyo Puplonganon, 2016 (Photo courtesy of Panahon TV)

text:
Radyo Puplonganon / Siday is a five-minute program of poetry written by its listeners, read following the 7 am newscast. The program began in 1979 when Custodio capped the newscast with a puplonganon (saying, quotation, or proverb) that was relevant to the news of the day, in the Samar-Leyte language, Waray. A year later, listeners were invited to send their own puplonganon, which were read on the air. Contributions from the audience poured in, including poems, that the station gave it its own time slot. Initially titled Puplonganon, it was soon also called Siday (poem or poetry) due to the popularity of the Waray poetry penned by listeners, mostly ordinary folk from Samar and Leyte. With more contributions than airtime, the program became a competition and the entry selected for the day was the winner. Daily winners competed for the annual prize that grew with the program.

Poet Merlie Alunan attributes audience enthusiasm for the program not to the prize money but to its ability to serve as a means of literary publication in the region. The DYVL siday, written about current issues, serves as a creative outlet and an alternative to local print weeklies and dailies not too open to literary contributions such that it became the Waray siday. On the other hand, scholar Jose Duke Bagulaya laments that most Waray are today unaware of the variety of Waray poetry and associate the word siday with the only poetry they hear, the daily Radyo Puplonganon/Siday. Required by competition rules to teach moral lessons, the DYVL siday sounds preachy to some, but poet Victor Sugbo attests that the Waray audience loves them.

The program was awarded the Gawad Iluminado Lucente in July 1998 by the Komite ng Centro ng Wikang Filipino, University of the Philippines Tacloban College. Credited for the proliferation of the siday, DYVL is frequently invited in siday contests such as the first poetry contest in Waray, the Pasidungog Eduardo A. Makabenta Sr Parahan Siday, 2010, in honor of well-known Waray writer Eduardo A. Makabenta Sr. Written by Allison Anne G. Atis

Sources:

Alunan et al. 2005; Bagulaya 2006; Custodio 2013; DYVL 2013, n.d.; Lopido 2010, 2011.

With more contributions than airtime, the program became a competition and the entry selected for the day was the winner. Daily winners competed for the annual prize that grew with the program.

value.desc: Francisca “Babes” Custodio on Radyo Puplonganon, 2016 (Photo courtesy of Panahon TV)

article.value: Poet Merlie Alunan attributes audience enthusiasm for the program not to the prize money but to its ability to serve as a means of literary publication in the region. The DYVL siday, written about current issues, serves as a creative outlet and an alternative to local print weeklies and dailies not too open to literary contributions such that it became the Waray siday. On the other hand, scholar Jose Duke Bagulaya laments that most Waray are today unaware of the variety of Waray poetry and associate the word siday with the only poetry they hear, the daily Radyo Puplonganon/Siday. Required by competition rules to teach moral lessons, the DYVL siday sounds preachy to some, but poet Victor Sugbo attests that the Waray audience loves them.

The program was awarded the Gawad Iluminado Lucente in July 1998 by the Komite ng Centro ng Wikang Filipino, University of the Philippines Tacloban College. Credited for the proliferation of the siday, DYVL is frequently invited in siday contests such as the first poetry contest in Waray, the Pasidungog Eduardo A. Makabenta Sr Parahan Siday, 2010, in honor of well-known Waray writer Eduardo A. Makabenta Sr. Written by Allison Anne G. Atis

text:
RECUERDO(Memento) 6 Jan 1954 to 29 Jun 1955, 8:00-8:30 pm, Wednesdays, DZIP. Writer: Clodualdo del Mundo, then, later, Brigido Batungbakal.

This weekly post-war radio soap followed the common tropes of love stories that triumph over class distinction and deception, which eventually end in reconciliation.

Before Recuerdo (became a radio drama, it was a comics serial written by Pablo S. Gomez in the comic book series Tagalog Klasiks (Tagalog Classics) published by Ace Publications, Inc. On 1 Nov 1953, following the comics-turned-movie era, a film version of the comics story was released under the same name, also written by Gomez but signed using his pen name, Carlos Gonda. Directed by Octavio Silos and shown at the Dalisay movie theatre until 10 Nov 1953, the film starred Fred Montilla, Gloria Romero, Ramon Revilla, and Myrna Delgado. It was produced by one of the major movie studios at the time, Sampaguita Pictures. The following year, Recuerdo was serialized on DZPI.

The radio serial starred the distinctive and memorable voice of Ben David as narrator. Its voice actors included Ben Aniceto, Rosie Concepcion, Betty Roxas, Matimtiman Cruz, Melita Cruz, and Er Ramos. Recuerdo is also remembered for its theme song “I’ll Take You Home Again, Kathleen,” an American pop song composed by Thomas P. Westendorf. Written by Yna Marei Aguilar

Aniceto 2007; "Ben David" 1967; Del Mundo 1997; Santos 2012; Soriano 2011; "RADIO" 1954, 1955.

text:
REEL TIMESince Feb 2011, Sundays, 9:45-10:45 pm, later moved to Saturdays, 9:15-10:15 pm, GMA News TV. Program Manager: Nowell M. Cuanang. Supervising Producers: Eleazar del Rosario, Sharon Rose Masula, Jayson Bernard Santos. Directors: Aaron Papins Mendoza, Eleazar del Rosario, Jayson Bernard Santos. Researchers: John Michael Cristobal, Searle Kathleen Lira, Justin Baluyot. Video Journalists: Cocoy Gaa. Assistant Video Journalist: Lemuel Anorma, Marlon Cartagena. Video Editors: Eman Payumo, Eugene Gonzales, Paul Franklin Mejia, Jayr Magtoto, Katherine Bunag-Arrojado, Michael Santos. Production Assistants: Annalyn San Pedro, Diane Delgado. Graphics Artists: Jayr Magtoto, Rovie de la Cruz, Francis Almario, Alex Tabisaura, Eric Del Rosario, Aaron Papins Mendoza. Post Production Supervisors: Godjoy Rubio-Cate, Arla Fabella, Alan Ebora. Production Administrator: Jhoalyn Nieva.

Reel Time is GMA News TV’s flagship documentary program that examines the lives of individuals and communities in situations that reflect national dilemmas. The stories are presented without a host or narrator, highlighting the viewpoint of ordinary people whose daily lives are made inhuman because they lack access to basic necessities, such as food, shelter, education, and health services. Following the cinema verite style of filmmaking, the documentaries narrate the common person’s struggles to have a life that is just and humane in the midst of seemingly insurmountable odds. Related topics explored by the program include environmental issues, such as wildlife trafficking; the social aspects of health, such as sexually transmitted diseases; the changing dynamics of the Filipino family, such as long-distance relationships; commitment to work that demands more than the self’s personal aspirations, such as dedicated teachers, doctors, and social workers in far-flung areas who attend to needs of neglected sectors beyond what is required of their professions; and other individual narratives of responding to the challenges of a poor country like the Philippines.

Reel Time’s programming schedule is an attempt by the network to put a documentary on primetime on a weekend to challenge other networks’ preoccupation with entertainment in highly contested timeslots that are often given to programs that are commercial in orientation.

Many of the program’s notable episodes are about children. “Salat” (Famished) documents the lives of malnourished children in slum areas. “Lusong” (Take a Dip) is about children who, in order to provide for the needs of their family, scour the dirty shores of an urban coastal community for marine resources and recyclable garbage. “Alitaptap sa Dagat” (Firefly of the Sea) presents two children who go out to fish at night using improvised underwater lamps. “Batang Halau” (Banished Children) tackles the stateless identities and the precarious situation of undocumented Sabah-born Filipino children who are considered illegal aliens in Malaysia; their parents were Mindanao residents who were forced to move to Malaysia because of political turmoil and poverty in Mindanao and are undocumented settlers in Sabah. “Buho” (Bamboo) follows the lives of three children who cut bamboo poles of 14-50 feet in height from the forest and carry them to their lowland settlements, which their parents chop up as barbecue sticks. “Tira” (Go Ahead) explores the lives of alcohol-addicted adolescents engaging in unprotected sex who are afflicted with sexually transmitted diseases. “Dungkoy” is about nine-year-old Dungkoy, who, in spite of being abandoned by his parents, religiously takes care of his paralyzed grandmother. “Silang mga Wala sa Mapa” (They Who Are Off the Grid) documents the lives of children belonging to the Blaan ethnic group living in the mountains of Saranggani in Mindanao and how a volunteer doctor, with help from volunteer nurses and social workers, attend to all their medical needs. “Gulong” (Wheel) is about a 15-year-old person with disability who begs for alms on a national highway to sustain the basic food needs of his family. “Isinulat sa Tubig” (Written on Water) chronicles the travails of children who have to cross neck-deep rivers to go to school while they await the fulfillment of politicians’ promise of a bridge that will connect their settlements to the community center where the school is located. “Isang Paa sa Hukay” (One Foot in the Grave aka The Price of Gold) is about impoverished children who risk their lives diving down narrow mine shafts with only an air compressor to support their breathing for very little pieces of gold. “Nibulaysir” (Nebulizer) presents a 25-year-old mother, derided as ignorant by her seven-year-old daughter, who decides to return to school as a Grade 1 student, with her daughter as a classmate.

Reel Time’s documentaries have won several awards. “Salat” won the George Foster Peabody Award, the Silver World Medal at the New York Festivals, and the grand prize of the UNICEF Asia-Pacific Child Rights Awards for Television, all in 2013, and the Entertainment Press Society (ENPRESS) Golden Screen TV Award for outstanding documentary program and the Ani ng Dangal Award of the National Commission for Culture and the Arts, both in 2014. “Batang Halau” received the Migration Advocacy and Media Awards for Best TV Show in 2012, the Philippine Red Cross Award for Humanitarian Reporting in 2013, and the Gold Award in the Documentary and Short International Movie Awards in 2015; it was also selected by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in its Refugee Film Festival in 2014. “Nibulayser” won the Japan Prize Maeda Award in 2014. “Dungkoy” received the Silver Screen Award at the US International Film and Video Festival in 2014. “Silang Wala sa Mapa” won the Silver Screen Award at the US International Film and Video Festival in 2014 and the Silver World Medal at the New York Festivals in 2015. “Pula” (Red aka The Color of Courage), about a leukemia-stricken Filipino overseas worker in Singapore, won the Gold Award in the International Film Festival for Women, Social Issues and Zero Discrimination in 2015. “Buho” and “Isinulat sa Tubig” won the grand prize at the UNICEF Asia-Pacific Child Rights Awards for Television in 2015 and 2016, respectively. “Isang Paa sa Hukay” won the Bronze World Medal in the New York Festivals, the Gold Medal in the Documentary-Public Affairs Program in the US International Film and Video Festival, and the Best Documentary Program in Promoting Children’s Rights in the World Television Awards, all in 2016. Reel Time received the Hildegarde Awards for Outstanding Achievement in Broadcasting in 2016. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Jane O. Vinculado

text:
REPORTER’S NOTEBOOK14 Sep 2004-present, 11:30 pm to midnight, Tuesdays and Saturdays, then 4:30-5:00 pm, Thursdays, GMA. Executive Producer: Ian Simbulan. Reporter-hosts: Jiggy Manicad, Maki Pulido. Former hosts: Lei Alviz, Tina Panganiban-Perez, Rhea Santos, Iris Cruz, Jun Veneracion. Producer-Writers: Joseph Laban, Johnson Tam, Derick Cabrido, Michael del Rosario, Jonathan Espiña, Anj Guidaya, Pima Arizala, Ritz Solitario, Ma. Juzzara Simbulan, Joy Madrigal, Pia Cabanela. Director: May de los Santos. Editors: Ferdie Abril, Rob Casiño.

A weekly investigative news magazine television program, Reporter’s Notebook condenses into half an hour two different social issues, each chosen and reported by journalists Pulido and Manicad. Stories about children living dangerous lives have become a staple topic, with investigative reports on kids who climb coconut trees to get tuba (coconut wine), minors sentenced with capital punishment, child pornography, young scavengers, gangsters, and children involved in prostitution, mining, and other dangerous manual work. Other featured issues were indigent senior citizens, drugs, prostitution, violent crimes, corruption, the ailing health system, education, environmental disasters, the illegal trade of animals, victims of natural and human-induced tragedies, corruption, and the latest political controversies.

The most notable episodes are those about the predicament of millions of Filipinos abroad and the often bizarre conditions of the poor in the country. “Pinoy Exodus sa Lebanon” (Filipino Exodus from Lebanon), 2007, is about thousands of Filipinos, mostly domestic helpers, caught in a Middle East war zone, particularly in the aftermath of the Israeli air and artillery attacks on Hezbollah bases in south Lebanon. The episode was memorable for showing how a Filipina, locked up in her employer’s house, dropped a note from her room window, pleading for the Philippine government to rescue them. “Pinays for Export: The Asian Sex Trafficking Trail,” 2008, traces the routes that traffickers use to sneak Filipinas into neighboring Asian countries, specifically the southern borders of the country to get to Sabah and the northern direction to gain entry to Macau and Hong Kong, and how the trafficked women sell their bodies so that they could send money home. “Backdoor,” 2006, documents the seven-hour ordeal in the Sulu Sea of poor Filipinos in search of a better life in Malaysia, with no food, money or identification cards, as they travel on small boats that would bring them to Sabah and enter the border illegally by swimming toward the shores. “Slaughterhouse,” 2006, documents the unsanitary practices in a slaughterhouse for pigs and cows in Bacolod City. “Batang Kalakal” (A Child’s Merchandise), 2007, is about an 11-year-old girl who wades through garbage-strewn and murky rivers to scavenge for plastic and tin cans which she sells at junkshops to support herself through school. “Gatilyo” (Trigger), 2007, is about the illegal arms trade. “Engkuwentro” (Encounter), 2007, is about reporter Veneracion and his crew getting caught in a seven-hour firefight in Basilan between government military forces and rebels belonging to the Moro Islamic Liberation Front. “Lunok Droga” (Swallowed Drugs), 2008, is about how international drug smuggling syndicates employ Filipinos, called drug mules or couriers, to stuff illegal drugs inside their bodies and transport these across the globe. “Diskriminasyon” (Discrimination), 2007, is about the poor state of the country’s public schools. “Pulong Diablo” (Evil Island), 2007, describes the criminality in an impoverished island on a river in Manila. “Batang Kargador” (Children Stevedores), 2011, documents children porters carrying cement sacks in a pier in Bacolod City.

The program sometimes displeased the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board (MTRCB). Its episode “Batang Hit Man” (Child Hit Man), 2006, about child assassins ensnared in clan wars in Abra province, was given an R-18 rating, thus preventing its inclusion in the free screenings of GMA Cine Totoo (Truth Cinema) documentaries at SM Megamall. “Puslit Droga” (Drug Smuggling), a feature on the illegal drug trail from Luzon to Puerto Galera in Oriental Mindoro, was given an X-rating by the MTRCB.

In the Asian Television Awards, the program was highly commended for the episode “Batang Hit Man,” produced and written by Tam and del Rosario, 2007; and winner of the best current affairs program for “Giyera sa Lebanon,” produced and written by Tam, 2008. In the New York Festivals for Television, “Engkuwentro,” produced by Arizala, won the Bronze World Medal for the coverage of an ongoing story, 2008; “Batang Kalakal,” produced and written by Laban, won the Gold World Medal for best human interest story; and “Pinays for Export: The Asian Sex Trafficking Trail,” produced and written by Cabrido and del Rosario, won the Bronze World Medal for best public affairs program, 2009. From the U.S. International Film and Video Festival, it won Certificates for Creative Excellence for the Documentary/Social Issues category for “Gatilyo,” produced and written by Tam and del Rosario, 2007; “Slaughterhouse,” produced and written by Guidaya, 2006; “Pulong Diablo,” produced and written by Arizala, 2008; and “Pinays for Export,” 2009; and the Silver Screen Award for the Best Documentary/Social Issues category for “Backdoor,” produced and written by Madrigal and Cabanela, 2005; “Batang Kalakal,” produced and written by Laban, 2008; and “Lunok Droga,” produced and written by del Rosario and Espiña, 2009. Reporter’s Notebook received citations from the UNICEF Child Rights Awards in 2007 and a special recognition from the National Commission for Culture and the Arts in 2009. Written byJPaul S. Manzanilla and Eulalio. R. Guieb III

Sources:

Lee 2006; Reporter's Notebook website.

text:
REYNA NG VICKS(Queen of Vicks) 1950s, 10 am, daily, DZRH. Producer: Ira Davis. Sponsor: Vicks International. Host: Fidela Magpayo aka Tiya Dely (Aunt Dely).

This highly popular radio program was formatted like a game show but it may be described as an early type of reality program. Before a live studio audience, the host interviewed selected women who, in the process, narrated their sad experiences. It was a contest of who received the most applause, shed tears most copiously, and visibly generated the most sympathy by making the audience cry with her. The winner was proclaimed Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks) for the day.

Ira Davis, then DZRH station manager, produced the show and designed the program such that the contestants were treated with dignity and were never made fun of. The personal disclosures of the daily lives of ordinary women, rather than dramatizations by professional actors, made the show immensely popular.

Reyna ng Vicks was adapted into a movie in 1958 titled Mga Reyna ng Vicks (The Queens of Vicks), released for public screening on 5-14 Mar 1959. Under the direction of Mar S. Torres, the movie starred Gloria Romero, Rita Gomez, Amalia Fuentes, Susan Roces, Ric Rodrigo, Luis Gonzales, Juancho Gutierrez, Romeo Vasquez, and Dolphy as the master of ceremonies. The screenplay of the movie was written by Mar S. Torres, Chito Tapawan, Bert Mendoza, and Venchito Galvez. Mga Reyna ng Vicks the movie was also sponsored by Vicks International. It portrayed the situations of fictional contestants who wanted to join the radio program Reyna ng Vicks. Written by Lia Gabriele A. Ballesteros

Sources:

"DZRH History" n.d.; Ordoñez 2012; Tabunan 2014; Velasco and David 2009.

Before a live studio audience, the host interviewed selected women who, in the process, narrated their sad experiences. It was a contest of who received the most applause, shed tears most copiously, and visibly generated the most sympathy by making the audience cry with her. The winner was proclaimed Reyna ng Vicks (Queen of Vicks) for the day.

Ira Davis, then DZRH station manager, produced the show and designed the program such that the contestants were treated with dignity and were never made fun of. The personal disclosures of the daily lives of ordinary women, rather than dramatizations by professional actors, made the show immensely popular.

Reyna ng Vicks was adapted into a movie in 1958 titled Mga Reyna ng Vicks (The Queens of Vicks), released for public screening on 5-14 Mar 1959. Under the direction of Mar S. Torres, the movie starred Gloria Romero, Rita Gomez, Amalia Fuentes, Susan Roces, Ric Rodrigo, Luis Gonzales, Juancho Gutierrez, Romeo Vasquez, and Dolphy as the master of ceremonies. The screenplay of the movie was written by Mar S. Torres, Chito Tapawan, Bert Mendoza, and Venchito Galvez. Mga Reyna ng Vicks the movie was also sponsored by Vicks International. It portrayed the situations of fictional contestants who wanted to join the radio program Reyna ng Vicks. Written by Lia Gabriele A. Ballesteros
"DZRH History" n.d.; Ordoñez 2012; Tabunan 2014; Velasco and David 2009.

text:
ROSAS(Rose) 1979, Sundays, 9:30-10:30 pm, Channel 4. Creators: Salvii Casino, Eric Celis. Director: Maryo J. de los Reyes. Writer: Orlando Nadres. Actors: Beth Bautista, Rio Locsin, Veronica Jones, Lorna Tolentino.

A weekly anthology, Rosas dramatizes the different struggles of women. The drama experiments on narrative plot, delineates characters with depth, texture, and complexity, and explores themes seldom tackled in drama programs of the period.

The premiere episode, “The Clock,” aired on 1 Apr 1979, is a suspense drama about a telephone suicide assistance volunteer who, after several days of phone counselling, is unable to trace a distraught woman caller who spoke of committing suicide. The counsellor suspects something fishy when she finds out that the husband has married so soon after the death of the wife. It turns out the new wife is also the distraught “caller,” who pretended to be the first wife in order for the two lovers to establish the first wife’s suicidal tendencies and thereby cover up their own crime. The husband and the new wife run after the counsellor when they figure out the latter has found them out. In the end, the counsellor outwits the two.

In another episode, “Infinity,” a wife confronts the painful loneliness of the remaining days of a dying husband. Bravely and quietly, the couple deals with the many complex issues of dying, from practical concerns like preparing one’s own funeral arrangements to philosophical musings about life and death, and the poignant acceptance of the inevitable fate.

Each week, the drama anthology featured one of its major actors in an episode in which she could showcase her acting potential. The four were considered among the few popular “bold” stars of the period who could act. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III

"Jim Paredes..." 1979; Torre 1979c.

text:
THE RX CONCERT SERIESPremiered 1990, Mondays, DWRX 93.1. This radio program airs live musical performances of Filipino and international bands. Conceived in 1990, the long-running program promotes original Pilipino music (OPM) and musical talent by featuring mostly Filipino artists, from established musical performers to new bands struggling to break into the mainstream music scene, balladeers to rappers, folk musicians to rockers, show bands to alternative outfits, and even classical music artists.

Performers play their music from the station’s studios but occasionally from public venues where the concerts are held for free. Hosts interview the musicians while listeners join the conversations by phone.

Initially the show aired concert recordings of foreign artists. In 1993, with the collaboration of After Image frontman Wency Cornejo, the program began airing recorded concerts performed exclusively in a radio station for a radio audience, a format that was the norm during Philippine radio’s early days. Soon the concerts were performed live on air, encouraging OPM growth in the 1990s and 2000s. It then helped make popular a musical style that became a trend starting in the 1990s called “unplugged.” Performers played acoustically without the effects of electronic amplification except for the microphone. Thus came the live band concept which became popular among radio listeners and was copied by other radio stations.

The program won the 2009 Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster ng Pilipinas (KBP) Golden Dove Award for Best Games/Variety Program on Radio; the 2005 and 2006 Catholic Mass Media Award for Best Radio Entertainment Program; and the 1998, 2000, 2001, 2004, and 2010 KBP Golden Dove Award for Best Musical Variety Show. Written by Maria Carmela Barbaza

Sources:

Cueva 1998; Inductivo 1995; Lagbao 1992; Reyes 2013.

text:
RYAN RYAN MUSIKAHAN(Music with Ryan) 1988- July 1995, ABS-CBN. Executive Producer: Stephanie Quirino. Directors: Leo Rialp, Menchu Dalusong, Johnny Manahan. Writers: Jim Paredes, Leo Katigbak, Chris Violago. Host: Ryan Cayabyab.

Ryan Ryan Musikahan was a weekly one-hour late night music show and one of the first shows of ABS-CBN after the network’s relaunch following the EDSA people power revolt. It was named after celebrated musical artist Ryan Cayabyab, who hosted the program from its inception to its final run. Director Dalusong, who replaced Rialp, directed the majority of the episodes for the entirety of Ryan Ryan Musikahan’s time on ABS-CBN. In the mid-2000s, a short-lived version of the show focusing on international Filipino music artists called World Musikahan (World Music Festival), featuring the likes of Christine Adiaz and Daphne Mombay and broadcast abroad on The Filipino Channel (TFC), came into existence. Since 2012, complete re-runs of the original Ryan Ryan Musikahan have continued to air on the ABS-CBN-owned cable channel Jeepney TV.

In each episode, Ryan Cayabyab invited a musician, or a group of musicians, to perform with him on stage. He usually accompanied each performer as a pianist except in cases when doing so would become disruptive, for example if the guest was a solo instrumentalist of a different musical instrument. In between songs, Cayabyab would interview his guests. Each of these conversational interludes would cover a range of topics, from the guests’ current projects to their own personal stories of how they ended up pursuing a life of music.

Cayabyab, affectionately known as Mr. C and The Maestro in the local music industry, was instrumental in the success and enduring presence in the history of the program. Being a multi-awarded conductor, composer, arranger, pianist, and singer himself and having served as mentor to multiple successful popular stars and singing groups, Cayabyab understandably enjoyed extensive contacts at all levels of the music and recording industry. Many artists who would normally never appear on a televised music show agreed to become guests simply because it was Cayabyab who invited them to come.

The sheer variety of musical guests that could appear on every episode is one of the biggest reasons why the show became so successful. One week, Cayabyab may play host to a currently popular singer with a smash hit on the Top 40, and the next, he would have a trio of classical musicians, more at home playing concertos in old theaters than getting interviewed on national television, playing cello and trombone in front of the camera. Viewers would often discover new artists to patronize, and performers find new segments to address, simply from guesting on the show. The show became an iconic part of the television landscape for Filipino viewers during the years it was on air, and it was an honor for local performers to perform in the show.

Due to its long tenure on ABS-CBN, Ryan Ryan Musikahan has a wealth of noteworthy episodes in its history. Its first guest on its pilot episode was a young Gary Valenciano, the same year that Valenciano won his first music award, the best theme song award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences for the song Ibulong Mo Sa Diyos (Whisper It to God). The first and only Filipino international champion of the iconic US talent show Star Search, Josephine Banig Roberto, flew to Manila just to be a guest on the program. Smokey Mountain, a children’s singing group mentored by Cayabyab himself that produced classic hits such as Paraiso (Paradise) and Kailan (When), appeared on a 1990 episode of the program. When the group’s first and second batches of young singers later disbanded, its most popular alumni, such as Geneva Cruz, Jeffrey Hidalgo, Anna Fegi, and Shar Santos, would later return to the show to do solo acts.

It would not be an exaggeration to say that almost every significant Filipino music artist of the 1980s and the early 1990s, such as Regine Velasquez, Monique Wilson, Celeste Legaspi, Kuh Ledesma, Basil Valdez, Martin Nievera, Lea Salonga, and Pilita Corrales, once shared the stage with Cayabyab on Ryan Ryan Musikahan.

More recently, Ryan Ryan Musikahan’s nostalgia-inducing re-runs on Jeepney TV have proven to be surprisingly popular to an entirely new set of viewers. Its success has prompted the network to fund two concerts based on the old show that were then later broadcast as TV specials. The first concert, held at the Rockwell Tent in Makati City, was a Christmas special entitled Ryan Ryan Musikahan: At Home For Christmas (Music of Ryan: At Home For Christmas), with musical direction by Gerard Salonga. It aired on Jeepney TV on 14 Dec 2014. Industry veterans such as Gary Valenciano, Bamboo Mañalac, Aiza Seguerra, Menchu Lauchengco-Yulo, and Cayabyab himself performed a plethora of classic Christmas songs and carols. The Orchestra of Filipino Youth and the Advertiser’s Chorale also participated in the event with their own musical numbers. Jeepney TV aired a second TV special, titled Ryan Ryan Musikahan: Piyano at Gitara (Music of Ryan: Piano and Guitar), on 9 Aug 2015. Directed by Johnny Manahan, this show featured performances from some of the country’s most popular contemporary acoustic artists. Cayabyab performed with singer-songwriter Nyoy Volante, singer Kyla, guitarist Bullet Dumas, independent musician Johnoy Danao, and television matinee idol Xian Lim. These two television specials proved to be a big success for Cayabyab and the network. While a revival of the original version of the show seems unlikely, its continued popularity almost guarantees the production of more one-time themed specials in the years to come.

Ryan Ryan Musikahan won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1988 and 1992; best music program in the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1988, 1989, and 1990; and best musical show in 1989 and 1992, and best musical show host for Cayabyab, also in 1989 and 1992 in the Star Awards of the Philippine Movie Press Club. Written by Laurence Roxas with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
SA LINGGO NAPO SILA(They Will Be Here Sunday) 1987-89, IBC 13, 12:00-2:30 pm, Sundays; 28 Jan 1990-29 Jan 1995, ABS-CBN. Directors: Danny Caparas, Victor de Guzman. Main hosts: Jim Paredes, Danny Javier, Buboy Garovillo. Co-hosts: Agot Isidro, Amy Perez, Ariel Rivera, Bing Loyzaga, Jun Encarnacion, Lara Melissa de Leon, Ilonah Jean, Star Querubin, Daniel Mendoza.

Sa Linggo nAPO Sila was a weekly musical variety show hosted by the members of the popular singing group APO Hiking Society. The title is a pun that combined the program’s live shooting schedule time with the name of the APO Hiking Society. The program was directed by Danni Caparas and was shot live from the Delta Theater in Quezon City. The show served as direct competition against rival network GMA’s similar Sunday music-variety program, The GMA Supershow.

Each episode primarily involved musical performances from the permanent cast as well as special numbers from other guest artists. In contrast to modern versions of the Sunday musical-variety program that stick solely to song and dance performances, Sa Linggo nAPO Sila also featured the occasional non-musical segments such as the sponsored raffles “Cleene Premyo sa Rolyo” (Cleene Prize in the Roll) and the “Sarimanok Sweepstakes.”

The eponymous Apolinario Mabini (APO) Hiking Society’s position as the creative leads of the program helped shape the type of entertainment the show featured, and would eventually become known and loved for. The multi-awarded and highly prolific singing trio is widely considered to be preeminent figures in the movement to promote Original Pilipino Music (OPM) in the country. They influenced Sa Linggo nAPO Sila to shine the spotlight on local artists that may have otherwise gone unnoticed. Many acts that would have otherwise been doomed to languish in the land of “almost-made-it” instead reaped unheralded success thanks to repeated exposure to the masses through guest appearances on Sa Linggo nAPO Sila.

The OPM alternative music boom of the early to mid-1990s owes a great deal to the opportunities given to them by APO and Sa Linggo nAPO Sila. While OPM has always produced and continues to produce great local bands making high-quality music, the lack of mainstream exposure has always held these groups back from becoming truly successful. Sa Linggo nAPO Sila changed all that. From experienced industry vets like The Dawn, Wolfgang, Razorback, Orient Pearl, and Alamid to then-new bands like Color It Red, After Image, True Faith, along with future rock legends Rivermaya and Eraserheads, all had their television introduction to the Filipino masa as performers on the program. The goodwill APO had generated back in that era is so pervasive that even a full decade after the show’s last episode, a plethora of OPM bands, both new and old, clamored to be part of two tribute albums Kami nAPO Muna: Tribute to APO Hiking Society (It’s Our Turn: Tribute to APO Hiking Society) and its follow up record Kami nAPO Muna Ulit: Tribute to APO Hiking Society (It’s Our Turn Again: Tribute to APO Hiking Society) dedicated to celebrating APO’s staggering accomplishments and contributions to the local music scene.

The show aired its last episode on 29 Jan 1995 and was replaced by ASAP, another musical-variety show in a similar format but with a new set of younger hosts like Martin Nievera, Zsa Zsa Padilla, and Pops Fernandez.

After the country’s longest running variety show Eat Bulaga! jumped ship from ABS-CBN to rival GMA, Sa Linggo nAPO Sila was rebranded into a new noontime show called ’Sang Linggo nAPO Sila (They’re Here All Week) to fill ABS-CBN’s weekday noon schedule. This new show ran six days a week, 90 minutes from Mondays to Fridays and 150 minutes on Saturdays. It retained APO Hiking Society as the main hosts along with original co-hosts Isidro, de Leon, Loyzaga, and Perez, in 1995-98. The new members of the hosting team included Kris Aquino, Michelle Van Eimeren, Manilyn Reynes, John Estrada, Rannie Raymundo, Aiko Melendez, Pops Fernandez, Gelli de Belen, and Roderick Paulate. It also had an extensive list of special and guest hosts, many of whom, like Randy Santiago, Willie Revillame, and Bayani Agbayani, would later move on to headline the show’s successor, Magandang Tanghali Bayan (Good Afternoon Nation). ’Sang Linggo nAPO Sila aired live from Delta Theater just like Sa Linggo nAPO Sila until management elected to move it to Studio 3 at the ABS-CBN Broadcast Center.

While the ’Sang Linggo nApo Sila tried its best to retain many of the same elements of Sa Linggo nAPO Sila at first, particularly the promotion of OPM acts, the program was eventually forced to add more game show, sketch comedy, and beauty pageant-style segments in order to compete with the show it replaced while going against GMA’s Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!). One of the more popular and successful segments for the new program was called “Calendar Girl,” a beauty pageant for young women aged 15 to 21 years old. Though the new “sexy” elements of the segment were uncharacteristic for the show, it nevertheless proved to be extremely popular with the Filipino noontime audience.

’Sang Linggo nAPO Sila only managed to stay on air for a little over three years, from 6 Feb 1995 to 28 Nov 1998. While it enjoyed moderately good television ratings in certain market segments, it could not consistently beat the ratings of Eat Bulaga! Written by Laurence Roxas

text:
SALAM(Peace) Nov 2006-07, The Knowledge Channel and ABS-CBN. Funded by the US Agency for International Development (USAID). Executive producer: Marcela Claudette V. Sevilla. Associate producer: Ma. Gracia T. Panganiban. Muslim consultant: Datu Jammal Ashley Abbas. Consultant from the Department of Education: Estrella Babano, Nerissa Losaria. Advisers from USAID: Dr. Thomas Kral, Alvan Lee Amit. Child psychologist: Mian Villanueva. Director: Jon Red. Writer: Ian Victoriano. Script committee: Mariles Gonzales, Cita DC Musni. Assistant director: Maria Bernice Anita Ilagan. Second unit director: Caloy Santos Jr. Supervising cameraperson: Gerry Constantino. Camerapersons: Tony Silvestre, Arvin Vicente, Edgar Napucao. Sound design and special effects: Manie Magbanua Jr, Vincent San Antonio, Julius Tagapan. Technical director: Angel Calizo Jr. Lighting director: Totoy Alcancia. Production designer: Arnold Limjoco. Audio person: Allan Hilado. Boom person: Nestor Fuentes. Postproduction supervisor: Caloy Santos Jr. Technical support manager: Chris P. Sioco. Administrative officer: Monette Calsa-Lim. Child actors: Diane de la Fuente, Jeff Hernandez, Ping Medina, Dimples Romana.

Salam is a TV series that inspires children and adults to work for peace not only in times of war but in everyday life. The program focuses on the lives of four children, two of whom are Muslims and the other two Christians. The child characters are Lorena, Majid, Ato, and Farida. The narrative is set in conflict-torn Mindanao.

 

Conflicts are mainly brought about not by differences but by a misunderstanding of other people’s motivations, as shown in the episode “Batang Isnabero” (Child Snub) and “Magkapitbahay” (Neighbors). In “Drill,” differences are about diversity, which does not necessarily mean a contradiction of one’s personal beliefs or a community’s standards of human relations, but one that enriches social life. A misunderstanding of differences, not the differences per se, is the cause of conflict. In “Reunion,” religion unites rather than divides. Peace also means the acceptance of differences. Friendship and a sense of community are important in attaining peace with those opposite one’s beliefs, as narrated in “Mural,” “Dalawang Bata” (Two Children), and “Bagong Kaibigan” (New Friend). The community as friendship helps in resolving conflict, as in the sense of belongingness invoked in rituals as presented in “Kanduri.” The program indicates that peace is an ethical issue and a moral obligation, and suggests that peace is attained if the deeper causes of conflict are ethically addressed, such as issues related to environmental degradation as examined in “Pangingisda” (Fishing), land claims in “Bakwit” (Evacuation) or human rights as explored in “Bayan ni Pepay” (The Town of Pepay). “Karapatan” (Rights) espouses the virtue of empathy, which means that one can help others without necessarily having to be friends with them. Peace, as explicitly stated in this episode, means promoting the basic rights of others. “Rebelde” (Rebel) ends with a very important quote: “Walang daan tungo sa kapayapaan. Ang kapayapaan ang daan.” (There is no road to peace. Peace is the way.)

Salam received the Anak TV Seal Award given by the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children and Television in 2007. It was also screened in the Prix Jeunesse International Media Bar in 2014. Written by Arjay B. Bartolome and Eulalio R. Guieb III

 

Sources:

Abbas 2012; Correa 2013.

text:
SALAMISIM(Reflections) 1966-68, 8:30-9:30 pm, Wednesdays, ABC5. Producer: Lea Productions. Overall Director: Mitos Villareal. Writers: Consuelo “Ateng” P. Osorio, Liza Moreno. Lead Actor: Marlene Dauden. Guest Actors: Lourdes Medel, Caridad Sanchez, Roger Calvin, Joseph de Cordova, Emmanuel H. Borlaza, Eddie Alcantara, Jeanne Young, Eddie Garcia, Lauro Delgado, Mary Walter, Ador Villena Jr, Alfonso Carvajal, Mars Funtilla Jr, Pilita Corrales, Tony Cayado, Nello Nayo, Gina Alajar.

Salamisim was a weekly drama anthology with stories that usually revolved around the main character, played by Dauden. The stories were mainly about love, life transitions, shattered dreams, and wanton hopes.

Acknowledged as the finest television drama series of its time, Salamisim won the Citizens Awards for Television of the Citizens’ Council of Mass Media, for Dauden as best female performer in 1967 and for Villareal as best director in 1968.

In 1968, the drama anthology was adapted into film with the same title by Lea Productions as the movie outfit’s sixth anniversary presentation and entry to the Manila Film Festival. The film adaptation won for Lourdes Medel the Best Supporting Actress Award in the 17th Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS) Awards in 1969.

ABS-CBN acquired Salamisim from ABC5 and renamed it Panagimpan (Dream), which started airing on ABS-CBN Channel 3 in Oct 1968. The staff of Salamisim also served as Panagimpan’s creative team, and Dauden continued hosting and playing the lead role in the reconceptualized drama anthology. Written by Sharon May D. Mesias and Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
SI ALING JUANANG MAPAG-IMPOK(The Thrifty Madam Juana) 1938-40, daily, KZRM. Writer and Host: Carolina Flores-Trinidad aka Lina Flor.

Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok (The Thrifty Madam Juana) was a daily radio series aired on KZRM, the biggest radio station in the country in the 1930s. After more than a decade of experimentation and pioneering stations, the radio industry was already thriving at this time, mainly with news and with bodabil-inspired entertainment programs. Flor then introduced a new daytime format that became the model of post-war soap opera cum advice radio programs (Enriquez 2008).

Flor hosted the program not as herself but as Aling Juanang Mapag-impok, who talked about domestic matters and proper behavior. Listeners, particularly housewives, wrote letters seeking advice about problems concerning their homes and families. After passing the review of an American production supervisor, the letters were read aloud by Flor on the air and she responded to them with advice on how to deal with family issues, save energy while performing household chores, conserve natural resources for the future, and prepare nutritious meals for their families. She gave tips on how to be orderly, neat, and thrifty housewives. The program included live skits featuring the characters of Aling Juana, her children, and their playmates to illustrate how to live with virtue. Among the actors who played one of her children was Flor’s sister Loida, who later became a prolific writer for radio, television, and film.

A familiar household name among daytime radio listeners before the outbreak of World War II, Aling Juana endorsed Philippine-made products and foods as the show was sponsored by the National Development Company, a Commonwealth government corporation that developed and promoted local goods to compete with imports from the United States. Drawing more listeners than English programs, the show cued American radio operators in the 1930s that the new program format, delivered in Tagalog, was attractive to advertisers as well. After the war, programs similar to Si Aling Juanang Mapag-impok, became a staple on Philippine radio, along with the soap opera. Written byRalph Jake T. Wabingga with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Sources:

Aniceto 2007; De Guzman 1980; Enriquez 2008; Reyes 2000.

text:
SIC O’CLOCK NEWS1987-89, IBC 13. Executive producers: Lily Yap, Gus Abrera, Marivin Arayata. Director: Marilou Diaz-Abaya. Writers: Amado Lacuesta, Jose Bartolome, Tony Apon. Editors: Diaz-Abaya, Ray Lugo. Video/film researchers: Mayet Diaz, Vinci Lirios, Jun Segovia. Newscasters: Jaime Fabregas, Ces Quesada. Cast: Jon Achaval, Khryss Adalia, Ching Arellano, Celeste Bueno, Manny Castañeda, Errol Dionisio, Wilson Go, Junix Inocian, Joji Isla, Geraldine Padilla, Rene Requiestas.

A television parody of a news program, the show delivered scathing criticisms on a range of issues—from the presence of United States military bases in the country to issues of corruption, unemployment, economic inflation, media censorship, and human rights abuses. Witty and irreverent, it deviated from the star system of the industry, using talents from the theater, the academe, and progressive cultural groups, who seized the post-EDSA democratic space to provide an entertainingly serious political satire.

A staple comical style of the program is that of reading the news with actual footage of the event interspersed with movie clips, video files of other real-life events, or cartoon images to mock the news report. Another style is anecdotal, showing a character complaining about a specific issue who is then joined by a second character that provides the counterpoint to his litany. For example, a street vendor is suddenly engaged in conversation by a businessman railing against foreign presence in the country but who later asks for a blue seal cigarette. Another anecdote shows its take on the inversion of social order, with members of the comprador bourgeoisie (rich traders) rallying for an increase in rice prices. The humor lies in the satirical rendition of events and characters.

The show encountered problems with advertisers and censors. Fabregas experienced the boycott by several companies not only in this show but of his other programs as well. The show’s word plays, such as presidentita (aunt president) and kangkongresman (a lawmaker as worthless as a water spinach), suffered the axe of the censors. Some of its dialogues were muted and some of the scenes were literally blacked out as “censored,” causing viewers’ discontent, but at the same time served as a visual commentary on the state of media censorship. The program won the Gawad CCP Para sa Radyo at Telebisyon in 1987, 1988, 1989, and 1990. Written by JPaul S. Manzanilla, with notes from Eulalio R. Guieb III

text:
SINESKWELA (School on Air) Jun 1994-2004, 9:30-10:00 am, Mondays-Fridays, ABS-CBN; also shown on The Knowledge Channel, and The Filipino Channel. Company Producers: ABS-CBN Foundation with the Science Education Institute of the Department of Science and Technology and the Department of Education, Culture and Sports (DECS), now the Department of Education. Producer: Gina Lopez. Executive Producers: Rowena Concepcion, Freddie Esteves. Directors: Jon Red, Rene Guidote, Noel Añonuevo. Head Writers: Jovita Zarate, Pauline Mangilog. Writers: Cenon Palomares, Andrea Guevarra, Poots Calzo, Cris Lim, Dean Saltarin, Dang Bagas, Ian Victoriano. Theme Music Composer: Ryan Cayabyab. Cast: Jon Santos, Winnie Cordero, Christine Bersola, Brennan Espartinez, Giselle Sanchez, Sheena Ramos, Frederico Gonzales.

Sineskwela was a daily 30-minute curriculum-based science educational program that catered to public elementary school children and teachers from Grades 2 to 6. The lessons for each day targeted a specific grade level: Monday for Grade 2; Tuesday for Grade 3; Wednesday for Grade 4; Thursday for Grade 5; and Friday for Grade 6.

The show utilized special effects, dramatization, catchy songs, and other creative production techniques to explain complicated principles and concepts of science and technology in a more interesting manner. The program was divided into different segments which vary depending on the topic or the subject matter for a specific episode. In “Mga Kwento ni Ate Winnie” (Stories of Big Sister Winnie), host Cordero narrates a moral-laden story related to the topic for the episode. “Alam N’yo Ba: Dagdag Kaalaman sa Sineskwela” (Did You Know? Additional Information from Sineskwela), usually inserted between discussions, features insights and trivia on the topic under discussion. “Experiments and Demonstrations” explains the topic by showing the actual application of the concepts in children’s daily lives. “Features” is the lecture part which shows video footage of the topic under discussion with a voiceover that directly addresses the audience in a conversational manner rather than a straight talk. Footage shown in this segment were from materials from the French and American embassies, the US Information Services, the library of ABS-CBN, and libraries of other institutions such as the University of the Philippines National Institute of Science and Mathematics Education. “MTV” is the summary of the topic in the form of a music video performed by the hosts of the program.

Sineskwela had eight major sponsors and earned seven million pesos in airtime sales even before the program was broadcast. The viewing of the program was made mandatory by the Department of Education, Culture and Sports for public elementary schools, which translated to good ratings due to its captive audience. The show’s first rating was 24, unprecedented for its morning slot. Sineskwela, along with other educational television shows, such as Bayani (Hero), 1995-2000, Hiraya Manawari (Reaching One’s Dreams), 1995-2003, and Math Tinik (Math Genius), 1997-2003, reached 14 million schoolchildren nationwide. Studies showed that children who viewed the shows had a 19-20% difference in academic achievement.

The most prominent topics of Sineskwela were those that focused on the formerly pristine Pasig River. The episodes depicted how human activities contribute to the river’s deterioration over time and how children can be involved in addressing environmental problems. Children participated in activities that allow them to understand the conditions of the river. Towards the end of the episodes, they came to realize the benefits of a biologically alive river and offer practical ideas on how to help the Pasig River regain its natural condition.

Sineskwela won the Prix Jeunesse in the Television Science Programme Festival, 2003, held in France. A description of the program’s Pasig River episodes appeared in a 400-page catalogue of the 20th International Scientific Audio Visual Conference. It was a recipient of the Anak TV Seal Award from 2000 to 2004 and in 2009 and one of the “20 Most Favorite Shows in the Philippines” of the Anak TV Foundation. It won best children’s program in the KBP Golden Dove Awards and best educational show in the Movie and Television Review and Classification Board Awards for Television in 2009. Written by Yna Marei Aguilar

ABS-CBN Foundation Inc 2011; Bengua 1995; Carballo 2012; Cristobal 2003; Endriga 2015; FilipiKnow 2013; "ABS-CBN Wins 24 Awards..." 2009; Philippine Entertainment Portal 2009; Riosa 1997; Rodrigo 2006; Santiago 2008.
