text:
STUDENT CANTEENJuly 1958, Mondays-Fridays, Chronicle Broadcasting Corporation (CBN) DZXL; 1959-64, noon to 1:30 pm, Mondays-Fridays, CBN TV Channel 9; 6 Jan 1975-86, noon to 1:30 pm, Mondays-Saturdays, GMA; 20 Feb 1989-90, noon to 1:30 pm, Mondays-Saturdays, RPN 9. Producer on CBN: Simoun “Moning” Almario. Producer on GMA: Program Philippines, Inc. Executive Producer on GMA: Bobby Ledesma. Director: Ramon Romano, then Ariston “Aris” Bautista. Technical Director: Arturo Ramos. Floor Directors: Ric Tierro, then Bobby Ledesma, then Aris Bautista. Musical Director: Rudy Angus. Prize and Quiz Coordinator: Ben Arguelles. Talent Coordinator: German Moreno. Researcher: Oscar Gonzales. Production Assistant: Pearl Padilla. Spinner: Eddie Velasquez. Hosts of CBN Canteen: Priscilla Aristorenas, then Leila Benitez. Hosts of Student Canteen on CBN TV: Benitez, Pepe Pimentel, Armando Datuin, who was replaced by Eddie Ilarde, and joined in by Bobby Ledesma. Hosts of revamped Student Canteen on CBN TV: Pimentel, Ben Aniceto, Boots Anson, Nelda Navarro. Hosts of Student Canteen on GMA: Ilarde, Ledesma, Pimentel, Ricky Manalo Jr; then Ilarde, Ledesma, Coney Reyes, and later joined by Helen Vela: then Ilarde, Ledesma, Vela, Chat Silayan, Chiqui Hollman, Jackie Lou Blanco. Hosts of Student Canteen on RPN 9: Ilarde, Ledesma, Malu Maglutac, Jean Garcia, Cherry Pie Picache, Atoy Co.

Student Canteen was the first daily noontime variety show on Philippine television which became a top-rating program. It went on air for a total of 18 years, punctuated by years of absence from 1965-74 and 1987-88. It had its roots on radio CBN-DZXL, titled CBN Canteen, a 15-minute lunchtime musical program that began in July 1957. It featured Priscilla Aristorenas, the “Kolynos Girl of the Philippines.” Kolynos was a popular brand of toothpaste at that time. She sang live, with a piano, bass, and drums. Students, mainly from Letran, Lyceum, and nearby schools, came to the CBN studio on Aduana Street in Intramuros to watch her sing. The show became so popular that it was extended to 30 minutes. The program was reformatted as a daily talk-music show when Leila Benitez replaced Aristorenas, who moved to London with her husband, saxophonist Bernardo Aristorenas. Hordes of college students regularly trooped to CBN to watch Benitez at work in the studio booth. Because of its popularity, it was reformatted in 1958 to enable greater participation from the program’s youth followers and was given the title Student Canteen, with additional hosts Ilarde and Pimentel, and singer Nelda Navarro. Its new segment, a regular amateur singing contest, attracted its young audiences to participate in the contest, which did not require a good singing voice but simply the guts and the heart to carry a performance through. Such format led to a lot of funny situations. The show’s brand of humor was never loud. The hilarity depended on the spontaneous, rapid-fire banter and friendly one-upmanship of the three hosts. In 1958, a time when television was the new medium of broadcasting, management moved the show to CBN TV Channel 9.

Ledesma joined the hosting group in 1960. He first worked as the show’s floor director and occasionally did the voiceover of the program’s opening lines “Hello there. It’s 12 high noon and welcome to Student Canteen!” He also would sometimes render a song or deliver a few spiels until he became a regular host of the show. In 1964, a serious misunderstanding with management led Benitez, Ilarde, and Ledesma to give up on the show. The three hosts announced on the show that they were ending the program, and they walked out of the show. When the walkout occurred, CBN executives had new hosts Aniceto and Anson ready to join Pimentel who decided to stay on the program. Ledesma and Benitez moved over to Channel 11 where they, together with Eddie Mercado, hosted Darigold Jamboree. Ilarde went on with his radio program The Eddie Ilarde Show. The new batch of hosts, however, failed to maintain the popularity of the show. Its young audiences drifted to other shows. The show folded up in 1964, six months after the original hosts left the program.

Student Canteen was revived on 6 Jan 1975 on GMA, whose general manager then was Rod Reyes. The revival of the show was ably supported by GMA stockholders Gilberto Duavit and Menardo Jimenez. The show was co-produced by the network with new blocktimer Program Philippines Inc. Ilarde, Ledesma, and Pimentel returned as hosts of the program, with Pimentel leaving the show after six months. Pimentel was replaced by Ricky Manalo Jr, who, finding it difficult to fit in the group, left the show after a month. A new young female host was introduced in the program, Coney Reyes, who would later become one of local television’s best hosts and most-awarded actors. In a short period, Student Canteen was able to re-establish its hold on Philippine television. Its rating continued to soar, not going below 30 percent of the audience share, sometimes spiking to 45 percent, the highest ever attained by a noontime show during the period. Its standing in terms of audience share was similar to topraters John en Marsha (John and Marsha), a weekly sitcom starring Dolphy and Nida Blanca, and the canned foreign program Six Million Dollar Man

.

The revived Student Canteen maintained its original talk-variety format. The rapport among the hosts worked well. The program offered intelligent entertainment through games, dance contests, comedy team contests, choral competitions, oratorical contests, and promotional gimmicks from sponsors such as Magnolia’s “Libo Libo sa Lobo” (Thousands in a Balloon). It had several local and foreign celebrities as guests, the most famous of which was the group The Jackson 5, which included the young Michael Jackson, in 1976. Mondays to Thursdays had a singing contest with a daily winner, followed by a daily quiz called “Quiz for the Day.” During Fridays, all the winners in the singing contest of the past four days vied to top the weekly finals, the winners of which vied for the monthly finals. The monthly winner in the singing competition would hold the title Canteener of the month. A Canteener served as an occasional co-host of the program. Some Canteeners who later became popular on television and show business were Janet Basco, Debbie Toledanes, Kennedy Tolentino, Liberty Palileo, Carmen Delia Gill, and Marco Sison. Its singing contest “Search for Johnny Mathis of the Philippines” produced 100">Bert Nievera.

Saturdays were marked by the program’s most popular segment “IQ Seven,” a quiz show, which saw the rise to popularity of Rogelio “Bong” Barrameda, who was then an Industrial Engineering student at the University of the Philippines (UP). Barrameda won the contest’s finals several times. He became the heartthrob of the show’s youth audience. He had to give away autographed pictures of himself and answer questions to the cheers of his own fans club in the studio. Another popular quiz champion was Ramon Lorenzo, also from UP. The first and only female quiz champion in another quiz segment, “Battle of Campus Brains,” was Essem Zisenia Solomon.

Each daily show of Student Canteen cost around 3,000 pesos to produce or a monthly production budget of 60,000 pesos, minus airtime.

Many shows tried to topple Student Canteen from its top position in the ratings game and its share of the audience. A noontime show on Channel 11, with Cris de Vera, Oscar Obligacion, and Sylvia La Torre, failed to rival the popularity of Student Canteen. The Channel 11 show was later withdrawn and transferred to the early evening time slot where it became a success as Oras ng Ligaya (Hour of Entertainment).

In 1964, when Benitez and Ilarde left Student Canteen, Ira Davis of MBC put up Show Business to fight the revamped Student Canteen of Pimentel, Aniceto, and Nelda Navarro. Show Business dislodged Student Canteen, which folded up at the end of 1964.

The Student Canteen of the 1980s suffered its greatest setback when rival show Eat Bulaga! (Lunchtime Peek-a-boo!), then with RPN 9, introduced the “Mr. Macho” contest to rival Student Canteen’s “Body Language” contest. Eat Bulaga! (EB) surpassed Student Canteen in the ratings game in Aug 1980. In 1982, Student Canteen absorbed EB host Chiqui Hollman and unceremoniously gave Coney Reyes the walking papers. A month later, Reyes was seen co-hosting with Pimentel, another Student Canteen alumnus, the pre-noontime show Daigdig ng mga Misis (World of Mothers), BBC 2. EB eventually unseated Student Canteen from its hold of the daily noontime programming. In 1982, the switch of RPN 9 to domestic satellite (DOMSAT), which provided EB with a nationwide coverage of its broadcast, and highlighted by the transfer of Coney Reyes to EB, marked the gradual decline of Student Canteen in the ratings game. It never recovered and finally ended its run in 1986. It resurfaced in 1989 on RPN 9, but ended in 1990 due to conflicts between the management and the hosts. Written by Eulalio R. Guieb III and Christine Jesalva

text:
SUGPUIN ANG KORUPSYON (Fight Corruption) aka Anatomiya ng Korupsyon sa Radyo: Sugpuin ang Korupsyon (Anatomy of Corruption on Radio: Fight Corruption) [2004-08], Walang Kukurap (Let No One Blink) [2008-12], and DiskArte (Artistic Strategy) [2012-present]. Premiered 27 Apr 2004, 2:00-2:30 pm, now 2:00-3:00 pm, Saturday, DZRH. Producers: Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and Manila Broadcasting Company. Drama and magazine writer-producers: Athena Agustin, Eva Mari Salvador, Ian Wong. Hosts: Ruth Abao (2004-07), Reggie Espiritu (2007-11), and Henry Uri and Flordeliz Abanto (2012-present).

This public affairs program started as a radio drama-talk show tackling issues of malfeasance and misfeasance in government agencies and institutions. Its first eight episodes were a radio-drama adaptation of Malou Jacob’s play on corruption titled Anatomiya ng Korupsyon. Succeeding episodes were dramatized accounts of letter senders on their experiences with graft and corruption. Each episode starts with a short drama, which is then followed by a discussion on the topic or theme tackled in the dramatic segment. The hosts moderated the discussion with a guest resource person, usually a government official. Listeners are encouraged to report instances of corruption and anomaly in government through texting, calling, or sending of documents and letters.

Anchored on CCP’s vision and mission to use arts for social transformation, art forms like drama (recorded and live), music (Filipino classics, kundiman, and guitar), and poetic jousts like the balagtasan and its modern version called flip top, were used in the program to trigger discussions on issues involving corruption or even best practicesof good governance. The program has become a staunch ally of marginalized groups in mainstreaming issues and getting government response on cases such as the illegal mining that affected agriculture in MacArthur, Leyte and Palawan, the electoral fraud in Maguindanao during the 2007 national elections, the unpaid wages of public school teachers in Sulu and Basilan, and the plight of overseas Filipino workers in the Middle East.

The program evolved into Walang Kukurap toward the end of 2008, to advocate for vigilance against corruption at the local level. In 2012, it was renamed DiskArte to further advocate for social transformation, with the arts as a framework to understand, reflect, or articulate social issues. It continues, however, to receive tips and requests for assistance to get action from government agencies.

Sugpuin ang Korupsyon won numerous awards: the KBP Golden Dove Award for Best Public Affairs Radio Program in 2005; the Catholic Mass Media Awards (CMMA) Best Public Service radio Program in 2006, 2007, and 2008; and a Special Citation from CMMA in 2009. In 2010, Sugpuin ang Korupsyon was elevated to the CMMA Hall of Fame. In 2013, it received the Freedom Project People’s Choice and Jury Prize from The Friedrich Naumann Foundation for Freedom of Germany. Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, with notes from Eva Mari D. G. Salvador and Flordeliz L. Abanto

text:
SUNDAY, SWEET SUNDAY1969-72; 1973-74, noon to 1:00 pm, Channel 13. Directors: Rollie Grande, Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. Writer: Fides Cuyugan-Asensio. Singers: Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, Jimmy Melendrez, and Antonio Garcia Llama. Host: Fides Cuyugan-Asensio and Jimmy Melendrez.

Sunday, Sweet Sunday was a ground-breaking weekly musical program on television that brought classical music to a wider public. Grand dame of Philippine stage Cuyugan-Asensio and co-host Melendrez sang arias, Broadway musical pieces from Carousel and Camelot, excerpts from the operas La Traviata, Le Nozze di Figaro, and Romeo and Juliet, and popular Tagalog kundiman. The show prides itself for being the first program in the Philippines to broadcast in color. With the new technology, the program staged Madame Butterfly on color television, which was ideal because of its beautiful costumes and sets.

The show was momentarily discontinued when martial law was declared in 1972, as its home studio was padlocked. During the martial law period, Cuyugan-Asensio and Melendrez hosted another TV show, Zing, 1972-1973, KBS Channel 9, directed by Al Quinn, which later became Curtain Call. When Zing ended its run in 1973, the two hosts revived Sunday, Sweet Sunday in 1973, also on Channel 13. Cuyugan-Asensio temporarily bid TV farewell when the program ended in 1974. The show came to an end with the hosts singing the final song “Sunday, Sweet Sunday with nothing to do; Lazy and lovely my one day with you.” Cuyugan-Asensio resurfaced in 1989 on A Little Night of Music, GMA, with violinist John Lesaca and, later, flutist Jong Cuenco as co-hosts. It ran for 13 years. Written by Michael B. Makri

(Filipino Trademark) 1990-94, ABS-CBN. Executive Producer: Laurenti Dyogi. Director: Leo Katigbak. Hosts: Jim Paredes, Gel Santos Relos. Writer-segment producers: Chris Violago, Wenn Deramas, Noel Ferrer, Ronald Arguelles, Mouse Muñoz, Ginny Monteagudo.

Tatak Pilipino was a weekly 60-minute telemagazine (television magazine) program that showcased Philippine arts and culture in a manner that was then considered hip, to cater to the youth generation. Features and bumpers or brief announcements usually covered offbeat aspects of Filipino culture, such as tuli or circumcision of pubescent boys done collectively in secluded but public spaces during the summer, eating dog meat and balut or boiled duck egg with a nearly developed embryo, gay lingo, lavish fiestas, extremes of Filipino hospitality, to other forms of popular culture like movies, dance, music, crafts, architecture, theater, radio, television, komiks, cuisine, games, historical landmarks, national heroes, superstitions, myths, and other icons of Philippine culture. The “Top 10” or “Top 20” segment listed favorite or popular artifacts, accounts, places, oddities, fads, traits, and other cultural symbols, like the ten most popular movies, Philippine National Artists, and top destinations.

The program also presented some thematic episodes that focused on a single topic for the week, such as the features on Dekada (the decade of the 1950s, 1960s, 1970s), in which the studio’s production design, including the hairdo, make up, and costumes of the hosts, reproduced the look of the period. Some episodes were taped on location for a feel of the milieu, such as those that featured Corregidor, Casa Manila in Intramuros, and Luneta. The program sometimes featured “Barkadahang Tatak Pilipino,” a group of young people playing Filipino games like piko (hopscotch), patintero (block the opponent), and siyato (stick game).

Tatak Pilipino was programmed in the late-night time slot, and did not get much support from advertisers. The program won the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon in 1990, 1991, 1992, and 1993. It won the PMPC Star Awards for TV as best cultural magazine show. Its hosts were chosen best cultural magazine show hosts in 1991, 1992, 1993, and 1994. Written by Maria Angelina S. Relos

text:
(Call of the Stage) 1950, DZBB then DZRH; 1965, ABS-CBN Channel 3; Late 1960s, RPN 9; 1989, Sundays, GMA 7; 2016, ABS-CBN. Sponsor: Procter and Gamble Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC). Hosts: Dolphy and Panchito (DZBB and DZRH); Lopito and Patsy (DZBB and DZRH); Pepe Pimentel (ABS-CBN Channel 3); Bert Marcelo and Pilita Corrales (RPN 9).

Tawag ng Tanghalan was the longest running amateur singing contest in Philippine broadcasting. It featured aspiring singers who competed with each other in the hope for a career as professional singers. Contestants were either eliminated by the interruption of a gong or a bell or allowed to finish their renditions. Sponsored by Procter and Gamble Philippine Manufacturing Company (PMC), it was first hosted by the comic duo of Dolphy and Panchito. Six months later, when producers took the show on the road, Dolphy left the show to concentrate on his movie career. Another comedy pair, Lopito and Patsy, succeeded them. Regional championships were held until 1954.

Until 1954 the show held only regional championships. In 1955, Tawag held its first grand national finals, proclaiming as winner Pepe Pimentel, then known as Jose Gonzales, for his rendition of the Spanish song “Angelitos Negros.” In 1957, the show was aired simultaneously on radio and television. In 1965, Tawag became purely a television program, airing on ABS-CBN Channel 3, with its first national champion Pepe Pimentel as host, until 1969.

Some of the show’s winners who carved careers in music, film, and broadcasting were Diomedes Maturan, Cenon Lagman, Armando Ramos, Boy Leonardo, Baby Carmelita, Eva Adona, Ofelia Dayrit, Novo Bono Jr, Ric Manrique Jr, Edgar Mortiz, and Jonathan Potenciano. Its most notable champion was Nora Aunor in 1967, whose victory through a rendition of “Moonlight Becomes You” won her roles in variety shows and bolstered her long-standing career in music recording, film, radio, and television.

From the beginnings of radio before the war, many shows were owned and produced by advertisers. In the late 1960s advertising strategy began to shift and advertisers sold their programs to stations, buying only commercial placements in a variety of programs. PMC sold Tawag ng Tanghalan and its soap operas, such as Gulong ng Palad (Wheel of Fate) to broadcast stations. Tawag then became a weekly show on RPN 9. The show’s popularity then waned. Attempts to revive it were unsuccessful. In 1981, however, RPN 9 launched a new program, Bagong Kampeon (New Champion). The show’s success can be attributed to the winning chemistry of its hosts, comedian Bert Marcelo and “Asia’s Queen of Song” PilitaCorrales. It also contracted the services of Dominic Salustiano as musical director. Bagong Kampeon is credited for having launched the careers of pop chanteuse Regine (then Chona) Velasquez and Josephine “Banig” Roberto.

In 1989, the show found a new home in GMA 7 where it was aired on Sundays as Tanghalan ng Kampeon (Stage of the Champions). The newly reformatted show continued the tradition started by TawagngTanghalan, placing the spotlight on and bringing to the forefront the country’s best amateur talents. With the advent of “reality TV show” programming from the late 1990s to the early 2000s, the convention of local TV amateur singing contest adjusted to conform to the dominant style of multinational companies, examples of which were Search for a Star, 2003; Star in a Million, ABS-CBN, 2003; Little Big Star, ABS-CBN, 2005-07; Philippine Idol, TV5 and GMA Network, 2006-08; Pinoy Idol, GMA Network, 2006; Pinoy Pop Superstar, GMA, 2006; and The Voice of the Philippines, ABS-CBN, 2013. In 2016, the noontime variety show It’s Showtime, ABS-CBN, introduced a segment titled “Tawag ng Tanghalan,” with the same format as the original amateur singing contest. Written by Malou L. Maniquis, with additional notes by José S. Buenconsejo and Elizabeth L. Enriquez

text:
6 Jan 1986 to 3 May 1996, Monday-Saturday, 5:30-6:30 pm, GMA. Producer: GMA. Host and Line Producer: German Moreno. Directors: Willie Callao, Ben Vasquez, Conci Flores. Executive Producers: Pinky Garciano, John Feir. Writers: Bing Hernandez, Vera Farajillo. Program Coordinators: Arnel Natividad, Rams David. Technical Director: Buddy Daliwan. VTR Heads: Gel Garciano, Abby Cura. Postproduction Supervisor: Carol Reyes. VTR Editor: Evelyn Borero. Chargen Operator: Baby Santos.

That’s Entertainment is a teen-oriented variety show cum talent search aimed at discovering young talents who could be the next big stars of movies and television by honing their skills in hosting, dancing, singing, and acting. It easily became a hit among young viewers.

Talents were presented daily in groups, as in Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday. The daily show usually followed the variety format with members performing song and dance numbers, gags and skits, and acting out scenarios in a segment billed as “Workshop on the Air.” Saturday Entertainment is the culminating show every weekend where the five groups converged and competed for the title best group of the week via a grand showcase that mixes song, dance, and theater, with production numbers that drew heavily from Broadway musicals and vaudeville acts, mainly due to the influence of host Moreno who was a vaudeville performer in the 1950s.

The show became the launching pad and breeding ground of future stars of the local entertainment scene. Among the most notable are: Lea Salonga who belonged to the show’s original batch and would later become an international star of West End and Broadway and win a Tony Award and a Laurence Olivier Award for Best Performance by an Actress in a Musical, the smash hit Miss Saigon, 1989; King of Pinoy Rap, Francis Magalona; singer, songwriter, and comedian Janno Gibbs; and actors Lotlot de Leon, Ruffa Gutierrez, Carmina Villaroel, Aiko Melendez, Manilyn Reynes, Tina Paner, Sheryl Cruz, Rita Avila, Jestoni Alarcon, Romnick Sarmenta, and Billy Crawford. More than 200 talents had been part of the show during its 10-year run, some of whom have achieved immense popularity and are now familiar names in the local entertainment industry. They include Judy Ann Santos, Piolo Pascual, Rufa Mae Quinto, Jean Garcia, Hazel Reyes aka Ara Mina, Sunshine Dizon, Donna Cruz, Karla Estrada, Gladys Reyes, Assunta de Rossi, Vina Morales, Isko Moreno, Rachel Alejandro, Sunshine Cruz, Glydel Mercado, Jessa Zaragoza, Cris Villanueva, Harlene Bautista, Dranreb Belleza, Ramon Christopher, Jojo Alejar, Keempee de Leon, and Ian Veneracion.

That’s Entertainment may be seen as the predecessor of the reality talent searches that would later invade Philippine television, like GMA Network’s Starstruck, ABS-CBN’s Star Circle Quest, and TV5’s Star Factor and Artista Academy. With television becoming the most pervasive medium after the 1986 EDSA Revolt, producers and talent managers relied on TV shows like That’s Entertainment for launching potential stars, promoting their latest projects, and outsourcing fresh and upcoming talents.

The show was recognized as Best Variety Show, 1992, and Best TV Special for its That’s… The Reunion TV Special, 1996, in the Star Awards for Television by the Philippine Movie Press Club. That’s Entertainment cemented the reputation of German Moreno as a major starbuilder. It provided the local entertainment industry with some of the best and brightest stars whose careers are still flourishing up to this day. Written byElmer L. Gatchalian, with notes from Ramel David and Gelmikee Garciano

article_title: Tinig ng Nursia: Women's Studies on the Air
text:
(Voice of Nursia: Women’s Studies on the Air) Oct 1995-Jun 1997, 2:00-3:00 pm, Mondays; Jul 1997-Dec 1998, 9:00-10:00 am; Ultrasonic Broadcasting Corporation, DWSS K-Love, 1494 mHz. Producer: Institute of Women’s Studies, St. Scholastica’s College Manila. Production Team and Hosts: Rebecca Padilla-Marquez, Kristina Gaerlan, Arche L. Ligo, Ruth Cervantes.

Tinig ng Nursia, a live radio talk show, was an extension of the training provided by the Institute of Women’s Studies of St. Scholastica’s College Manila, thus, the subtitle Women’s Studies on the Air. The list and organizational flow of the topics discussed in the show were based on the modules of the women’s training programs.

The show aimed to educate the public and increase their awareness of women’s rights and issues affecting women’s daily lives. The program also became a venue for exchange on women’s problems and their experiences and views about these challenges. Discussions on various women’s issues were rooted on feminist theories. Topics included sectoral concerns such as those by comfort women, the urban poor, peasants, workers, salesgirls, vendors, students, and professionals. Issues tackled included the women’s movement in the Philippines, the so-called woman question, feminist theories, patriarchy, women and development, women in the Bible, women and the environment, women in media, women in education, and gender-fair education.

Each episode featured an invited expert. Listeners phoned in questions and shared their views. Regular features included interview clips, people-on-the-street interviews, feminist and women’s songs, plugs on women’s rights and issues, and announcements on activities of women’s groups. Written byRebecca Padilla-Marquez

text:
(Mestizo) 1968-69, Wednesdays, 7:00-8:00 pm, ABC 5. Creator: Nonoy Marcelo. Director: Nick Lizaso. Actors: Jimmy Morato, Pilar Pilapil, Edmund Sicam, Willy Dumapias, Bert “Tawa” Marcelo, Eric Celis, Moody Diaz, Jon Belandres, Nanette Jacinto. Sponsors: Kaminomoto ‘O’ San, Manila Bankers Insurance Company Inc, Lifebuoy, Rinso, Coca-Cola, Broncho Rub, Hunt Cigarettes, and Loyola Memorial Park.

Tisoy (slang for mestizo) was a weekly television social satire which was a witty commentary on the culture of the urban youth of the 1960s. It was based on a daily cartoon comic strip by Nonoy Marcelo in The Manila Times in 1963. The cartoon strip, on the other hand, was based on the comic strip Pytik, which Marcelo, while a student, created for The Advocate, the student paper of the Far Eastern University (FEU). The show mirrored the beatnik culture of the turbulent decade, exposed the dilemma of the restless youth, and highlighted the contradictions between the young and the old. The characters Tisoy (Morato), Maribubut (Pilapil, then Miss Philippines 1967), Professor Naspu (Sicam), Clip (Dumapias), Ka Tiquio (Bert Tawa), Caligula (Celis), Aling Otik (Diaz), Pomposa (Belandres), and Tisay (Jacinto), spoke the slang language of the streets of the city. The main character Tisoy, a beardless youth modeled after Marcelo’s mentor and then FEU Dean of Arts and Sciences Alejandro “Anding” Roces, personified the rejection of traditional roles imposed on the youth by society. Then young writers Bibsy Carballo and Joan Orendain were the models for Maribubut and Aling Otik, respectively, while poet Florentino Dauz served as the model for the frail Caligula. The characters were stereotypes fashioned after the characters of Jose Rizal’s novels Noli Me Tangere and El Filibusterismo: Tisoy was Pelaez, Tikyo was Placido Penitente, Maribubut was Maria Clara, and Pomposa was Doña Victorina.

Because of the popularity of Tisoy in The Manila Times, a group of college students from the University of the Philippines (UP) led by Tony Gloria, now a broadcast, advertising, and film producer, with friends Marcy Garcia, Alcide Alforque, and Sicam, staged a version of the comic strip, with Rene Ciriacruz playing Tisoy, as part of their presentation for UP’s annual Speech Festival. Because of the success of their first presentation at the Abelardo Hall, the amateur play Tisoy was staged two more times in a span of four months, and was also staged in Cavite. Months later, executives of ABC 5 approached the same group of UP students to join the cast of the TV version of the comic strip, which the station started airing in 1968.

Tisoy was turned into a movie in 1969, directed by Lauro Pacheco, with Morato, Pilapil, and Bert Tawa reprising their roles. Others in the cast were Ike Lozada, Aruray, and Jerry Pons. Another film version was produced by Nora Aunor’s NV Productions in 1977, directed by Ishmael Bernal and written by Marcelo himself. Bert Tawa, who by then had become a popular comedian, played Ka Tiquio for the third time; Diaz played Aling Otik again. Christopher de Leon and Charo Santos replaced Morato and Pilapil. Jay Ilagan was a new member of the cast, while Aunor, Amy Austria, Bembol Roco, and Niño Muhlach appeared in cameo roles. Written byCynthia Cruz-Paz

text:
(Teacher) 11 Aug-13 Oct 2013, Sundays, GMA News TV Channel 11. Producer: GMA News and Public Affairs. Executive Producer: Alemberg Ang. Associate Producer: Mayeth Malca Darroca. Creator: Nessa S. Valdellon. Director: Alvin Yapan. Writers: Alvin Yapan, Nessa S. Valdellon. Director of Photography: Dexter dela Peña. Production Designer: Whammy Alcazaren. Art Directors: Aleli Mesina, Rita Vargas. Production Manager: Maxie Cuangco Evangelista III. Editor: Piah Luna. Music: Teresa Barrozo. Actors: Lovi Poe (Michelle Maturan), Mara Lopez (Rosa), Agot Isidro (Teacher Sandra), Irma Adlawan (principal May Deroca), Gardo Versoza (Sir Gil), Mikael Daez (Kurt Reyes), Carl Guevarra (Neil), Dennis Marasigan, Arnell Ignacio, Dennis Corteza, Maita Soriano, Justin Salamida, Ivy Enaje, Isadora, Sue Prado, Rocco Nacino, Risa Hontiveros.

A follow-up to the GMA News TV mini-series, Bayan Ko (My Country), 2013, Titser is a 10-part drama that examines the state of public education in the Philippines. The story follows the travails of three women. Michelle, the class valedictorian in the fictional San Simeon High School, dreams of becoming a teacher, but must work as a housemaid after high school in order to make ends meet. With hard work and the help of friends, she is able to finish college and eventually become a teacher. Rosa is the class salutatorian and best friend of Michelle, who likewise struggles to finish her studies in spite of financial difficulties. She becomes a single mother, but is able to rise above her circumstances to become an entrepreneur. Sandra, the mentor of Michelle and Rosa, is a principled teacher who battles the corrupt practices of the school principal, May. In the conclusion, Michelle and Rosa return to their hometown after they have achieved a degree of success in their personal lives. After overcoming some more obstacles, the friends, now teacher and entrepreneur, put up a school in the mountains in order to give the children in the remote area a chance at education.

Titser dramatizes the difficulties that young people have to go through to get their education, as well as the various reasons why these students drop out of school. It portrays the resistance of parents to the education of their children. It shows the misdeeds of pupils and teachers alike and depicts concerns such as lack of good teachers, books, chairs, and classrooms. It exposes the corrupt practices of school administrators and bureaucrats and the tragic results of such practices.

The final episode of Titser is a primer, which recaps its highlights and reveals that the show was inspired by the true story of howthe remote and rural Sindangan Elementary School in Southern Leyte leapt from the rank of 78 in the National Elementary Achievement Test of the Department of Education to number one in 2006.

Titser was cited for Outstanding Achievement in the Broadcast Media at the 8thHildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communications in 2013 by the St. Scholastica’s College Manila. Written by Patrick F. Campos

In the conclusion, Michelle and Rosa return to their hometown after they have achieved a degree of success in their personal lives. After overcoming some more obstacles, the friends, now teacher and entrepreneur, put up a school in the mountains in order to give the children in the remote area a chance at education.

article.value: Titser dramatizes the difficulties that young people have to go through to get their education, as well as the various reasons why these students drop out of school. It portrays the resistance of parents to the education of their children. It shows the misdeeds of pupils and teachers alike and depicts concerns such as lack of good teachers, books, chairs, and classrooms. It exposes the corrupt practices of school administrators and bureaucrats and the tragic results of such practices.

The final episode of Titser is a primer, which recaps its highlights and reveals that the show was inspired by the true story of howthe remote and rural Sindangan Elementary School in Southern Leyte leapt from the rank of 78 in the National Elementary Achievement Test of the Department of Education to number one in 2006.

Titser was cited for Outstanding Achievement in the Broadcast Media at the 8thHildegarde Awards for Women in Media and Communications in 2013 by the St. Scholastica’s College Manila. Written by Patrick F. Campos

text:
1970S, DZRH; 1992, DWIZ. Host: Rey Langit.

To Saudi with Love was a daily radio program that appealed to families of overseas Filipino workers (OFW) by dramatizing their stories and connecting them with their OFW family members through free telephone calls aired live. The show began airing in the late 1970s, a time when the number of Filipinos taking up contract work abroad began to rise dramatically. The program became the model for shows targeted at OFWs and their families, giving rise to what is now called migrant journalism. During the period, a significant number of Filipino contract workers provided labor in the Middle East oil fields and construction projects, many in Saudi Arabia. It was a time before mobile phones and expensive long distance telephone calls were the only means to connect their families with them instantly, which the program provided. The show included a segment dramatizing the plight of the OFWs and the families they left in the Philippines. Often, the telephone calls also provided real-time drama of real lives as the conversations expressed the pain, loneliness, and hardships experienced by the OFWs and their families.?Langit moved to Aliw Broadcasting Corporation’s DWIZ in 1992, taking the program with him, which was later re-named Kasangga Mo ang Langit (Heaven is on Your Side), with the same segments called True to Life Drama and LibrengTawag (Free Call). The program also facilitated the repatriation of OFW remains and extended assistance to migrants and their families who were victims of abuse. In 1999, Langit and his son Reyster Langit produced the television show Biyaheng Langit (Voyage to Heaven), a spinoff of the program, documenting the joys and struggles of Filipino migrants abroad. Hosted by the two, with Reyster later replaced by another son JR upon Reyster’s demise, the weekly show first aired on IBC 13, then moved to RPN 9 and later to NBN 4. Kasangga Mo ang Langit then declined as mobile phones and texting became common. It was soon replaced with Biyaheng IZ, the radio version of Biyaheng Langit, on DWIZ.

In 1995 To Saudi With Love earned the Papal Distinction Award from Pope John Paul II, while the Catholic Mass Media Awards named it the best radio public service and counseling program in 1984, 1985, and 1986. Biyaheng Langit was named best adult educational TV program by the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 2004. It received the annual Anak TV Seal Award from 2003 to 2008 and from 2011 to 2014. Written by Elizabeth L. Enriquez and Ralph Jake T. Wabingga

1950s, DZBB, then later on 7 pm, Mondays, DZPI. Sponsor: Philippine Manufacturing Corporation (PMC). Director: Ric Valdez. Sound Effects and Music Scoring: Art Correll. Voice Actors: Phil Delfino, Fernando Cruz, Teddy Baldemor, Letty Miguel, Fernando Fernandez, and Luis Robledo.

 

Tony Narra was the first detective drama program on Philippine radio. Along with PMC shows Camay Theater of the Air and Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage), Tony Narra first aired on Robert Stewart’s newly-debuted station DZBB in 1950, which was a challenge to frontrunner DZRH. The program, patterned after American detective serials, was the model for Lagalag (Footloose), a radio sleuth hero aired later on DZRH, which in turn inspired the movie of the same title in 1964, launching actor Eddie Fernandez to stardom. The movie was so successful that several films in the same genre, with Fernandez in the lead role, enjoyed popularity in the 1960s, such as Bakas ng Dragon (The Dragon’s Footprint), 1964; Scorpio, 1964; and Hongkong 999, 1965. Written by Maria Criselda C. Sto. Domingo, with notes from Elizabeth L. Enriquez

Aniceto 2007; The Saturday Herald Magazine 1956b.

text:
Oct 1986–2015, weekly on IBC 13; bi-monthly on GMA 7; weekly airing on Channel 23, 11:15 pm; Saturdays 9:30 am on ANC. Producers: Department of Tourism, Gemini Video, Travel Time Productions, Inc. Producer/ host: Susan Calo-Medina. Co-hosts: Calvin Millado, Ogie Alcasid, Marc Medina, Manu Sandejas. Directors: June Gonzales, Jose Mari Avellana, Maria Montelibano, Chito Roño, Susan Calo-Medina. Writers: Rikki Lopez, Baba Flores, Dez Bautista, Susan Arcega, Jaime Laya, Bambi Harper, Floy Quintos, Susan Calo-Medina.

Travel Time is the longest-running travel show to date, spanning close to three decades. Its producer-host Susan Calo-Medina, dubbed as Philippine television’s “Queen of Travel,” is recognized as the pioneer in producing a full-hour show on vacation, discovery, and travel. Before the pioneering program, tourist spots were shown as mere segments in existing magazine shows.

The show featured travel destinations in the Philippine archipelago flavored with history, culture, the arts, and adventure. It was known for its intelligent and entertaining coverage of people and places that were uncommonly seen on TV. Calo-Medina even went to conflict-ridden areas like Basilan and Tawi-Tawi to document an indigenous wedding and the art of local mat weavers. The program’s long life span enabled it to record the heritage structures of Pampanga before these were buried in lahar from Mt Pinatubo’s eruption, and the churches of Bohol before these were reduced to rubble by the 2013 earthquake. It was able to show Sagada and Batanes in their relatively pristine states, long before these became regular tourist destinations. Audiences were treated to experience a place in the context of its history and local people, such as the coverage on Capiz as a charming and relaxing province for vacation or retirement. In commemorating the 150th birthday of Jose Rizal, the show tackled tourism and heroism in a journey tracing Rizal’s life and death in Laguna, Dapitan, and Manila. Travel Time promoted the safeguarding of intangible cultural heritage through episodes such as those on the Ifugao hudhud and the Maranao darangen. There were episodes on endangered legacy of marginalized peoples, such as the ancient writing of the Mangyan and the Palawan.

Travel Time was given the distinction as one of 10 best shows in 1989 by the Gawad CCP Para sa Telebisyon. It won the Gawad Tanglaw Award for Best Travel Show from 2009 to 2012. Other awards include the Catholic Mass Media Awards Hall of Fame and the StarAwards. In the 2010s, the program’s success gave birth to its glossy print version, Susan Calo-Medina’s Travel Time. The multi-awarded show continued airing briefly after the untimely death of Calo-Medina in 2015. The esteemed TV host was posthumously given the Dangal ng Hiraya Lifetime Achievement Award in 2016 by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts. Perhaps the most important contribution of the show is that it helped develop domestic tourism. Calo-Medina encouraged generations of Filipinos to discover little-known aspects of Filipino life in local sites with her famous line at the end of every episode: “Huwag maging dayuhan sa sariling bayan.” (Do not be a foreigner in your own country.) Written by Rosalie S. Matilac

Sources:

Abunda 2015; Francisco 2001a; Rañoa-Bismark 2011.

text:
(The Potchi Troop) 19 Dec 2009 to 15 Jan 2011, Saturdays, 10:00-10:30 am, QTV11. Starting 30 Apr 2011, Saturdays, 9:00-9:30 am, GMA. Creator: Columbia International Foods, Inc. Producer: Elvira Yap Go. Supervising Producer: Gigi Santiago-Lara. Executive Producers: Buboy Favor, Roche Guison. Associate Producer: Abegaye Evasco. Program Manager: Ian Rica Roxas. Director: Louie Ignacio. Assistant Director: Nathan Jacob Jesuitas.Floor Director: Alan Razo. Writers: Augie Rivera, Jorron Monroy. Segment Producers: Eva Marie Ercilla, Wilfred Villaruel, Leonard Gasid, Cheryl Ingles, Virna Canete, Neil Cruz, Alan Ebora, Joy Mendoza, Bidz dela Cruz, Jamie Reyes, James Mayo. Art Department and Wardrobe: Rhedd Martinez, Benedick Rellama, Ever Lawrence Gutierrez, Erwin Jaranilla, Miguel Angelo Cristobal. Mascot operator: Alexander Dasmariñas. Cast: JK Anicoche (voice of Potchi mascot), Ella Cruz, Julian Trono, Sabrina Man, Miggy Jimenez, Ayla Mendero, Jessu Trinidad, Bianca Umali, Liane Valentino, Len Len Frial, Nomer Limatog, Kyle Ocampo, Miggs Cuaderno.

 

Tropang Potchi (The Potchi Troop) was initially a children’s variety game program on QTV that featured games on reasoning, numbers, words, music, people, self, and nature, children-produced videos, and short stories in which the characters are played by the children hosts and a strawberry-colored mascot called Potchi, patterned after a candy produced by the creator of the show. When the program transferred to GMA in 2011, it fused two formats: narrative and magazine. The set was redesigned as the interior of Potchi’s house where the tropa (friends) hang out to share stories and their experiences the previous week.

 

The narrative starts with a problem by one member of the tropa that the children solve with the help of each other and their families. The problem is about things they encounter in their young lives, such as poor eyesight, managing academics and extra-curricular activities, misunderstandings between friends, hurt feelings about a parent’s refusal to buy them a new electronic gadget, broken family, depression, setting life goals, bullying, puppy love, and addiction to TV, computer games, and social networking sites. The stories highlight the importance of friendship, family, and values, such as respect, patience, helpfulness, honor, integrity, and responsibility.

 

The format shifts when the cast go on adventures, which are presented as segments that include travel, children’s hobbies, science, sports, food, people, and events. Examples are their visit to the communities of the Talaandig and the Manobo of Bukidnon, features on Philippine heritage sites, the life goals of a volunteer teacher and people from all walks of life, the science behind rides in a carnival, and building one’s character through arnis (stick martial arts), running, sand boarding, the yoyo, figure skating, camping, wall climbing, rappelling, dancing, storytelling, dog training, clay animation, puppetry, and food styling.

 

Tropang Potchi was inspired by of one of Columbia’s product taglines: “Bata Ka Pa, Pero Kaya Mo Na” (You are Just a Kid, but You Can Already Do It). The stories, for example, show that children can make the right decisions with proper guidance and help by people around them, including those of their age level.

 

Tropang Potchi received a certificate of recognition for being child-friendly and pro-Filipino from the Department of Education and the National Council for Children’s Television in 2012. The program’s hosts were best children’s show hosts in the PMPC Star Awards for TV in 2013 and outstanding hosts in the Golden Screen Awards for TV in 2014. It won the Anak TV Seal by the Southeast Asian Foundation for Children and Television in 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2013, outstanding educational program in the 5th ENPRESS Golden Screen Awards for TV in 2014, and the Silver World Medal for children/youth programs in the New York Festivals in 2014. Written by Jason Paolo R. Telles

 

Sources:

"2014 World's Best Television & Films Winners" 2014; Roxas 2014.

(Radio Friends) 2010, 7:00-8:00 pm, Mondays to Fridays, DZUP 1602 with livestream on www.dzup.org. Producers/Writers/Hosts: Jane Vinculado, Chryl Bhefer M. Martinez, Janyn Berame, Christian Faith Navarro, Annicalou Tañaquin, and Romar Jay Tirona.

Tropang Rad’Yo is the longest running program of DZUP, the official radio station of the University of the Philippines. It is a youth-oriented talk show that discusses issues that confront young adults, such as relationships, studies, health, careers, and identities.

Tropang Rad’Yo! received the Kapisanan ng mga Brodkaster (KBP) Golden Dove Award in 2015 for best radio special for its episode “Second Summer,” aired on 5 Aug 2014. It was about the experiences of the University of the Philippines community when a second summer term was held as the university shifted its academic calendar from June-April to August-June. Written by Ma. Ivy A. Claudio

(Child Talk) Nov 2002- Apr 2014, 6:00-7:00 pm, Saturdays, then later on, 6:00-6:30 pm, DXND in Kidapawan City and DXMS in Cotabato province. Director and Program Coordinator: Aurora Madreguera-Parreno. Hosts: Paul Randy Gumanao and Shirlyn Macasarte, Kurt Louis Solis, Jessa Mariel Parreno, April Dyan Gumanao, and Rae Marie Manar.

This 30-minute children’s radio magazine program popularized the Children and Youth Welfare Code of North Cotabato and the program of the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) on children’s right to participation. Usapang Pambata discussed the impact on children of issues affecting the environment, peace, and cultural solidarity.

It was part of the North Cotabato provincial government’s Early Childhood Care and Development (ECOD) program. The province’s Council for the Welfare of Women and Children and UNICEF’s Country Program for Children funded its production.

All but two members of the production staff were children aged 10-16. The only two adults in the production staff were the program director and the chair of the Committee on Children and Youth of the Sangguniang Panlalawigan of Cotabato.

Usapang Pambata was the brainchild of the late journalist Aurora Madreguera-Parreno who was the program’s coordinator and director until her death in 2014, which also ended the program.

In four consecutive years from 2005 to 2008, Usapang Pambata received the Kapisanan ng mga Broadkaster ng Pilipinas Golden Dove Awards for best children’s radio program. Written byDivine Marie Joanne P. Endriga

Manar 2008; MindaNews 2006, 2014; “Obit” 2014; Salterio 2005.

text:
(Once Upon a Time) Original run 22 Jun 1997 to 27 Feb 2005; re-aired 2006-07; remade beginning 11 Sep 2010, ABS-CBN. Producing Companies: CineMedia and ABS-CBN. Producers: Charo Santos-Concio, Malou N. Santos. Directors: Johnny Manahan, Wenn Deramas, Jerry Lopez Sineneng, Francis Pasion, Lino Cayetano, Jerome Pobocan, Dondon Santos, Don Cuaresma, Malu Sevilla, Trina Dayrit, Erick C. Salud. Writers: Joel Mercado, Cris Lim, Wali Ching, Noreen Capili, Clarissa Estuar, Danica Domingo, Marietta Lamasan, Dindo Perez, Benedict Mique, Mariami Tanangco, Shugo Praico. Cast mainstays: Sharlene San Pedro, Nash Aguas.

Wansapanataym is a weekly fantasy series that features stories of different people and their everyday lives as they encounter the world of myths and magic. The stories show how they face life’s circumstances and how their lives are changed and influenced by nature spirits and the elementals. The series features two child characters (Aguas and San Pedro) who, in every episode, take out and read a magical book from a chest. The program ends with the two returning the book inside the chest.

Teen actors Judy Ann Santos and Rico Yan graced the first episode of the show. Out of 590 episodes, the program showcased several adaptations, like Inday Bote (Lady Bottle), about a bottle vendor who discovers a magical bottle that contains two genies who grant her wish of an easy life. Inday realizes in the end that it is more important to be true to herself and work hard in life than rely on instant success. “Bandanang Itim” (Black Handkerchief), loosely based on the Snooky Serna movie Blusang Itim (Black Blouse), is about an ugly lady who transforms into a beautiful and admirable woman when she wears a black magical kerchief. When the protagonist becomes rude and self-centered, the scarf loses its power. She then realizes that true beauty lies in the heart of a person. “Super Kikay and Her Flying Pagong” (Super Dainty and Her Flying Turtle) is about Kikay, a simple lady who wants to become a hero. She and her brother save a magical sea turtle which later gives her power to save humankind and to protect marine life as well.

Wansapanataym re-emerged as Wansapanasummer (Once Upon a Summer) in 2010. It remade some remarkable episodes of the first series, such as “Plastik Pantastik” (Fantastic Plastic) and “Cocoy Shokoy” (Cocoy, The Merman). A series of re-runs was presented in 2013, called Wansapanataym Classics (Once Upon a Time Classics). 29 Jan to 22 Apr 2012, Sundays, 9:00-10:00 am, GMA News TV; 1 Jul-23 Sep 2012, Sundays, 7:00-8:00 pm, Talk TV; 28 Jul 2013, Sundays, 7:00-8:00 pm, Solar News Channel; Sep 2015, CNN Philippines. Creator: A Different Story Productions. Executive Producer and Director of Photography: Monet Silerio. Production Head: Mac Dones. Production Manager: Girlie Dones. Director: Frederick Tam. Second Camera Operator: Michael Enriquez. Steadicam Operator: Jeffrey dela Cruz. Lighting Assistant: Allan Semana. Stills Retoucher: Jake Espedido. Colorist: Timmy Torres. Postproduction Consultant: Adrian Tecson. Host: Francisco “Paco” Guerrero.

What I See is a one-hour travel photography documentary that focuses on people, places, treasures, and cultures of the Philippines from the lens of Manila- and Madrid-based photographer Francisco “Paco” Guerrero. The host interacts with local artisans for their stories and photographs their everyday lives, economic activities, and forms of artistic expressions.

The program’s strength lies in Guerrero’s story-filled photographs and the show’s cinematography that capture the different nuances of what it means to be a Filipino. The program views travel not simply as a form of recreation, but as a historical and cultural way to understand Filipino culture.

Alongside his travels, the host gives photography advice as he takes images of people and places with a rich piece of history to tell. No episode is complete without the portrait session by Guerrero himself. He chooses a spot, lets his subjects stand in front of a black backing, and directs them to pose for the camera.

In the final sequence, the host is by himself in a select spot, shares his reflections on his travel experiences, and closes the program with the spiel “Ako si Paco Guerrero (I am Paco Guerrero), and this is what I see.” All the photographs taken by the host during the episode are shown on screen before the closing credits roll.

What I See spun off from Two Stops Over, a 30-minute television show on photography also hosted by Guerrero which aired every Sunday at 7:30 pm from 7 Nov 2010 to 13 Feb 2011 on 2nd Avenue, a channel of Solar Entertainment Corporation.

The program pioneered in placing photography as a subject of a television documentary.

What I See has featured Legazpi, Batangas, Bohol, Cebu, Lake Sebu, Ilocos Norte, Ilocos Sur, Siargao, Batad, Bacolod, Davao, Palawan, Masbate, Marinduque, Iloilo, Capiz, Abra, Oslob, Bukidnon, Dumaguete, Siquijor, and Lanao del Sur. Written byCamille S. Intal

text:
(Womanwatch / Womanwatch Radio) Sep 1986-Mar 1994, PTV-4; 1985-1986, DZSR Sports Radio; 1986-88, Radyo ng Bayan; 1988-90, DWWW, 1990-93, DWIZ. Producer: Women’s Media Circle. Co-producers: DZSR Sports Radio, PTV-4. Director: Maria V. Montelibano. Host: Nikki Coseteng.

Womanwatch is the first media production for, by, and about women in the Philippines, beginning as a pre-taped weekly radio program in Oct 1985, and spinning off a weekly television show in Sep 1986. It pioneered on women’s use of media to influence social change. Its call phrase is “panahon na” (it’s about time). The concept of the program was inspired by From Priestess to Prostitute, a slideshow on the story of Philippine women through the centuries produced in Mar 1985 by the Progressive Women’s Spiritual Association (PWSA) and the radio program All Things Considered, heard by journalist Anna Leah Sarabia during a visit to the USA in Jul 1985 over the network National Public Radio, which featured the ongoing United Nations World Conference on Women in Nairobi, Kenya.

In order to work on the pioneering program, its producers, the Women’s Media Circle (WMC) incorporated in 1986 and became a foundation in 1987. WMC started out as a volunteer partnership of three activist women’s groups: PWSA, Pilipina, and the Women’s Desk of the Concerned Artists of the Philippines (WD-CAP). Three women served as representatives of each group in the conceptualization of the program: Anna Leah Sarabia for PWSA, Remmy Rikken for Pilipina, and Marra PL. Lanot for WD-CAP. TV Director Maria V. Montelibano trained the WMC pioneers to put together a TV production in the early months of 1986, while activist-turned-TV executive Doris Nuval Baffrey and veteran media manager Patricia L. Monzon facilitated the move of the radio program to a television show.

The TV program was first broadcast from the government-owned network during the Marcos era. Therefore, criticism of government policies had to be done from the perspective of women’s issues and not to campaign for toppling the government.

After the EDSA Revolution, the radio program moved to Radyo ng Bayan, and began broadcasting live in Mar 1986. Political events forced the producers to move to DWWW in 1988, where it evolved into a thrice weekly program, and then to DWIZ in 1990, where it had a daily hour-long schedule, until finally signing off at the end of Aug 1993.

Radyo Womanwatch (Womanwatch Radio) over DWWW became a teaching program, where WMC shared its airtime venue with Kaiba Women’s Party, Samahan ng Malayang Kababaihan/Gabriela, Women’s Health Coalition, Katipunan ng Bagong Pilipina, and the Women’s Studies Association. They took turns every two weeks producing a radio program and promoting women’s issues. Some of these groups eventually found the funds and developed the capacity to produce their own radio shows.

But it was the television program Womanwatch that caught public attention when it first aired in Sep 1986 over PTV-4. The host, Nikki Coseteng, was then a well-known “street parliamentarian” and a leader of the left-oriented group WOMB or Women for the Ouster of Marcos and Boycott, as well as the owner of an art gallery with a high-profile basketball team that sported her name, Gallerie Dominique.

Womanwatch started out as a variety and magazine show, focusing on a wide range of topics, giving proof to the feminist statement that “all issues are women’s issues.” Guests were interviewed live in the studio, while pre-taped segments were shot on location in Ilocos, Zamboanga, Hong Kong, Paris, and Dharamsala featured a wide variety of stories. These ranged from the travails of overseas Filipino workers, migrant brides from New Zealand to Dubai, the veterans of the Japanese era women guerrillas, child prostitutes, LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender) activism, indigenous women artists, women farmers, women in religious orders, and women rising in the corporate world.

Womanwatch became the launching pad of several heretofore “private” issues into the public sphere, like incest, sexual harassment, abortion, domestic violence,and child abuse. Through phone line audience participation, actualincidents and problems were reported on the air by victims andfamily members.These discussions sometimes led to the formation of national campaigns, andeven to theconvening of conferences on such issues.The Tigil Bugbog Hotline and the Kababaihan Laban sa Karahasan or KALAKASAN Hotline were established in May 1991, first, because of reports made to PTV-4 and to the office of Coseteng inCongress about wife beating and violence, and, second, because of the seeming non-existence of either government or non-government initiatives to address such problems.

Womanwatch was “unintentionally” put off the air while a live discussion on women activists showed footage of the resurrection of the underground left-wing MAKIBAKA (Malayang Samahan ng Bagong Kababaihan) in 1987. It was several times criticized by station managers as being too “aggressive” and advised to tackle “tamer” subjects like cooking, fashion, and child-rearing.

The producers took up the suggestions but put a feminist twist to these topics. Eventually, Womanwatch became a venue for the promotion of traditional baro’t saya (blouse and skirt ensemble), the unofficial national dress of the Filipina. Coseteng donned a fabulous example of the dress every week, as well as different types of regional dress.

The program was abruptly cancelled in Mar 1994, when Coseteng joined the political opposition, and filed her candidacy three hours before the airing of the last episode, in Mar 1994. The program won best women’s program for radio and television in the Catholic Mass Media Awards in 1988, 1989, and 1990. Written byAnna Leah Sarabia

text:
1972-73, 1:00-2:00 pm, Sundays, KBS Channel 9. Producer: Jay Hess. Director and Choreographer: Al Quinn. Production unit manager: Tony Llenes. Production assistant: Bobby de la Cruz. Hosts: Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, Jimmy Melendrez. Cast: Carmen Pateña, Eddie Peregrina, Ike Lozada, Lirio Vital, Neddie Decena.

Zing was a weekly musical program that aimed to bring music to a wider audience. The hosts were long-time opera stars who brought to the public beautifully rendered fine music. The program featured all types of music.

The program had three regular segments. The Broadway segment showcases excerpts from well-known Broadway musicals, like West Side Story, Porgy and Bess, and Annie, Get Your Gun. The Tagalog segment, called The Tagalog Corner, focused on Filipino music to honor local tradition of fine music. The third segment presented special features of music of varied styles and tradition.

Cast members Pateña, Peregrina, Lozada, Vital, Decena, and guests provided excellent support to the production numbers of the program. A regular feature was a chorus-dance number from a chorus-dance troupe choreographed by director Quinn, who is also a dancer.

Zing replicated the weekly musical program Sunday, Sweet Sunday, 1966, Channel 13, which went off the air when martial law was declared in 1972. Sunday, Sweet Sunday was hosted also by Cuyugan-Asensio and Melendrez.

When Zing ended its run in 1973 on KBS 9, the two hosts revived Sunday, Sweet Sunday, 1973-74, also on Channel 13. Written byEulalio R. Guieb III
